title: Contract Awards
description: The Raytheon Company received $100million in Army contracts for improved Hawk antiaircraft missiles and ground support equipment, it was announced yesterday. The Army also awarded $44.9million to Day & Zimmermann for operation of the Kansas ammunition plant at Parsons, Kan., and the Lone Star ammunition plant at Texarkana, Tex.

title: Canada Vote Shows Limitations of Polls
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31The danger of using political polls to predict more than they in fact measure was shown today by the results of the federal election in Canada.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 31 (UPI)Mrs. Philip Cudone of Myrtle Beach, S. C. and Mrs. Nancy Rutter of Williamsville, N. Y., carded threeoverpar 75's today to share the firstround lead of the 15th annual North and South senior women's golf championship.

title: BLASTS REPORTED WITHIN MILKY WAY
description: Reports received in recent days from observatories in various parts of the world indicate that four explosions of a seemingly unprecedented nature were recorded in September within the Milky Way Galaxy, or star system, of which the earth is a part.

title: JOHN HEANEY
description: WILTON, Conn., Oct. 31 John Heaney, naval architect who headed his own business, John Heaney and Associates, in New York and in this community, died yesterday at his honte, 21 Evans Lane, of a heart attack, He was 68 years old.

title: 30 Die, Many Hurt in Turkey As Trains Crash HeadOn
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 31 (AP)At least 30 people were reported killed when a passenger train and trackrepair train collided headon today near the westcentral Turkish city of Eskisehir.

title: Manpower Rise to Fill 3 Vacant Firehouses
description: Three new firehouses that have remained vacant for nearly a year, because the department did not have the manpower to staff them, will be manned as a result of the city's ending of its freeze for the uniformed services.

title: Erratic Penn, Rebounding Yale To Test Leaders in Ivy League
description: Playing a tie football game is like taking your best girl out for the big evening only to have her jilt you at the end.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON,.Oct. 31These are hard days on liberal democracy and charismatic leaders. Seldom a week goes by without news of some conservative comeback or triumph somewhere in the world, or the revival of nationalism and protectionism.

title: ExPeace Corps Head Shifts
description: MIAMI, Oct. 31 (AP)Jack Hood Vaughn, former Peace Corps director, has resigned dean of international affairs at Florida International University to become a television executive. Mr. Vaughn, 52 years old, will join the Children's Television Workshop, which produces Sesame Street.

title: DR. HARRY P. BURDEN
description: MEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 31, (AP)Dr. Harry P. Burden, former dean of the College of Engineering at Tufts University, died yesterday at the age of 81.

title: U. S. Agency to Sell Silver Dollars Made In Nevada in 1880's
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31The United States General Services Administration announced plans today for the public sale of more than two million historic silver dollars produced at the Carson City (Nev.) mint from 1882 to 1884.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: GOTEBORG, Sweden, Oct. 31 (AP)Dick Stockton, the Trinity University player from Port Washington, L. scored a major upset in the first round of the Goteborg World Championship Tennis Tour tournament today when he defeated Bob Carmichael of France, 6.3, 61.

title: Demagogy on Schools...
description: In his recent radio address on education, President Nixon actually boasted of his record of having vetoed three successive education appropriation bills, posing the champion of prudent rather than profligate spending. Yet, in the course of the year, forced economies have cut the heart out of many successful school programs.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A threatened strike at midnight by drivers and maintenance workers against three major bus lines in Westchester County was averted last night by a settlement between the companies and Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union. The terms of the settlement, reached during negotiations at the Holiday Inn in Yonkers, were not made public pending ratification by a mail ballot.

title: Giants Bracing for Floyd Little
description: With visions of Larry Brown romping over, through and around them still clogging their heads, the Giants now have to brace themselves for the real live appearance of Floyd Little.

title: NoGoal Stemkowski Keeps Rangers Laughing for Game Tonight
description: A bell inadvertently went off during the Rangers workout yesterday and brawny Pete Stemkowski immediately leaped over the boards with grace.

title: NIXON IS WIDENING CAMPAIGN EFFORT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 President Nixon has scheduled a lastminute round of television and radio addresses to present to the public his case for reelection, the White House announced today.

title: Boyhood Tragedy of Hijacking Suspect Called Key Influence by ExAssociate
description: When he was about 9 years old, Charles A. Tuller, the former Commerce Department official now charged with murder and hijacking, was taking his 4yearold brother across a New Jersey highway to join their father.

title: Bronx, Grand Jury Indicts 5 Inspectors In Building Bribery
description: A Bronx grand jury indicted five building inspectors yesterday on charges of taking total of $1,100 in bribes from the builder of a daycare center.Investigation Commissioner, held a news conference to announce that the five had been seized, and noted that the case provided unusual documentation of payoffs being demanded at every stage of the construction.

title: Milton Schilback Is Dead at 65; Rackets Prosecutor for Dewey
description: Milton Schilback, who had been assistant prosecutor when the late Thomas E. Dewey was Special Rackets Prosecutor in the 1930's, died Thursday apparently of a heart attack. He was 65 years old and lived at 35 East Ninth Street.

title: Hijacking Suspect With Nitro Subdued by Airline Clerk Here
description: An unidentified man who tried to hijack a Miamibound National Airlines jetliner at Kennedy International Airport yesterday by threatening to explode a hag of nitro was subdued and captured by a ticket agent and two sky marshals.

title: Two Printing Unions Reach Accord on Merger Terms
description: WASHINGTOI, Oct. 31Directors of the International Printing Pressmen and Assistants Union and the International Stereotypers and Electrotypers Union agreed today on terms for a merger.

title: PRICES ON AMEX AND OTC CLIMB
PFIZERDEAL DATA SOUGHT BY F.T.C.
description: The Federal Trade Commission has asked Pfizer, Inc., for ccrtain information concerning its acquisition of Howmedica, lnc., Pfizer disclosed yesterday in a prospective filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Explosion in Belfast Kills 2 Small Girls As Violence Erupts
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 31 (Reuters)  Two girls, aged 4 and 6, were killed tonight when an explosion wrecked a bar in a Roman Catholic district of Belfast.

title: Heath Faces a Crisis on Inflation as Parliament Opens
description: LONDON, Oct. 31  The Peers in their, scarlet and ermine robes crowded into the House of Lords today, alongside bewigged judges and women guests wearing sequined dresses and diamond tiaras. Queen Elizabeth, head erect under the imperial crown, was opening a new session of Parliament.

title: FOE SAID TO CROSS CAMBODIA BORDER
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 31Authoritative Western military sources reported today that large numbers of North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops were moving out of their Cambodia border base areas into South Vietnamapparently as part of a Communist attempt to seize control of as much South Vietnamese territory as possible before a ceasefire is declared.

title: Provisions of Truce Draft
description: Under the provisions of the ninepoint draft agreement between North Vietnam and the United States, the following would occur upon signing:

title: Senate Contest
description: SANTA FE, N. M.Pete Domenici eased his way through, the sparse crowd, stopping to exchange pleasantries in Spanish with a grizzled cowboy, or patting the shoulder of a stout woman wearing a huge Nixon button and laughing with her, or dancing with a buxom SpanishAmerican girl when the twoguitar band, well amplified, cut off his conversation.

title: Upset in Canada
description: Canadian voters, especially those from Ontario westward to the Pacific, have delivered a stunning and unexpected blow to Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's bid for reelectionas well as confounding the pollsters. They have also divided so evenly between Mr. Trudeau's Liberals and the opposition Progressive Conservatives as to make effective government all but impossible.

title: Dance Marathon. Welcome for Ailey
description: Monday night ushered in the latest entries in the City Center's American Dance Marathon at the ANTA theater: the Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Theater, which will be performing all week through Saturday night, sharing alternate programs with either Anna Sokolow's Players Project or the Viola Farber Dance Company.

title: 5th Albany Escapee Caught
description: ALBANY, Oct. 31 (AP)The fifth of 12 Albany County Jail inmates who broke out of the prison four days ago, was recaptured today, the police said. Vernon Branch, 17 years old, was cornered in a taxi after he fled from a downtown! apartment when tipped off that policemen were closing in. Seven of the escapees remained large.

title: Eggs and Rocks Thrown as Boycott at Canarsie School Continues
description: Partisans on both sides in the Canarsie school dispute exchanged epithets and hurled eggsand, in a few instances, rocks at each other yesterday as white parents continued to keep most of their children out of the area's schools.

title: Equity Financing
description: The South Carolina Electric and Gas Company announced yesterday it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission 1,060,000 common shares for sale through Kidder Peabody & Co. The company's stock was up  at 23 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Other News of Vietnam
description: In Paris, diplomatic sources reported that Hanoi and Washington had agreed on an international trucesupervisory commission consisting of Canada, Indonesia, Poland and Hungary and on a peace conference to follow within 30 days of the signing, with Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations participating.

title: DOLLAR SELLING IN TOKYO GOES ON
description: TOKYO, Oct. 31Heavy selling of dollars in the Tokyo foreignexchange market, which began in the final week of September, continued into this week in anticipation of a second upward revaluation of the yen.

title: Laotians Flee to Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 1 (Agence FrancePresse) Mt)re than 1,300 Laotians fled across the Mekong River into Thailand early today after Communist forces overran the garrison town of Nam Thorn Buk Kwang, about 90 miles cast of Vientiane, according to press reports reaching here.

title: Election Day Deputies Are Named by Kugler
description: TRENTON, Oct. 31 (AP)Attorney General George F. Kugler Jr. said he had appointed a task force of 20 deputies, to respond to Election Day complaints across the state.

title: Prices of Newsprint Will Rise in Canada
description: Consolidated Bathurst, Ltd., announced in Montreal yesterday that it would increase its newsprint prices in Quebec and Ontario, effective Feb. 1. John D. Andrew, a vice president, said that the company would raise its listed newsprint prices by $7 a ton for customers in Quebec, and by $5 a ton in Ontario. This would bring the basic price to $161.75 a ton in Quebec, and $164 a ton in Ontario. Mr. Andrew said that the company's United States newsprint prices were not affected by the increases. At present base list prices f.o.b. New York are $165 a ton.

title: CARE Drive to Raise $7.5Million Is Opened
description: The annual CARE food crusade opened yesterday with the announced goal of raising $7.5million to help feed an estimated 28 million people, nearly all children, through the coming year in 34 countries.

title: Books of The Times; Fapesmo? Absquatulation? !!!
description: It is with understandable pride that the people at Oxford University Press now bring forth the first supplement to the monumental Oxford English Dictionary since 1933. And boast of its completeness it will encompass [when all three volumes are published] all of the words that have come into common use in the Englishspeaking world from 1884 to the present day"; its range"It will contain over 50,000 main words and onemillionandonehalf illustrative quotations"; its maintenance of tradition"The old boys loved [to note quotations onl the back of envelopes, says editor R. W. Burchfield. We've had nothing but 6by4inch slips since I've arrived. That's the climactic change I introduced"; and its reflection of both modern literature"All the works of major 20thcentury writers are covered"and the new scientific world"The vocabulary of Sociology, Linguistics, Computer Science, Anthropology, and Psychology is liberally represented. After all, the OED was the greatest wordmachine to be built in the 19th century, and it is reassuring to see it supplied with fuel to go on running in the 20th century. So congratters (sic) to Mr. Burchfield, his staff of researchers, and the Oxford Press for their accomplishment. (Congratters. , colloq. abbrev. of congratulations, usu. as int. of prec. and 1966 O. Norton School of Liars vi. 101. The Brig lifted his glass. )

title: Shriver Criticizes Proposal For Coalition in Vietnam
Vatican Lowering Rates Charged for Annulments
description: ROME, Oct. 31 (AP)  The Vatican has made marriage annulments in its tribunal cheaper, with new rates to go into effect tomorrow. The move drew immediate accusations that the Roman Catholic Church was competing with divorce courts.

title: Freeholders Up for Election in All Counties
State Collects $16.1Million
description: ALBANY, Oct. 31 (AP)The state collected $16.172,717 in parimuh:el taxes in the 72day summer meeting at Yonkers Raceway, the State Tax Department reported today. A total of 1,242.415 patrons wagered $142,626,520 during the meeting, which ended  Oct. 14.

title: EXITTAX WAIVERS TERMED GESTURE
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 31A high Soviet police official was quoted here today as having said that the recent granting of educationtax exemptions to Jewish emigrants was a gesture toward the United States, not a basic change in Soviet policy.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CAVALIERS BEAT 76ERS, 126 TO 116
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 31 (UPI)  Bobby Smith came off the bench in the second quarter tonight to spark the Cleveland Cavaliers to a 126116 victory over the nonwinning Philadelphia 76ers in the National Basketball Association.

title: US ASKING HANOI FOR REASSURANCE OF TROOP PULLOUT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31The United States is seeking reassurances from Hanoi that, once the Indochina settlement takes effect, North Vietnam will withdraw many of the 35,000 troops it now has stationed in the northern part of South Vietnam, even though it is not required to do so under the. terms of the agreement as: worked out.

title: Hell's Angels Link Seen in 3 Bodies Found in California
description: UKIAH, Calif., Oct. 31 (AP)  Three bodies have been recovered from a rumored Hell's Angels burying ground and policemen are searching for more possible grave sites, officials said today.

title: Suit Accord Reached
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) Four Manufacturers of fireprotection and burglaralarm systems have agreed to pay the Federal Government $250,000 in settlement of an antitrust damage claim filed against them in 1965, the Justice Department announced today.

title: N.F.L. Is Ordered to Repay Players Fined for Leaving Bench
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) A Government hearing examiner ruled today that the National Football League was guilty of an unfair labor practice in automatically fining players $200 for leaving the bench to participate in fights on the field.

title: Barry Sparks Warriors
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 31 (AP)Rick Barry scored 6 points in the final minute to give the Golden State Warriors a 112.104 victory over the Detroit Pistons tonight.

title: FEDERAL AGENCIES CALLED POLLUTERS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI)The General Accounting Office, in a report criticizing several Federal agencies, said today that the National Park Service had apparently ignored its own admonitions and contributed to air and water pollution and scenic blight.

title: Parents Win Refund on a Reading Aid
description: Consumer Affairs Commissioner Bess Myerson announced yesterday that she had obtained the largest cash refund ever negotiated by her department$380,000for parents who allegedly had been victims of teachingmachine swindle.

title: Judge Criticizes Con Ed On Billing of a Widow,77
description: A consumer's harrowing experience was recounted yesday by a Federal judge who declared that Consolidated Edison failed to give adequate notice to customers before shutting off their electricity.

title: U.S. '73 Sugar Requirement Is Put at 11.7 Million Tons
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP)  The United States will requite 11.7 million tons of sugar next year, 110,000 fewer than proposed as the 1973 quota on Oct. 3, the Agriculture Department annouced today.

title: Jacob Sher, 83, a Leader In Florida Racing, Is Dead
description: MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 31 (AP) Jacob Sher, a thoroughbredracing enthusiast who also was a pioneer in greyhound racing in Florida, died yesterday at the age of 83.

title: Kings Point Aide Honored
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) Capt. Raymond Eisenberg. the chairman of the department of shipboard training at the United States Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, L. I., was awarded the United States Commerce Department Gold Medal today for developing and maintaining the academy's oneyear atsea workstudy program.

title: Weehawken Hears Rumbles of Discontent
description: WEEHAWKEN, Oct. 31FitzGreene Halleck, in a lengthy romance in verse published in 1819, entitled Fanny, wrote:

title: OilStorage Deal Cited
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31A Federal judge has ruled that the Standard Oil Company of California has illegally monopolized the sale of petroleum products in American Samoa.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: A 10round nontitle bout between Roberto Duran of Panama, the unbeaten lightweight champion, and Esteban De Jesus of Puerto Rico was announced yesterday for Madison Square Garden on Friday night.

title: Paka at the Jungle Habitat In West Milford
description: WEST MILFORD, Oct. 31Paka, the 300pound lion who mauled an Israeli tourist at Jungle Habitat on Columbus Day will be returned to his pride tomrorow.

title: French Raise Minimum Pay
description: PARIS, Oct. 31 (Agece FracePresse)  The French Government today raised the hourly minimum wage by 5.8 per cent to 4.55 francs in move that means the monthly pay of some 700,000 workers will rise to at least 887 francs, or $177. Trade unions have been campaigning for a monthly minimum, wage of 1,000 francs.

title: JAMES EVANS, 77, STATE PARKS AIDE
description: COCOA BEACH, Fla., Oct. 31 James Frederick Evans, director of state parks in New York for 23 years and a public servant for 44 years, died today in Cape Canaveral Hospital of pneumonia and infirmities. He was 77 years old and had lived here since 1962, following his retirement the year before.

title: Laotian Negotiators Meet But No Progress is Made
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 31Delegations from the Laotian Government and the proCommunist Pathet Lao held their third weekly peace negotiation session here today in an atmosphere of marked rancor.

description: CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (AP) Two thirdperiod goals by Bob Whitlock and one by Bob Sicinski gave the Chicago Cougars a 31 victory over the Winnipeg Jets tonight in the World Hockey Association.

title: JAMES DENYER DIES; PARAMOUNT TV AIDE
description: HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 31James Denyer, director of publicity for Paramount Television, a unit of Paramount Pictures Corporation, died in his office yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 46 years old,

title: Madeleine Malraux Gives Piano Recital
description: Although she has made several appearances here, including performances in the New York City Ballet's Stravinsky Festival last spring, Madeleine Malraux had not given a full public recital in New York until Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. The event was a benefit for the Concert Artists Guild, and it drew an audience of wellknown people from governmental, cultural and social circles.

title: End of City's Job Freeze Is Unlikely to Aid Minority Groups
description: Commissioners and personnel directors of the city's three uniformed forces said yesterday that the new appointments to come with the end of the job freeze would not substantially advance the goals of hiring more minoritygroup members and city residents.

title: 5 New Stage Ventures Line Wings Off Broadway
description: Off Broadway is experiencing a burst of activity with five new stage ventures announced for presentation this season.

title: REFERENDUM IS SET BY SEOUL ON NOV. 17
description: SEOUL, South Korea. Oct. 31, TheGovernment announced today that a national referendum would be held on Nov. 21 on the sweeping constitution amendments proposed by President Park Chung Hee last Friday.

title: HERMAN H. STONE, INVESTMENT AIDE
description: Herman Hart Stone, a Wall Street investment banker, died yesterday at the Waterbury, Conn., Hospital, to which he had been admitted last week with a heart condition. He was 65 years old and recently had moved to Southbury, Conn., after living for 25 years in Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Foe Said to Rule Out Truce
description: PNOMPENH, Oct. 31 (AP)Vietnamese Communist troops in Cambodia have received orders to continue fighting against the Government despite any ceasefire reached in Indochina, a high military intelligence source said today:

description: Underwriters of new taxexempt bonds pushed yields down a notch yesterday, but investors were reluctant to follow their lead and a large amount of the bonds remained in Wall Street hands.

title: Sunrise Highway Section Opens, Cutting Time to the Hamptons
description: HAMPTON BAYS, L. I., Oct. 31 What state transportation officials described as the best route from New York City to the Hamptons, a 12mile section completing Sunrise Highway to Shinnecock Hills, was opened today.

title: Business Briefs
description: Sales of noload mutual fundsthose with little or no sales chargesdropped to $60.4million in September from $67.8million a month earlier, the NoLoad Mutual Fund Association reported here yesterday.

title: Thieu Grants 637 Amnesty
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 31 (AP)President Nguyen Van Thieu granted 637 convicts amnesty today on National Day, the official Government news agency Vietnam Press announced.

title: Personalities: Green Nears 1,000th
description: Johnny Green, who was the first draft choice of the New York Knicks in 1959, will play his 1,000th game in the National Basketball Association tonight when he takes the floor for the Kansas City Omaha Kings against the Knicks in Omaha. Only two other players have played 1,000 league games, Hal Greer of the Philadelphia 76ers, who has played 1,090 games, and Dolph Schayes, who retired in 1964 after 1,059 games.

title: Pathe to End Cadence Suit; Spinoff of Hudson Cleared
description: A suit filed last week by Path Industries, Inc., to prevent the Cadence Industries Corporation from spinning off Hudson Pharmaceutical shares, is to be dropped under a settlement.reached yesterday.

title: Dr. Roberts's Rites Today
description: A memorial service for Dr. Henry L. Roberts, who was professor of history at Dartmouth College and had earlier headed the Russian Institute at Columbia University, will be held today at 2:30 P.M. in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia. Dr. Roberts died Oct. 17 in Randolph, Vt., at the age of 56.

title: Columbia Wins at Soccer
description: The Columbia soccer team evened its season wonlost record at 4.4 yesterday at Baker Field with a 41 triumph over City College. The Lions bunched their scoring into a 12minute stretch of the second half, with Pete Vasudhara recording the winning goal with 16:26 remaining.

title: The State Assembly
description: We make the following endorsements among candidates for the New York State Assembly from the metropolitan area. Incumbents are designated by an asterisk.

title: Thieu Calls Draft Accord Surrender to Communists
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Nov. 1President Nguyen Van Thieu today deInounced the draft peace agree, ment that was to have been (signed yesterday as a surrender of the South Vietnamese people to the Communists.

title: Hanoi Said to Speed War Supplies Into South
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31United States military intelligence officials said today that North Vietnam began a heavy movement of war materials into South Vietnam about 10 days ago in an apparent effort to build up its forces in preparation for a ceasefire.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Perhaps the the most realistic value a player for the New York Jets takes with him into later life is that pro football is a business, not a sport.

description: To the Editor:

title: 12 Doctors From China End Tour of Facilities in U.S.
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31 (UPI)Twelve doctors from China who ended a threeweek, tour of medical facilities in the United States today, said, We must learn from you sincerely.

description: Partisans on both sides in the Canarsie school dispute exchanged epithets and hurled eggsand, in a few instances, rocks at each other yesterday as white parents continued to keep most of their children out of the area's schools.

title: Queson Reported Lost
description: SAIGON, Wednesday, Nov. 1 (AP)Enemy forces reportedly, struck at more than 100 Government positions yesterday throughout South Vietnam for the sixth consecutive day. struck at more than 100 Government positions yesterday throughout South Vietnam for the sixth consecutive day.

title: Study for White House Suggests A Radio Network to Alert Public
Canada Faces Uncertainty After Election Standoff
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 31Unofficial returns today from all 264 electoral districts in the Canadian parliamentary election gave the Opposition party, the Progressive Conservatives, 109 seats, to 108 for Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's Liberalsthe narrowest margin in Canadian history.

title: Aeros Trip Oilers, 4 to 3
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, Oct. 31 (UPI)  The Houston Aeros scored three goals in the last 28 minutes to rally from a 31 deficit and edge the Alberta Oilers, 43, tonight. Ted Taylor's sixth goal of the season was decisive. Gordon Labossiere, with his eighth, Larry Lund and Larry Hale notched the others.

title: Nixon Signs Final Bill of '72, A $4.9Billion Appropriation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) President Nixon signed today his final bill of 1972, $4.9billion supplemental appropriation that the Democraticcontrolled Congress had cut by more than $800million.

title: Business Briefs
description: TAIPEI, Oct. 31 (Reuters)The Ford Motor Company has decided to invest $40million in Taiwan to manufacture cars and engines for sale in Asia, Government sources confirmed today.

title: The Screen: Golan's 'Escape to the Sun'
description: Current events, current problems, seem to spawn bad movies with some special generative power of their own. Films about war protest, ecology, race relations have all added their quota of bad faith to noble causes. And now, to treat the plight of Jewish intellectuals in Russia, which isn't a joke, comes Menahem Golan's "Escape to the Sun," which is.Wholly reminiscent of the cold-war chase melodramas, "Escape to the Sun" assembles a cross-section of disaffected Russians who want to emigrate to Israel and can'tlegallyand pits them against the tormented cunning of one Soviet intelligence officer, a Major Kirsanov. The would-be emigrs include a professor (Peter Capell), an out-of-favor World War II air ace (John Ireland), an idealistic novelist (Jack Hawkins), assorted middle-aged folk and a pair of young lovers (Josephine Chaplin and Yuda Barkan) who are the real heroes of the movie. In other days and better movies their antagonist might have been Claude Raines, or even just Yul Brynner. But here it is Laurence Harvey, who brings to the evil enigmatic Kirsanov all the fascinating animation of a pillar of salt.It is easiest to fault "Escape to the Sun" on the quality of performance, which ranges from the professionally inept (Mr. Harvey) to the almost amateurish (Miss Chaplin) and which deals in a helpless pseudo-realism that has all the minor characters speaking with Russian accents but alows the major characters accentsBritish mostlyof their own. But it is the direction that really subverts the movie and keeps sinking it beneath the level, to which it might have aspired, of the merely routine.Given the premises of an adventure film that should always move, Menahem Golan generally stalls. A bit of intentionally fuzzy focus here, a distorting camera angle there, some clichd youthful lyricism, an agonized flashback"Escape to the Sun" continually strives to be fancy without ever achieving competence. It knows exactly why its people are fleeing Russia, but is sloppy as to how. And it is wrong  philosophically wrongfor an escape movie to be clear as to the meaning of escape and so confused about the means."Escape to the Sun" opened yesterday at the Criterion Theater.

title: Dispute Disclosed By U.S. Financial With S.E.C. Staff
description: U.S. Financial, Inc., a company with a big stake in the housing business, indicated yesterday that it was involved in a dispute with the staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission over its previously reported financial results for 1971.

title: 500 Bakery Drivers Strike Against 8 Concerns Here
description: More than 500 bakery drivers struck here today at 12:01 A.M. against eight wholesale bakeries that supply most restaurants in the area with specialty baked goods, the union said.

title: Real Estate Man Charged With Renting Apartments He Did Not Own
description: Algis Gale, a realestate entrepreneur also known by various names including A. J. Jurgela, was arrested yesterday and accused of renting apartments he did not own to welfare clients and collecting security deposits, rent and brokerage fees from the city. The houses in which Mr. Gale allegedly placed welfare clients, and some who were not on welfare, were onefamily to fourfamily buildings in Brooklyn that had been insured by the Federal Housing Administration and were being foreclosed. Some of his tenants had lived in the houses since 1970.

title: Fleming of Paterson Keeps Jersey CrossCountry Title
description: WEST PATERSON, N. J., Oct. 31  Tom Fleming of William Paterson College won the sixth annual New Jersey intercollegiate crosscountry championship today in a record time of 23 minutes 36 seconds.

title: ChamberIndustry Group Merger Weighed
description: Eight years after a merger proposal was narrowly defeated in a bitter battle, the New York Chamber of Commerce and the Commerce and Industry Association of New York are again considering a proposal to merge.

title: The Kissinger Peace Plan: Thieu Is the Catch
description: BERKELEY, Calif.If only it were true that, as Henry Kissinger says, peace is at hand, if only there were some sign that the Vietnam war will soon pass into history, a bitter yet faded memory. Along with the Vietnamese, our country badly wants an end of the war, so that we grasp at the nearest rumor, seize on the slightest pretext to believe a settlement is in reach. The imminence of peace is a message that Henry Kissinger has repeatedly conveyed, in varying forms and intensities, since early 1969, and this time around it was accepted with an eagerness that surpassed even the usual unblinking credulity.

title: LANDRY IS HAPPY WITH DALLAS TEAM
A Rebuke for Trudeau on Issues
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 31  Disenchantment with Pierre Elliott Trudeau's colorful personality, loss of confidence among Englishspeaking Canadians in his handling of the Quebec issue and controversy over his political and economic policies combined to wreck his fouryear, hold on she Canadian Government. The setback in yesterday's election was in large part a personal repudiation of the Prime Minister. The freeswinging style that made him the heroic man of Canada's future four years ago struck many Canadians as inappropriate, even distasteful, in a Prime Minister. Thousands of his countrymen turned to the Conservatives led by a bland, staid campaigner, Robert L. Stanfield.

title: Business Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 31The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia announced today that exploration for natural gas was being pressed in a Siberian region that is expected to supply gas to Japan and the United States by the nineteeneighties.

title: Says Grass Helped Him
description: PORTOLA VALLEY, Calif., Oct. 31 (AP)The American League's grass infields and the skills of his catcher, Ray. Fosse, were credited today by lanky Gaylord Perry for the performance that won him the Cy Young award.

title: jazz, Rock
description: A jazz band with real roots turned up in an unlikely situation Monday evening. The occasion was the presentation at the Riverboat of the four winning groups in a talent contest conducted last month in the five boroughs by the Department of Cultural Affairs and the Department of Recreation of the Parks Administration with the help of the Department of Public Events, Brooklyn Museum and the Brooklyn Arts and Cultural Association.

title: Bridge: A Translated Swedish Book Helps Readers Guess Right
description: Students of bridge literature tlisually have to do without works published on the European continent. Several significant books have appeared in French, but only a small minority here can digest their contents effectively.

title: McCarthy Says McGovern Let the Issues Get Confused
In Escape to Past, Magicians Hail Houdini
description: The ceremony of the broken wand was conducted yesterday with due solemnity at the grave of Harry Houdini at the Machpelah Cemetery in Glendale, Queens. Two dozen magicians gathered there on the 46th anniversary of the death of the master showman and escape artist.

title: Burger Refuses to Put Off Suit On Listing G.O.P. Contributions
Metropolitan Briefs
description: City Health Department, in an extraordinary move, warned the public away from Dr. Emanuel Revici and Trafalgar Hospital, where the doctor is accused of treating thousands of narcotics and barbiturate addicts with an untested drug.

title: Market Place: Research Part of Street Shift
description: The young president of a major trust company is predicting that brothersinlaw and oldschooltie boysfixtures in Wall Street since the Buttonwood Tree  will be among the chief casualties of the shakeout caused by the current profit squeeze downtown.

title: ExBrewster Aide Testifieson Donations and Lobbying
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31A tale of cash in envelopes, checks made out to a dummy committee, an office slush fund and lobbyists writing speeches and letters for a member of Congress unfolded today at the bribery trial of former Senator Daniel B. Brewster.

title: Higher Domestic Output Is CitedRevenues Gain in Periods
POLICE SAY MAFIA CONTROLS PARKING
description: The Police Department yesterday accused six trucking concerns that have purported links to the Mafia of having monopolized curb space in the city's garment district, and it began a campaign of summonses against them.

title: Sharks Triumph, 42
description: QUEBEC, Oct. 31 (AP) Thirdperiod goals by Bart Crashley and Bernie MacNeil lifted the Los Angeles Sharks to a 42 victory over the Quebec Nordiques tonight.

title: Facade of Harlem Hospital Falling Off
description: A little more than three years after its completion, the marble facade of the $25million Harlem Hospital Cen, ter is falling down. No one knows why.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: TakeOver of Cotton Mills By Indian Government Set
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 31 (UPI)The Government today took over the management of 46 private textile mills as a prelude to their ultimate nationalization.

title: M'GOVERN DECRIES HEAVY ARMS COST
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 31Senator George McGovern today blamed excessive military spending for the plight of the cities, declaring that President Nixon was afraid to stand up to the goldplaters and the big wasters in the Pentagon.

title: All Will Fight O'Halloran, His Brother's Conqueror
description: BOSTON, Oct. 31 (AP) Muhammad All will fight Jack O'Halloran in a 12round bout at Boston Garden Dec. 13, Sam Silverman, the promoter, said today.

title: LILCO REPORTS RISE IN NET AND REVENUE
U.S. ARMY ATTACHE RELEASED BY SYRIA
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 31 (AP)A United States Army officer detained by Syrian authorities since Sept. 9 was released tonight in Damascus.

title: Rockefeller Stumps for Nixon; Hints He Will Seek 5th Term
DOCTOR ACCUSED ON ADDICTS'CARE
description: The City Health Department, in an unusual action, is taking steps to halt the activities of a 78yearold Rumanianborn physician who is said to have treated hundreds of narcotic addicts with a new and untested drug.

title: INFLATION ACCORD ADOPTED BY EEC.
description: LUXEMBOURG, Oct. 31 The Common Market nations, whose prices are rising by an average of 6 per cent a year, decided today on a joint antiinflation program that will probably have little effect on prices in coming weeks but that could be important over the longer term.

title: INQUIRY IS URGED ON A YOUTH GRANT
description: A member of the City Council has called for an investigation into the city's granting of $20,000 to the ItalianAmerican Civil Rights League for a summer recreation program for youths.

title: U.S. and Hanoi Reported In Accord on Truce Body
description: PARIS, Oct. 31An international commission to supervise a Vietnamese ceasefire has been agreed upon by the United States and North Vietnam; according to diplomatic sources here.

title: Notes on People
description: I'm not going to give up the ship as long as the captain needs me, said George H. Boldt, chairman of the Federal Pay Board, in reply to reports that he was thinking of resigning. But, he added in Washington, I do hope that in the next several months the President will be willing to relieve me. The chairman said he wanted to go home to Tacoma, Wash., not to resume sitting as a Federal District Court Judge, but to have a part in speeding up the judicial process.

title: Antipoverty Chief Assails Shriver's Campaign Letter
Farm Prices Rose To October Record On Gains by Wheat
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP)The farm price of wheat averaged $1.89 per bushel in October, the most for the month in nearly a decade, and helped raise prices of farm products generally to another record, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Rev. Dr. Dale DeWitt, Led American Unitarian Group
description: The Rev. Dr. Dale DeWitt, who was executive director here of the Middle Atlantic States Region of the American Unitarian Association from 1939 to 1964, died yesterday in nursing home near Baltimore. He was 74 years old and lived in Southhampton, L. I.

title: M'GOVERN DECRIES HEAVY ARMS COST
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 31Senator George McGovern today blamed excessive military spending for the plight of the cities, declaring that President Nixon was afraid to stand up to the goldplaters and the big wasters in the Pentagon.

title: $30,000 Donation Traced
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31A report by the staff of the House Banking and Currency Committee raised new questions today about possible violations of campaign financing, banking and tax laws in connection with several large contributions to the Committee for the Reelection of the President.

title: Foe Overruns Second Camp in Highlands
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Nov. 1  Enemy troops reportedly continued to attack strongly in the Central Highlands yesterday, overrunning the second Government position there in two days. Meanwhile, American B52 bombers flew heavy raids over the southern part of North Vietnam.

title: Hanoi Silent on a KissingerTho Talk
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Oct. 31 (Agence FrancePresse) Official sources remained silent, today on the possibility of a new meeting between Henry A. Kissinger and Le Due Tho, but optimistic observers saw hope in an official omission yesterday of any reference to the deadline of today for signing a ceasefire accord.

title: Muti Conducts With Easy Command
description: Conductors may he divided, for purposes of today's discussion, into two types: those who make the orchestra play, and those who let it. Riccardo Muti impressed one as Type Two in his appearance with the Philadelphia Orchestra at Philharmonic Hall on Monday night. Mr. Muti, who is music director of Florence's Orchestra del Maggio Musicale, has conducted opera at La Scala as well as in Florence, and his ability to let the melodic line float attested to that experience. Obviously, a conductor worth hearing more than

title: Big 4 Envoys Meet in Berlin
description: BERLIN, Oct. 31 (Reuters)Ambassadors of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union met here today for a fifth round of talks aimed at clarifying their rights in Germany after the expected entry of East Germany and West Germany into the United Nations.

title: WEALTH DEPARTMENT CITES 15 FOOD PLACES
description: The Health Department has cited 12 restaurants, two grocery stores and a candy store for serious violations of the city Health Code.

title: Stage:MadamedeSade
description: Yukio Mishirna's Madame de Sade, presented Monday and Tuesday as the opening production in this season's Matinee Series at the Theater de Lys, is, in the author's words, Sade seen through women's eyes, a play about de Sade in which de Sade does not appear.

title: Kings Subdue Canucks, 41; Triumph Is Fifth Straight
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 31 (AP) Butch Goring scored three goals tonight to help Los Angeles set a club record of five victories in a row as the Kings notched a 41 National Hockey League triumph over Vancouver.

title: The Watergate Mystery
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Despite 19 weeks of intensive investigation, sensational disclosure, and heated political debate, the dimensions of the Watergate affair are far from fixed.

title: FIREPROOFING SHIFT OPPOSED BY HOLDER
description: Thomas G. Wyman, who with his family, owns more than 18,000 common shares of the General Fireproofing Company, Youngstown, Ohio, has sent a letter to other shareholders urging that they oppose the proposed shift by management of the company's state of incorporation from Ohio to Delaware.

title: 3 DOCTORS SEIZED ON DRUG CHARGES
description: Complaints that holloweyed young men and women had been seen stumbling out of doctors offices and drug stores in Brooklyn led to the arrest yesterday of three physicians and three druggists on charges lof illegally prescribing and selling dangerous drugs.

title: Last Lap Near for Two Race Series
description: And now that the chill winds of November have arrived, the season is just about over. The principal roadracing series have been completed, and the United States Auto Club and NASCAR each has just one more race. USAC's Championship Trail ends Saturday with a 150miler at Phoenix, Ariz. Next to a victory in the $50,000 event, the most important objec tive is a high position in the season's point fund, which has approximately $100,000 to distribute.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Doctors Rebuffed by Shapp On Ousting Commissioner
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 31 (UPI)  Gov. Milton J. Shapp has rejected a demand by the Pennsylvania Medical Society that he discharge the State Insurance Commissioner,, Herbert Denenberg.

title: CITY ENDS FREEZE ON POLICE, FIRE, SANITATION JOBS
description: Mayor Lindsay, in a drive to make the city safer and healthier, ended his job freeze yesterday on the uniformed services and ordered the hiring of 3,150 policemen, 800 firemen and 780 sanitationmen by June, 1974.

title: Lansky Said to Offer Million to Any Land Giving Him a Haven
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 31Diplomatic sources here say that Meyer Lansky, the American underworld figure, has offered $1million and substantial investment to any country that will give him haven.

title: Wallace Backs Democrats In South Carolina Races
School Counselor Slashed By a Youth in the Bronx
description: A counselor and gym instructor at the evening community center in a Bronx public school was slashed with a knife last night while escorting five unruly youths from the building.

title: TrickorTreating Till Stroke of 7
description: A tiger and a witch stalked the hallways of a West Side apartment building last night. Their prey was candy, or, failing that, ,the coin of the realm.

title: MRS. ETTA HARRIS
description: Mrs. Etta Harris. a jeweler and formerly an interior decorator, died on Monday at her home. 142 West End Avenue. She was 78 years old. Mrs. Harris was the widow of Charles B. Harris, vice president of the Society of American Magicians and president of B. Harris & Sons, retail jewelry concern.

title: Kahane Freed on Bail
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 31 (AP)Rabbi Meir Kahane and nine young members of his Jewish Defense League were released on bail by a Jerusalem court today after pleading not guilty to a charge of disturbing the peace. They were arrested yesterday after trying to nail mezuzah  a Jewish religious talisman  to the Damascus Gate.

title: By I. F. Stone
description: WASHINGTON"An act of healing rather than a source of new division. This, Henry Kissinger said last week, was the Nixon objective in the ceasefire negotiations. But the agreement promises more recrimination, disillusion and bloodshed.

title: Judge Orders Amputation Despite Patient's Protest
Perry of Indians Voted Cy Young Pitching Award
description: Gaylord Perry, a 24game winner for the fifthplace Cleveland Indians, was named yesterday winner of the American League's Cy Young award as the outstanding pitcher. Wilbur Wood of the Chicago White Sox was a close second in the balloting by baseball writers.

title: To Simplify Life, a Jewel Sale
description: Will Sophia Loren finally get the 34.30carat emerald ring that her husband, Carlo Ponti, tried unsuccessfully to buy for her in 1968? Tune in Dec. 7 and see.

title: Mitchell Leisen, Director, Dies; To Each His Own Among Films
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. Oct. 31 (UPI)Mitchell Leisen, the screen director, whose films included Death Takes a Holiday. I Wanted Wings, Hold Back the Dawn and To Each His Own, died Saturday at the Motion Picture Relief Hospital in Woodland HMS: He was 74 years old.

title: Search for Boggs Grounded By Weather for Third Day
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Oct. 31 (UPI)The search for Hale Boggs, the House majority leader, and three companions was grounded for the third straight day today by snow, rain and fog.

title: Jersey Sailor Died in Fire
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 31 (UPI)  A sailor who was killed in a fire yesterday aboard a Navy submarine rescue vessel was identified today as James Lombard, 25 years old, of Oak Ridge, N. J. The blaze broke out in the forward hold of the Florikan, which was undergoing repairs, at the naval shipyard in Long Beach. Mr. Lombard's wife and two children live in the San Diego area.

title: Phillies Obtain Jim Lonborg In 7Man Deal With Brewers
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 (UPI)The Philadelphia Phillies, who finished last in the National League Eastern Division, acquired 29yearold Jim Lonborg and three other pitchers from the Milwaukee Brewers in a sevenplayer interleague deal designed to shore up Philadelphia's oneman pitching staff.

title: WineMonth Results Slip Despite Turnaround in Third Quarter
description: The United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday turnaround in thirdquarter earnings from last year's loss, but net for the first nine months trailed the yearago level despite higher sales in both 1972 periods.

title: $30,000 Donation Traced
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31A report by the staff of the House Banking and Currency Committee raised new questions today about possible violations of campaign financing, banking and tax laws in connection with several large contributions to the Committee for the Reelection of the President.

title: 2 STRIKES CUT OFF LIQUOR DELIVERIES
description: Deliveries of wine and liquor throughout the metropolitan region will be cut off today by two strikes against wholesale liquor distributors.

title: U.S, ASKING HANOI FOR REASSURANCE OF TROOP PULLOUT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31The United States is seeking reassurances from Hanoi that, once the Indochina settlement takes effect, North Vietnam will withdraw many of the 35,000 troops it now has stationed in the northern part of South Vietnam, even though it is not required to do so under the terms of the agreement as worked out.

title: Citibank Clarifies Its Bid To Open Office in Soviet
description: Donald J. Colen, vice president and director of public affairs at the First National City Bank, said yesterday that his bank was negotiating with authorities of the Soviet Union to open a representative office in Moscow. Mr. Colen said that statement that he made on Monday to The New York Times that Citibank was seeking a full branch in the Soviet Union was a result of a misunderstanding between himself and officials of Citibank's international banking group.

title: Canadian Conservative Leader Robert Lorne Stanfield
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 31  A week ago in Vancouver, Robert Lorne Stanfield had scheduled one of the many news conferences of his campaign for the leadership of Canada's Government, and 40 or so reporters were milling around a hotel reception room. Mr. Stanfield entered the room and walked to the podium, which in the case of most national figures would have brought the reporters quickly to attention. But they just kept drinking coffee, chatting and milling about, and Mr. Stanfield's press secretary finally had to take the microphone and say, as he often did during the campaign: Gentlemen, if we could begin now, please.

title: C.A.B. Ignores an Appeal By Eastern on Caribair
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board today ignored Eastern Airlines appeal for immediate approval of the acquisition of CaribbeanAtlantic Airlines, leaving Caribair's future in doubt.

title: The Proceedings in the U.N.
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: The Watergate Mystery
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Despite 19 weeks of intensive investigation, sensational disclosure, and heated political debate, the dimensions of the Watergate affair are far from fixed.

title: DR. MANCUSIUNGARO, INTERNIST, 90, DEAD
description: NEWARK, Oct. 31Dr. Lodovico MancusiUngaro, whose family's association with medical practice began in Italy in 1550, died on Saturday in Mountainside Hospital, Montclair. He was 90 years old and lived at 156 Mount Prospect Avenue.

title: Advertising: Innovation on TV
description: Usually when an advertiser promises a highly innovative advertising project, the response is, Ho hum, another one,

title: U.S. Willowbrook Study Calls For Smaller Mental Hospitals
description: In a highly critical report on overcrowding and inadequate programs at the Willowbrook State School for the mentally retarded, a Federal team urged New York State yesterday to develop more communitybased services as alternatives to large institutions for mental patients.

title: First New License Plates Since '65 Are Due January 1
description: ALBANY, Oct. 31For the first time in seven years, New Yorkers will receive new license plates for their cars starting on Jan: 1:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Michigan Gets NoFault
description: LANSING, Mich., Oct. 31 (UPI)Gov. William G. Milliken signed into law today nofault auto insurance legislation that he said will speed payments and assure adequate wage loss coverage to accident victims.

title: Lindsay Hails Coop
description: Mayor Lindsay has presented a certificate of distinction to the builders of a new cooperative residence at 60 East End (Avenue, at 82d Street, for excellence of design and commending them for their faith in New York City. The builders who received the award are Leonard Litwin and Martin B. Swarzman. The architect is Philip Birnbaum.

title: Advisory Board Asks Coney Hospital Chief to Resign
description: The community advisory board of Coney Island Hospital has asked for the resignation of the hospital's executive director, Frank Hays.

title: City to Put Social Workers In Poorest Neighborhoods
description: The city's welfare agency announced a program yesday to decentralize its social workers into neighborhood locations within 40 new human resources districts based on boundaries of community planning districts. The new emphasis on socialwork efforts is starting with the opening of the first community social services facility today at 45 Williams Avenue in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (Reuters)The average yield of accepted bids for fourmonth commitments to buy 7 per cent Federal Housing Administraton and Veterans Administration mortgages was 7.736 per cent at today's auction, the Federal National Mortgage Association reported today.

title: NIXON IS WIDENING CAMPAIGN EFFORT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 President Nixon has scheduled a lastminute round of television and radio addresses to present to the public his case for reelection, the White House announced today.

title: ARNOLD M. DIAMOND
description: TERRA. VERDE, Fla.., Oct. 31  Arnold M. Diamond. founder and president of Arnold M. Diamond, Inc., a construction management concern, died on Saturday at his home. He was 65 years old and lived here and at I Gracefield Drive, Kings Point. L. I.

title: Economics and Politics
description: The American Economic Association, according to its rules, is the organ of no party, sect, or institution. However, the effort of the economists professional body to stay purely professional faces a tough test.

title: Social Reform of Business Seen
description: We are in the opening phase of a revolution that will, if it runs its apparent course, radically change the character and performance of business institutions in our society, Prof. Melvin Anshen said yesterday at Columbia University in the first lecture of a series on Managing the Socially Responsible Corporation.

title: FloodVictim Homes Unused
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., Oct.31 (AP)  More than 1,500 mobile homes brought here to house flood victims are empty, according to officials of the Housing and Urban Development office here. They said that Government programs for the use of camper trailers on a flood victim's property and utility repairs to make parts of houses liveable had steered many residents away from the mobile home parks.

title: Goodman Is Honored As Man of the Year
description: State Senator Roy M. Goodman was named Man of the Year last night at a dinner for nearly 1,000 persons sponsored by BrotherhoodinAction.

title: N.Y.U. Senior and His Roommate Are Slain in Their Apartment in the Bronx
description: A 22yearold New York University senior and a 24yearold former student were found shot to death yesterday afternoon, in the apartment they shared.across the street from the University Heights campus in the Bronx.

title: Israeli Charge of Capitulation On Arabs Denied by Brandt
description: BONN, Oct. 31 (Reuters)Chancellor Willy Brandt today rejected Israel's accusations that West Germany had capitulated to terrorism by freeing three Arab guerrillas Sunday.

title: U.N. WILL GET AID ON UGANDA ASIANS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct, 31  Private welfare organizations, including Christian and Jewish agencies, have volunteered to help with United Nations efforts to resettle stateless Asians ordered deported from Uganda by Nov. 8.

title: FASHION TALK
description: If it's a long term trend you're looking for, Seventh Avenue is working on one for spring. After about a decade of drawing clothes closer to the body, like a second skin, everybody's sort of letting go. It's caftans every place you look. It's tent dresses, smocks, loose tops. So when you wear no underwear, nobody can tell.

title: TV: After School Fare
description: Bully for the American Broadcasting Company. Its second After School special in a new monthly series for youngsters rings the bell, quietly and firmly, as did the first entry. The program goes on at 4:30 this afternoon.

title: PROFITLESS '72 SEEN PROBABLE FOR FIAT
description: ROME, Oct. 31  Giovanni Agnelli, the president of Italy's giant automobile producer, Fiat, said today in Turin, Italy, that the company would probably not be profitable in 1972, it was reported here today. Last year, Fiat had a profit of more than $26million.

title: Bulls Down Kings
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (AP) Chet Walker and Bob Love poured in 17 points during the third quarter tonight to help the Chicago Bulls to a 10495 victory over the Kansas CityOmaha Kings.

title: Belle Geste and Jumbo Jet Report for the International
description: LAUREL, Md., Oct. 31 (AP)Belle Geste of Canada and Jumbo Jet of Singapore, entries in the $150,000 Washington, D.C. International, arrived at Laurel Race Course today.

title: OTB IS PLANNING TELEVISION RACE
description: Unless state racing officials block the plan, New, York horseplayers will soon be able to make a $2 offtrack bet on weekly Aqueduct superfecta and then watch the race either On television or at the track.

title: Police Investigate Village Fight That Led to Black Youth's Death
description: The police are investigating an incident in which one youth died and another was seriously wounded after a brawl between black and white teenagers in Greenwich Village last week

title: Two Intradivision Games Clues to Jets Playoff Bid
description: The Jets, along with 13 other teams of the 26 in the National Football League, are realistic contenders for one of the eight postseason playoff positions and what happens in two games at Kansas City and Pittsburgh on Sunday will affect their chances. The Jets, trailing the Dolphins by two games in their division. must think realistically about their role as the possible wildcard qualifier rather than catching up with Miami. a powerful outfit with an easy schedule the rest of the way.

title: SUPERFECTA PAYS A RECORD $32,874
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 31 The superfecta in Roosevelt Raceway's eighth race tonight returned $32,874.80, the highest ever here, on the 8274 combination.

title: Fort Lee Tax Aide Indicted as Dodger
description: NEWARK, Oct. 31  A Federal grand jury today indicted Edward A. McDermott, Tax Collector and Republican leader of Fort Lee, on charges of willfully failing to file tax returns covering more than. $296,000 in income since 1966.

title: Halloween Is a Memory in Pumpkin Center
description: PUMPKIN CENTER, Ind., Oct. 30Pumpkin Center? the old farmer said, Sure. You go down this here road a piece to Millersburg. Keep goin'. Then you'll come to Tater Road.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: BRUSSELSAn outstanding feature of this historical period is the development of multinational trading institutions as a factor in world relationships. Certainly this city, capital of an increasingly integrated Europe and host to many octopus corporations, keenly aware of this fact.

title: Thieu Calls Draft Accord Surrender to Communists
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Nov. 1President Nguyen Van Thieu today denounced the draft peace agreement that was to have been signed yesterday as a surrender of the South Vietnamese people to the Communists.

title: R. S. Rauch 3d Weds Miss Prentice
description: Miss Sheila Prentice and Rudolph Stewart Rauch 3d, a correspondent with Time magazine, were married here yesterday afternoon by Judge Refold A. Felix of the New York State Family Court at the home of the bride's brother and sisterinlaw, Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon E. Prentice.

title: Rockets Top Hawks, 106105
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 31 (UPI)Calvin Murphy scored with three seconds to play tonight to give the Houston Rockets a 106105 victory over the Atlanta Hawks.

title: Theater: Alan Bates Stars in Butley
description: Ben Butleytattered, battered superantihero of Simon Gray's play Butley  is coming adrift at his moorings. Desk lamps don't work for him, bananas and warm whisky have lost their kick, his wife has left him for another man and his roommate and protg haswellalso left him for another man. This English play, with Alan Bates in the softly bravura, underplayed virtuoso role of his career, opened last night at the Morosco Theater.

title: CITY ENDS FREEZE ON POLICE, FIRE, SANITATION JOBS
description: Mayor Lindsay, in a drive to make the city safer and healthier, ended his job freeze yesterday on the uniformed services and ordered the hiring of 3,150 policemen, 800 firemen and 780 sinitationmen by June, 1974.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: SEA BRIGHT, N. J., Oct. 31All the summer people have left this sandbar town for another year. It's time for the permanent residents to batten down before the arrival of the strong northwest, and then northeast, winds that change the shape of Sea Bright each winter and spring.

title: SickleCell Tests Given
description: More than 2,000 Harlem :school children yesterday received blood leadlevel tests and examinations for sicklecell anemia, hypertension and tuberculosis in a family health fair, sponsored by the Harlem Commonwealth Council and Sydenham Hospital Neighborhood Family Care Center, 215 West 125th Street.

title: Dubuffet, at 71, Abounds With Fantasies
description: All this attention makes me think that this is the year of Dubuffet in New York, said the French artist Jean Dubuffet, who has been in town this past week. He had a decidedly strong point, for the season will be full of Dubuffet accolades.

title: SULLIVAN IS WINNER OF PRIZE IN SCIENCE
description: BOSTON, Oct. 31The trustees of Boston's Museum of Science announced today that Walter S. Sullivan, Science Editor of The New York Times, will be the 1972 recipient of the Bradford Washburn Award Award for increasing public understanding of science.

title: U.S. TEAM SWEEPS JUMP AT GARDEN
description: The United States Equestrian Team, defending its team.title at the National Horse Show, served notice on Its Canadian and Mexican rivals that it is going to be hard to beat this year.

title: Agnew Advocates A Public Stigma For Draft Evaders
Canada Faces Uncertainty After Election Standoff
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 31Unofficial returns today from all 264 electoral districts in the Canadian parliamentary election gave the Opposition party, the Progressive Conservatives, 109 seats, to 108 for Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's Liberalsthe narrowest margin in Canadian history.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES OFF AFTER GAINS
description: Soybean futures declined yesterday, as expected, after some recent sharp advances. Profit taking helped cut prices to $3.54 a bushel in terms of the November delivery, from $3.57 Monday.

title: MRS. WILLIAM H. THORN
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 31 Mrs. Patricia Phleps Thorn wife of William H. Thorn, a vice president of Fred S. James & Co., insurance brokers, died yesterday of undetermined causes in Lawrence Hospital where she was awaiting an operation. She was 46 years old and lived at 23 Sturges Road.

title: 8,000 Demonstrate Near Boston Hall As Mrs.Nixon Talks
Other News of Vietnam
description: In Paris, diplomatic sources reported that Hanoi and Washington had agreed on an international trucesupervisory commission consisting of Canada, Indonesia, Poland and Hungary and on a peace conference to follow within 30 days of the signing, with Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations participating.

title: WILLIAM A. PARENTAU
description: William A. Parentau, chief controller of the tower at Kennedy International Airport in Queens, died yesterday at Franklin General Hospital, Manhasset, L.I., after a long illness. He was 56 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CABINET RESIGNS IN CHILE UNREST
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 31 (AP)All 15 members of Chile's Cabinet resigned today to give President Salavador Allende Gossens a free hand in seeking means to end three weeks of strikes, street demonstrations, sabotage and political conflict.

title: Giants Bracing for Floyd Little
description: With visions of Larry Brown romping over, through and around them still clogging their heads, the Giants now have to brace themselves for the real live appearance of Floyd Little.

title: N.Y.U. Senior Slain With His Roommate
description: A 22yearold New York University senior and a 24yearold former student were found shot to death yesterday afternoon in the apartment they shared across the street from the University Heights campus in the Bronx.

title: Inquiries Begun in Chicago Train Crash That Killed 44
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 31  Investigations were being conducted today by Federal, state and city officials seeking the, cause of the crash of two Illinois Central commuter trains yesterday morning that resulted in the death of 44 persons and injuries to at least 320 others.

title: ... Boycott in Canarsie
description: The boycott of Canarsie schools by local parents unconscionable as well as illegaland it is vital that there be no surrender to such tactics. State Education Commissioner Nyquist, the city's Board of Education, Chancellor Scribner and the United Federation of Teachers have all justifiably characterized the action by District 18's white parents as shameful and intolerable.

title: LLOYD L. MAURER
description: Lloyd L. Maurer, sales department offices manager of the American Smelting and Refining Company, died Monday at the Mary Hitchcock Hospital, Hanover, N. H. He was 60 years old and lived296 Burns Street, Forest Hills Gardens, Queens.

title: Wit and Insularity In Farber Dances Seen at Marathon
description: Viola Farber has two styles of choreography: clean as whistle and cleaner. She offered a sample of each on Tuesday evening at the ANTA Theater while sharing a program with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. It was her first appearance as part of the City Center American Dance Marathon.

title: 76ERS ARE BEATEN 10TH TIME IN ROW
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 (UPI) Rudy Tomjanovich made all eight of his shots in the final period tonight and led the Houston Rockets to a 108104 victory over the Philadelphia 76'ers. It was the 76ers 10th straight loss; they have yet to win in the National Basketball Association this season.

title: Q: Are polls an accurate measure of opinion? A: Well, yes and no.
description: WASHINGTONThe polls point to a landslide victory for Richard M. Nixon but observers have been rightly suspicious over the implication of an unprecedented Democratic disaster.

title: U.S. Drug Drive Called Failure In Reports Prepared for H.E.W
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UPI) Two research organizations have told the Government that its antidrug campaign is having a destructive and unsuccessful impact on the nation's youth, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare said today.

title: NIXON SAYS MONEY HE GAVE TO CITIES SET RECORD IN AID
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 President Nixon said today that, while his predecessors had fruitlessly spent billions of dollars on the problems of the cities, he had spent even more but had made it count.

title: Still in the Balance
description: Despair is hardly justified that peace did not come to Vietnam precisely on Oct. 31, the day Hanoi's spokesmen heralded as their proposed ceasefire date. Despite his spectacular assertion just one week ago, that peace is at hand, Dr. Kissinger never publicly committed himself to such an early conclusion to last month's secret negotiations.

title: 1,200 Security Aides in Schools To Be Added Starting Nov. 20
description: The city's program to place 1,200 security aides in the public schools will go into operation the week of Nov. 20, according to Eldridge Waith, the Board of Education's Safety Director.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 (AP)Jack Kelly Jr., president of the Amateur Athletic Union, called today for a Congressional investigation into the activities and functions of the National Collegiate Athletic Association. Kelly said he would ask that a special commission be formed to determine the legitimate scope of the N.C.A.A.'s activities, including methods of enforcement employed by its executive offices under Executive Director Walter Byers.

title: United Merchants
description: United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., reported yesterday higher net income for the first quarter ended Sept. 30 of $3.14million, or 52 cents a share, compared with $3.11million, or 51 cents a share in the like 1971 period. Sales rose to $180million from $177.5million.

title: Hendricks Back to Orioles
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (UPI)The Chicago Cubs traded Ellie Hendricks, a catcher, to the Baltimore Orioles today for Francisco Estrada, also a catcher.

title: 4.5 Million Called Excluded From School Lunch Project
description: Federal freelunch programs for poor children still exclude 4.5 million needy youngsters, a staff member of the Senate Select Committee on Nutrition and Human Needs said yesterday.

title: Lubovitch Dancers Open Run With 2 Premieres
description: Lar Lubovitch, whose dance company opened Tuesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music for a run through Sunday afternoon, does not appear to present himself as a ground breaker. Yet he is breaking all the rules in his own manner and getting away with it very nicely.

title: Adm. Sir George Creasy, Head Of Naval Operations for DDay
description: LONDON, Nov. 1 (AP)Admiral of the Fleet Sir George Elvey Creasy, who was responsible for planning naval operations for the Allied invasion of Europe in World War II, died today. He was 77 years old.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: GOTEBORG, Sweden, Nov. 1 (UPI)Topseeded John Newcombe of Australia ran into trouble against Dick Stockton of Port Washington, L. I., before the former Wimbledon champion advanced to the quarterfinal of the Goteborg $50,000 World Championship of Tennis tournament tonight. Newcombe won by 6.7, 76, 61.

title: A NEW RAID INQUIRY URGED BY SENATOR
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UPI) Senator Harold Hughes said today that the Senate Armed Services Committee should renew its investigation of illegal air raids over North Vietnam unless the Pentagon conducts a thorough inquiry.

title: Vietcong Irritation Over Concessions By Hanoi Reported
description: PARIS, Nov. 1American sources in close touch with the Vietcong's delegation in Paris said today that the Vietcong were irritated and unhappy with North Vietnam for having dropped three of its crucial demands in reaching a ceasefire agreement with the United States.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: MONTEVIDEO, Nov. 1 (AP)Former Foreign Minister Jorge Peirano Facio was detained and questioned for several hours today about a $10million Government loan allegedly misused by his bank. He was released, his brother remained in custody.

title: The President on Crime
description: Implicit in the President's recent radio address on crime is the belief that it is posiible to fool most of the people nearly all of the time during election years. Four years ago candidate Nixon got considerable political mileage out of heavily overstated campaign pledges on law enforcement. Having driven the lawandorder issue so hard as candidate, Mr. Nixon is now under pressure to show that he has performed well as incumbent.

title: Recalled Cars Not Returned
description: DETROIT, Nov. 1 (AP)Only a third of 6.7 million Chevrolet owners have returned their cars for possibly crucial engine mount corrections in the largest recall in automotive history, the company says. The recall began Feb. 18, when Chevrolet, under pressure from Federal safety officials, issued the recall for 196569 cars.

title: Lincoln Mask Closing
description: The Lincoln Mask, V. J. Longhi's play about the private life of Abraham Lincoln and his wife from 1840 to 1865, will end its run at the Plymouth Theater on Saturday after eight performances. The cast is headed by Fred Gwynne as Lincoln and Eva Marie Saint as Mary Todd Lincoln.

title: Market Rises 13.02
description: The stock market scored one of its best gains of 1972 yesterday, buoyed mainly by hopes for a ceasefire, agreement in Indochina. The DowJones industrials rose 13.02 to 968.54, closing five points below the 1972 high, as volume expanded to 21.36 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange. Page 63.

title: U.S. Schedules an Inquiry Into Immigration Services
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1A fivepronged Federal investigation of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, which also will consider the overhaul of the immigrant preference system, is planned to begin in early January.

title: IN THE NATION
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1California's Secretary of State Edmund G. Brown Jr. predicted yesterday that nine million voters and maybe more will go to the polls here next Tuesday, a record. If so, that might bolster George McGovern's chances to win a state everyone agrees he has to win if he is to have any chance for a national victory.

title: Rate of Borrowing On Notes for City Declines to 3.36%
description: The city's standing in the money market showed substantial improvement yesterday.

title: Fashion Is on Menu for 7 Apparel Makers
description: For the last 20 years, seven apparel manufacturing concerns executives have met precisely at 1 P.M. every day in a respite from Seventh Avenue's frantic pace.

title: National General Corp. Not for Sale, Klein Says
description: Eugene V. Klein, chairman of the National General Corporation, declared here yesterday that the company was not for sale.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 1 (AP)The National Hockey League's board of governors appointed today a fiveman committee to work with the N.H.L. Players Association on future international competition.

title: QUEENS YOUTH HELD IN A FIFTH ATTACK
description: A 17yearold Baruch College, freshman, who had been free on $15,000 hail since being) charged with the knifepoint) rape of three Queens women in September, was arrested again: yesterday and charged with threatening a pregnant Forest Hills housewife with a knife in the elevator of her apartment building Tuesday afternoon. It was the fifth similar attack in which he is a suspect.

title: HERBERT HAMM OF STATE COURT
description: TROY, N. Y., Nov. 1Herbert D. Hamm, a retired Justice of the State Supreme Court, died yesterday of a respiratory ailment at his home in East Greenbush. His age was 76.

title: Letter Bombs in Malaysia
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Nov. 1 (AP)Military bomb experts defused 15 letter bombs last night that were addressed to people in the United States, London and Rome, army sources said today.

title: Repairs of 70 Car Models Found To Average From $282 to $522
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1The first major study of the average cost to repair damages caused by automobile crashes shows that the average bill was lowest for two Chrysler Corporation products, the Plymouth Satellite and the Dodge Coronet $282followed by the Chevrolet Vega station wagon, $287, and the Dodge Charger, $289.

title: Mario, Son and 2 Others Indicted After T railer Bug
description: Paul Vario Sr., a reputed Mafia leader whose Brooklyn headquarters were hugged for six months this year by the District Attorney's office, was indicted yesterday for the second time in eight days along with his son, his bodyguard and a Nassau County prison guard.

title: ROBERT LIGHT, HEAD OF KING FOUNDATION
description: Robert E. Light, a writer and executive director of the Martin Luther King Foundation, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. He was 47 years old and lived at 35 Orange Street, Brooklyn.

title: Malamutes Prove Their Worth As Protectors and Show Dogs
description: When Frank and Claire Bongarzone of New Shrewsbury, N. J., acquired an Alaskan malamute bitch five years ago, they were among the growing number of people buying dogs for protection.

title: Dellinger and Hayden :Get Permission for Trip to Hanoi
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (AP)Two antiwar activists, David Dellinger and Tom Hayden, were given permission by a judge today to go to Hanoi after they said they had a request from the North Vietnamese regarding the possible release of additional United States prisoners of war.

title: People and Business
description: A year ago yesterday, when the DowJones industrial average stood at 839, Eliot Janeway shocked Wall Street with his prediction that this bellwether indicator would sink to 500 in 1972. Yesterday, when the Dow closed at 968.54, the economist was no less certain that the average was headed for big fall.

title: Middlebury Undefeated Since It Was Grounded
description: A year ago Middlebury had an unexpectedly good football season, passing its way to six victories against two defeats. Pete Mackey broke all New England college passing records. The team set New England passing offense records and led the nation in touchdown passes with 25.

title: New Housing Chief Andrew Pitman Kerr
description: Since he joined the Lindsay administration as an unpaid director in the city's Policy Planning Council four years ago, Andrew P. Kerr, the city's new Housing and Development Administrator, has played the role of efficiency expert.

title: Protestant Group Continues SitIn of Council of Churches
description: A group of eight Protestants, six black and two white, continued for a second day yesterday their occupation of the headquarters of the Council of Churches of the City of New York to protest what they considered the council's failure to speak out on racism.

title: I.O.S. Agrees to Exchange Commonwealth Debentures
description: The Commonwealth United Corporation moved a step closer yesterday to gaining 100 per cent acceptance on the part of its creditors of an offer to exchange their debentures for stock in Seeburg Industries, a vending machine subsidiary.

title: COURT HIRES GROUP TO AID IN RESEARCH
description: The state court system has retained the research arm of a Manhattan public relations concern to study the communications needs of the courts.

title: British Set Ulster Referendum; Roman Catholics Voice Doubts
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 1 The British Government announced today the terms of the Plebiscite in which the people of Northern Ireland will be asked to express their view about the division of Ireland into two countries.

title: ROBERT H. M'ARTHUR, PRINCETON BIOLOGIST
