description: PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 1Dr. Robert H. MacArthur, the Henry Fairfield Osborn Professor of Biology at Princeton University and a specialist in the field of population biology, died today at his home after a long illness. He was 42 years old and lived here at 106 Broadmead Road.

title: Segretti Moves Cited
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1 Donald H. Segretti asked about joining a local Democratic club here shortly before the California primary last spring and at about the same time apparently volunteered to work in the campaign of Senator George McGovern.

title: Business Briefs
description: KUWAIT, Nov. 1 (AP)Iraq declined to agree to the Persian Gulf states oilparticipation agreement mainly because it called on Baghdad to pay $400million in compensation to the nationalized Iraq Petroleum Company, the Kuwait newspaper, Al Siyassah, reported today. Baghdad, the paper said, insisted on paying I.P.C. a maximum $15million.

title: Smith Narrowly Escapes Elimination in Paris Tennis
description: PARIS, Nov. 1 (Agence FrancePresse)Stan Smith needed all his resources to survive the first round of the Coubertin tennis tournament today.

title: GEN. MIN OPPOSES DRAFT AGREEMENT
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 1Duong Van Minh, the retired general who is the principal rallying point of the opposition to President Nguyen Van Thieu, declared today that he disagreed with the ceasefire plan drafted by the United States and North Vietnam.

title: MICHAEL MANSFIELD
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Nov. 1Michael Mansfield, vice president of Stern Merritt, manufacturers of Christian Dior neckwear, who came here from New York to recover from open heart surgery, died yesterday at the age of 36.

title: Laotians Report Victories
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 1Military sources reported today that Laotian Govenment troops had retaken two important towns but that one of them was more than half destroyed when withdrawing North Vietnamese set fire to it.

title: Sound Housing Pledged By New Head of H.D.A.
description: Andrew P. Kerr was sworn in yesterday as head of the city's Housing and Development Administration, and promised to press for the maximum number of sound housing units for New Yorkers at all income levels.

title: Paper Endorses McGovern
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 (AP) The Philadelphia Daily News today endorsed Senator George McGovern for President, asserting the issue here is honesty. The News is part of the Knight newspaper chain. Its sister paper, The Philadelphia Inquirer, endorsed Mr. Nixon last week.

title: Current Reactor Design Found Acceptable by A. E.C. Advisers
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1The Advisory Committee on Reactor Safeguards, a group of nongovernmental experts, has reached the conditional conclusion that power reactors of current design can be operated without undue risk to the health and safety of the public.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and P.M. to discuss draft resolution on nonuse of force in international relations and permanent prohibition of use of nuclear weapons and report of Committee on Colonialism.

title: Young Black Players Will Join Women's Tennis Tour in 1973
description: In a significant step toward providing greater opportunities for blacks in bigtime tennis, the American Tennis Association will enter promising players in tournaments against Mrs. Billie Jean King, Mrs. Nancy Gunter and other stars of the Women's International Tennis Federation next year.

title: Leaders Keep Tight Rein On Protesters in Canarsie
description: Flanked by a burly young man in a black trench coat, apparently acting as her bodyguard, Mrs. Gertrude Pastelnick, moved quickly about the streets surrounding Junior High School 211 yesterday, shoring up her battle lines.

title: Nixon's P.M.A.Or Lack of It
description: CHICAGO Why did you support Mr. Nixon in the 1968 campaign?

title: Scarcity of Knowledge About Traffic on Ho Chi Minh Trail Expected to Be Thorny Problem for Peace Pact
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 1There is an apparent lack of reliable knowledge these days about the current state of Communist traffic on the Ho Chi Minh Trail, and this underscores one of the thorniest problems negotiators will face in future efforts to bring peace to Indochina.

title: Jersey Man Asserts Segretti Described Florida Espionage
description: A New Jersey man says that Donald H. Segretti told him last spring of the political espionage and disruption directed against Democratic Presidential candidates in the Florida primary, holding up the tactics as examples of what could be done to help reelect President Nixon.

title: Middlebury Undefeated Since It Was Grounded
description: A year ago Middlebury had an unexpectedly good football season, passing its way to six victories against two defeats. Pete Mackey broke all New England college passing records. The team set New England passing offense records and led the nation in touchdown passes with 25.

title: Mrs. Cudone Has 68 for 143 To Lead NorthSouth Golf
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Nov. 1 (UPI)  Mrs. Philip Cudone of Myrtle Beach, S. C., shot a record 68, five under par, to take sole possession of the lead today after the second round of the North and South senior women's golf championship.

title: Citibank Slashes Size of Issue In InvestmentCompany Project
description: The First National City Bank, faced with general public disenchantment about the stock market, has cut back sharply the size of Advance Investors Corporation, the new closedend investment company that it first proposed last June.

title: Opera: A Happy Revival
description: It is always instructive to dear a revival of an opera that once drove audiences mad with delight but has dropped out of the repertory. Occasionallyvery occasionallyit is also a pleasure. One of the more worthwhile revivals of the latter sort took place Tuesday night at Alice Tully Hall, where Rossini's second opera, La Pietra del Paragone, was given in concert form, with minimal staging, by Clarion Concerts with Newell Jenkins conducting.

title: East Germans Release Prisoners
description: BERLIN, Nov. 1The East Germans began releasing from prison thousands of criminals and political prisoners today, sending the first group of 54 released men across the wall to West Berlin.

title: Jets to Be Wary of Biggs, ExTeammate, on Sunday
description: Although they were never teammates, Bob Svihus, the Jets offensive tackle, will not have to be introduced to Verlon Biggs, Washington's defensive end, when the two teams meet for the first time ever on Sunday in Shea Stadium.

title: Personal Finance
description: Computers and pennyminded savers have brought about sharp changes in recent years in the way banks and other savings institutions figure compound interest.

title: Two Airports Add Tax on Passengers After Ban Is Vetoed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) In the wake of President Nixon's veto of legislation to ban airport passenger taxes, two airports put into effect head taxes today, and air travelers faced the prospect of similar fees at many other terminals.

title: Jazz: A Rich Choice of Vocal Duets
description: Jackie Cain and Roy Kral, infrequent visitors to New York in recent years, have found a very complementary setting for their tight and polished jazz vocal duets at the new Half Note, 149 West 54th Street. They are sharing the bandstand there this week with Al Cohn and Zoot Sims, the two saxophonists who were in almost permanent residence at the Half Note when it was on the Lower West Side.

title: U.S. VOTER ROLLS UP BY 13 MILLION
description: More than 94.5 million Americans, an increase of some 13 million since 1968, are registered to vote Tuesday in the Presidential election, according to a New York Times analysis of preliminary registration data.

title: 'Trouble Man' Arrives
description: "Trouble Man" is a new white-financed black film starring Robert Hooks, one of the founders of New York's Negro Ensemble Company, as a supremely self-assured Los Angeles private eye known simply as Mr. T. It opened yesterday at the Juliet II and DeMille Theaters, and although it's a bad film, it represents such a peculiar collaboration of interests that it should be of concern to both black and white film sociologists. Also, it dramatizes such a wild confusion of values I'm not sure it wants to be described as cool or uppity.Because of the way "Trouble Man" sanctifies Mr. T and his successesthe loving care with which the camera explores his closets full of shirts, ties, shoes and $300 suitsthe film passes through the needs of black fantasy-feeding and comes out on the other side, as a four-square, all-American movie that urges the preservation of the rotten system that makes all the loot possible.In the most mindless fashion, this commercial film neutralizes not revolution but all sorts of other less cataclysmic social changes. Witness Mr. T and his woman, Cleo (Paula Kelly), who is supposedly a nightclub singer but so loves Mr. T that she refuses out-of-town engagements and spends all day lolling about her flat waiting for him to call. No matter that her hair is cut Afro, nor that the objets d'art surrounding her are African, She's still a house slave.Cleo never asks Mr. T what he doesin this case he's finding himself set up to be the fall guy in a gang war involving both blacks and whites. Cleo doesn't inquire because she knows that he knows that she would worry. And, of course, when she's in his arms, the world is quite all right. He's her kind of man, kind and gentle and helpful to the poor. That is, off-screen.On-screen, he's supercat, boozing ("a little gin with one ice cube"), turning on black women and white women ("Will I see you again?" asks one. "I'll think about it," he answers), and murdering anyone who gets in his way with an abandon that surpasses the demands of even this foolish plot.There have been other white-financed black films (including "Shaft") that have done more or less the same thing, in a similar fashion. The thing that distinguishes "Trouble Man" is the strong implication that the squalid conditions of Mr. T's world are worth protecting for the big payoffs to the lucky ones who beat the system, who can surmount the conditions.In the film's climactic sequence, set in the ultramodern Century City of Beverly Hills, Mr. T single-handedly knocks off all the members of a mob of white gangsters who are holed up in the ultraposh Century Plaza. On the one hand, the action is that of the conventional black private-eye film, but the scenery looks like the illustrations for a prospectus for Century City, where, if we are good and don't rock the boat, we may all be able to live some day. Either Century City, or some place just like it."Trouble Man" is a horrible movie, but it's worth thinking about.

title: Tokyo Plans Major Aid For Indochina After War
description: TOKYO, Nov. 1  Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ohira today told a special envoy from South Vietnam, Pham Dang Lam, that Japan would contribute heavily to the postwar economic reconstruction of Indochina.

title: Guider
description: MIME TIME The American Mime Theater is 20 years old, which makes it something of a longliver in its line. Its line is not, according to its management, pantomime, which is done by people who handle imaginary objects. The company of 10 works in tights, and what it does is act in works that emplay elements of theater, dancing, playwriting, stage design and voice.

title: JOHNNY LONG DIES; BANDLEADER WAS 56
description: PARKERSBURG, W. Va., Nov. 1 (AP) Johnny Long, the bandleader whose recording of Shanty Town sold over 4 million copies, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home here. He was 56 years old.

title: A Tense Calm Holds Among Youths
description: No matter how brave we talk, we're all scared, said Dominick, a white youth Who formerly attended Canarsie High School. He made the admission as black youths faced white youths yesterday across police lines in the second day of nearclashes between the two groups.

title: Waldheim Is Silent On Report of Paris Role
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 1 (UPI)Secretary General Waldheim declined today to comment on a report that he would participate in a Vietnam conference 30 days after they signing of a truce.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Nixon and Tower Endorsed By Speaker of Texas House
Cambodian Is Optimistic After Briefing by Rogers
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1Foreign Minister Long Boret of Cambodia said today that he was optimistic about the future of his country after receiving a detailed briefing from Secretary of State William P. Rogers on the current diplomatic efforts to settle the Indochina conflict.

title: U.S. VOTER ROLLS UP BY 13 MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 More than 94.5 million Americans, an increase of some 13 million since 1968, are registered to, vote Tuesday in the Presidential election, according to a New York Times analysis of preliminary registration data.

title: Cambodians Lose Town
description: Pnompenh, Cambodia, Nov. I (AP)Enemy forces captured Trapeang Kraleng, 35 miles west of Pnompenh, and Government columns were unable to dislodge them, Brig. Gen. Norodom Chantarangsei reported today. It was the first district town to fall since April.

title: F.T.C. REQUESTS PESTICIDE CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1The Federal Trade Commission moved today to force three big manufacturers of pesticides to include health warnings in their advertising.

title: Flames Defeat Wings, 4.2
description: DETROIT, Nov. 1 (UPI)Lew Morrison's second goal of the game gave the Atlanta Flames a 42 triumph over the Detroit Red Wings tonight. The loss was the Wings fourth straight in the National Hockey League.

title: Troops Sweep Catholic Area
description: BELFAST, Thursday, Nov. 2 (UPI)  Hundreds of British troops sealed off Belfast's Roman Catholic Ardoyne District early today and arrested at least six leaders of the Irish Republican Army, including battalion commander, the British army said.

title: 41% OF INCOMES ROSE IN OCTOBER
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1Fortyone per cent of United States households reported higher incomes in October than they had a year earlier, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: SEGRETTI QUOTED ON FLORIDA SPYING
description: A New Jersey man says that Donald H. Segretti told him last spring of the political espionage and disruption directed against DDemocratic Presidential candidates in the Florida primary, holding up the tactics as examples of what could be done to help reelect President Nixon.

title: BOND PRICES GAIN ON A BROAD FRONT
description: Bond prices surged on broad front yesterday, apparently drawing renewed inspiration from progress toward peace in Vietnam and from a belief that the financing demands of industry and Government would be manageable in the months ahead.

title: 14 Contests Slated In New Gymnasium For C. C. N. Y. Five
description: City College's basketball team, coming off a 149 wonlost season, will open a 24game schedule Dec. 2 against Columbia at C.C.N.Y.'s new 3,500seat Jeremiah T. Mahoney Hall.

title: U.S. Reports Heavy B52 Strikes in North and South
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Nov. 2The United States resumed heavy B52 attacks on Communist targets in North Vietnam and South Vietnam overnight after having diverted many missions to North Vietnamesebase areas in Laos and Cambodia yesterday, the American command reported this morning.

title: Concern Unveils Copier
description: The battle for the office copierduplicator market appeared to be escalating yesterday as the International Business Machines Corporation introduced a new intermediatespeed model that could challenge the Xerox Corporation's dominance of that multibilliondollar industry.

title: Mundy I. Peale, 66, ExHead Of Republic Aviation, Is Dead
A Florida Democrat Objects To Being Tied to McGovern
Vietcong Irritation Over Concessions By Hanoi Reported
description: PARIS, Nov. 1American sources in close touch with the Vietcong's delegation in Paris said today that the Vietcong were irritated, and unhappy with North Vietnam for having dropped three of its crucial demands in reaching a ceasefire agreement with the United States.

title: A Group of Frenchmen Traveled Here to Study The American Kitchen
description: ITHACA, N. Y.Georges Blanc, who is 30 years old and looks all of 19, runs one of the most respected small restaurants of France in the RhOne Valley village of Vonnas.

title: Chess: No CliffHangers Wanted In That Last Crucial Round
description: What every player and team captain wants in a crucial last round is a flat, cold win. Cliffhangers and cutandthrust brawls may delight the spectators, but they turn the players ashen and give team captains ulcers.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to build a synthetic natural gas plant at a site on the Mississippi River 20 to 25 miles south of Baton Rouge, La. George F. Kirby, the company's president, said the plant would cost $175million and would gasify approximately 110,000 barrels of light liquid hydrocarbons a day to produce 500million cubic feet of pipeline quality gas.

title: Continental Telephone
description: CHANTILLY, Va., Nov. (AP)The Continental Telephone Corporation, the nation's thirdlargest independent telephone company, announced today that its revenues and profits rose in the third quarter.

title: Police in Syracuse Seize 100 Pounds of Marijuana
description: SYRACUSE, Nov. 1 (AP)The city police made a record haul of marijuana early today when two outofstate men allegedly attempted to sell 100 pounds of the plant to an undercover agent.

title: Young Black Players Will Join Women's Tennis Tour in 1973
description: In a significant step toward providing greater opportunities for blacks in bigtime tennis, the American Tennis Association will enter promising players in tournaments against Mrs. Billie Jean King, Mrs. Nancy Gunter and other stars of the Women's International Tennis Federation next year.

title: Lindsay Gives Priority in Capital Budget to Crime and Fire Peril
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday gave top priorities for the 197374 capital budget to buildings, equipment and devices that would increase the efficiency of public safety agencies.

title: Stepfather Held in Death
description: AMITYVILLE, N. Y., Nov. 1 (AP)Homicide detectives arrested Thomas Gray, 23 years old, at his home here last night on a charge of manslaughter in the death of his 3yearold stepson. The polic said the boy died yesterday at a hospital following a beating.

title: U.S. Schedules an Inquiry Into Immigration Services
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1A fivepronged Federal investigation of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, which also will consider the overhaul of the immigrant preference system, is planned to begin in early January.

title: 4 WOMEN CHARGED WITH HIDING ESCAPEE
description: ALBANY, Nov. 1 (AP)The police charged four young women yesterday with harboring a felon after police officers captured a man they said was one of 12 county jail inmates who escaped last Friday night. The women pleaded not guilty to the felony charges at Police Court and were sent to the jail after failing to post bail.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The Offtrack Betting Corporation will accept wagers on the Washington, D. C. International turf classic to be raced at Laurel Race Course in Maryland on Saturday, Nov. 11. OTB, which will have a separate parimutuel pool for the International, will begin accepting bets Nov. 10 at all branch offices.

title: DR. MURRAY SKINKER, RESEARCH DIRECTOR
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Nov. 1Dr. Murray F. Skinker, associate director of research for 18 years for the Brooklyn Edison Company and Consolidated Edison Company of New York, died Oct. 10. He was 74 years old.

title: Sensitive Pianism Of Perahia Shown In Meaty Program
description: Murray Perahia is a very special pianistic talent and he has been getting a very special showcase at Hunter College Playhouse. Last week he performed two concertos with an orchestra conducted by Alexander Schneider, this Friday he joins the Guarneri Quartet for chamber music and Tuesday he appeared on his own in a solo recital.

title: J. S. GRAY
description: MONROE, Mich., Nov. 1 (AP)J. S. Gray, president and editor of The Monroe Evening News since 1927, died this morning in his home at the age of 82.

title: 23 BEGIN PROGRAM TO LEARN DRAFTING
description: Twentytwo young men and a young woman began trainingprogram yesterday aimed at bridging the gap between their disadvantaged backgrounds and qualification as junior draftsmen.

title: PEKING LINKS U.S. WITH THIEU STAND
description: PEKING, Nov. 1Premier Chou Enlai said today that the United States must bear some ,of the responsibility for the passing of yesterday's deadline for the signing of a Vietnam peace agreement.

title: Barker, a Watergate Defendant, Convicted of False Notarization
description: MIAMI, Nov. 1Bernard L. Barker one of the seven men indicted in the breakin at the Democratic headquarters in the Watergate complex in Washington was found guilty here today of falsely notarizing signature on a $25,000 check that had gone through the Finance Committee to Reelect the President.

title: Arthur Daley
description: Gaylord Perry, a refugee from the National League and a 24game winner for the Cleveland Indians, has just been named the winner of the Cy Young Award as the outstanding pitcher in the American League. Never before has pitcher switched from one league to another and grabbed the brass ring on his first spin on the new and unfamiliar merrygoround. The batters in both leagues insist, however, that Perry gains high goals in slightly unorthodox fashion, a charge that lie piously denies. There's only one synthetic field in the American League, he explained, and natural grass helps me because I keep my pitches low by throwing sinkers.

title: Ezra Pound Dies in Venice at Age of 87
description: VENICE, Italy, Nov. 1Ezra Pound, one of the 20th century's most influential poets, died today in selfimposed exile from the United States, which had once accused him of treason. He was 87 years old.

title: NIXON SAYS MONEY HE GAVE TO CITIES SET RECORD IN AID
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 President Nixon said today that, while his predecessdrs had fruitlessly spent billions of dollars on the problems of the cities, he had spent even more but had made it count.

title: Bridge:Hybrid Blackwood I Used By Young New York Experts
description: Countless efforts have been made to improve the Blackwood convention, which has been in standard use for almost four decades, but only two of them have achieved wide popularity. One is KeyCard Blackwood, in which the king of the potential trump suit counts as a fifth ace. The other is Roman Blackwood, in which a fiveclub response shows no or three aces, five diamonds shows one or four, and other responses show two aces in a somewhat complex fashion.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Team Captures First Three Places at Garden
Christmas Stockings Being Filled Already
description: For people who never get their tulip bulbs planted by Election Day and have not yet put away the summer camping gear and slipcovers, it is a low blow to be told the news.

title: Alleged Mafia Chieftain On Trial for Perjury Here
description: James Napoli, reputed to be one of the five leading Mafia chieftains in the metropolitan area, went on trial in State Supreme Court here yesterday on charges of perjury and contempt in connection with a 1969 Manhattan grand jury investigation into fixed boxing matches.

title: Dear Oscar Rescheduled
description: Dear Oscar, a musical based on the life of Oscar Wilde, has postponed its opening at the Playhouse from Nov. 13 to Nov. 16. The show's book and lyrics are by Caryl Gabrielle Young, its music is by Addy 0. Fieger, and Mary W. John is the producer.

title: Exhibition Reveals Diversity of Shells
description: Even Sally, who sold them by the seashore, probably failed to realize the infinite variety of structure, form and design to be found among sea shells.

title: Burden Plays Host to a FundRaising Bash for Bella
description: Although Carter Burden didn't really like the name of the party, he was the host last night of what was billed as a Carter Burden Bash for Bella in his palatial, duplex apartment overlooking the East River.

title: Instrument Containing Radium Has Disappeared
description: SEATTLE, Nov. 1 (UPI)A 7inch instrument containing enough radium to be dangerous has disappeared from a hotel lobby and is the object of a citywide search.

title: 2 Survive CarTrain Crash
description: DARIEN, Conn., Nov. 1 (UPI)A man and woman es4 taped serious injury when their small foreign car slammed into a Penn Central train here last night, the police said. Pieternella Bakker, 28 years old, of Norwalk, Conn., and James Harris, 29, of Scarsdale, N. Y., were treated briefly at a Stamford hospital. Their Volkswagen was demolished and burned.

title: BELGIAN VIOLINIST, WERTHEN, PERFORMS
description: Jeunesses Musicales is a 33nation organization that tries to stimulate an interest in music among the young. One way it does so is to arrange exchange tours by youthful artists from different countries. Carnegie Hall presents several of them each season, and on Tuesday night the first of the current group appeared in Carnegie Recital Hall. He was Rudolf Werthen, a 26yearold Belgian violinist.

title: The Judicial Candidates
description: Once again New York voters are called upon to perform the impossiblesit in judgment on the legal ability, fairness and philosophy of a long list of judicial candidates. Some reform leaders, commendably, screen candidates before party designation. But the need remains for a broadbased citizens panel, including independent members of the community as well as of the bar, to appraise and recommend potential judges, who should then be appointed by Governor or Mayor.

title: FASHION TALK
description: The cheerful news today from Seventh Avenue for any woman who's old enough to have voted for President before this year is that the youth craze has receded. Not disappeared. Receded. Which means there are plenty of clothes for the postpuberty set. Old favorites, such as the dresscumjacket, that grew so dowdy they were wiped off fashion's slate look snappy now with, say, a pleated skirt and longer jacket. Coat and dresscombines look new without their stiff interlinings and of course the nowaistline caftans are fine for women who voted for

title: Ralston Purina
description: The Ralston Purina Company had higher operating net income in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30 of $62.7million or $1.87 a share, compared with $55.7million, or $1.72 a share, in the prior year. Sales were a record $1.8billion, up 5 per cent from last year's $1.7billion.

title: Parc Vendome Fights 50Story Building
description: The City Planning Commission heard a proposal for a 50story, 1,000unit luxury apartment building on West 57th Street denounced yesterday by residents of Parc Vendome, housing complex on the same block that would be affected by the development.

title: President Appoints Two To Commerce Commission
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) The White House said today President Nixon has made recess appointments for two new members of the Interstate Commerce Commission who were not confirmed by the Senate before Congress adjourned.

title: CHINESE ARE BUYING MORE U.S. WHEAT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1The Department of Agriculture announced today the sale of more wheat to China.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Protesters scheduled to hold a demonstration at the offices of the New York State council on the Arts at 250 West 57th Street canceled it yesterday when they learned their museum in Queens had been granted additional funds. Tom Lloyd, director of the Storefront Museum at 16202 Liberty Avenue, in South Jamaica, said that the demonstration was called off after he learned that the council had allocated $20,000 for this year.

title: Government to Drop Last of its Charges Against Miss Bacon
description: The Federal Government yesterday said it would drop the last of its charges against Leslie Ann Bacon, who had been awaiting trial under an indictment charging her with conspiring to fire bomb a branch of the First National City Bank here two years ago.

title: Double Bill of Ersatz Chillers
description: Three hours of mutants and witches should be just what the horror crowd would order. But "Superbeast" and "Daughters of Satan," the double order of ersatz chillers served up at local theaters yesterday, generate more yawns than goose bumps. The Philippines, where both were filmed in vivid colors, is scenic and arresting, and provide a good deal more interest than the films' jerry-built plots."Superbeast," a fiction that borrows from "The Most Dangerous Game" and "Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde," has a pathologist, Antoinette Bower, deep in the rain forest after those mutants who have been killing innocent citizens. Well, she discovers an expatriate American researcher, Craig Littler, who has come up with an elixir, not yet perfected, to rehabilitate criminals. But he's being subsidized and practically held captive by Harry Lauter, a rich, American hunting nut, who doesn't want them cured but would rather stalk and kill them.Forget about those eminent screams in the night and those mutants, who, like the scientist, get to look like Mr. Hyde. Mr. Littler, an improbable scientist, is as handsome as any Esquire model. Miss Bower, who occasionally appears to be somewhat vague about the dire goingson, is fetching in tight slacks. And the Philippines never looked lovelier.There's an improbability about "Daughters of Satan" too. Our hero, Tom Selleck, is also an intellectual, a buyer for museums, who latches on to a 16th-century painting of witches burning because one of them is a dead ringer for his pretty bride, Barra Grant. Why this should lead a coven of local, modern witches, including Tani Phelp Guthrie and Paraluman, to entice Miss Grant into satanic shivarees, eventually becomes obviousso we can have some metaphysical mumbo jumbo, a few, obligatory seminude scenes and explicitly sexy talk.Miss Grant and Miss Guthrie are photogenic, if little else, and Mr. Selleck, a handsome, virile, mustachioed type, is natural in his confusion about the bewitchery. Miss Bower, of "Superbeast," puts both of these manufactured supernatural exercises in focus when she exclaims in mild shock, "this is unbelievable."

title: Russians, Using a Single Carrier Rocket, Launch Eight Cosmos Satellites Into Orbit Around the Earth
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 1Indications mounted today that the Soviet Union might be deploying a worldwide system of data relay satellites linking its wideflung naval forces with Moscow.

title: SUGAR PRICES UP IN BRISK TRADING
description: World sugar futures captured some heavy trading interest yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Prices rose quite sharply in the brisk trading of 3,899 contracts.

title: Market Rises 13.02
description: The stock market scored one of its best gains of 1972 yesterday, buoyed mainly by hopes for a ceasefire agreement in Indochina. The bowJones industrials rose 13.02 to 968.54, closing five points below the 1972 high, as volume expanded to 21.36 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange. Page 63.

title: Speculation on Howser
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., Nov. 1 (AP)The Texas Rangers will hold a press conference tomorrow morning, with speculation afoot that the new manager of the American League team will be the New York Yankees third base coach, Dick Howser.

title: Private Denies Role in Slaying 0f 2 Army Officers in Vietnam
description: FORT ORD, Calif., Nov. 1In nearly four hours of testimony, Pvt. Billy Dean Smith repeatedly denied today any involvement in the murders of two Army officers in Vietnam.

title: Wood, Field and Stream Halieus Takes the Rod From Physicus and Lo! He Soon Lands a Fish
description: Having recently acquired a fourthedition copy of Sir Humphry Davy's Salmonia, published in 1851, this writer was reminded anew that the relationship between trout and the fly fisherman has remained. basically unaltered for more than a century.

title: LTV Unit Stock Tendered
description: The LTV Corporation yesterday said about 1.3 million common stock purchase warrants of its Wilson & Co. subsidiary had been tendered in connection with its offer to exchange them for LTV commonstock purchase warrants. The company added that the offer, made on Oct, 2, is being extended to Nov. 15.

title: Knicks Overwhelm Kings Five, 12285, For Seventh in Row
description: OMAHA, Nov. 1 (AP)The New York Knicks hit their first seven shots for a 142 read and went on to rout the Kansas CityOmaha Kings, 12285, in the National Basketball Association tonight.

title: STERLING CABLE TV IN 200EVENT DEAL
description: More than 200 events at the Madison Square Garden Center and affiliated facilities will be made available for exhibition over pay cable television under terms of an agreement signed recently by Madison Square Garden Center, Inc., and Sterling Communications, Inc.

title: Monzon Conviction Upheld
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 1 (UPI) An Argentine appeals court upheld today a lower court's conviction of the world middleweight champion, Carlos Monzon, for slugging a photographer five years ago. Monzon has requested a stay of sentence until after his Nov. 11 title defense here against American Benny Briscoe.

title: Books of The Times
description: I was once fond of listening to a radio program that, I believe, was called Negro Church of the Air. It consisted of spirited sermon and gospel singing. During the sermon, there was a man other than the preacher who seconded his statements by crying out, after a particularly telling one, something like That's right! or I know it's the truth! I always wanted to be that other man. Lest anybody misunderstand me and suppose that I was indulging a taste for the picturesque, I want to make it plain that I envied, and thrilled to, his convictionhis sense of having heard and grasped the truth.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 3  No Title
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.There is a moral and religious dimension of the current Presidential election campaign that cannot be overlooked or silenced by default. It is just the fact that as autumn leaves turn and the summer's last flowers await the sure coming of frost, there is treason in the air.

title: GEN.MINH OPPOSES DRAFT AGREEMENT
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 1Duong Van Minh, the retired general who is the principal rallying point of the opposition to President Nguyen Van Thieu, declared today that he disagreed with the ceasefire plan drafted by the United States and North Vietnam.

title: Inmates Donate to Charity
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Nov. 1 (AP) The Muscular Dystrophy Association said it had received a check for $362 today from a group of about 210 inmates at the Attica Correctional Facility. The check was presented in a cell at the facility, a spokesman said.

title: Guggenheim Museum Stage Lists ThomsonStein Opera
description: The Mother of Us All, an opera with music by Virgil Thomson and libretto by Gertrude Stein, will open at the Guggenheim Theater on Nov. 26 for an indefinite run.

title: H. PRESTON PETERS OF TV AD CONCERN
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 1 H. Preston Peters, chairman of the executive committee of Peters, Griffin, Woodward, Inc., television station advertising representativei of New York died.in Greenwich Hospital last evening after a long illness. He was 63 years old and lived at 4 Perkins Road.

title: Soviet Buys U.S. Computer
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 1 (AP)A Finnish company, Paragon, Itd., has sold an American Burroughs B4700 computer to the Soviet Union, it was announced today. The deal consisted of a $2.3million data center, with special equipment, sold to the Soviet Oil Ministry. The Finnish company represents the American Burroughs Corporation.

title: CHANGE IN ATTITUDE ON PROFITS IS URGED
description: Commerce Secretary Peter G. Peterson told businessmen here yesterday that unless they attempted to correct what he called the incredible misconceptions of consumers about corporate profits, they could expect to see a dramatic rise in costs, a decline in competitiveness and a loss of jobs.

title: 2 Ask the City to Halt SubwayCar Purchases
description: Two City Councilmen urged the city yesterday to halt purchases of new subway cars in view of Monday's commutertrain collision in Chicago in which 44 were killed and at least 320 hurt.

title: Harvard's Resident Sage Marks 85th Birthday Today
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 1  Life makes the man and man makes the life, and occasionally  as with Prof. Harry A. Wolfson  both life and man are a marvel to behold.

title: BOARD ACCEPTS IRVING'S QUITTING
description: The board of directors of the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center yesterday accepted with deep regret the resignation of Jules Irving as artistic director, effective at the end of the 197273 season. No successor was named.

title: Barker, a Watergate Defendant, Convicted of False Notarization
description: MIAMI, Nov. 1Bernard L. Barker, one of the seven men indicted in the breakin at the Democratic headquarters in the Watergate complex in Washington, was found guilty here today of falsely notarizing a signature on a $25,000 check that had gone through the Finance Committee to Reelect the President.

title: ADM. M'CAIN RETIRES AFTER 41YEAR TOUR
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI)  Adm. John S. McCain Jr., former Commander in Chief of United States forces in the Pacific, quietly retired from the Navy today after 41 years of active duty.

title: CeaseFire Hopes Push Stock Prices Up by 13.02
description: Stock prices rose sharply yesterday, propelled mainly by the latest peace rally on Wall Street.

title: Science Hall in Flushing Will Reopen This Month
description: The Hall of Science, visited during the 196465 World's Fair by some five million of the curious, is being revived, replete with its model accelerators, lifesized earth satellites and whirring, flashing scientific devices.

title: Free Ride for Hijackers
description: No one can say for sure that Stanley E. Hubbard, the Eastern Airlines gate attendant who was killed by hijackers at Houston International Airport Sunday, would be alive today if the House had enacted a Senateapproved bill that would create a new Federal airport security force and prescribe other actions to detect and deter aerial pirates.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: ABERAVON, Wales, Nov. (Agence FrancePresse)Clark Graebner of New York narrowly scored his first victory in the Dewar Cup series by beating Jan Zabrodsky of Sweden, 67, 61, 76, in the second round tonight.

title: Sarah Caldwell Will Stage Young Lord at City Opera
description: Sarah Caldwell will be stage director for the New York City Opera production of Henze's The young Lord, planned for the spring season at the New York State Theater. This will be Miss Caldwell's debut as an opera stage director tin New York.

title: Operators Unable to Pay $1 Million Speedway Rent
description: ONTARIO, Calif., Nov. 1 (AP)Operators of the new multimilliondollar Ontario Motor Speedway, east of Los Angeles, have served, notice they cannot pay the $1million rent due on Dec. 15.

title: DR. FRED W. GRAEF
description: Dr. Fred W. Graef, surgeondirector of the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital from 1939 to 1959, died Tuesday in Doctors Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 151 East 80th Street.

title: Equity Financing
description: The Bates Manufacturing Company said yes. terday it had submitted a written offer to The Martin Foundation, Inc., a membership charitable corporation, to repurchase the 827,990 shares of Bates common, at $10.25 a share, and 31,000 shares of Bates convertible preferred owned by the foundation. The foundation is subject at present to an order by the Supreme Court of New York providing for the distribution of the Bates stock as part of plan of liquidation and dissolution of the foundation. Bates common closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at 10, up .

title: Operation Tiger Seeks Million to Save Species
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1Unless protective action is taken quickly the tawny Bengal tiger will be extinct outside of zoos within 10 years, the World Wildlife Fund said today.

title: Amstar Cuts Price Of Refined Sugar In Several Areas
description: The Amstar Corporation announced yesterday that it had reduced its prices for industrial grades of refined sugar by 10 cents a hundredweight, effective immediately.

title: M'GOVERN DRAWS A CHEERING 20,000 IN GARMENT AREA
description: Senator George McGovern told thousands of people in the garment center yesterday that the Nixon Administration had made undercover deals with big business but had done nothing for more than five million unemployed Americans.

title: Wrestlers Assail U.S. Olympic Unit, Withdraw Backing
description: STILLWATER, Okla., Nov. 1 (AP)The United States Wrestling Federation withdrew its support from the United States Olympic Committee today aid urged Congress to speed an investigation of Olympic Committee policies and practices.

title: GATT Chairman Optimistic
description: GENEVA, Nov. 1In a mood described as tempered optimism, the world's major trading nations began an examination here today of the prospects for a new assault on barriers to international trade.

title: BLACK EXPO OPENS AT THE AMERICANA
description: Black Expo. 72, the Second International Black Cultural and Business Exposition sponsored by the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, opened for a fourday run yesterday at the Americana Hotel.

title: Frisella Also in Deal2dBase Spot Filled
description: The New York Mets, plagued by harumscarum abilities at second base, sought to solve the problem yesterday by acquiring Felix Bernardo Martinez Milian from the Atlanta Braves.

title: Dance: Ailey'sSeaChange in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 Is it the forthcoming Presidential election, is it boredom, or plain simple lassitude? Is Washington already bored with its Kennedy Center? Is Washington, after years of drought, now having too much ballet and dance? The questions are posed by the American Ballet Theater's current season at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Per forming Arts.

title: Trudeau Sees Top Aides; Delays Decision on Plans
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 1. Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau discussed his Government's future today at a long afternoon meeting with his Cabinet ministers and senior Liberal party officials.

title: 3 Hell's Angels Charged in California Slayings
description: UKIAH, Calif., Nov. 1 (UPI) Three members of the Hell's Angels, a motorcycle club, were arrested today on charges of murdering two men and a woman whose bodies were found on a remote northern California ranch.

title: Assembly's Eighth Week, U.N. Business as Usual
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 1This session of the General Assembly entered its eighth week today, and it proved to be a day that was largely typical.

title: Mackerras Leads Met's Orfeo
description: Gluck's Orfeo ed Euridice returned to the stage of the Metropolitan Opera on Tuesday night, and there was nothing anybody in the new Met administration could do about its reappearance. Rudolf Bing had scheduled it some time ago, even though it was one of the unhappiest productions of his last season.

title: BURGLARY VICTIM SLAIN BY MISTAKE
description: A 20yearold Bronx father was killed and a policeman critically wounded yesterday in a tenementhouse shootout in which each mistook the other for a robber.

title: Improved Racial. Balance Is Sought
description: Citing the present crisis situation in Canarsie, the city Board of Education directed the president of the area's local school board last night to report no later than tomorrow on steps being taken to rezone and improve racial balance at three controversial schools.

title: Libyans Indicate 2 Hijackers Won't Be Tried or Extradited
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Nov. 1Libyan officials are making it clear that they will reject any request for prosecution or extradition of two Palestinians who hijacked a Lufthansa jetliner Sunday and forced the release of three terrorists who participated in the attack on the Israeli Olympic team in Munich in September.

title: INTEREST FOR CITY DECLINES TO 3.36%
description: The city's standing in the money market showed substantial improvement yesterday.

title: Personalities: A's Finley Pays for His Generosity
description: Charles O. Finley, the tempestuous owner of the worldchampion Oakland A's, was fined $2,500 yesterday by Commissioner Bowie Kuhn for having attempted to reward some of his players during the recent World Series with Cincinnati. Kuhn said Finley had violated baseball law when he announced $5,000 salary increases to Gene Tenace, the catcher, and Joe Rudi, the left fielder, after the second game. Rule 46A stipulates that contending clubs are forbidden to award a bonus or prize to any player until the end of the Series, Kuhn said. He added that the rule was not intended to affect the cornmitments made by Finley to the players.

title: Rites for William Plunkert Attended by Health Officials
description: More than 150 persons, including city and state health officials, civic, business and labor leaders and other friends attended a funeral service yesterday for William J. Plunkert, founder and executive director of the Alcoholism Recovery Institute, the New York. City affiliate of the National Council on Alcoholism.

title: M'GOVERN DRAWS A CHEERING 20,000 IN GARMENT AREA
description: Senator George McGovern told thousands of people in the garment center yesterday that the Nixon Administration had made undercover deals with big business but had done nothing for more than five million unemployed Americans.

title: Newark Museum to Show Ways of Using Watershed
Blues Tie Stars, 33
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 1 (AP)Danny O'Shea's rebound goal with 80 seconds left to play tonight gave the St. Louis Blues a 33 tie with the Minnesota North Stars.

title: Cambodian Is Optimistic After Briefing by Rogers
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1Foreign Minister Long. Boret of Cambodia said today that he was optimistic about the future of his country after receiving a detailed briefing from Secretary of State William P. Rogers on the current diplomatic efforts to settle the Indochina conflict.

title: Business Incorporations Dip
description: New business incorporations dipped 1.1 per cent to 26,612 in August, but the month still showed the third highest gains on record, Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. The declines appeared mainly in Massachusetts, Vermont and Texas. Through August 1972, there were 215,054 businesses newly incorporated, 12 per cent more than in the similar period last year. All but two states, and the District of Columbia, gained over the 1971 figures.

title: HOLDER QUESTIONS COMPANY DIVIDEND
description: The General Fireproofing Company, Youngstown, Ohio, Which on Monday announced that it had declared a dividend of 5 cents a share, earned only 4 cents a share during the third quarter, it was pointed out yesterday by Thomas G. Wyman. Share earnings for the nine months were 6 cents.

title: Soviet Said to Agree to Restore SAM6's in Egypt
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 1The Soviet Union has agreed to bolster Egypt's airdefense system by restoring SAM6 mobile missiles that had been removed when Soviet advisers were ousted by Cairo in July, according to reports published here today.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1A strange thing, this. And yet it sounds so dully mechanical, so unstrange, that one hesitates to come right out with it for fear of driving away readers. If it were about sex or mugging or the President, we could go right to the point in smashing declaratives. Sex pledged today that immediately after its reelection it would initiate a 14point program of....

title: FURNITURE ABOUNDS FOR ANTIQUES SHOW
description: City and country furniture and decorations meet today in the 29th annual antiques show at Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street, for a run through Sunday.

title: MRS. JOHN R. BABSON
description: GREENWICH, Conn. Nov. 1Mrs. Jane H. Babson, vice president of the CocaCoca Company in Havre de Grace, Md., and the wife of John R. Babson, vice president of the IngersollRand Company, died yesterday at Greenwich Hospital after long illness. Her age was 50, and she lived at Fox Lair on Rocky Craig Rd.

title: Market Place: Margin Growth Called a Threat
description: Now that the market seems to be getting its footing and moving ahead on the threat of peace, as they say in Wall Street, brokers are beginning to see hopes of a broad new advancea continuation of yesterday's sharp gains.

title: BILL DURNAN, 57, HOCKEY GOALIE
description: TORONTO, Nov. 1(AP)Bill Durham, whom many hockey fans acclaimed as the greatest goalie of modern times. died last night after a long illness. He was 57 clears old:

title: Business Briefs
description: The New York Stock Exchange indicated yesterday that it was looking into the reimbursement of customers by Shearson, Hammill & Co. for possible losses in connection with their purchases of limited partnerships in the GeoTek Resources Fund, Inc.

title: BRAZIL REPORTS DRUG RING BROKEN
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 1The Brazilian police said today that they had dismantled the top rank of the Mafia in this country with the arrest of the leaders of an international narcotics ring.

title: McGovern Wins Test
description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Nov. 1 (AP)  Senator George McGovern received 806 votes to President Nixon's 484 in mock election at the Missouri Penitentiary last night. Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama received 144 writein votes.

title: Panel Says 550 AddictBabies Were Born Here in 71
description: A special legislative committee reported yesterday that at least 550 children were born addicted to drugs in New York City last year, suffering from withdrawal symptoms because their mothers had been using heroin or methadone.

title: Stepfather Held in Death
description: AMITYVILLE, N. Y., Nov. 1(AP)Homicide detectives arrested Thomas Gray, 23 years old, at his home here last night on a charge of manslaughter in the death of his 3yearold stepson. The polic said the boy died yesterday at a hospital following a beating.

title: DNB MARION WINS NEW GRASS STAKE
description: A new race was run at Aque duct yesterday, and Johnny Rigione had the honor of being the first trainer to win it. The event was the Rare Treat, which enjoyed the distinction of being the first race on grass for 2yearolds ever run in this state.

title: 2 Philadelphia Police Shot
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 (UPI)  Two police officers were listed in good condition today at Philadelphia General Hospital after a shootout last night in which a narcotics suspect was killed. The two detectives, Richard Smith, 27 years old, and Keith Quick, 21, were wounded as they attempted to serve a warrant at a home in Southwest Philadel

title: G.O.P. Agrees to Disclose Two New Lists of Donors
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 President Nixon's main election finance committees agreed under court and political pressure today to disclose before Election Day the names of some hidden donors.

title: Amex and OTC Prices Score Best Increases in Over a Week
description: The American Stock Exchange and overthecounter market turned in their best performances in more than a week yesterday as both lists advanced in more active trading.

title: Segretti Moves Cited
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1 Donald H. Segretti asked about ioining a local Democratic club here shortly before the California primary last spring and at about the same time apparently vonumteered to work in the campaign of Senator George McGovern.

title: Learson Remark Cited
description: Chief Judge David N. Edelstein yesterday gently took to task the International Business Machines Corporation and its chairman and chief executive officer, T. Vincent Learson, for discussing the Justice Department's antitrust suit against the computer company with the press contrary to a special court order.

title: Film:
description: Prosperous, plump, middleaged, a hit rheumatic, but with a lovely young wife and two adoring kids, Giuseppe Di Noi, successful construction engineer, packs his family in the car and drives off from his Swedish home for a brief vacation in Italy, which he has not visited since he left it six years ago. He gets as far as the border. He is stopped at Customs, taken from his family, rushed away by the Italian police, charged with the crime of involuntary homicideas he learns much laterin the death of one Franz Kaltenhruner, a German whom he is certain he does

title: By Albert H. Cantril and Charles W. Roll Jr.
description: Senator McGovern seems to be running at least as hard against George Gallup and Louis Harris as he is against Richard Nixon. Once again, the polls have become an issue, diverting attention from their value as an instrument for assessing the basic concerns underlying the mood of the electorate.

title: Judge May Bar Dredging Of Harbor at New Haven
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. Nov. 1 (AP)A Federal judge has ordered the Army Corps of Engineers to delay its dredging of New Haven Harbor until it files an environmental impact statement.

title: Ireland Adopts Value Tax
description: DUBLIN, Nov. 1  Ireland took a step into the economic structure of Europe today by adopting the European Economic Community's system of consumer taxationthe valueadded tax.

title: MRS. RICHARD WEIL JR.
description: Mrs. Allene Hall Weil, widow of Richard Weil Jr., a former president of Macy's New York, died yesterday. She was 63 years old and lived at 28 East 70th Street.

title: Ezra Pound: A Man of Contradictions
description: Like many poets, Ezra Pound wrote his own epitaph. It was a poem called E. P. Ode pour l'Election de son Sepulchre (Ode on Choosing His Tomb), written just after World War I:

title: OZARK IS NAMED MILS MANAGER
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7 (AP)  Danny Ozark, an experienced minor league manager and thirdbase coach of the Los Angeles Dodgers the last four years, was named manager of the Philadelphia Phillies today.

title: Jauron Runs Long Except in Interviews
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 1Yales Dick Jauron is the Duane Thomas of the Ivy League in that he has a tremendous talent as a running back and says next to nothing to the media people. Beyond that the parallels stop.

title: Red Sox Drop Three
description: BOSTON, Nov. 1 (AP)The Boston Red Sox released today two pitchers, Gary Peters and Ray Culp, and a first baseman, Bob Burda.

title: BURGLARY VICTIM SLAIN BY MISTAKE
description: A 20yearold Bronx father was killed and a policeman critically wounded yesterday in a tenementhouse shootout in which each mistook the other for a robber.

title: Chou Tells of Objections
description: PEKING, Nov. 1 (AP)Premier Chou Enlai told a group of British newsmen today that President Thieu had objected to seven of nine points in an agreement drafted by Americans and North Vietnamese. Mr. Chou quoted the South Vietnamese President as saying that if he did not put his own signature to that agreement, There will be no peace.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Arrests for drunken driving have more than doubled on the New Jersey Turnpike this year, according to former Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, the chairman of the Turnpike Authority.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: HACKENSACK N. J.It wasn't a fiery Knute Rockne pep talk. Coach Mike Miello just gave his Hackensack High School football team a simple message beforee it took the field last Saturday to meet previously undefeated Ridgewood High School.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Pound's Battle Cry: Make It New
description: Ezra Pound touched on 20thcentury poetry in so many different ways that he made up a oneman academy. He was teacher and object lesson in one. Creator, critic, goad, catalyst, guide to the young, he was, to use one of his own phrases, the gunsight along which others aimed. His aid to writers as diverse as Yeats, Frost, Joyce, Williams and Wyndham Lewis is well known. He believed in

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Briefs
description: The helpwanted advertising index fell sharply September from the August level but was still substantially above that of September, 1971, The Conference Board said yesterday.

title: 20 FOOD CONCERNS FAIL 2D INSPECTIONS
description: The Health Services Administration cited 20 more food processing establishments yesterday for failing, after a second inspection, to correct violations of the city's health code.

title: Brewster Defense Says Alleged Bribe Money Was for Political Contributions
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 Defense lawyers in the bribery trial of former Senator Daniell B. Brewster tried today to show] that the alleged bribe money served as political contribu tions and that much of it went to one of Mr. Brewster's aides.

title: Pistons Down Sonics
description: SEATTLE, Nov. 1 (AP)Dave Bing and Bob Lanier shut the door on a late Seattle rally tonight as they lead the Detroit Pistons to a 116106 National Basketball Association victory over the SuperSonics.

title: Disaster Aid Sought
description: BOSTON, Nov. 1 (AP)Representative Michael J. Harrington and Senator Edward M. Kennedy, both Massachusetts Democrtas, said today that they had asked the Federal Government to declare Plum Island a disaster area because of continuing storm damage.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Nov. 1 (AP)Heavily favored Cougar II staged his patented stretch run today and won the $100,000 Oak Tree Invitational for the second straight year and probably earned a berth in the Washington, D. C. International Handicap at Laurel Nov. 11.

title: Republican Campaign Trip Ends in Disarray
S.E.C. HEARINGS SET ON PROFIT FORECAST
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it would hold public hearings later this month on the issue of prohibiting or permittingor possibly even requiringcompanies to make formal forecasts concerning revenues and earnings.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Canadiens 71 Victors
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 1 (UPI) The Montreal Canadiens tallied three times in the first period tonight and coasted to a 71 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising:
description: Advertising clutter, which rivls the wether s n reof much tlk nd little ction, ws discussed t considerble length yesterdy tn ssocition of Ntionl dvertisers workshop entitled, The Chnging Fce of Medi.

title: Police Campaign on Curb Space Is Continued in Garment Center
description: More summonses were issued and a truck was towed away yesterday as the police continued their parking harassment campaign against six trucking and apparel companies that, they say, have links with Mafia members.

title: Loomis Backs U.S. Aid for Public TV
description: LAS VEGAS, Nov. 1  The new president of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting today endorsed spending Federal money to support public television.

title: TRAFALGAR SEEKS BOWATER CONTROL
description: Trafalgar House Investments, Ltd., a major British real estate and hotel operator, said yesterday it had offered to acquire the outstanding common stock that it did not already own of the Bowater Corporation, a worldwide paper, pulp and board producer, for stock valued at about $327million. Trafalgar already owns 1,395,000 Bowater common shares and now seeks the remaining 56,822,028 shares.

title: Common Market Assists Fruit, Vegetable Growers
description: LUXEMBOURG, Nov. 1The European Common Market today increased the protection of its fruit and vegetable growers without damaging. American suppliers. The decision was taken not so much to benefit the United States as to help, Britain.

title: Improved Racial Balance Is Sought
description: Citing the present crisis situation in Canarsie, the city Board of Education directed the president of the area's local school board last night to report no later than tomorrow on steps being taken to rezone and improve racial balance at three controversial schools.

title: A Tense Calm Holds Among Youths
description: No matter how brave we talk, we're all scared, said Dominick, a white youth who formerly attended Canarsie High School. He made the ad, mission as black youths faced white youths yesterday across police lines in the second day of nearclashes between the two groups.

title: Amex Is Weighing Layoffs Because of Slow Volume
description: The American Stock Exchange said yesterday that it was considering a layoff of 30 people, or about 5 per cent of its personnel, because of the slow trading volume that has prevailed in the stock market for the last six months.

title: FEW AT N.Y.U. CAN RECALL SLAIN MEN
description: Most of the New York Univerity students hurrying to class on the University Heights campus in the Bronx yesterday said they knew about Abraham Sutton and Anthony Pierre only after they had read in the morning papers that the two had been shot to death in their apartment at the edge of the campus.

title: Hanoi Willing to Talk Again
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Nov. 1 (Agence FrancePresse)Wellinformed sources said today that the North Vietnamese Government would not be opposed to a further meeting between its special negotiator, Le Duc Tho, and Henry A. Kissinger.

title: G.O.P Agrees to Disclose Two New Lists of Donors
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1President Nixon's main election finance committees agreed under court and political pressure today to disclose before Election Day the names of some hidden donors.

title: ISLANDERS BEAT GOLDEN SEALS, 62
description: OAKLAND, Nov. 1 (AP)Germain Gagnon scored three goals tonight to lead the New York Islanders to a 62 National Hockey League victory over the California Golden Seals.

title: QuarterHorse Rider Gets 5Year Suspension in Ohio
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 1 (AP)The Ohio State Racing Commission suspended a jockey for five years today for using a batterypowered electric whip in a quarterhorse race at Beulah Park this fall.

title: RULE ON RESERVES STANDS ON APPEAL
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 The Federal appeals court here let stand today a lower court ruling that it was unconstitutional for members of Congress to hold Reserve commissions in the armed forces. More than 50 of them now do hold such commissions.

title: Democrats Vote to Sell Center Here for Million
description: The membership of the National Democratic Club voted last night to sell its 19thcentury, sixstory granite headquarters at 233 Madison Avenue to the Government of Poland for $1million cash.

title: LEAFS WIN, HALT SABRES  STRING,71
description: TORONTO, Nov. 1 (UPI)Dave Keon and Errol Thompson, a rookie, scored two goals each tonight as the Toronto Maple Leafs trounced Buffalo, 71, to snap the Sabres 10game unbeaten streak.

title: City Hall Disputes Charge of Secrecy In Job Information
description: City Councilmen looking into alleged patronage abuses of the Lindsay administration sought to show yesterday that public information about city employes and salaries has been shrouded in secrecy in recent years.

title: Senate Contest
description: DETROIT, Nov. 1 At the Ark Lane in suburban Warren, where the automobile workers are bowling and taking a shot or a beer at 10 in the morning, Don Rehahm said he would vote for Robert P. Griffin, a Republican, rather than Frank J. Kelley, his Democratic opponent.

title: Brasilia, If Not the Poetic, Functional City Its Planners Dreamed of, Has Emerged as a Real Capital
description: BRASILIA, Oct. 20This supreme monument of modern urban design has become a real capital, with many of the usual pleasures, frustrations and flaws.

title: William J. Berg Dies at 64; Chemical Bank Trust Aide
description: William J. Berg, vice president in the personal trust department of the Chemical Bank, died at New York Hospital on Tuesday after a long illness. He was 64 years old and lived at 2762 Brian Street, Oceanside, L. I.

title: Boston Museum Gets Cezanne SelfPortrait
description: BOSTON, Nov. 1 (AP)The Museum of Fine Arts said yesterday that it had received a selfportrait by the French postimpressionist Paul Cezanne.

title: Bribery Indictment Names ExBrokers
description: Two former stockbrokers were indicted in Federal court here yesterday on charges of bribing the managers of an investment fund to buy stock at inflated prices that amounted to $700,000.

title: Advertising:
description: Scali, McCabe, Sloves, which last week got a piece of Revlon busIness, yesterday got a chunk of the Homelite Division of Textron. It will do the creative and marketing work for chain saws and lawn and garden equipment, while the SFM Media Service Corporation does the media planning and buying.

title: Household Finance Lifts Income in 3d Quarter and 9 Months
description: The Household Finance Corporation, the country's largest personalloan company, had sharply higher net income in the third quarter and the nine months. In the quarter. net rose to $23.9million from $21.2million while for nine months net increased to $72.7million from $64.1million.

title: URUGUAY PRESIDENT NAMES NEW CABINET
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 1 (Reuters)President Juan M. Bordaberry has named the third cabinet of his sevenmonthold administration in a reshuffle prompted by the resignations Sunday of three ministers angered at the military arrest of Senator Jorge Batlle Ibafiez.

title: RANGERS CONQUER BLACK HAWKS, 32
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 1  Gilles Villemure turned off an aroused Chicago hockey team for the entire first period and much of the third, and in between the New York Rangers produced a rapid threegoal flurry for a 32 victory over the Black Hawks tonight.

title: Sassoon Calls It Time To Stand Hair on End
description: Just when everybody's moaning that hairdos are natural that it'd hardly worth getting up in the morning to go to the beauty salon, Vidal Sassoon decides it's time to stand hair on end. Literally.

title: ChainStore Sales Up for September
description: A high level of apparel sales and increased demand for home furnishings brought a substantial increase in sales of chain stores in September, according to a survey by The New York Times. A leading group of chain organizations posted a sales gain of 11.9 per cent over September, 1971.

title: Crime Among Leading East Side Issues
Notes on People
description: There was Sonny Jurgensen, the injured quarterback for the Washington Redskins football team, resting after an operation in a hospital. The phone rang and, sure enough, it was the Country's No. 1 Redskin Fan  President Nixon. The President urged the quarterback to make a comeback next year, because you mean a great deal to the country and to the game of football.

title: 4 Horses Tie for Top Honors In Puissance Stake at Garden
description: The $2,000 Puissance (strength) Stake, a test of high jumping, proved just too much for the jumpers at the National Horse Show last night and ended in fourway tie for top honors before a crowd of 11,500 at Madison Square Garden.

title: POLITICAL GIFT TIED TO M'DONALD PRICES
description: Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, Democrat of Queens, charged yesterday that the Federal Price Commission had granted the McDonald hamburger chain a price increase in return for a $208,000 contribution to President Nixon's reelection campaign.

title: The Nixon Paradox
description: The two things that have preoccupied President Nixon most of his waking hours for the last two years have been winning the war in Vietnam and winning reelection to the Presidency. Both have been hard, ambiguous and agonizing problems, but the contrast between his handling of the war and his direction of the election campaign is startling.

title: Wilmington Paper Halted In Strike by Truck Drivers
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. (AP) The Morning News, struck by a union representing drivers who deliver newspapers, did not publish a Friday edition.

title: Strong U.S. Economy Seen
description: GENEVA, Nov. 2The United States is in a strong economic position both at home and internationally at a time that the world economy has entered period of more vigorous output and trade growth, United Nations experts said today.

title: Bust of Robert Kennedy Unveiled by His Widow
description: A smiling, bronze likeness of Robert F. Kennedy faced out on Brooklyn yesterday as his widow, Ethel, gently tugged a cloth covering from the city's first official memorial to the Senator.

title: Matinee Opening Set For O'Neill's Electra
description: Eugene O'Neill's trilogy, Mourning Becomes Electra, will open at the new Circle in the SquareJoseph E. Levine Theater in the Uris building at Broadway and 50th Street on Nov. 15 at 2 P.M.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: A few days ago in a corridor leading to my office desk I found a small, yellowing maple leaf, and was strangely moved.

title: 140 Strikes on North
description: SAIGON, Friday, Nov. 3 (UPI)The United States command reported yesterday that American jet fighterbombers flew more than 140 strikes over North Vietnam on Wednesday.

title: Ordination of Women as Priests Is Urged by Episcopal Bishops
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 2 (AP)  The Episcopal House of Bishops has adopted a resolution urging admissin of women into the priesthood.

title: October Sales Climbed at Retail Chains
description: Retail business surged ahead in October, providing several of the country's largest chains with their best monthly gains in several years.

title: Comment by Stone
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (AP)Mr. Stone said tonight that the actual figure for his contribution was, as a matter of fact, more than $1million.

title: 2 Fatally Stabbed At Jamaica Park; Killer Is Sought
description: Two men were found slashed to death last night in the commercial section of Jamaica, Queens.

title: SHARES OF DCL DIP ON CHARGEOFF NEWS
description: Shares of DCL, Inc., the parent holding company of Diebold Computer Leasing, Inc., declined yesterday following the company's announcement that it had expected to make a material chargeoff against its 1972 income. The stock closed at 3  on the American Stock Exchange, down  on the day.

title: Twelve Chairs Opens at the Regency
description: The Twelve Chairs, which opened yesterday at the Regency Theater, is the officially approved Soviet film version of the classic Ilf and Petrov comic novel about greed, avarice and practically universal bureaucratic corruption in postrevolutionary Russia. It's not a great film, but it's a historically fascinating and often tumultuously funny one that makes big, uninhibited lunges for laughs any way it can  with pratfalls, satire, parody and even animation. It's definitely not to be confused with Mel Brook's frantic and denaturalized 1970 film adaption, made in Yugoslavia with an international

title: NIXON'S AIDES GET DATA ON M'GOVERN
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 White House aides involved in President Nixon's campaign have received reports of the Secret Service, whose agents are assigned to protect Senator George McGovern, about confidential meetings of the Democratic Presidential nominee, according, to a source in the Secret Service.

title: MARKET RALLIES IN HEAVY TRADING
description: A late rally yesterday pushed the stock market, as measured by the DowJones industrials, to within an eyelash of its 1972 high as trading volume continued heavy. Drugs, motors and brokeragehouse issues scored. gains.

title: COALITION ON RACE TO BE SET UP HERE
description: A citywide coalition of ethnic and neighborhood groups will be set up before Christmas in an effort to reduce racial polarization and avert such confrontations as the Canarsie school dispute.

title: Songs at Club
description: For New York to get, simultaneously, a new, intimate supper club with warmth and charm and a program made up of a pair of skillful performers who are ideally suited to such a setting is the kind of rewarding conjunction that one almost despairs of finding. But it has happened on East 74th Street, at the corner of Lexington Avenue, where the Soerabaja, a small GreekFrench restaurant, has opened an upstairs room in which Bucky Pizzarelli strokes his guitar and Corky Hale plucks her harp, plays her piano and, when the portents are right, sings.

title: Lack of Funds Closes ArtRestoration Center
description: ROME, Nov. 2The Central Institute of Restoration, one of the world's leading centers for training and technicalscientific work in art restoration, has closed indefinitely because the Italian Parliament has not acted on its request for more funds.

title: 500 Indians Seize U. S. Building After Scuffle With Capital Police
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 About 500 American Indians protesting injustices, took control tonight of the Bureau of Indian Affairs building after scuffles with the police outside and inside the building.

title: TRUDEAU TO STAY AND PUT DECISION UP TO PARLIAMENT
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 2  Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau announced tonight that despite setbacks in Monday's election his Government would carry on and face the next Parliament as a minority.

title: Chamber Meets on Merger Plan
description: The 204yearold New York Chamber of Commerce convened in its Great Hall downtown yesterday to consider a proposed merger, with the munch younger Commerce and Industry Association of New York.

title: $661,000 Loss Reported By Cargill in Sale to Soviet
description: Cargill Incorporated, the third largest seller of wheat to the Soviet Union in a controversial $1billion grain deal last summer, yesterday said it had lost $661,000 on its $119mi1lion share of the sale.

title: Agnew Cancels Visit To Jersey Tomorrow
Kennedy Is Pushing Hard To Aid McGovern's Drive
Two Officials Link Train Crash In Chicago to Safety Violation
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 2A key safety rule of the Illinois Central Gulf Railroad was violated just before the crash Monday of two of its commuter trains that resulted in 44 deaths and injuries to more than 350 people, two officials said today.

title: Foes of OTB Challenge Revenue Figures
description: ALBANY, Nov. 2Offtrack betting netted only $5million, in government revenue from gross income of $53.8million during its first fiscal year, a harnessracing spokesman told the Delafield Commission here today.

title: Emporia to Honor Editor
description: EMPORIA, Kan., Nov. 2 (AP) Emporia's civic auditorium, will be named for W. L. White, editor and publisher of The Emporia Gazette, and a dedication program is scheduled for Sunday. The City Commission voted yesterday to name the auditorium for Mr. White, who has ben in ill health, is not expected to attend the ceremony.

title: The Urban Issue
description: The manysided problem of the nation's cities. inspires humility even among experts. One side of.the problem is to enable whites and blacks of diverse educational and economic levels to live in tolerable harmony. Another is the enormous increase in the cost of Municipal services, brought about mainly by the higher wages and pensions paid to civil service employes.

title: Music: A British Star
description: The difference between impressive vocalism and impressive singing, so often overlooked in times that put more emphasis on brawn than brain, was demonstrated fully at Philharmonic Hall Wednesday night. Janet Baker, Britain's most valuable feminine contribution to the lower voice categories since Kathleen Ferrier, took up Berlioz's song cycle, Nuits d'ete, with the complete sympathy and support of the Boston Symphony Orchestra under Colin Davis,

title: Rancor by 4 Sides Marks Talks in Paris
description: PARIS, Nov. 2The four delegations to the Paris talks on Vietnam engaged in recriminations today that reflected strains in both the American and Communist alliances as well as the continuing dispute over the ceasefire draft agreement between the United States and North Vietnam.

title: SAFESTREETSAID BY U.S. ASSAILED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP)  A study prepared for the National Urban Coalition says the Government's multibilliondollar program to fight crime in the streets has failed to improve understanding of the problem or promote better ways of dealing with it.

title: F.C.C. IS REDUCING GOVERNMENT ROLE IN BROADCASTING
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2The Federal Communications Commission today took the first in what is promised to be a long series of steps reducing the amount of Government regulation of the broadcasting industry.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 2 (AP)The Minnesota North Stars and the Minnesota Fighting Saints squared off last night, not on the ice rink but at the gate.

title: STATES MAY GET JOB SAFETY ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2The Labor Department disclosed today a new plan to permit a great majority of the states to operate their own occupational safety and health programs next year without a prior determination that they were at least as effective as the Federal law.

title: Market Place: McCulloch Sets Accounting Shift
description: The McCulloch Oil Corporation, a company that has managed to report increased earnings every quarter for the last 10 years, said on Wednesday after the close of trading that accounting changes would result in a thirdquarter profit that was lower this year than last.

title: McGovern Presses Effort In 3 Midwestern States
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 2Senator George McGovern, his voice hoarse and cracking, campaigned doggedly through three states today in an effort to close the apparent gap between himself and President Nixon in the final days of the Presidential race.

title: $75 Million, 2,000Room Hotel Is Being Planned for Times Sq.
description: Plans arc under way for a $75million, 2,000room luxury hotel to rise on Times Square in twin, linked towers of more than 50 stories, city officials confirmed last night.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Proposition One, the $1.15.billion Environmental Quality Bond Act before the voters Nov. 7, should be defeated. Saving our environment is commendable, but putting the taxpayer in a financial straitjacket for years to come is not.

title: Board Criticizes Scribner On Unsent Canarsie Note
description: A draft of a letter written by Dr. Harvey B. Scribner, the city's School Chancellor, has been criticized by members of the Board of Education, who said it would hurt efforts to resolve the Canarsie school controversy.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Political and Security Committee3 P.M.

title: Business Briefs
description: Directors of the Anaconda Company declared a dividend of 12 cents a share yesterday on the common stock. It will be payable Dec. 5 to holders of record Nov. 13. John B. M. Place, president and chief executive officer, attributed the action to improved earnings.

title: A MOTION IS PUT OFF IN THE SHERWIN CASE
Rats Kill Infant in Virginia
