title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Film: 'Black Girl' Arrives on Screen:Ossie Davis Directs Miss Franklin's Play A High School Dropout Seeks to Be Dancer
description: When J. E. Franklin's play, "Black Girl" opened off Broadway in 1971 it received very favorable reviews, and it ran for six months at the Theater de Lys. Not having seen the play, I don't know how much has been lost in the transition from stage to screen. But I suspect that a good deal has been lost, because Ossie Davis's film version, adapted by Miss Franklin herself, is not only a poor movie; it is a poor movie that makes it look as if there never had been a good play.Billie Jean, the black girl of the title, is a recent high school dropout and aspiring ballet dancer who lives at home in a Southern suburb with her mother, Mama Rosie, her two (older) half-sisters, her grandmother, and a mild-mannered man named Herbert  who loves the grandmother and helps with the rent. Mama Rosie has never been able to suppress a soft spot for other people's children. Her special favorite, Netta, a neighbor's daughter, is now in college getting an educationmuch to the disgust of the half-sisters, who despise Netta and education, in that order.Netta wants to save Billie Jean, to get her into college and into dance education. The half-sisters want to ruin Billie Jeanto get her into sex and perhaps early pregnancyfor no discernible reasons except jealousy and a well-practiced love of mischief for its own sake. There is much, much more going on in "Black Girl," notably the story of Mama Rosie and her estranged husband, Earl, but its central action is the conflict between Netta and the half-sisters over the future of Billie Jean. It is an action that combines elements of Cinderella with the sort of middle-class social-aspiration melodrama prominent in the 1930's. But in the 1930's, the hero might have been Jewish and male, and his aim might have been medical school.One of the problems with "Black Girl" is that going up seems so much less attractive than staying down. Netta, at least in Leslie Uggams's too genteel characterization, looks less like success than like loss of identity. The half-sisters accuse her of virginity, and they may be right. They, on the other hand, have no apparent mtier beyond wasting timewhich allows them to sharpen their wits and get off the best lines.Some of the acting is very good. Peggy Pettitt, a newcomer, as a quite complicated Billie Jean; Gloria Edwards as the more evil of the half-sisters; above all, Brock Peters as the rich, nimble, sweet-talking Earl. On the stage, Earl apparently disgraced the family by managing a whorehouse; in the movie, he runs a shoe store, and the reasons for his expulsion by Mama Rosie aren't so clear.But I suspect that the real difference between the successful play and the failed movie lies in Ossie Davis's direction, which ranges from pedestrian to downright helpless. Sloppy editing, awkward confrontations, dull and obvious camera techniqueall are the director's responsibility. From time to time you can almost feel the actors asking for stage management. They don't get itand that, in a work not without some interest, seems a pity."Black Girl" opened yesterday at the Penthouse Theater, the 59th Street and 85th Street Twin I cinemas.

title: 130 Refuse to Join Ship; Most Reassigned by Navy
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 9One hundred thirty men attached to the aircraft carrier Constellation refused for hours today to obey an order to board their ship in the latest incident of racial conflict involving warships of the Pacific Fleet.

title: Nixon Backs Guidelines On Newsmen's Sources
description: ALBANY, Nov. 9 (UPI) President Nixon says that, while he would not oppose proposed Federal legislation that would permit newsmen to protect the identity of their sources, he thinks the Attorney General's guidelines on the subject are preferable to Federal legislation at this time.

title: A MISTRIAL CALLED IN RATTENNI CASE
description: A Federal Court judge here declared a mistrial on some of the charges in the jurytampering case against Nicholas Rattenni, the alleged Mafia leader of Westchester County, and two codefendants.

title: Customs Executive Was a Guest Of Subject of Inquiry by Agency
description: Myles J. Ambrose, while U.S. Commissioner of Customs, was the house guest last winter of a millionaire Texas rancherbanker who was then under investigation by customs officials for smuggling.

title: TV Review
description: The television format of talking heads dominating the screen is frequently the object of knowing sneers. Interviews and conversations, the theory goes, offer pretty static fodder to a medium that thrives on action, live or filmed. The theory is, demonstrably, nonsense.

title: PRICES OF SUGAR DECLINE SHARPLY
description: World sugar prices moved down quite sharply in futures trading on the New. York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday, reversing the previous day'supward move. There was a combination of factors at work to induce some selling by speculators.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARIS  The emphasis of U.S. foreign policy must inevitably shift back to Europe early in President Nixon's second term. There are three compelling reasons for this.

title: Democratic Committee Bars C.B.S. Film Crew From Capital News Conference as Strike Goes
description: A film crew from the Columbia Broadcasting System was barred from a postelection news conference by the Democratic National Committee yesterday because of a strike by the network's cameramen, audio engineers and other technicians.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Political and Security Committee3 P.M.

title: JAMES R. KILPATRICK
description: DETROIT, Nov. 8 (AP)James R. Kilpatrick, long a photographer for The Detroit News, died today at a hospital where he had been under treatment for a heart ailment. His age was 63.

title: LATE RALLY CUTS LOSSES ON AMEX
description: A rally in the last hour of trading enabled the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market yesterday to trim earlier losses considerably.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: JEAN T. CURRY DEAD; ADVERTISING OFFICER
description: Jean T. Curry, the first woman officer of Cunningham & Walsh, Inc., advertising agency, died Wednesday evening at her home, 201 East 19th Street. She was 57 years old.

title: PoundDollar Parity Disclosed
description: LONDON, Nov. 9 (AP)Britain disclosed today the pounddollar parity governing the guarantees it gave 62 nations to safeguard their sterling balances held in this country.

title: Bar Meets at Acapulco
description: ACAPULCO, Mexico, Nov. 9 (AP)The annual midyear meeting of the New Jersey State Bar Association is under way in this resort.

title: ISRAELI JETS HIT SYRIA IN 2 RAIDS
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 9Israeli jets struck twice into Syria todayclashing with Syrian MIG's during the second raidand Syrian artillerymen shelled the occupied Golan heights.

title: Penn Aims to Match Eli Power
description: Among Yale University's rabid alumni are some curmudgeons who insist Yale's wishbone formation is nothing but the Yale Y upside down.

title: Commodity Price Index Fell To 124.2 During the Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 124.2 from 124.9 last week.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Use of Drugs at Olympics Found to Be Widespread
description: Despite elaborate doping control procedures, the use and availability of drugs at the recent Olympics appear to have been the most widespread and open in the history of the modern games.

title: Big U.S. Base to Pass To Saigon on Saturday
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 9 (Reuters)Longbinh camp, the biggest American base in Vietnam and United States Army headquarters for the war, will be formally turned over to. the South Vietnamese Saturday, it was announced today.

title: Aides Say Nixon's Plans Could Expand His Power
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Nov. 9 High Administration sources suggested today that President Nixon's announced intention to restructure the Federal Government could further increase the authority of his own Executive Office and accelerate a longterm decline in the power of the Cabinet.

title: Protesters in Newark Halt Black Project
description: NEWARK, Nov. 9A group of demonstrators led by two State Assemblymen today halted construction on a 16story lowand middleincome housing project sponsored by a black nationalist organization headed by the poet and playwright Imamu Amiri Baraka.

title: Bridge Closed for Hour
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9 (UPI)Traffic was halted on the Golden Gate Bridge for an hour early today while two traveling bridges were hoisted onto the span's main cables as part of a maintenance program. Huge cranes were used to hoist the traveling bridges, whose feet rest on wheels on the cables. The bridges stretch across the roadway.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 9 (AP)Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., advanced through to the quarterfinals of. the $63,500 Stockholm open tennis tournament today as fellow Americans, Frank Froehling and Jeff Borowiak, were beaten.

title: F.P.C. Proposes New Plan to Spur Rise in Gas Supply
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9The Federal Power Commission proposed today a third change in its regulations intended to increase the supply of natural gas by letting the price rise.

title: DEMOCRATIC CHIEF TO FIGHT FOR POST
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9The woman whom Senator George McGovern installed as Democratic National Chairman said today that she would resist mounting efforts to oust her in the wake of the party's crushing defeat in the Presidential election.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: An accountant for the city Department of Finance was sentenced to four years in jail for stealing $129,550 from the city.

title: Increase Below 4%
description: The nation's money supply is growing at a rate below per cent, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

title: Add Oil Refineries, Experts Urge U.S.
description: The United States may be unable to meet its needs for petroleum products in the future because of a growing shortage of domestic refining capacity, a group of industry experts warned yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Increases in the price of milk, perhaps as early as the coming weekend, were forecast yesterday for the five boroughs of the city and Nassau and Westchester Counties.

title: L.I. Officer Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) The Defense Department announced today that Capt. Dennis W. Finnegan of the Army, who is from Lynbrook, L. I. had been killed in Vietnam.

title: Restoring Fatherhood
description: WALTHAM, Mass.Those very qualities which are most universal about human families  a long, helpless, motherdependent childhood, longterm sexual pairing between adult males and females, and a considerable amount of postnatal fathering  are unique to the human species. But these are precisely the characteristics of family life that have been under continuing assault by Americans.

title: Protesting Students at Southern U. in New Orleans Force Resignation of School Official
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 9Protesting students who had occupied a campus building for nine days forced the resignation today of the chief executive officer of the New Orleans branch of predominantly black Southern University.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: A man who plans to spend an extended period of time in the bush would do well to avoid, as much as possible, wearing garments with zippers.

title: Slogan Now Greeting
description: WASHINGTON, Nov 9 (AP) Telephone calls to President Nixon's national campaign headquarters are now answered with a cheery Four more years. Earlier callers were greeted with Committee for the Reelection of the President. Four more years was a Nixon campaign slogan,

title: MENTALCARE STUDY ASSAILED BY DAVITS
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, has issued a statement expressing disappointment with a Federal report on the state's mental health retardation program.

title: CANARSIE BOY COTT OF SCHOOLS ENDS; 6,000 IN CLASSES
description: Heeding new pleas by community leaders that they end their twoweek school boycott Canarsie parents sent nearly 6,000 children to classes yesterday as a measure of normalcy returned to schools in the troubletorn Brooklyn area.

title: LATE RALLY LIFTS PRICE OF STOCKS
description: A late rally in oldline blue chips lifted the DowJones industrial average yesterday to its highest level in more than six and onehalf years and put it within striking distance of the tantalizing 1,000 mark.

title: Army Court Plans to Open Hearings Dec. 4 on Calley
description: WASINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP)The Army Court of Military Review will open hearings Dec. 4 on First Lieut. William Calley Jr.'s appeal from his murder conviction in the killing of South Vietnamese civilians at Mylai.

title: WASHINGTON
description: In reorganizing the Cabinet and the White House staff for his second term, President Nixon is confronted with a number of critical questions and conflicting ambitions. He may even have to trade in a little efficiency for a little laughter.

title: Sabres, Seals Tie, 00
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 9 (AP)The Buffalo Sabres and California Golden Seals played to a 00 tie in the N.H.L. tonight. The deadlock extended Buffalo's undefeated streak at home to nine games this season. Mary Edwards had 28 saves to 23 for Buffalo's Roger Crozier.

title: Blue Cross Is Challenged By State on Rate Increase
Inquiry at Kennedy Finds 1 in 8 Flies to Europe on Illegal Fares
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board said yesterday that a recent investigation of transAtlantic airlineticket discounting at Kennedy International Airport indicated that one passenger in eight was flying on illegally low fares.

title: Flyers Top Black Hawks
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 (AP)  The Philadelphia Flyers scored three times in the first 7 minutes 33 seconds and held on for a 53 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight. The Flyers were led by Rick, MacLeish's three goals.

title: Chick Meehan, Football Coach Of N.Y.U. and Syracuse, Dead
description: SYRACUSE, Nov. 9Chick Meehan, a noted football coach of New York college teams from 1920 to 1937, died today in a Syracuse hospital. He was 19 years old.

title: The Unmandate
description: WASHINGTONTo carry 49 of the fifty states by heavy popular majorities while your party was being rejected as a claimant for the legislative majority required to execute your programs this marks a turbulence among the American people which would lead to at least two more years of bitter national disunity. Even personally popular Presidential candidates, such as Eisenhower, have won the White House and been denied the Capitol before. But the magnitude of Nixon's personal victory in the face of repudiation of his party makes the outcome both unique and ominous.

title: Rail TonMileage Up 23.9%
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9The Association of American Railroads announced today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week was an estimated 16.7 billion tonmiles, 23.9 per cent above the corresponding week last year when traffic was affected by dock and coal strikes. The A.A.R. also reported rail carloadings last week totaled 550,094 cars; 25.9 per cent above last year.

title: Indians Seize Letter Bombs
description: BOMBAY, India, Nov. 9 (UPI) The police picked up seven; more suspected letter bombs; today, bringing to 42 the number seized here in the past sevoral days. Thirtyfive of them were picked up in a postal sorting office near the Bombay Airport. A postal sorter was seriously injured when one esploded several days ago.

title: Matthew Geis, an ExCoach Of Track at Princeton, Dies
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 9Matthew T. Geis, former coach of track and crosscountry at Princeton University, died today of cancer at the Princeton Medical Center. He was 84 years old.

title: Washington Drops Charges Against 17 Foes of Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP)Charges were dropped today against 17 persons, including Dr. Regina Pustan, mother of the world chess champion, Bobby Fischer. They had been accused of blocking the entrance to the office of the Committee for the ReElection of the President on Nov. 1.

title: Reagan Shuns Cabinet Post
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 9 (UPI) himself out today as a possible member of President Nixon's Cabinet. I've got two years to [go as Governor and, the Lord willing, I intend to fill them out, said the Republican Governor, who was chairman of Mr. Nixon's victorious campaign in California. Mr. Reagan also told a news conference that he had made no decision on whether to run for the Senate in 1974 when his gubernatorial term expires.

title: Dog Owners Protest Bill To Force Street Cleanup
description: Dog owners protested sharply and loudly yesterday as the City Council's Committee on Environmental Protection began considering legislation to make owners clean up after their pets.

title: RISE IN FOOD PRICES BELIEVED SLOWING
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UPI) Food price increases will probably slow down in the fourth quarter of this year, and increases in the first half of 1973 may be smaller. than those posted in the first half of this year, Agriculture Department economists. said today.

title: DAYAN CRITICIZED OVER OCCUPATION
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 9Government leaders attacked Defense Minister Moshe Dayan's policies in the occupied Arab territories tonight.

title: The Year of Europe
description: PARIS, NOV. 9  Europeans have often suspected that, because of conflicting economic and commercial interests, the United States would try to break up the Common Market once it had become too strong.

title: C.B.S. IS REBUFFED ON MOVE BY UBELL
description: Supreme Court Justice Edward T. McCaffrey has denied a motion by the Columbia Broadcasting System to prevent Earl Ubell from working as a news director for the National Broadcasting Company.

title: East Side Restaurant Is Happy Find
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

title: Pakistan Shift Hoped For
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 9High officials of India and Bangladesh expressed cautious optimism here today that Pakistan would soon perceive the realities in the subcontinent and take what they described as a more positive attitude toward the problem of normalizing relations among the three countries. desh expressed cautious optimism here today that Pakistan would soon perceive the realities in the subcontinent and take what they described as a more positive attitude toward the problem of normalizing relations among the three countries.

title: Holland Adds Directorship
description: Jerome H. Holland, the first black director of the New York Stock Exchange, was elected yesterday to the board of the General Cigar Company, Inc. Mr. Holland, 56, is also a director of the American Telephone & Telegraph Company, the Gencral, Foods Corporation, the ManUfacturers Hanover Corporation, the Union Carbide Corporation, the Chrysler Corporation; Federated Department Stores, Inc., and the Continental Corporation.

title: City Starts Enforcing Noise Law. by Citing Music Store
description: A small phonographrecord store was filling Lexington Avenue with sounds of pop music yesterday as two of the city's new noisepollution inspectors arrived to begin enforcing the new noisecontrol law.

title: Youth Board Institute to Be Dissolved
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that the Youth Board Research Institute, a major operating arm of the scandalridden Youth Services Agency, would be dissolved and its activities absorbed in a thorough reorganization of the agency.

title: ISRAELI JETS HIT SYRIA IN 2 RAIDS
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 9Israeli jets struck twice into Syria todayclashing with Syrian MIG's during the second raidand Syrian artillerymen shelled the occupied Golan heights.

title: Brewster Denies That $9,500 Gift Involved Bribery
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 9 (AP)  Former Senator Daniel B. Brewster testified today that he had received a total of $9,500 from a mailorder house lobbyist, but he denied that his vote and influence were ever for sale.

title: OLYMPIC DECISION FOUR MONTHS OFF
description: LONDON, Nov, 9 (AP) Lord Killanin, president of the International Olympic Committee, said today the cities lining up to stage the 1976 Winter Games might have to wait at least four months for a decision.

title: POTSY CLARK DEAD, LIONS'
description: DETROIT, Nov. 9 (AP)George (Potsy) Clark, the Detroit Lions first coach and a former coach for the Brooklyn Dodgers football team, died yesterday at the age of 78.

title: Dale Dance Studios Accused of Bilking 500
description: The Department of Consumer, Affairs sued Dale Dance Studios yesterday, charging that the concern had bilked more than 500 students by charging exorbitant fees for dance lessons after using fraudulent bait and switch tactics.

title: Advertising:
description: The two big news magazines handled the job of providing the election results diferently.

title: U.S. Planes Bomb in Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 9 (Reuters)  United States planes bombed an area 14 miles south of Pnompenh today as guerrilla activity increased.

title: Verdict of Guilty Is Upheld In 1967 Slaying of Marine
description: The Appellate Division upheld in a 3to2 decision yesterday the manslaughter conviction of William A. Maynard Jr., who was described as an aspiring actor and theatrical agent active in the black militant movement, for the shotgun killing of a Marine sergeant in Greenwich Village in April, 1967.

title: 130 Refuse to Join Ship; Most Reassigned by Navy
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 9One hundred thirty men attached to the aircraft carrier Constellation refused for hours today to obey an order to board their ship in the latest incident of racial conflict involving warships of the Pacific. Fleet.

title: Bridge: 6,000 Are Expected to Attend Fall National Championships
description: LANCASTER, Pa., Nov. 9  The Fall National Championships, which begin here tomorrow and continue for 10 days, will attract some 6,000 players from all parts of the North American continent.

title: Woman Defies Superstition, Tours Tunnel After a 2Year Fight
description: SILVER PLUME, Colo., Nov. 9  The shouts rang down from the men strapped high up in the tangle of reinforcing bars on the walls of the tunnel that cuts through the Continental Divide 10 miles west of here:

title: PATRICK MONAGHAN
description: Patrick Monaghan, public relations and marketing communications consultant and an author, died Wednesday at his home, 480 Halstead Avenue, Harrison, N. Y. He was 69 years old.

title: UNION SETS PROTEST ON TEXTILE IMPORTS
description: Louis Stulberg, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, exasperated at what he said was inaction to stem a flood of foreign textiles that had cost more than 250,000 American apparel workers their jobs since 1961, yesterday announced plans for a nationwide protest.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 12 European Lands Agree To Merge 2 Space Groups
description: PARIS, Nov. 9 (Reuters)A West European space conference will meet in Brussels next month to set in motion a common program under a single organization, officials said here today after a meeting in Paris of science ministers from 12 countries.

title: Bank Robbed of $1,300
description: A holdup man who said hr had a bomb in an attache case got away with $1,300 from the Jamaica Savings Bank, at 370 82nd Street, Jackson Heights. Queens, shortly after 12:30 P.M. yesterday. The man, about 45 years old, fled.

title: BOYLE DATA CITED BY SENATE PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9The Senate Labor Subcommittee sent to the Justice Department today a letter alleging possible new criminal misuses of United Mine Workers funds by the Union's president, W. A. Boyle.

title: Larsen to Give Exhibition At Manhattan Chess Club
description: Bent Larsen, the chess grandmaster from Copenhagen, Denmark, will give a simultaneous exhibition at the Manhattan Chess Club 14 East 60th Street, at 4 P.M. tomorrow.

title: Doctors Trip to Hanoi Reported Put Off
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9Seciretary of State William P. Rog ers reportedly urged Senator Edward M. Kennedy today not to send a team of five prominent United States physicians to North Vietnam at this time.

title: Advertising:
description: How do the master promoters of Madison Avenue get their own people to contribute to the United Fund? Apparently the same way as they sell products, with advertising (posters) and consumer incentives (time off or sweepstakes).

title: Aides Say Nixon's Plans Could Expand His Power
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Nov. 9 High Administration sources suggested today that President Nixon's announced intention to restructure the Federal Government could further increase the authority of his own Executive Office and accelerate a longterm decline in the power of the Cabinet.

title: MAGNAVOX GIVING UP FACSIMILE BUSINESS
description: The Magnavox Company has decided to give up its facsimile business and take a maximum loss after tax of about $3million. The company said yesterday it was discontinuing all marketing activities for facsimile products, which it marketed under the Magnavox name, and planned to phase out of the business. It noted that possible sale of technology and other assets might reduce the loss, which would be treated as an extraordinary charge and identified separately in corporate operating statements.

title: Record Funds Reported in States On the Eve of Revenue Sharing
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 State and local governments are about to begin receiving billions of dollars of Federal revenuesharing funds at a time when their fiscal situation is the easiest in many years, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Boycott Over, Canarsie Pupils Are Eager to Work
description: Junior High School 211 in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn returned to something approaching normal yesterday after a 12day boycott, and, most of the 1,003 students in attendance seemed glad to be back and eager to catch up on the work they had missed.

title: MRS. W. R. KIRKLAND JR.
description: Mrs. Sally Sprague Kirkland, the wife of William R. Kirkland Jr., an insurance broker with Fred S. James & Co., died Wednesday evening at her home, 580 Park Avenue. She was 62 years old.

title: Admission in '72 Doubted
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 9The East GermanWest German treaty opens the way for the two states to become members of the United Nations, but admission is not expected before next year. Many diplomats here believe that the Germanys will he admitted at the 28th General Assembly, which opens here Sept. 18, 1973.

title: NETS BOW, 120101 5TH TINE IN ROW
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 9The New York Nets had to play without their backcourt star, Johnny Roche, tonight and were routed by the Utah Stars, 120101, in the American Basketball Association. It was their fifth. loss in a row. Roche injured his back in the game with San Diego and could hardly bend. The Nets have now lost eight out of nine games on the road.

title: If the Bridge Comes, the Houses Must Go
description: RYE, N. Y.They came to see a century of history in houses, paying $5 for the privilege. But over and over again on Tuesday, the talk turned to other endangered thingsto wetlands and wooded walks, to ravines and rock outcroppings and to the flocks of blue heron and Canadian geese that feed at dawn in the marshes of this community. If they put the bridge in, we can say goodby to the wetlands and wildlife, said Katherine Bergman ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? bridge planned to span Long Island Sound between Rye and Oyster Bay.

title: TOD ANDREWS, ACTOR OF STAGE AND TV, 51
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 9 (UPI) Tod Andrews, a stage and television actor, died of a heart attack at his home in Beverly Hills Monday. He was 51 years old.

title: 50 Inmates of Attica Cause a Brief Disturbance
description: AITICA, N.Y., Nov. 9 About 50 prisoners caused a brief disturbance yesterday afternoon at the Attica Correctional Facility when they joined hands and shouted slogans in an exercise yard, according to Ernest L. Montanye, the prison superintendent.

title: REVIEW OF SECRETS BY JUDGES OPPOSED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP)  The Nixon Administration argued in the Supreme Court today that judges had no authority under the 1970 Freedom of Information Act to examine documents classified by the Government as secret.

title: WORLD CUP GOLF STOPPED BY RAIN
Article 1  No Title
description: KAMPALA, Nov. 9 (UPI)The United Nations completed the airlift of stateless Asians from Uganda to Europe last night as the last 174 left aboard a charter flight for Spain. Earlier 180 had flown to Malta.

title: Steel Union Donations
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 9 (AP)The United Steelworkers of, America, which withheld its support in the campaign for the Presidency, contributed a total of $296,000 to other candidates, according to Common Cause, a nonpartisan campaign monitoring organization.

title: YOUTH INSTITUTE TO BE DISSOLVED
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that the Youth Board Research Institute, a major operating arm of the scandalridden Youth Services Agency, would be dissolved and its activities absorbed in a thorough reorganization of the agency.

title: City's First Drugs Coordinator Is Accused of Medicaid Fraud
description: Dr. Efren E. Ramirez, whom Mayor Lindsay brought here from Puerto Rico in 1966 to become his first Addiction Services Agency Commissioner was accused yesterday of having improperly billed the city for more than $28,000 in Medicaid payments for private psychiatric services to addicts that he allegedly never provided.

title: Some Blacks Pay Rises in South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 9A large South African mining concern said today that it had unilaterally increased the wages of its black workers by 30 to 50 per cent, and an employers association offered a 46 per cent wage increase yesterday to lowpaid blacks in the retail and distributive trades.

title: Knick Rally Tops Ha wks, 10199
description: Trailing by 23 points in the. final minute of the first half, the New York Knicks produced a scintillating second half last night and defeated the Atlanta Hawks, 101.99, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 (UPI)Coach Johnny McKenzie of the Philadelphia Blazers said today he would give up coaching duties temporarily so that he could help get the World Hockey Association team a few more victories. The Blazers have won 2 game's and lost 11.

title: Business Briefs
description: Congress should establish a Federal Fiscal Stabilization Board that would improve the effectiveness of Government economic policies, Henry Kaufman, Salomon Brothers economist, proposed last night at the fall dinner meeting of the Money Marketeers of New York University.

title: Notes, on People
description: To thank Pablo Casals for his beneficence over the years, a children's institution in Guadalajara, Mexico, built a home there for the 96yearold cellist. But when Casals made a surprise visit to play at a benefit concert in Guadalajara last month, be declined the house with thanks, saying he preferred to continue living in Puerto Rico. The house, its planned swimming pool canceled, is being converted for use by the children's home,

title: MRS. JOHN W. BANKS
description: CATSKILL, N. Y., Nov. 8Mrs. Gladys E. Banks, the first Republican woman to be elected to the State Assembly from Bronx County, died Sunday in Greene County Memorial Hospital. She was 75 years old and Made her home here.

title: Latin Music Draws Festival Crowd
description: Several hundred New Yorkers clapped and swayed to a Latin tempo outside Madison Square Garden yesterday as a dozen top LatinAmerican artists offered a promotional preview of what can be expected tonight at the auditorium's first Latin Music Festival.

title: Business Plans 11% Increase in Spending
description: A booming increase in capital spending is planned by United States business next year, indicating a strong economic outlook and an eventual rise in productivity in the manufacturing area, McGraw Hill Publications said yesterday.

title: PEACE GROUPS PLAN PROTESTS ON NOV. 18
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UPI) President Nixon's landslide reelection will bring a significant shift to the antiwar movement and return demonstrators to the streets, leaders of the peace movement said today.

title: Nobody Loses in the Translation
description: Roberto Duran of Panama, the lightweight champion of the world, will fight Esteban DeJesus, the champion of Puerto Rico, in a 10round nontitle bout next Friday at Madison Square Garden, but yesterday they let their agents do the talking at a promotional luncheon.

title: RUNNERS IN N.F.L. GET GOOD MARKS
description: When National Football League club owners voted last spring to move the inbounds markers 3 yards closer to the center of the field, many people scoffed at the suggestion that the change would help put more offense into the game,

title: Average Mortgage Yields Fall at Ginny May Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (Reuters)Average mortgage yields dropped to 7.58 per cent in October at the Government National Mortgage Association auction from 7.61 per cent at the September auction, Ginny May reported today.

title: CEREMONY IS SET FOR CANONTRO II
description: W. J. (Buddy) Hirsch, the capable King Ranch trainer, had just seen his favored Prove Out finish second to Marion Frankel's Banderlog in yesterday's $12,000 feature at Aqueduct. However, the campaignwise conditioner did not seem too disappointed.

title: Protest in Oregon
description: CORVALLIS, Ore., Nov. 9 (UPI)A group of Indians stayed in the gymnasium of an abandoned Air Force station, law enforcement officials indicated that they planned to let the occupation continue at least for a while.

title: S.E.C. Tightens Control Over Inside Information
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has broken new ground in regulating the use of inside information in a case involving Investors Diversified Services, Inc., the nation's largest mutualfund organization.

title: Theater: The Foursome in Capital
description: WASHINGTON  For the American premiere of E. A. Whitehead's The Foursome, the stage at the Arena Stage is completely filled with clean white crystalline sand. It is not just the expansiveness of the sand that is remarkable but the precision with which the setting has been designed by Robert U. Taylorpresumably in collaboration with the director, Alan Schneider. Except for I the absence of surf, this is a real beachspeckled by reeds and stones and shifted into dunes. It is the sort of inviting set that one wants to touch to see if it is real.

title: Personalities: Unitas Works on Option Ploy
description: John Unitas, one of Pro. football's outstanding quarterbacks for 17 years, does not expect to play for the Baltimore Colts next year. In the last year of a threeseason $375,000 playing contract, Unitas said after practice on Wednesday, I'll honor my contract the rest of the year and then it's up to the club. If they don't exercise their option by May 1, I'll be placed on waivers or become a free agent. Unitas, who will be 40 next season, wants to keep playing. When he does retire, he will have a job with the Colts under the terms of a 10year personal services contract signed by the previous Baltimore Carroll Rosenbloom.

title: Legislative Storm Cellar
description: In the aftermath of one of the most complete Republican Presidential sweeps of New York State in memory, the Democratic party nonetheless remains alive and relatively healthy. The Nixon landslide had remarkably little impact on state and local political contests. While there was a gain for Republicans here and there in the State Legislature, these gains were indeed minimal and fax below most forecasts.

title: Books of The Times
description: Do all good novelists begin their lives as bedwetting little boys? Though this question may not be quite fair to The Unknown Orwell, it is true to the feeling I brought away from the book. The authors, Peter Stansky and William Abrahams, have moved heaven and earth to discover what made George Orwell the writer he was, but I'm afraid they haven't moved me. After. all their infinite pains, he remains a. Jekyll and Hyde.enigma: totally uninteresting man until the day he publshed his first and, in my opinion, best book, Down and Out in Paris and London.

title: 11 Restaurants Hit by an a la Carte Strike
description: Waiters, waitresses and bus boys at 11 wellknown Manhattan restaurants went on strike yesterday for higher pay and other contract improvements.

title: Rule onPerformance Fees
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9The Securities and Exchange Commission also announced today the adoption of a previously proposed rule affecting payment by mutual funds of performance type fees to their investment advisers.

title: The Paris Talks Conform to Ritual, But Occasionally There Is a Smile
description: PARIS, Nov. 9The North Vietnamese delegate, a slight man with a heavy overcoat and blackrimmed glasses stepped quickly up to the microphones on the sidewalk outside the Hotel Majestic. He said a few words, went in, came out three hours later and said a few words more.

title: Satellite Is Orbited To Be Radio Link For All Canadians
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Nov. 9 The United States launched tonight a communications satellite to serve all of Canada, the first domestic communications satellite in the world.

title: Brandt Sees a New Era
description: BONN, Nov. 9 (UPI) Chancellor Willy Brandt told newsmen today that the treaty of reconciliation between his country and East Germany marked a turning point in postwar history and ended a major phase of the cold war.

title: WORLD CUP GOLF STOPPED BY RAIN
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov: 9 (AP)Heavy rain forced cancellation of play today in the World Cup golf championship.

title: Boss Tweed's Unearthed City Records Mask Shed Light on Official Chicanery
Contraceptives at Harvard
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 9 (UPI)  The Harvard student agencies will soon begin selling contraceptives at newsstands in the freshman dining hall at Harvard Union. Harold Rosenwald, attorney for the student agencies, said that the contraceptives would be sold to persons regardless of age.

title: People and Business
description: Aubrey G. Lanston & Co., Inc., the wellknown government securities house, has been rebuilding its staff since last summer when Lehman Brothers, Inc., took two of its key men, William N. Griggs and Leonard J. Santow, for new Government securities unit. The two had long worked as a team on the Lanston weekly money and bond letter and are now writing a similar letter for Lehman.

title: GENERAL ANDERSON OF CANADIAN ARMY
description: TORONTO, Nov. 9 (Canadian Press)Maj. Gen. Thomas Victor Anderson, Canadian chief of staff at the start of World War II, died yesterday in Riverdale Hospital. He was 91 years old.

title: 17 Americans Died in War Last Week, 15 in Helicopter
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 9 (AP)The United States command reported today that 17 American servicemen were killed in action in Indochina last week and that 2 were wounded.

title: CANARSIEBOYCOTT OF SCHOOLS ENDS; 6,000 IN CLASSES
description: Heeding new pleas by community leaders that they end their twoweek school boycott, Canarsie parents sent nearly 6,000 children to classes yesterday as a measure of normalcy returned to schools in the troubletorn Brooklyn area.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Nov. 9  The Jersey City StateMontclair State football game tomorrow night at Roosevelt Stadium in Jersey City will determine the New Jersey State College Conference champion.

title: Fans Get a Peek at Skating's New Look
description: In a swirl of blue skirt and pixiecut blonde hair, Janet Lynn spun through the air in a double Axelthat brought murmurs of approval from viewers at the Skating Club of New York.

title: Crangle Signals Bid for Top Party Job
description: The state Democratic chairman, Joseph F. Crangle, signaled his candidacy for the national chairmanship yesterday by calling for changes in personnel and programs of the party.

title: The Other Prisoners
description: Although a United States spokesman in Paris has expressed optimism about an early resumption of secret negotiations with North Vietnam, there is disturbing evidence that the delicate fabric of a prospective peace settlement may be in danger of unraveling. Hanoi now also appears to be backing away from important terms of the outline agreement that the North Vietnamese made public last month.

title: Reality in Germany
description: Even if his coalition should be turned out in the Bundestag elections Nov. 19, this will have been a year of spectacular accomplishment in foreign policy for West German Chancellor Willy Brandt. It would be hard exaggerate the significance of the treaty, just concluded, to establish normal relations with the Communist Government of East Germany.

title: Few in FloodWary Bound Brook Buy U.S. Insurance
President Pledges an End To Era of Permissiveness
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9President Nixon, promising the American people the rigors of selfreliance instead of the soft life says he hopes to use the second term to lead the nation out of a crisis of the spirit.

title: Cone Will Join U.S. Team For Horse Show in Toronto
description: TORONTO, Nov. 9  Mac Cone, a 20yearold rider from Germantown, Tenn., will join the United States Equestrian Team at the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show, the last stop on the fall indoor circuit, tomorrow.

title: Equity Financing
description: A public offering of one million shares of Arizona Public Service Company common at $23.50 per share was made yesterday by an underwriting group managed by First Boston, Blyth Eastman Dillon and Dean Witter. Proceeds to the company will be used to reduce shortterm indebtedness incurred in connection with construction and other purposes. The company's stock was up  at 23 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: PROTESTERS HALT NEWARK PROJECT
description: NEWARK, Nov. 9A group of demonstrators led by two State Assemblymen today halted construction on a 16story low and middleincome housing project sponsored by a black nationalist organization headed by the poet and playwright Imamu Amiri Baraka.

title: LETTER BY NIXON IS SAID TO PRESS THIEU ON A TRUCE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 President Nixon has sent a personal letter to the South Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu urging him to accept a ceasefire plan as soon as possible wellplaced Administration officials said today.

title: ASIANS WHO STAYED COUNTED BY UGANDA
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Nov. 9  The head count of Asians left in Uganda began here today as the last of the stateless Asians registered with the United Nations were being flown out.

title: 1776 Comes to the Music Hall Screen
Temporal Bone Laboratory Dedicated at Hospital Here
description: The New York Eye and Earl Infirmary dedicated the East Coast's first temporal bone dis section laboratory yesterday,

title: Princeton Defeats Harvard, Yale in CrossCountry Run
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 9Princeton captured the Main Memorial Trophy for the second straight year today, defeating its crosscountry rivals, Harvard and Yale.

title: F. X. STEPHENS JR., REAL ESTATE LAWYER
description: Francis X. Stephens Jr., a lawyer and a leading Catholic layman, died Wednesday at his home, 720 Pelham Road, New Rochelle, N. Y. He was 70 years old.

title: Oil Earnings Halved
description: Earnings of the Royal DutchShell Group, the largest corporate enterprise outside the United States, fell sharply in the quarter and ninemonth periods ended Sept. 30.

title: DEMOCRATIC CHIEF TO FIGHT FOR POST
description: WASHINGTON Nov. 9The woman whom Senator George McGovern installed as Democratic National Chairman said today that she would resist mounting efforts to oust her in the wake of the party's crushing defeat in the Presidential election.

title: Alberta 72 Victor
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, Nov. 9 (UPI)Jim Harrison poured in two goals and assisted on two others tonight to lead the Alberta Oilers to a 72 victory over the Los Angeles Sharks.

title: Savings Banks Assailed on Mortgage Policy
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Nov. 9Vernon E. Jordan Jr., executive director of the National Urban League, charged here today that the nation's savings banks and savings and loan associations were participating in a massive disinvestment policy that undercuts their own growth, is helping to destroy the cities in which they operate and betrays their depositors.

title: Statements From PreElection Interview With Nixon Outlining 2dTerm Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9The following statements by President Nixon are taken from the transcript of an interview last Sunday with Garnett D. Horner, White House correspondent of The Washington StarNews. The President did not want the interview published in questionandanswer form, but he did authorize direct quotation. This summary contains virtually all of his remarks; the material omitted includes two brief comments put off the record at Mr. Nixon's request.

title: Shriver Talks of His Future in Party
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 Back in his law office on his 57th birthday, Sargent Shriver looked anything but crushed by the worst defeat that ever befell a Democratic VicePresidential candidate.

title: DepartmentStore Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9The Department of Commerce today estimated department store sales last week at $903million, up 5 per cent from the yearearlier $856million. Total retail sales were estimated at $9.1billion, up 12 per cent from the yearearlier $8.1billion.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Mrs. Henry B. Cross Jr. of Llewellyn Park, N. J., mother of four. whose golf handicap is 6, was elected president of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association yesterday at the Princeton Club. The s association has 1,622 members.

title: BRITAIN PUTS REIN ON MONEY SUPPLY
description: LONDON, Nov. 9The British Government today bolstered its 90day freeze on wages and prices with a new antiinflation move designed to limit the growth of the money supply.

title: FASHION TALK
description: The Norell mystique continues, too, even though Norman Norell died last month. A small group of linen and wool jersey dresses that he put in work before his death is being presented to store buyers in his showroom now.

title: CHARLES BERWIND, LED BIG BROTHERS
description: BRYN MAWR, Pa., Nov. 9 (UPI)Charles Berwind, a founder of the Big Brothers of America, the volunteer organiZation that helps fatherless :boys, died today, at Bryn Mawr Hospital. He was 78 years old.

title: PARK DEDICATION ENDED BY PROTEST
description: Mayor Lindsay abruptly canceled the dedication of a $400,000 park rehabilitation project in the Bronx yesterday when he was berated by 50 protesting women who let him know that the park was far from completed.

title: Prison Transfers Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UPI) Civilian libertarians sued in United States District Court today to prevent prisoners from being arbitrarily transferred from one Federal prison to another. The suit, filed by the National Prison Project of the American Civil Liberties Union, asked that such transfers be declared unconstitutional because they were one of the most severe forms of punishment prison authorities exercise.

title: President Pledges an End To Era of Permissiveness
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9President Nixon, promising the American people the rigors of selfreliance instead of the soft life, says he hopes to use the second term to lead the nation out of a crisis of the spirit.

title: Champion Oil Wins Damages In Sinclair Refining Suit
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 9 (UPI)A Federal court jury has awarded Champion Oil Services, Inc., an operator of gas stations in Butler County, Ohio, $989,457 in damages against the Atlantic Richfield Corporation's Sinclair Refining division in a civil antitrust action.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: MADRID, Nov. 9 (UPI)Hen Ford 2d, chairman of the Ford. Motor Company, today paid visits to the Spanish vice president, Admiral this Carrero Blanco, and the Industry Minister, Jose Maria Lopez de Letone, amid speculation that Ford planned to join other makers in manufacturing cars in Spain.

title: Redskins in Way of Giants Playoff Hopes
description: LOCAL TEAMS The Redskins are favored over the Giants on Sunday as they attempt to make a sweepthree straight victories over New York teams. This game will be telecast from Washington, Channel 2 at 1 P.M. The Jets are big favorites at home agaisnt Buffalo. The late television game will be Baltimore at San Francisco, Channel 4,.4 P.M. The Monday night game is Cleve land at San Diego, Channel 7, 9 o'clock. Here is a preview of all games with wonlosttied records in parentheses:

title: Bar Meets at Acapulco
description: ACAPULCO, Mexico, Nov. 9 (AP)The annual midyear meeting of the New Jersey State Bar Association is under way in this resort.

title: TERRORISM ISSUE TAKEN UP AT U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 9The United Nations today began what promises to be a difficult and politically sensitive task taking substantive action against international terrorism.

title: Graebner Beats Mendoza, Advances in Dewar Tennis
description: TORQUAY, England, Nov. 9 (UPI)Clark Graebner, the former American Davis Cup player, beat John De Mendoza of Britain, in the quarterfinals of the fourth Dewar Cup indoor tennis tournament today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: INDIANS RIPPED UP FEDERAL BUILDING
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 Militant American Indians left behind them today a battered Bureau of Indian Affairs Building that may take months to restore to usefulness.

title: New Parks Director Richard Michael Clurman
description: Richard Michael Clurman, whose appointment as Commissioner of Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs was announced yesterday, was,in a limousine going uptown. I must admit, he was saying, that my wife runs one of the most interesting salons I've ever attended. Mrs. Clurman, who was also in the limousine, turned and smiled and, in a voice exactly like Carol Chan fling's said: Yes, and sometimes I say, Damn it, Dick does it have to be Meet the Press every night?

title: LETTER BY NIXON IS SAID TO PRESS THIEU ON A TRUCE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9President Nixon has sent a personal letter to the South Vietnamese President, Nguyen Van Thieu, urging him to accept a ceasefire plan as soon as possible, wellplaced Administration officials said today.

title: Judge Is Slated to Head State G.O.P.
description: State Supreme Court Justice Richard M. Rosenbaum, a former Monroe County Republican chairman, is slated to succeed Charles T. Lanigan as the party's state chairman.

title: Skull Pushes Back Man's Origin
description: Ancient bones found in Africa have been assembled into a skull that may extend man's immediate ancestry back more than one million years earlier than previously believed.

title: Unused Franchise
description: The biggest loser in Tuesday's election was the democratic process. Only a little more than half of all Americans of voting age exercised that most distinctive right of citizenship, the casting of their ballots for Federal, state and local officials.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The United States Olympic Committee tendered conciliatory hand yesterday to the National Collegiate Athletic Association, which withdrew from the organization last month.

title: Dance: Ballet Theatre Contemporain
description: Ballet Theatre Contemporain, a fouryearold French gompany dedicated to the concept of modernism as it is understood in France, is Ilow on its first North American tour. It made its local debut last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music for a run through Sunday afternoon.

title: Dave Anderson
description: In a workout shortly after the Miami Dolphins opened their 1970 training camp, their first under Don Shula as coack, Larry Csonka and Jim Kiick casually lined up running backs in simulated pass protection while Bob Griese, the quarterback, threw long to his wide receivers. Suddenly, from 40 yards away, Shula shouted:

title: ENGINEERING GROUP MODIFYING CHARTER
description: The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, which has basically been a professional and technical organization for its 10year history, is amending its constitution to allow it to try actively to influence Government policy.

title: City's First Drugs Coordinator Is Accused of Medicaid Fraud
description: Dr. Efren E. Ramirez, whom Mayor Lindsay brought here from Puerto Rico in 1966 to become his first Addiction Services Agency Commissioner, was accused yesterday of having improperly billed the city for more than $28,000 in Medicaid payments for private psychiatric services to addicts that he allegedly never provided.

title: U. S. Optimistic at Paris
description: PARIS, Nov. 9 (AP)  The United States delegation to the Vietnam talks again expressed optimism today that peace was near, despite another fruitless session at the conference table.

title: Voting Results Corrected
description: In the voting tables in The New York Times yesterday there were several typographical errors or omissions.

title: Exhilarating Concert
description: The tiny auditorium below street level at the New York Cultural Center is host to concerts every Wednesday night and sometimes other times as well. A grabbag of talent is presented, under the direction of John Harms. Now, with the aid of financial gifts, he has been able to program a series devoted to contemporary music. For $3, one will be able to hear such distinguished pianists as John Ogdon and Charles Rosen or the Concord String Quartet in works not too often heard.

title: Pakistan, Strengthening Friendly Ties, Recognizes North Korea
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 9 (Reuters)  Pakistan announced recognition of North Korea today, only one day after withdrawing from the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization.

title: Rider's Double Pays $1,563
description: SAN MATEO, Calif., Nov. 9 (UPI)Randy Schacht rode both ends of a $1,563 daily double today at Bay Meadows. Schacht rode Lovely Irish to a $71.60 victory in the first race and then came back to take second on Deserved, which paid $75.20. A total of 41 tickets was sold on the 126 combination, all of the $2 variety. It, was the biggest double payoff at Bay Meadows this fall.

title: Jets Turn Back Nationals, 4 to 1, As Hull Is Held Scoreless Again
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 9 (UP1)The Winnipeg Jets got three goals in the second period, then coasted to a 41 victory over the Ottawa Nationals in the World Hockey Association tonight.

title: Haig Meets With Thieu
description: SAIGON. South Vietnam, Friday, Nov. 10General Haig arrived in Saigon this morning, apparently expecting to spend only a couple of days getting President Thieu's agreement to an Indochina peace settlement.

title: Clarman Will Head Parks Department; Heckscher Resigns
description: Richard M. Clurman, a vice president of Time Inc. and chairman of the board of the City Center of Music and Drama, was named by Mayor Lindsay to succeed August Heckscher, the Administrator. of Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs, whose resignation was made public yesterday.

title: Books of The Times
description: For some 20 years and with eight books, A. R. Ammons has been creating a body of work that stands outside the day's fashionable modes. He is no incantatory bard, careering down the highways from here to California or hungering after strange gods in foreign lands. The secrets of the marriage bed or illness of the mind or the trauma of divorce have no appeal to this poet and no place in his work. He is no minimal poet, but a dense one, though his brief poems and narrow lines may suggest the contrary. Nor does he indulge in a running dialogue with himself, adding cryptic notations to the text as an attempt at epic greatness. Nor is he the conventional academic poet of smooth regularity, trying out French models or Italian forms.

title: Judicial Outcome
description: The voting pattern for the judiciary in New York City and State indicated that voters tended to follow the party line instead of judging each candidate as an individual. Judicial distinction and potential were evidently not the main consideration. Faced with unfamiliar names, voters took the easy way out and pulled party levers. Once again, election of judges is shown to be the poorest way for the public to achieve quality.

title: SERIES PAYDAYS REACH NEW HIGHS
description: The world baseball champion Oakland A's and the runnerup Cincinnati Reds received record individual shares from the 1972 World Series, Commissioner Bowie Kuhn announced yesterday.

title: Clurman Will Head Parks Department Heckscher Resigns
description: Richard M. Clurman a vice president of Time Inc. and chairman of the board of the City Center of Music and Drama was named by Mayor Lindsay to succeed August Heckscher the Administrator of Parks Recreation and Cultural Affairs whose resignation was made public yesterday.

title: JURY IN FIRE SUIT FINDS NEGLIGENCE
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 9 A State Supreme Court jury returned a verdict of negligence today against the Yonkers !Jewish Community Center in a multimilliondollar negligence suit brought by survivors of the 12 persons who died in a fire there in 1965.

title: Racing Groups Warned
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 9 (UPI)  The United States Bureau of Land Management has threatened legal action against any group or individual who holds offroad vehicle races on, California public lands without obtaining newly required permits. The bureau's director, 3. R. Penny, said We will take whatever legal action is necessary to see that the regulations are complied with.

title: 2 PACERS HIT 10,000 IN LOSS TO SQUIRES
description: HAMPTON, Va., Nov. 9 (AP) Mel Daniels and Roger Brown of Indiana became the American Basketball Association's first 10,000point career scorers tonight, but the Pacers were defeated by the Virginia Squires, 134126.

title: U.S. Continues B.52 Raids Over North
description: SAIGON South Vietnam, Friday, Nov. 10 (AP)United States B52 bombers struck heavily in the southern part of North Vietnam yesterday and today in a continued effort to blunt a supply buildup there before any ceasefire.

title: Boy Shot as 2 Men Argue In a Harlem Apartment Hall
description: A 9yearold boy was shot twice yesterday when he walked between two men who were arguing in a Harlem apartmenthouse hallway.

title: California Is Urged to Keep Any Religious Theory on the Creation Out of Textbooks
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 9  Religious beliefs about the origin of man have no place in the science and instruction offered in California's public elementary schools, a state commission told the California Board of Education today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Chile Ultraleftists Critical Of Military in the Cabinet
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 9 (AP)Chile's main ultraleft organization has criticized the inclusion of the military branch in the Cabinet of President Salvador Allende Gossens.

title: Skull Pushes Back Man's Origin
description: Ancient bones found in Africa have been assembled into a skull that may extend man's immediate ancestry back more than one million years earlier than previously believed.

title: Norell Left Estate to Friend And Parsons Design School
description: Norman Norell, the fashion designer, left all of his $500,000 estate to a Texas friend and the Parsons School of Design here.

title: Britain, Citing Hardship, Eases Some Sanctions for Rhodesians
description: LONDON, Nov. 9  Britain has decided on humanitarian grounds to exempt individual Rhodesians from some of the economic penalties being carried out against the breakaway colony.

title: LAWMAKERS SEEKING TO ADD OTB UPSTATE
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 9 (AP)Local lawmakers urged the state today to extend offtrack betting on horse racing into western New York. But racing spokesmen claimed New York's horseracing industry would die if this were done.

title: G,&W. UNIT SEEKS TALCOTT NATIONAL
description: The Associates First Capital Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire all the outstanding common stock of the Talcott National Corporation, a leading diversified financial concern, for cash and securities valued at about MI million. The agreement was apI proved by the boards of both companies yesterday and is subject to certain other conditions, including approval by Talcott's share holders. Associates is a subsidiary of Gulf & Western Industries, Inc. Under the agreement, each of Talcott's approximately three million outstanding common shares would be exchanged for $17 in cash and sixtenths of a Gulf & Western warrant that Is traded on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Responses to the Lessons of Eagleton
description: To the Editor:

title: Spaceships Named
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 10 (UPI)Apollo 17's astronauts today named their spaceships America and Challenger for next month's final Apollo moon landing flight.

title: The Uzbeks Turn Out in Force to Serve King Cotton
description: SAMARKAND, U.S.S.R., Nov. 4Despite a determined effort to mechanize agriculture, the harvesting of cotton here still depends on tedious, backbending, bollbyboll handpicking by tens of thousands of city people reinforcing peasants.

title: Notes on. People
description: The world's oldest reigning monarch, King Gustaf VI Adolf of Sweden, is to celebrate his 90th birthday in Stockholm today. Although his reign is thin on power and thick oh ceremony, the tall, bespectacled King is very popular. Many of the crowned heads of Scandinavia are due to attend his birthday party. Among the commoners expected are Presidents Urho Kekkonen of Finland, Kristian Eldjarn of Iceland, and Sweden's Premier, Olof Palme, whose Social Democratic party has long called for abolition of the monarchy. Mr. Palme was head of the committee that organized the birthday

title: LESS BORROWING SEEN BY BRIMER
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Nov. 10 The nation's capital markets may be approaching a watershed in which the demand for funds will moderate considerably, Andrew F. Brimmer said here today.

title: More Funds Are Sought For Mapping Wetlands
GRANT'S UP IN AIR OVER TWO RACES
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 10  In 1960, Hugh Grant of Bradford, Pa., an owner of both thoroughbred and standardbred horses, saw his Airman's Guide win the $23,250 Black Eyed Susan at Pimlico in the afternoon. Then he flew to New York and saw his Countess Adios capture the $141,786.15 Messenger Stakes at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: EASTERN ASKS C.A.B. FOR AID APPROVAL
description: Eastern Air Lines yesterday petitioned the Civil Aeronautics Board to advance additional funds to financially troubled Caribbean Atlantic Airlines, Inc. (Caribair).

title: Horsemen Here Would Replace Exacta With Quinella
description: Quinellas could be the answer to racing's exoticbet predicament, a survey of horsemen at Aqueduct indicated yesterday.

title: Business Briefs
description: TOKYO, Nov. 10 (AP)Japan's exports validated in October totaled $2.64billion, up 22.3 per cent from a year earlier but down from $2.73billion in September, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:Although I agree that efforts to encourage the development of health maintenance organizations (H.M.O.'s) have been hurt by lack of Congressional action, I must take strong exception to the allegation by Nancy Hicks in her news article in your Oct. 10 edition that the Administration, in the person of the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, is backing away from the concept of health maintenance organizations.

title: Stock Market Soars to Record High; Average Tops 1,000 Before Dropping
description: The DowJones industrial average broke through the 1,000 barrier yesterday, before is barrage of profit taking sent prices lower. The market's most closely watched indicator still managed to gain 7 points and finish at a record closing high of 995.26.

title: LookAlike Seized, Youth, 17, Held in 4 Rapes, Is Freed
description: A 17yearold Baruch College freshman held for a week on $60,000 bail on multiple rape charges was freed yesterday as the Queens District Attorney's office announced the arrest on other rape charges of a 20yearold Bronx gypsy cab driver who looks strikingly like the college student.

title: Keino in Farewell Race
description: LONDON, Nov. 10 (Reuters) Kipchoge Keino of Kenya, in the twilight of a career as one of the greatest distance run ners in history, makes his fare. well appearance tomorrow in Britain in the international athletes club cross country race. Keino, now 32 years old, will be battling with more than 1100 rivals.

title: N C.A.A. Denies, U. S.O. C. Charge Of Private Talks
description: KANSAS CITY, Nov. 10 (UPI)  The National Collegiate Athletic Association denounced today as not true an announcement by the United States Olympic Committee that secret negotiations were under way between the two groups. The N.C.A.A.. dropped out of the Olympic group recently.

title: 3D RAIL KILLS MAN RETRIEVING $5 BILL
description: An unidentified man was killed instantly yesterday in Brooklyn subway station when he jumped to the tracks to retrieve a $5 bill he had dropped, according to the police.

title: Dayan Wins $100,000 Trot
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Noe. 10 (AP)Dayan stormed down the stretch to capture the $100,000 American Trotting Classic at Hollywood Park tonight, spoiling the retirement of Super Bowl, who finished last after 18 straight victories,

title: Curran Makes 30 Saves As Fighting Saints Win, 51
description: WINNIPEG, Manatoba, Nov. 10 (UPI)  Minnesota's goalie, Mike Curran made 30 saves tonight as the Fighting Saints skated to a 51 World Hockey Association victory over the Winnipeg Jets.

title: BANGKOK SAYS AIDES SOLD MILK FROM U.N.
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 10 (Agence FrancePresse)  Thai officials responsible for the distribution of skimmed and powdered milk donated by a United Nations agency were accused today of selling it on the open market.

title: Dr. Erich M. Schlaikjer, 66, Brooklyn College Geologist
description: Dr. Erich M. Schlaikjer, a former professor of geology at BrooklynCollege, died Sunday at his home in Littleton, Colo. He was 66 years old.

title: Black Militants Deny Guilt In Killing of Four in Illinois
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (UPI)Four reputed members of the black militant group De Mau Mau pleaded not guilty today to charges of murdering four members of the Paul Corbett family in suburban Barrington Hills.

title: MARY J. SHIPLEY
description: Mary J. Shipley, for 20 years corporate secretary of Franklin Spier, Inc., an advertising agency specializing in books, died Wednesday at her home in Sarasota, Fla. She was 67 years old. Miss Shipley, who retired in 1968, had been active in the Publishers Advertising Club, the Women's National Book Association and children's libraries in New York.

title: CELTICS SET BACK BRAVES BY 106104
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 10 (UPI)Don Nelson's two free throws with 47 seconds left gave the Boston Celtics a 106104 National Basketball Association victory over the Buffalo Braves tonight.

title: TEACHERS RATIFY ROOSEVELT PACT
description: ROOSEVELT, L. I., Nov. 10 The monthlong strike by 254 teachers here ended early today when the Roosevelt Teachers Association ratified a threeyear contract calling for an overall 19 per cent salary increase.

title: OFFICER HEALTH CLUB REPORTED USING G.I.'S
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UPI) The General Accounting Office, the auditing arm of Congress, reported today that 24 enlisted men were assigned to fulltime duty as cooks, waiters, accountants, record clerks, stewards, desk clerks, room attendants and other service jobs at the Alaskan Chateau and Health Club at Elmendorf Air Force Base, Anchorage.

title: LIQUOR DEALERS FEAR 4. DRY SPELL
description: Owners of liquor stores and bars said yesterday that they feared a dry spell throughout the metropolitan region if warehouse men and drivers failed to end their strike within few days.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10 (AP)It used to be the hottest ticket in town. But the city will place about 4,000 tickets on sale Nov. 15 for the ArmyNavy football game at John F. Kennedy Stadium Dec. 2. The tickets, at $8.50 each, will be sold at 11 agencies. Robert W. Crawford, recreation commissioner, said there were twice as many available this year to Philadelphians.

title: AllStar Revue at Loew's To Aid Harlem Theater
description: With a river of red plushenough to carpet 30 football, fieldsand a lot of polish, Loew's Victoria Theater on I25th Street has been primed, for an allstar benefit revue, Monday night.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 10 (AP)Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif.; Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill.; Ilie. Nastase Rumania and Torn Okker of the Netherlands gained the semifinals of the $63,500 Stockholm tennis tournament today. Smith beat 33yearold Nikki Pilic of Yugoslavia, 63, 76. Riessen outlasted Roger Taylor of Britain, 64, 3.6, 63. Nastase downed Cliff Drysdale of South Africa, 6.3, 6.4, and Okker defeated 23yearold Andrew Pattison of Rhodesia, 6.3, 62.

title: Jersey Women Golfers Elect Mrs. Jerome Tripp
description: SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Nov. 10 Mrs. Jerome. C. L. Tripp of Baltusrol was elected president of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association today at the 50th anniversary meeting at the Baltusrol Golf Club. The other officers chosen were Mrs. Wilson Elmore of Essex County, first vice president; Mrs. Bradford Harrington of Essex Fells, tournament chairman and second vice president; Mrs. Robert Weldon of Echo Lake, secretary; Mrs. Robert Mc. K. Thomas of Baltusrol, treasurer and Mrs. William Littlefield of Montclair, chairman of admissions.

title: Political Censorship
description: Even among unionists there is diminishing disposition these days to regard the crossing of a picket line as mortal sin, to be shunned under any and all circumstances. Pickets often march for reasons that are arbitrary, frivolous or venal. And even where a legitimate labormanagement dispute is involved, few outsiders are in position to judge its merits. That is especially true when members of other unions in the same enterprise are ignoring the picket signs and reporting for work.

title: Hartford Campus Duel: Squaring Off With Pie
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 10 (UPI) The president of the University of Hartford has accepted a challenge to a duel with a student leader at high noon Monday on the campus. The weapons: custard pies at three feet.

title: Kin of Astronauts Killed in 1967 Fire Awarded $300,000
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 10 (AP)The families of two astronauts who died in an Apollo capsule fire at Cape Kennedy in January, 1967, received monetary awards totaling $300,000 today from the builders of the spacecraft.

title: Mrs. Thomas S. Lamont Dies; A Public Service Leader Here
description: Mrs. Thomas S. Lamont, widow of the banker and a leader in many public service causes in this city, died in Boston yesterday after a brief illness. She was 71 years old and lived at 101 East, 72d Street.

title: Air Force Picks STOL Developers
description: The Air Force announced yesterday that it had picked the Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to start development of rival versions of an advanced short takeoff and landing transport plane.

title: NEWARK HOUSING STIRS NOT DEBATE
description: NEWARK, Nov. 10The two men who symbolize the racial polarization in this city confronted each other belligerently in an unscheduled debate in City Hall today over the fate of a blacksponsored housing project in a white neighborhood.

title: Where to Invest Is Problem in U.S.
description: The United States copper industry is being forced to change its ways of doing business.

title: The Abortion Front
description: An Intensely emotional issue in several of the New York legislative races last Tuesday was the fate of this state's abortion reform law. Both righttolife, antiabortion groups and feminist, proabortion groups played active roles in these key contests. In general, the proabortion forces won. There were two tossup races Nassau County in which incumbents who had favored abortion reform were being challenged by candidates pledged to vote for its repeal; the incumbents won both. In the Bronx, similar challenges were also turned back.

title: Board of Estimate Hears Debate On Yorkville Housing Proposal
description: East Side residents packed City Hall from morning to dusk yesterday for a hearing on $43million development package for 1,200 apartments and a new public school on the site of a city asphalt plant at 90th Street and the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive.

title: 5 Bombs Sent to Geneva
description: GENEVA, Nov. 10The federal authorities warned the public to be on the lookout for boobytrapped letters afer five had been intercepted at the airport postal center here.

title: The Church's War on Women
description: TEANECK, N. J.Pope Paul VI has reaffirmed the rules of priestly celibacy and debarred women from formal investiture by bishops in Roman Catholic orders. There were to be no female deacons, let alone female priests.

title: Knicks Send 76ers to 15th Straight Loss, 125106
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10Adversity in large doses continued to plague Coach Roy Rubin and his victoryless Philadelphia 76ers tonight as they were beaten, 125106, by the New York Knicks, for their 15th consecutive National Basketball Association defeat.

title: Treasury Plans to Raise $4.5Billion in Bill Sales
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10The Treasury announced today that it would raise $4.5billion in cash through two sales later this month of taxanticipation bills maturing in April and June.

title: LARGE OIL REFINERY PLANNED IN CANADA
description: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia (Canadian Press)A company headed by John M. Shaheen, New York industrialist, will construct a $223million oil refinery in the Canso Strait area of eastern Nova Scotia, it was announced today.

title: Carol Rosenberger Performs Schubert And Bach at Piano
description: Of the three largescale works on Carol Rosenberger's program in Tully Hall on Thursday night, Schubert's posthumous A major Sonata came last and fared the best. Everything the pianist played could not have been more lucidly laid out or more tonally attractive in this, her third New York recital in as many years, but her approach to each score, however intelligent, seemed plagued with some weakness.

title: Price Lag in Zaire Hurts Economy
description: KINSHASA, ZaireIncreased production of copper by this African country is serving to offset the effects of lower prices for the metal. But with imports still at a high level despite efforts to restrict them, Zaire the former Belgian Congoappears to be heading for her first trade deficit since 1967.

title: Survey Shows 16.8% of Jews In U.S. Wed Outside the Faith
description: TORONTO, Nov. 10  The first phase of a demographic profile released today disclosed that 16.8 per cent of American Jews married nonJews.

title: Responses to the Lessons of Eagleton
description: To the Editor:

title: Syria Vows More Support
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 10

title: Gonzalez Takes Ring Title
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 10 (UPI)Rodolfo Gonzalez of Long Beach, Calif., captured the World Boxing Council lightweight championship tonight when Chango Carmona of Mexico was unable to leave his corner at the start of the 13th round at the Sports Arena.

title: High Court Refuses To Delay a Sentence On Pentagon Papers
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 The. Supreme Court refused today to delay the execution of a contempt judgment against Harvard University political scientist who had refused to answer a grand jury's questions relating to the Pentagon papers.

title: Dispute on Program Authority Splits Public TV and Fund Arm
description: A controversy over programing authority has pitted the Public Broadcasting Service against its funding agency, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

title: Foyt Wins Texas 500 Pole With 170.273 M.P.H. Lap
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Nov. 10 (UPI).A. Foyt drove a 1971 Mercury Cyclone to a qualifying speed of 170.273 miles on hour today and won the pole position for Sunday's Texas 500 NASCAR race at the Texas World Speedway.

title: INJUNCTION URGED FOR PEPSICO DEAL
description: The staff of the Federal Trade Commission has urged that the commission seek to enjoin Pepsico, Inc., from acquiring the Rheingold Corporation until the legality of the merger can be determined.

title: HENRY BUCKLEY
description: SITGES, Spain, Nov. 10 (AP) Henry Buckley, retired correspondent of the British news agency Reuters, died after a long illness yesterday at his home in this eastern Spanish summer resort. He was 69 years old.

title: FRANK BRUNCKHORST
description: Frank Brunckhorst, president of the Boar's Head Provision Company of Brooklyn, meat processors, died Thursday in the Long Island Jewish Hospital, New Hyde Park. He was 65 years old and lived at 83 Westminster Road, Garden City, L.I.

title: A NEW VIRUS LINK WITH CANCER SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10Vi rus material that could be, the instructions for starting the cancer process has been found in human cancer cells, a team of scientists reported today.

title: ZUMWALT REBUKES TOP NAVY LEADERS ON RACIAL UNREST
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., the Chief of Naval Operations, using strong, brutally frank language, charged the Navy's senior commanders today with failures in leadership and with ignoring his directives on racial relations.

title: Voter Explains Why She Wasn't
description: SHAWNEE MISSION, Kan. Faced with a choice between Richard Nixon and George McGovern, Mrs. Wayne Tobin stayed away from the polls Tuesday.

title: Responses to the Lessons of Eagleton
description: To the Editor:

title: British Bill Rate Falls
description: LONDON, Nov. 10 (Reuters) The average rate at today's tender of British Treasury bills fell to 6.8638 per cent from 6.8838 per cent last week.

title: Business Briefs
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 10 (Reuters)Canada has sold 62.7 million bushels of wheat worth $150million to the People's Republic of China, Otto Lang, minister responsible for the Canadian Wheat Board, announced today.

title: Newark Asks for a Study Of Bankruptcy Procedure
description: TRENTON, Nov. 10Highly placed sources reported tonight that Newark's Department of Finance had requested a formal exploration of the legal procedures involving the possibility of a state takeover of city government there that is faced with the danger of fiscal bankruptcy.

title: Portent in Puerto Rico
