description: Puerto Rico's voters have delivered an unexpectedly emphatic verdict whose significance should not be lost either on official Washington or the United Nations. Rafael Hernandez Colon not only won the Governorship at 36 in a stunning upset but led the Popular Democratic party to a smashing victory that included control both houses of Congress and 72 of 78 municipalities.

title: Truck Tonnage Reported lip
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10The American Trucking Association, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage last week was 10.4 per cent above the corresponding week of last year. Truck tonnage last week was 2.5 per cent ahead of the immediately preceding week.

title: Bantustan Chief Accepts Apartheid, Seeks More Land
GAINS ARE SHOWN BY AMEX AND 0T0
description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market advanced yesterday in steppedup trading.

title: Stock Index Tops 1,000, Then Falls
description: The DowJones industrial average soared through 1,000 yesterday and then fell in late profit taking to end at a new closing high of 995.26, erasing the former closing mark of 995.15 set on Feb. 9, 1966.

title: U.N. Picks Nairobi as Site of New Environmental Unit
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 10The General Assembly's Economic Committee, overriding the strenuous objec tions of many Western countries, including the United States, voted today to set up the headquarters of the new United Nations Environmental Program in Nairobi, Kenya.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 10 (AP)The World Hockey Association said it was willing to settle differences with the National Hockey League out of court. But it warned that if the N.H.L. insisted on continuing court action to preserve its controversial reserve clause, it would seek to invalidate all N.H.L. contracts.

title: SCRAMBLE BEGINS FOR BOGGS'S POST
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10A major scramble for a House leadership post opened today when Representative Sam M. Gibbons of Florida announced that he would seek the presumably vacant job of House majority leader.

title: Engagements
description: DANASHAMDONThe engagement Is announced betWeen Joe, son or Mrs. Felix Dana or 7, Rule Lalo, Paris, and Stella, second daughter of Mr. & Mrs. Niazl Sha. moon oe 13, Doper Betrays Street, London.

title: Mayor Accepts U.S. Gift With Complaint
description: The Federal Government formally deeded to the city yesterday a small part of an abandoned Staten Island military airfield on which the city plans to build a $30million high school.

title: Flood Inquiry to Begin
description: LOGAN, W. Va., Nov. 10 (AP) A special Logan County grand jury will convene here Monday to begin investigating the Buffalo Creek flood disaster of last, February, in which 118 persons were killed.

title: Business Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 10 (UPI)James J. Needham, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, arrived in Moscow today for discussions with Soviet banking officials on financing increased AmericanSoviet trade.

title: WDD Freehold Victor
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., Nov. 10 (AP) WDD won the $3,500 Palermo Pace by a nose at Freehold Raceway today to pay backers $5.40, $3.20 and $2.60 for $2 across the board. Driven by Herve Filion, WDD paced the mile in 2:06 1/5. Wonder Colt returned $3 and $2.60 for place and Grantham Lobell $3 for show.

title: Giants Are Still in Race In Spite of Bad Trades
description: Winding up their altered preparations for the most important game they've had to play in nearly two years, the New York Giants yesterday found themselves hoping for strong performances in Washington tomorrow by John Mendenhall, Larry Jacobson, Jim Files, Ron Hornsby, Pat Hughes and Rich Houstonnot to mention Ron Johnson, Jack Gregory, Norn Snead, Don Herrmann, Bob Tucker, Henry Reed, Dick EnAerie and Joe Taftoni, among others.

title: OCCIDENTAL OIL TURNS A PROFIT
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation had a profit of $269,000 in the third quarter of this year, which was insufficient to cover preferreddividend requirements of $4.8million, the company reported late yesterday. In the yearearlier period, the diversified naturalresources company incurred an $8.4million loss.

title: Responses to the Lessons of Eagleton
description: To the Editor:

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: East Side residents packed City Hall for the Board of Estimate's hearings on a proposed $43million development package for 1,200 apartments and a new public school on the site of a city asphalt plant at 90th Street and the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive.

title: NAVY DISCIPLINES DISSIDENT SAILORS
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 10The first of 129 sailors who staged a dockside sitdown and refused to return to duty aboard the aircraft carrier Constellation were brought before a captain's mast disciplinary session today for punishment.

title: EXXON UNIT RAISES PRICES OF BENZENE
description: The Enjay Chemical Company, a unit of t'he Exxon Corporation, announced yesterday that it had increased its prices of benzene by 0.75 cents a gallon over current list prices.

title: Promise of 10c a Poster Cleans Up G.O.P. Campaign
description: WATERLOO, Iowa, Nov. 10 (AP)  Roger Pease, chairman of the Black Hawk County Republican party, announced Wednesday that 10 cents would be paid for each G.O.P. campaign sign and poster turned in to party headquarters, as an ecology move.

title: NEWARK HOUSING STIRS HOT DEBATE
description: NEWARK, Nov. 10The two men who symbolize the racial polarization in this city confronted each other belligerently in an unscheduled debate in City Hall today over the fate of a blacksponsored housing project in a white neighborhood.

title: Metropolitan Briefs

He leaves a job in many ways undoable. The battle against budget cuts and for maintenance of New York's parks has been, and still is, a fight against disaster; but he set his standards high.

Through the years there have always been doubts raised about Carnegie Hall as a venue for chamber music. The auditorium is too big; it lacks the intimacy that belongs to chamber music. But through the years string quartets have been appearing there, making the discussions academic.

title: Books of The Times
description: In this study of the large foundations ($100million or more), Waldemar A. Nielsen has exposed for scrutiny the history, workings and rationale of institutions we have heard a lot of and know little about. It makes good intellectual fare. It is not often that scholarship is treated in such an inviting way or that so austere a subject is presented in so genial a fashion. Mr. Nielsen, a scholar who has written about Africa and who is a former officer of the Ford Foundation, sees the groups not as disembodied structures but as enterprises set up and administered by human beings. The interplay between the personalities of the founders, the social functions of the institutions and which they operate makes for sparkling reading.

title: Nixon's Government Reorganization, 1973 and 1969
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Nov. 10 Government reorganization was hardly one of President Nixon's major campaign issues. But there is a certain symmetry to his efforts to make this the first order of business following his reelection, in the sense that he made similar reform his first priority following his inauguration nearly four years ago. When the President embarked on restructuring his executive office and Cabinet departments in early 1969, there was widespread suspicion that his wellpublicized emphasis on the forms of government was designed to divert public attention from what critics considered the rather modest content of his substantive proposals.

title: Screen: Kotto's 'Limit':Subject of Moderation Comes to Criterion
description: Yaphet Kotter's new movie, his first as a director, is called "The Limit." It might better have been called "The Center," because although it deals in contemporary violence, its real subject is the power of a sane pacific moderation. Though never anything special, it is an oddly pleasant, occasionally exciting movie to watch.Kotto is his own leading man. As Mark Johnson, a decent black Los Angeles motorcycle cop (the film was originally called "Speed Limit: 65," also a poor title) with a white cop (Quinn Redeker) as best friend, and a girl (Pamela Jones) who loves him, his life consists of major satisfactions and only minor irritations until he runs afoul of a motorcycle gang headed by one Big Donnie (Ted Cassidy). Though a bike bum by profession, Big Donnie has a streak of innate nobility. He also has a very pregnant, kvetchy motorcycle mama (Corinne Cole) who wants him to quit riding and start working so he can support her.But when Big Donnie awkwardly, tentatively approaches Johnson for advice, trouble brews among the bikers. Led by a second in command (Virgil Frye) they begin to threaten Mark Johnson's girl and Big Donnie's unborn babyand there follows a multiple revenge climax that is familiar in its elements, but is more restrained, less violent than most.The last third of the movie is a little difficult to follow. It seems to have been heavily cut, edited almost into insensibility, and this, in a film largely about moral relationships, proves very nearly fatal.Nevertheless, it seems worth saying a word for "The Limit," a film absolutely without pretenses, relatively without illusions, shocking only in its ability to find occasions for good feeling. Yaphet Kotto, though very inexpert, isn't the world's worst director. His achievement here has been not to rise above, but to humanize and slightly enliven the formulas that govern this kind of movie making."The Limit" opened yesterday at the Criterion Theater.

title: The Screen:Abstraction Prevails in Film Forum Shorts
description: In its latest collection of avant-garde short subjects, that mecca for experimentalists, the Film Forum, is illustrating again the theory that the abstract can speak more loudly, if not necessarily more clearly, than words. And if Stan Brakhage, a master of the so-called "subjective" camera, who has been at this specialized moviemaking for more than 20 of his 39 years, is the nominal star attraction of the program, he is also its most abstract contributor.In "The Riddle of Lumen," his individual technique illuminates his definition of the film as "a quest for an understanding of the nature of light and vision." Vision and color are artistically heightened as he captures varying light on objects, people, water, streets, skies and forest. But there seems to be more riddle than meaning in "The Process," his abstruse, staccato succession of quick cuts, lights, flashes, color panels, negative film and vaguely perceived human figures.While she is equally abstract, Rosalind Schneider, a painter, evokes visual pleasure in both "Orbitas" and "Still Life," studies of color and objects that often come vividly alive through her sensitive handling of her somewhat mysterious subjects.The most professionally rounded works of the eight 16mm. films on the bill, to this viewer, at least, are John Steinberg's "Trees" and "Water." His varied vignettes of shimmering autumn foliage and rippling seascapes may be repetitive on occasion, but they most often are observations of nature that are lucid and lyrical, not commonplace.Uncommon man is tackled in Vlatko Gilic's Yugoslav-made "One More Day," an eerie documentation of swarms of vilalgers wallowing in the mud and waters of a pond, presumably seeking cures for their ills. It is a fragmentary report, but its somber mood and ritualistic overtones are sharp and arresting. And in "Christopher Tree," Les Blank's observations of the titular musician who plays an amazing number of gongs, bells, cymbals and tympani against a sylvan setting, the subject and his music are unusual even if the camera work isn't.The Film Forum's package from the moviemaking underground is, as usual, interesting, but its parts are a good deal better than the whole.

title: WINE TALK
description: VOUGEOT, FranceThis little Burgundian village is not much more than a wide spot in the road, halfway between Beaune and Dijon. But it is in the center of what is probably the greatest wine region of France, and on certain nights of the year it is a mecca for the wine lovers of the world: the nights when the Chevaliers du Tastevin gather here to do honor to the wines of Burgundy.

title: F.T.C. Acts on Loan
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission has ruled that a loan arranged before United States Steel Corporation acquired one of its customers, Certified Industries, Inc., a producer of readymixed concrete, had substantially the same anticompetilive effect as the acquisition itself, it was announced today.

title: MISUSE OF CAR FEES LAID TO TWO BANKS
description: Two Long Islandbased banks, the First National Bank of Bay Shore and the Bank of Smithtown, have been accused by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz of misusing more than $18,000 collected from some 9,000 carbuyers over a fouryear period.

title: Wallace Brockway Dead at 67; Editor, Author in Field of Music
description: Wallace Brockway, editor, author and a wellknown figure in the field, of music, died Sunday Of a heart attack at his home, 400 East 57th Street. He was 67 years old.

title: Liz Ashton Wins On Scotch Valley In Toronto Show
description: TORONTO, Nov. 10LizAshton of the. Canadian equestrian team, and Mrs. Graziano Mancinelli, wife of Italy's Olympic goldmedal winner, both displayed superb riding form and coolness today. and won the first two international classes at the Royal Winter Fair horse show.

title: Bucks Beat Bullets
description: MILWAUKEE, Nov. 10 (AP)A balanced attack led by Lucius Allen's 24 points, and a defense that held Baltimore without a field goal for eight minutes, gave the Milwaukee Bucks a 12082 victory over the Bullets tonight,

title: Mutinous Sailors
description: The refusal of 130 sailors to board the aircraft carrier Constellation in San Diego the other day exposes dangerous flaw in President Nixon's conviction that he maintaining a strong America by giving top priority defense spending and by persisting in the search for military success in Southeast Asia.

title: Colonels Beat Cougars, 122117, Despite Cunningham's 42 Points
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Nov. 10 (AP) Billy Cunningham scored 42 points tonight, breakI ing his previous high set last week, but it wasn't enough to keep the Kentucky Colonels, from downing the Caroline] Cougars, 122117.

title: Koreas Are Calling Off Trace Line Broadcasts
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 10 (UPI)South Korea and North Korea announcedjointly today that they would stop broadcasting propaganda at each other at midnight tonight.

title: Dispute on Program Authority Splits Public TV and Fund Arm
description: A controversy over programing authority has pitted the Public Broadcasting Service against its funding agency, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

title: Indians Charge Administration Is Attempting to Divide Tribes
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10Charges and countercharges were heard today as attempts were made to fix the blame for the Indian taketwer of the Bureau of Indian Affairs Building and the looting or destruction of files, historical records and art objects.

title: Tentative Accord Set
description: The Taft Broadcasting Company announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire Cedar Point, Inc., in Sandusky, Ohio, operators of one of the country's largest amusement parks and recreational complexes. Taft said the transaction would involve is suance of about 1,284,000 of its shares. Based on Taft's closing price of yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, the transaction is valued at almost $70million.

title: Tarns Top Chaps, 122115
description: MEMPHIS, Nov. 10 (UPI)George Thompson and a reserve center, Lee Davis provided. the offensive punch tonight to give the Memphis Tams a 122115 victory over the Dallas Chaparrals.

title: WINE TALK
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 10  Mrs. Ronald Pruitt sat quietly off to one side at the wine auction on the third floor of Sakowitz's Post Oak store here last night. In her black lace dress and black stockings, she did nothing to attract attention until Lot 154 came up for bids. And, then, did she attract attention!

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:The current Charter Review Commission was created to establish Structure whereby the citizens of New York City would be able to participate in the decisionmaking process. Although the first priority in appointment of members to the commission is the demonstration of commitment to and depth of knowledge of the overall. city, an equally important criterion is a response to the rational desire for equal representation on the commission.

title: The Peace That Was at Hand but That Proved Elusive: Some Questions and Answers
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 More than two weeks have passed since President Nixon's chief adviser on foreign policy, Henry A. Kissinger, said peace is at hand in Vietnam. The Admin istration remains optimistic but a settlement has so far remained elusive. The following is an effort to sort out what is known about the current situation:

title: Georgia Asking $2Million From Ship That Hit Bridge
description: BRUNSWICK, Ga., Nov. 10 (UPI)  The state of Georgia filed a $2million suit today against a ship that struck a drawbridge and sent a string of vehicles and their occupants plunging into the waters of the Brunswick River. At least 11 persons died in the mishap Tuesday, but only five bodies have been recovered.

title: The Dance: Joffrey II
description: There are two Joffrey Ballet companies. The first, very visible in New York, is, of course, the City Center Joffrey Ballet. The second is the socalled Joffrey II Company, which tours the country and only occasionally pops up in the metropolitan area. In Septerriber, it danced in Central Park, and this week it hasbeen giving a series of morning and afternoon performances at the New York City Center.

title: Bridge: A Philadelphia Squad Ties a With Aces in Exhibition
description: LANCASTER, Pa., Nov. 10 The Fall National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League bepan here today with 674 pairs entered in the national mixed pairs, the first of five major events to be decided in a 10day period.

title: 5.000 Doctors In Britain Face Dismissal Over Fee
description: LONDON, Nov. 10 (Reuters) About one in 12 of Britain's doctors today faced professional dismissal for refusing to pay a new $12 annual registration fee.

title: U.S.Soviet Pact Near On Building Embassies
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10An agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union on the construction of new embassy buildings in Washington and Moscow is near completion, a State De partment source said tonight.

title: FloodWarning Unit Put in Brook Railed To Note Water Rise
Art: Aquatint Commentary on Poems
description: So many separate points interest are joined in the new Robert Motherwell exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art that the event seems to call for an inventory almost more than for a review. The exhibition, which is beautifully installed in the museum's Prints and Drawings Galleries, consists of a series of aquatints (plus studies for the series) executed as a visual commentary on a cycle of poems called A la Pintura (To Painting) by the contemporary Spanish poet Rafael Alberti. The entire work of 24 large unbound pages was recently published in an edition of 40 copies Universal Limited Art Editions.

title: FREDERICK PRITHAM, COUNTRY DOCTOR, 92
description: GREENVILLE, Me., Nov. 10 (AP)  Dr. Frederick Pritham, Maine's most famous country doctor, died last night at the Charles'A. Dean Hospital here. He was 92 years old.

title: Burger Shop in Harlem Shows It Can Cut the Mustard
description: After investing $170,000 in a McDonald's franchise restaurant that opened last March on Harlem's busy West 125th Street, three partners had to combat the Savage Skulls, the Wild Bunch and the Saigons to survive.

title: Suns Beat Rockets
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 10 (AP)Charlie Scott contributed 14 points during a 32point Phoenix Suns rally in the fourth quarter tonight as they beat the Houston Rockets, 115 to 109.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Nov. 10 (Agence FrancePresse)The 1972 Olympics broke all gate records, officials reported today. More than 4.4 million tickets were sold and receipts totaled $16.6million. Attendance was at 89.6 per cent of capacity, compared to 40.7 per cent at the 1968 Games in Mexico.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Going to Market in Russia: Food Shoppers Prefer to Stand on Line
description: MOSCOWThe two middleaged women examined the small carton of cake mix on the store shelf, read the description of contents and the directions and then decided against it.

title: DR. RICHARD FROST, A SOCIAL SCIENTIST
description: SYRACUSE, Nov. 10 (AP)Dr. Richard T. Frost, a political scientist and executive of the Syracuse University Research Corporation, was found dead at his home yesterday of undetermined cause. He was 45 years old. The Medical Examiner's office said chemical tests would be performed.

title: FLORENCE LENNON, THEATER ROXANNE
description: Florence Lennon, an entertainer who used the name of Roxanne when she led a 26man orchestra in the 1930's, died Thursday at Roosevelt Hospital, where she had been a patient since suffering a stroke three months ago. She was 81 years old and had lived at the Wellington Hotel, Seventh Avenue at 54th Street, for more than 30 years.

title: Man Hurt as 18 Letter Bombs Arrive in London and Geneva
description: LONDON, Nov. 10At least IS letter bombs addressed to Jewish companies, organizations and individuals, and assumed to have been sent by the Arab Black September group, reached London and Geneva today. All were mailed from India, and one of them exploded in the hands of the managing director of a diamond company here, wounding him.

title: University of Rochester Pays Tribute to Benefactor
description: ROCHESTER, Nov. 10The University of Rochester paid tribute today to one of this city's most famous citizens, the late Joseph C. Wilson, with a day of activities.

title: Yablonski Case Trials Set
description: ERIE, Pa., Nov. 10 (UPI)An Erie County judge today set separate trials for two United Mine Workers officials charged in the 1969 murders of Joseph A. Yablonski and his wife and daughter. Albert Pass, 53 years old, a U.M.W. international executive board member from Middleboro, Ky., will go trial Feb. 26, 1973, and William J. Prater, 52, a U.M.W. field representative from Follette, Tenn., will be tried sometime after the May term of the Erie County Criminal Court.

title: LookAlike Seized, Youth, 17, Held in 4 Rapes, Is Freed
description: A 17yearold Baruch College freshman held for a week on $60,000 bail on multiple rape charges was freed yesterday as the Queens District Attorney's office announced the arrest on other rape charges of a 20yearold Bronx gypsy cab driver who looks strikingly like the college student.

title: Auto Output Drop Seen
description: DETROIT, Nov. 10 (AP)1 Domestic automobile production was expected to drop about 2,000 units this week because of brief strikes by the United Auto Workers against the General Motors Corporation, according to the trade paper, (Automotive News.

title: U.S.Lists Trade Objectives And Timetable for GATT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10President Nixon's principal trade official proposed to the other main trading nations today a timetable.for the major negotiations scheduled to begin next year and outlined five major United States objectives.

title: Responses to the Lessons of Eagleton
description: To the Editor:

title: Equity Financing
description: Wells Fargo & Co. filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission 910,000 common shares to be offered for sale by an underwriting network headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith. The number of shares reflects a twoforone stock split scheduled Nov. 29.

title: Firm in Nashville Accused by S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10The Securities and Exchange Commission brought an insider trading case today against Tennessee brokerage firm that is a member of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Music: Mexican Artists
description: Concert Artists of Mexico, a new series being presented this season by the Carnegie Hall Corporation in cooperation with the Cultural Counselor of Mexico in New York, began at Carnegie Revital Hall Thursday night with a program of sonatas for violin and piano played by Manuel and Jorge Suarez.

title: Music: Rudolf Steps In
description: In the recent past, the New York Philharmonic sometimes looked like a school for young conductors, what with Leonard Bernstein's penchant for training assistants and keeping them in reserve. Pierre Boulez, Mr. Bernstein's successor as music director, has not named an assistant, and on Thursday night that lack of a backstop proved unfortunate.

title: The Boxwood Maze
description: Now why should sensitive, ingenuous Lee Appleton feel a quick stab of fear upon her arrival at Waverly, Aunty Gloria's spooky castle on the Hudson? Is it because Wilson, the chauffeur, gave her a funny look? Or is it the suspicious behavior of Davenport, the family overseer? The unexpected presence of Miss Tomkins, a sinister busybody out of Rebecca"? The increasing dottiness of Aunty? The disappearance of a precious artifact? The attempt made on her life?

title: Whose Siegfried Will It Be?
description: THE new production of Wagner's Siegfried which will be unveiled Friday at the Met is not really new at all. It was built and ready to go on stage during the fall of 1969. What kept it in mothballs for three years involves a tale of assorted woes much akin to the misfortunes that plagued Carmen, the company's only other new production of the season. Carmen, however, is a parade of hit tunes, unlike Wagner's fivehour monster epicpossibly the composer's least popular opera.

title: McIntosh, Rome or Delicious
description: Apples have traditionally been used as garnishes, cocktail dippers and ingredients in such diverse dishes as curries, soups and salads. But it is in desserts that they can be fully exploited. Gingerapple cream is a sophisticated version of applesauce; the meringue crowned poached apple an Alaska without ice cream.

title: The World
description: Since the 1967 Arab Israeli war, intermittent hostilities have continued in the Middle East. There have been exchanges of artillery fire across the Suez Canal. There have been Israeli raids into Jordan following Arab terrorism. More recently came Israeli attacks in southern Lebanon. And in the past two weeks the rolling thunder of artillery fire and airplane rockets has swung northeast to echo over Syria.

title: Pressures on Canada
description: Relations between the United States and Canada would have entered a difficult new phase after the elections in the two countries, whatever the respective outcomes at the polls. The difficulties could be compounded, however, by the juxtaposition of President Nixon's landslide reelection and the advent of minority government in Ottawa. It is clearly in the best interests of both countries to handle this situation with maximum circumspection.

title: Skiing, by Design And by Accident
description: Skiers create black on white patternshundreds of darkclad figures marching en masse across the snow in a crosscountry exercise, a lone downhill racer contemplating his next plunge, a family romping through an orchard. But the ultimate, inevitable pattern for novice and expert, young and old, is the one where man and snow meet, not only black on white but back on white.

title: LAWYERS SCORED BY VANDENHEUVEL
description: William J. vanden Heuvel, the chairman of the City Board of Correction, cited the case of defendant who has spent two years in the Tombs without trial, in charging yesterday that many criminal lawyers in the City have abandoned their impoverished clients.

title: A Dry Town Is Wet After a Long Fight
description: GREENWICH TOWNSHIP  I guess people won't be brownbagging any more, said Robert Thomas, the Mayor of this tiny (population: 963) rural community nestled in the heart of Cumberland County's rich tomato and corn farming region.

title: Penn State Routs No. Carolina State, 37 to 22, for Eighth Straight
THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: THE decisiveness of President Nixon's victory last Tuesday's election may exert considerable influence in the evolution and the execution national economic policy as he enters his second Administration.

title: William Gibbs Weds Ann Piderit
description: Miss Ann Mary Piderit, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick William Piderit Jr. of Richmond Hill, Queens, was married at noon yesterday to William Barton Gibbs, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Lewis Gibbs, also of Richmond Hill.

title: Lady Churchill Breaks Hip
description: LONDON, Nov. 11 (Agence FrancePresse)Lady SpencerChurchill, widow of Sir Winston Churchill, broke a hip bone today when she fell at her London home. She was taken to Westminster Hospital, where after an operation her condition was described as satisfactory. Lady Churchill is 87 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Palestine Arab grievance is the one and only root of the IsraeliArab conflict. The present horrors and attendant complications of the conflict are offshoots of the one and same root, namely the Palestine grievance to which your editorial of Oct. 18 rightly alluded.

title: Television
description: OCCASIONALLY I get the impression, from letters and direct comments, that some readers are not keenly interested in the technological side of broadcasting. In fact, the subject seems to bore them. Tell us about the programs, goes the implied command, about what you think  or what we should thinkabout that which we are about to receive, or have already received but not completely digested.

title: Iconoclastic Princeton Weekly Survives All the Brickbats
description: PRINCETON  The Princeton Alumni Weekly, founded in 1900, is the oldest weekly magazine in New Jersey and the fourth oldest extant in the nation.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Responding to Haim Ginott's article, A Lecturer's Notes, Or What You Learn If You Talk a Lot (Travel section, Oct. 22), is probably as simpleminded as his article. But behind it all I am simply puzzled as to why you would print such a silly, puffedup Ladies Home Journalman's meanderings. I try to picture just who the adoring audience is that he imagines himself addressing.

title: ...And Russians, Too
description: Patience is not necessarfly a characteristic of American businessmen. But we have to change our attitude in dealings with the Russians.

title: Boggs Search to Continue
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Nov. 11 (UPI)The Air Force says that it has no plan to suspend the search for the missing plane carrying the House majority leader, Hale Boggs, and three others, but it has cut down the scope of its activities. The Air Force has made 938 sorties, logged 3,275 hours and covered more than 192,000 square miles in looking for the missing men.

title: F. &
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., Nov. 11 (AP)  Franklin and Marshall capped an unbeaten football season today with a 260 victory over Muhlenberg as Jay Baumgardner scored three touchdowns. It was the ninth triumph for F & M.

title: Visit by High Soviet Clerics Postponed Due to Illness
description: Metropolitan Nikodim, the chairman of a group of religious leaders from the Soviet Union that was to have come to the United States today, has suffered a heart attack, it was announced here yesterday, and the visit has been postponed.

title: $750,000 Loan Spurs Housing
description: A $750,000 loan, without collateral or bonding, given to a minority businessman who had a dream, has resulted in the conversion of an abandoned building shell into a fine 30unit lowincome apartment house in the Brownsville section or Brooklyn. Even more important, the loan will probably result in the construction of 500 similar units throughout the BrownsvilleEast New YorkCrown Heights areas.

title: EightWeek Shutdown of Schools Is Approved in Detroit After Rejection by Voters of New Funds
description: DETROIT, Nov. 11The Detroit Board of Education has voted to close the city's 300 public schools for eight weeks starting Dec. 21 unless money can be found to make up part or all of an $80million deficit.

title: NIGHTMARE
description: To THE EDITOR: As witness to a performance of Dude during previews (actually preO'Horgan previews), I had fierce tremulations which manifested themselves in a nightmare in which Dude received unanimous raves with Clive Barnes leading the pack.

title: Payroll Deductions Backed For Lottery in Michigan
description: DEARBORN, Mich. Nov. 11 (UPI)  The richest statesponsored lottery in the United States, scheduled to open Nov. 24 in Michigan, has brought a new twist to legalized gambling herepayroll deductions for purchases of lottery tickets by city employes.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: George McGovern did not lose this election because he lacked credibility or could not appeal to the great middle of the American electorate although these factors were imoortant.

title: Course for Nurses
description: HACKENSACKThe New Jersey Regional Medical Program, sponsored a coronarycare courseit ended early this month  for licensed practical nurses at Hackensack Hospital.

title: State Department Aide Retires With Accolades
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP)Margaret J. Catucci a manstay of State Department press operations under nine Secretaries of State, retired yesterday with accolades from her bosses and from her clientele in the world press.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: I know exactly how Richard R. Lingeman feels. On the way back from lunch recently I walked through 67th Street, alive with police as usual, and turned down Park Avenue. At 63rd. Street a hideous tableau suddenly erupted. Two burly young blacks grabbed a short, stocky, grayhaired man; one, from behind, locked his arm around the man's throat. I couldn't see what the other was doing. While he could, the man yelled for help. The day was a bright, sunny one, and Park Avenue was anything but deserted at 2 o'clock in the afternoon. But no one paid any attention. grabbed the back of the throttler's leather jacket; seeing that, a man grabbed at the other man and shouted, Leave him alone! Leave him

title: Metropolitan Gets A Prize Greek Vase
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has acquired a Greek vase from about the year 500 B.C., which Thomas P. F. Hoving, the director, termed the finest example of its kind in existence anywhere.

title: Revival of a Ball Attracts the International Horse Set
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11The International Ball Committee, after being out of the charity benefit race for five years, was off and running Friday night. It brought in a $50,000 winner. Until its temporary demise, for a variety of reasons including committee member squabbles, the ball  always given on the eve of the running of the international race at the Laurel Race Course  was the most elegant and most chic benefit in the Washington area.

title: David H. Gerson to Wed Ellen Merrill
description: LAKE SUCCESS, L. I., Nov. 11  Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Merrill of Lake Success and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Merrill, to David Howard Gerson. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Gerson of Lake Success and Coral Gables, Fla.

title: The World
description: SAIGONSeldom in the checkered history of the Vietnam war have rumor, maneuver and confusion swirled as thickly in Saigon as in the three weeks since Henry A. Kissinger brought President Thieu the draft of a peace accord worked out with Hanoi. Vietcong agents have been making secret overtures to nonCommunist opponents of the Government who would have a role to play under the proposed transition from war to peace. The neutralists, while eager for a share of power, have been leery of partnership with the Communists. Mr. Thieu has been denouncing the accord as a surrender and sellout. Sources close to the Presidential Palace have been leaking counterproposals, each new one different from the last.

title: A Painting Long Believed Lost Is Found by Persistent Art Historian
description: An American painting of historical importance, long believed lost, has been tracked down by a persistent New York art historian. Cleaned and restored, it is now being exhibited for the first time in 50 years.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Child to Mrs. Lichstrahl
description: A daughter was born on Oct. 21 at St. Vincent's Hospital to Dr. and Mrs. Alan D. Lichstrahl of New York. The child, named Marni Ellen, is a granddaughter of Judge Milton Sanders of the Civil Court of the City of New York and Mrs. Sanders. Her mother is the former Miss Alison Lou Sanders. The child's father is an orthopedic resident at FlowerFifth Avenue Hospital. He recently completed a term of service in Vietnam as a major in the Army. The child is greatniece of Justice Birdie Amsterdam of the New York Supreme Court.

title: Brighten up your night life
description: Go out on the town and light up the night. Race about in a splash of razzledazzle sequins in soft little jackets, sleek pants and floorbrushing dresses. There glamour in sweaters glistening with metallic threads. The season looks bright.

title: Preps
description: POTTSTOWN, Pa., Nov. 11Lawrenceville completed an unbeaten season today by routing The Hill, 330, in the 68th meeting of the schools. Lawrenceville, tied only by Deerfield in eight games, took its 39th victory in the series. The Hill has won 18 times and there have been 11 ties.

title: The Adipose Complex
description: Would you think a novel could be based on a weightreducing program? No? You are probably right. Paul Deutschman (a photographer) transfers the 52pound weight loss of Odie Fondu (a photographer) to 372 selfindulgent pages, pendulous with exclamation points. The framework of the book is a 40week tour of duty Odie pursues with Weight Watchers, the fat people's A.A. White Odie's lard is gradually rendered, we are treated to flashbacks clumsily spliced in from his farflung career, to lowcalorie recipes, to endless ruminations about excess ballast, its cause and cure. The author addresses the reader as Friend, which may or may

title: Heir to $435,000 Named After ThreeYear Search
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 11 (AP) A 94yearold retired chef has been named sole heir to $435,000 in a case that had been open since 1969. The recipent only recently made his claim stating that he had not realized he was the closest relative.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is impossible for me to reconcile, your editorial stand on Vietnam, as expressed on Oct. 11, with the reality I perceived on a recent visit to that beleaguered country. I found a lively, vital and relatively open society that has made impressive strides in education, medical care, land reform, etc., against what seem insuperable obstacles.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: I just perused your article Battle of the Breakfast Table (Oct. 22). I can't believe I'm the only parent who buys only nonsweetened cereal. I do, and my six children add natural, raw sugar, if they want it (not all of them do).

title: Paris Police Oust Basques
description: PARIS, Nov, 11 (Agence FrancePresse)  Ten young Basque militants who started a hunger strike today in Notre Dame Cathedral were expelled by the police, along with 100 sympathizers. The militants were protesting Government measures banishing Spanish Basque refugees from French areas near Spain and were expressing solidarity with hunger strikers in the Bayonne cathedral.

title: Trudeau
description: MONTREAL  One evening shortly after the recent inconclusive federal election in Canada, a New Democratic party (N.D.P.) worker was sitting in a Montreal tavern, staring dejectedly into a glass of beer. The New Democrats, a small third party that will apparently hold the balance of power in the House of Commons, are supposed to be pleased these days with their new prominence, so the man was pressed to explain his gloom.

title: Germany
description: Next Wednesday evening the Berliner Sinfonie will give a performance in Bonnthe first by a leading East German orchestra in West Germany. The concert is, symbolic of a larger harmony that has been developing lately between the populations of the two oncehostile Germanys.

title: A Vital Session for Legislature
description: TRENTONIt used to be in New Jersey that the State Legislature would come back here after the November elections and quietly resolve all those highly sensitive or minor legislative problems that were left over from the preceding spring. The Governor would use the postelection session to hand out the favors he had withheld in the election campaign, the Senate would confirm some of his judicial nominees and some state agency that had run out of money would be given some more to help it get through until next year.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 11Michigan State pulled a stunning football upset today, defeating previously unbeaten Ohio State, 1912, in a Big Ten battle.

title: U.S. Presses for Nursing Home Care
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 11Nursing homes may be required to retain an organized medical staff or a medical director to qualify for Medicare or Medicaid programs in the future, according to an official in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: Students Evaluate WorkStudy Plan
description: ORADELLSamuel Friedman is teaching school in Westfield and getting college credits at the same time. Helene Levin is working for the Monmouth County Welfare Board, Richard Isaac is at the Bergen Pines County Hospital in Paramus and Louise Jafee is at an art school in Stillwater  all as part, of their educational experience in college.

title: Preps
description: WINDSOR, Conn., Nov. The Silver Spoon, a trophy fought over by Loomis and Kent on an annual basis for the last 26 years, returned to Loomis for the first time in four years today when Loomis defeated Kent 150.

title: Putting Its Bare Foot Forward
description: FOR the past few weeks moderndance has put up a most unusually strong showing in New York City. We are accustomed to classic ballet holding sway in the New York dance world, but this season moderndance has put its bare foot forward. Admittedly, there has been classic ballet in town. Tonight the City Center Joffrey Ballet ends a notably successful season at the City Center and we have had Maurice Mart's Ballet of the 20th Century at the Felt Forum of Madison Square Garden. In Brooklyn the Academy of Music is playing host to the French Ballet Contemporain. Yet moderndance has also been makine its headlines. not only with the City Center American Dance Marathon at the ANTA Theater, but also the appearances of the Lar Lubovitch

title: There's no one like Margaret
description: The sisterhood of Kappa Kappa Gamma can seldom have refused a keyshaped pin to a more promising dark horse than dowdy little Margaret Mead who wore a fatally wrong dress to a rush party at DePauw University in the fall of 1919.

title: Navy Lightweights Win
description: Navy defeated Columbia, 1713 in an Eastern Colegiate lightweight football league game on the losers field yesterday. The middies have a 4.1 wonlost record.

title: Japanese Businessmen in the U.S....
description: SAN FRANCISCOKizo Mineo, general manager of Mitsui & Co. (U.S.A), glanced out the window of his 30thfloor office at the expanse of San Francisco Bay spread before him. The bay was bathed in misty sunshine and an appreciative smile passed briefly across his face.

title: 8 Less Than Lofty Ski Areas, Topographically and Socially
description: THERE are scores of ski areas on the shunpike circuit in the Eastern United States. Here are some notes on eight of them. For lists and locations of others, the best bets are the regional ski maps available at state tourist bureaus and ski shops.

title: WASHINGTON
description: In his remarkable interview with Garnett Homer of The Washington StarNews, President Nixon has given his own interpretation of his election victory and defined his approach to the second White House term.

title: World News Briefs
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 11JeanLuc Pepin, Canada's Minister of Trade and Commerce, was defeated in the Oct. 30 federal election, a judicial recount in the Quebec district of Drummondville showed today.

title: The Hottest Spot In U.S. Skiing
description: IT shouldn't take the newcomer to Sky Valley long to realize that here is a ski resort with a difference. Most of the skiers come down from the top on their bottoms, betray ing the fact that many of them (more than half, actually) have never been on skis before. In addition, their dungarees, overcoats and other unconventional outfits give them away as people to whom skiing is truly a new and strange pastime. Even the geography is all wrong for a ski resort; Sky Valley is Way Down South in Georgia. That's right, Georgia. And this is Skiing, DixieStyle.

title: KISSINGER AND THO EXPECTED TO MEET LATE IN THE WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 Wellplaced Administration officials said today that they expected Henry A. Kissinger to return to Paris late next week to begin the concluding phase of negotiations for an Indochina settlement.

title: The World
description: LONDONPrime Minister Edward Heath stood on his head last week, just as President Nixon did 15 months ago. For, following the example of Mr. Nixon's new economic policy, the Prime Minister swallowed his own earlier words and told Parliament on Monday that there is to be a complete freeze on prices, wages, rents and dividends.

title: Circus Animals Kill 2 Indians
description: GORAKHPUR, INDIA, Nov. 11 (Reuter)A lion and two tigers that escaped from a circus have killed two persons and mauled 20 in the last week in villages near this northern India town, police officials said.

title: Janetha A. Benson Planning Bridal
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Nov. 11The Rev., Caryl V. Benson, pastor for 22 years of the Salem Lutheran Church in Bridegoprt, and Mrs. Benson of Fairfield and Spofford Lake, N. H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janetha Ann Benson, to Dr. Russell De Jong Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. De Jong of Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: Amid Trials of Croatian Nationalists, a Satirical Musical Comedy in Zagreb Evokes Laughter Through Tears
description: ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Nov. 11 In this old Croatian capital, under its winterlong mantle of fog and coal smoke, a musical production blending sharp satire and melancholic idealism has captivated sellout audi1 ences, evoking laughter through tears appropriate to Croatia's time of trials.

title: Preps
description: SHEFFIELD, Mass., Nov. 11Berkshire bunched all its scoring in the second and third quarters today as it upset Salisbury, 3218. Don Perry ran 41 and 26 yards for two scores from his quarterback spot.

title: Groton Defeats St. Marks, 207, On Long. Passes
Major Zoning Ruling Is Seen
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I.Within the next six weeks the state Court of Appeals is expected to rule on a case that could have broad implications for the entire question of zoning, review and the powers of the Suffolk County Planning Commission.

title: Opium Suppository Banned
description: PARIS, Nov. 11 (Agence France Presse)  The Government has banned the sale of certain suppositories because they can be melted down and distilled to provide pure opium, a pharmaceutical trade source said. The suppositories were manufactured to ease hemorrhoidal pain. But drug traffickers, aided by medical students, were melting them down, the source said this week.

title: Miss Nesbitt Affianced.
description: Mrs. William J. Nesbitt of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Pamela Nesbitt, to Gerald Scott Gras. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ranulf Gras of Lincoln, Mass. The future bride is the daughter also of the late Mr. Nesbitt.

title: BEIRUT HOLIDAYS STIRRING DISPUTE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 11A political uproar over legal holidays is threatening to delay a longneeded reform of the civil service in Lebanon and raising questions here about national unity.

title: Stonehenge
description: Who created Stonehenge? Not the Druids, suggest the authors, but an itinerant Egyptian architect sophisticated in the techniques of heavy construction  pyramids and all that. How did an Egyptian get to the Salisbury Plain in the Bronze Age: Hmm. Ever hear of Atlantis? Well, Stonehenge is a spinoff of the wars between Atlantis and Mycenae, which owned tinmine rights in the area. These prehistoric hypotheses are attractively packaged in the nostalgic gore of a simpler age that knew only how to kill one man at a time.

title: Bronx Aide Named
description: Bronx Borough President Robert Abrams announced yesterday the appointment of Jorge Batista, president of the South Bronx Community, Housing Corporation, as deputy borough president. Mr. Batista succeeds Louis C. Benza, who has held the post since January, 1970, and who is returning to the practice of law. Mr. Batista, who is 30 years old, is a graduate of Columbia College and Yale Law School.

title: WAVE OF BENGALIS FLEEING PAKISTAN
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov.11 (AP)For the second time in 12 months, Bengalis are fleeing Pakistani soil.

title: Ocean County Park Is Delayed
description: BERKELEY TOWNSHIPOcean County residents have a long wait in store before a new state park is begun on land that was acquired for that purpose more than eight years ago.

title: Justifiable Terrorism?
description: Is an act of terrorist violence committed in the name of some national or ideological cause a form of justifiable homicide that deserves the indulgence of the international community?

title: INDICTMENTS SEEN IN FUND OFFENSES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11Government sources disclosed, today that the Justice Department was confident that it would obtain indictments by the end of this month against the finance committees of both major Presidential campaigns for violations of the law on reporting campaign funds.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: Reviewing The New Oxford Book of English Verse, Helen Vendler places its editor, Prof. Helen Gardner, in Oxford... She then (parenthetically) wonders why the editor must always be domiciled at that university. It should comfort Mrs. Vendler to learn that Sir Arthur QuillerCouch, editor of the original Oxford Book of English Verse was not so domiciled.

title: Satellite's Cameras Scanning Coast
description: TRENTONThe entire state of New Jersey is having its picture taken by satellite cameras every 18 days as part of an experiment to survey the earth's natural resources and find better ways to utilize and control them.

title: A new (6th century B. C.) Greek vase for New York
description: For Dietrich von Bothmer, the Metropolitan Museum of Art's graying, 54yearold, Germanborn curator of Greek and Roman art, it is the acquisition of a lifetime. For Thomas P. F. Hoving, the Metropolitan's controversial director, it is one of the greatest acquisitions in the museum's entire 102year history, thus putting it on a par with several spectacular and spectacularly touted acquisitions of recent years: the 15thcentury Flemish Merode Altarpiece and Rembrandt's Aristotle Contemplating the Bust of Homer, that stodgy painting whose $2.3million price tag ushered in the era of milliondollar paintingsboth acquired by Hoving's predecessor, James J. Rorimerand a long list of classy acquisitions that can be credited to Hoving's fiveyear administrationamong them, the Velazquez painting of Juan de Pareja, acquired at auction for a recordbreaking $5.5million; the Lehman collection (a treasure trove of paintings, sculptures and objets d'art dating from the Middle Ages to Matisse, willed to the museum by the late Robert Lehman and to be housed in a new $5.5million wing now under construction), the 2,000yearold Egyptian temple of Dendur, awarded to the Metropolitan by the U.S. Government in 1967. (A gift of the United Arab Republic in return for the $16million U.S. contribution for the salvaging of monuments at the site of Egypt's Aswan Dam, the temple was dismantled stone by stone at its Nileside site and will be reconstituted, under a glass enclosure, on the Metropolitan's northside parking lot in 1974.)

title: President Says Argentina Won't Bar Peron's Return
description: MENDOZA, Argentina, Nov. 11 (UPI)President Alejandro A. Lanusse said last night that his Government would not bar the announced return on Nov. 17 of Juan D. Peron but warned that the arrried:. forces would deal sternly with any violence inspired by the former dictator's homecoming.

title: American exiles, an American family, an American rebellion, an American ally
description: The life of an exile is an often excruciating exercise in adjustment. In American history there have been many exiles, voluntary or involuntary, to this country. But there have also been those who left America, and these include the Loyalists of the American Revolution, Confederates who refused to live in a conquered South and the men who fled the draft in the 1960's. Among the last three types the Loyalists are beginning to receive increased attention, perhaps, in part, because of the approaching bicentennial of the occasion that marked their agony.

title: The Golden Flame
description: Now the larches are unmistakable in the woodland. The maples and birches have cast their leaves, the oaks have turned brown, and the larches stand like tall, slim candle flames. By late November they will be as naked as the maples, but for a little while they light up the woods like giant torches.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I am a working man living in the Adirondacks. In the summer there are so many bugs up here that it is difficult to enjoy the woods. In the fall bet the woods are beautiful.

title: Monzon Keeps Middleweight Title by Outpointing Briscoe
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 11 (AP)Carlos Monzon of Argentina, making good use of his greater height and reach, battered Benny Briscoe for 15 rounds to retain his world middleweight boxing title with a decision over the Philadelphia challenger tonight.

title: Southern U. Boycott Still On
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 11 (AP)Most of the students at Southern University's campus here and at the main campus in Baton Rouge continued boycotting classes today to push their demands, including the retirement of Dr. Leon Netterville, president of the Southern system.

title: CHIEFS AND JOLTERS SKATE HERE TODAY
description: The Chiefs will skate their first Roller Derby game at Madison Square Garden this season today at 1:30 P.M. They will face the Jolters, the team they beat for the International Roller Derby League championship at the Garden last April.

title: Deanie Stack Plans Bridal
description: SPARTANBURG, S. C., Nov. 11Miss Geraldine Stack of New York, whose friends know her as Deanie, plans to be married here Dec. 30 to Thomas Robertson Kennedy of Syracuse, N. Y. The ceremony will take place at the Trinity United Methodist Church.

title: Accountant Marries Joan Berger
description: Miss Joan Ellen Berger, daughter of Mrs. Josef Shallant of Greensboro, N.C., and Jack W. Berger of Shaker Heights, Ohio, was married here yesterday evening to John W. Lappin. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Adam Lappin of Winsted, Conn.

title: Illinois Sinks Indiana
description: CHAMPAIGN, III., Nov. 11 (AP)George Uremovich scored on a 96yard kickoff return and ran 32 and 5 yards for two more touchdowns today as Illinois, downed Indiana 3720.

title: La Prevoyante Wins 12th Straight Race
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., Nov. 11 Jean Louis Levesque's La Prevoyante became the fifth filly of the century to complete her first season of racing undefeated when she won the 18th running of the $190,920 Gardenia Stakes today.

title: Englewood Students Take Clearwater Cruises
description: ENGLEWOOD  The Hudion River will never look the same to some Dwight Morrow High School students. These are the ones who have sailed on the Clearwater, a 95foot sloop.

title: Blind Essex Dean Holds Jazz Class
description: NEWARKIn jazz circles some years back, the dean of academic affairs at Essex County Collegewas known as Downbeat Jackson.

title: Greater New York Soon to Be 75
description: The entire city will become one huge historical landmark during 1973 in celebration of its 75th birthday as Greater New York.

title: Television
description: FOR almost 12 years now, around 25 million Britons have settled down two nights a week to watch Coronation Street, a neverending television serial which chronicles the fictional lives of the inhabitants of a rundown working class street in the heart of industrial Lancashire. The squabbles, successes, and disasters of some very ordinary peopleclerks, laborers, smallbusiness menhave not only infatuated the British viewer and made Coronation Street the most consistently popular program in the United Kingdom. They have also attracted vast audiences in Australia, Canada, the Netherlands, Singapore, Nigeria and many other countries. Tuesday night at 10 on WNET/13, and every Tuesday and Thursday evening thereafter for 26 weeks, Coronation Street will test its appeal to American audiences.

title: Georgia Death Toll Now 10 In ShipBridge Accident
description: BRUNSWICK, Ga., Nov. 11 (UPI)The bodies of five victims of a shipbridge accident were recovered today, bringing the total of known dead to 10.

title: Survey Reports McGovern Got 87% of the Black Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) Senator George McGovern won about 87 per cent of the black vote in last Tuesday's Presidential election, the Joint Center for Political studies

title: Face Redskins Away
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11When the Giants played Washington in New York two weeks ago, with a chance to tie the Redskins for first place in the Eastern Division of the National Football Conference, there was no logical reason to expect them to win.

title: FolkArt Treasury Evokes Bygone America
description: From early trade and tavern signs and carved ships decorations to Mormon textiles and whittled toys, much of the content of a huge national archive documenting America's heritage in the popular and folk arts appears in print for the first time

title: The Icarus Complex
description: The Icarus Complex takes you backstage in the aerospace industry, and I somehow wish it hadn't. Bribery, corruption blackmail and collusionthat's what spatial hardware is made of. And the lifestyles are no different from those pursued in the pages of Jacqueline Susann adn Harold Robbins.

title: Food: Depot in HoHoKus
description: HOHOKUSThe old Victorian house on First Street is called The Depot, and each of its small rooms is crammed with handcrafted items, homemade foods, antiques and gifts.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Oct. 29 letter titled The Maimers and illustrated with a headless bowman contains several misstatements.

title: MonmouthOcean
description: Steve Peterson, the quarterback, fired a. 30yard touchdown pass to Jerry Costain, and ran for a twopoint conversion to give Toms River South a 1414 tie with Middletown yesterday at Toms River.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: In his appraisal of A Picture History of the Olympics, the British sportswriter Brian Glanville asks rhetorically, But what of Tommie Smith the fastest man in Mexico City now spurned and forgotten after his assertion of black power?

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONFew observers of Indian life were surprised last week when the Trail of Broken Treaties, a crosscountry caravan of Indian activists, led straight to this city. Tribal grievances have been blossoming here much longer than the cherry treessince 1792, in fact, when the Seneca Chief Red Jacket journeyed to Washington to lecture the Senate on the importance of keeping its promises.

title: Views of Review
description: To THE EDITOR: In his editorial advertisement, Where We Stand, in The Week in Review, Nov. 5, Albert Shanker, President of the United Federation of Teachers, strongly urged the defeat of Bella Abzug in the 20th Congressional District contest for Congress. That election is over. But the question of the means Mr. Shanker uses to promote his ends remains open for discussion.

title: Such Were the Joys
description: Five or six years ago I had a visit in my Sussex farmhouse from Peter Stansky and William Abrahams, and I suggested they interview Mrs. Vaughan Wilkes, the former headmistress of St. Cyprian's, the preparatory school [for boys aged 8 to 13] where Orwell and I were educated. Although she was then in her lucid eighties no one had thought of doing this before. In Journey to the Frontier, their book on Julian Bell and John Cornford, scions of Bloomsbury killed in the Spanish Civil War, the authors had mastered the sociology of the thirties, no easy task for Americans. And now they have tackled an even more remote and sophisticated period, the England of 191030, the fresh green lap of good King Edward's land. I was there, born three months after Orwell, although owing to the complexities of the educational system he always seemed a year senior. From St. Cyprian's I followed him to Eton College, after that our ways parted and friendship was not resumed till the middle thirties, when it lasted to his death.

title: OffDuty Transit Patrolman Shoots Himself in Dispute
description: A rookie offduty Transit Authority patrolman shot ,himself in the chest yesterday morning in a westside police station where he had been taken for questioning about dispute involving him, the police said.

title: Weeding Out Threatened
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) Admiral Zumwalt said today that officers who were insensitive or lax in dealing with racial problems would be weeded out of the Navy.

title: Old Church in Holiday Role
description: BRIDGETON  Year after year, Old Broad Street Presbyterian Church stands empty, yet preserved as the town's leading architectural gem. But on Nov. 23, as on other recent Thanksgiving Days, this Georgianstyle edificeit was completed in 1794will be the setting for ecumenical services sponsored by the local Ministerial Association. The services will begin at 10 A.M.

title: A HeliumFilled Balloon Beats Blackouts on TV
description: MIAMI, Nov. 11 (AP)Larry, Garfield, a Miami carpen. ter, has found a poor man's way to beat the television blackout of sports eventsa toy balloon antenna.

title: Hawks Beat Bucks, 111102
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 11 (AP)Lgu Hudson scored 32 points and George Trapp added 26 lead the Atlanta Hawks to 111102 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks tonight.

title: The African who kicked out the Asians, who said Hitler was right, who has made his country a state sinister
description: The dreams of Gen. Idi Amin, heavyweight boxer, flyweight philosopher and the seemingly punchdrunk President of the Second Republic of Uganda, have transformed life in his lush, landlocked East African state into a nightmare of terror for inhabitants of all hues. In one dream last August, according to the burly exsergeant, God appeared in person and instructed him to exorcise Uganda of its 50,000 Asian residents, most of them thirdgeneration Ugandans who collectively form the country's economic middle class. The Asians, Amin charged, had been sabotaging Uganda's economy, deliberately retarding economic progress, fostering widespread corruption and treacherously refraining from integrating in the Ugandan way of life. He gave them 90 days to quit the country, or they will find themselves sitting on the fire.

title: Ejemplo Scores by a Neck And Pays $30.20 at Calder
description: MIAMI, Nov. 11 (AP)Stephan A. Calder's Venezuelan import Ejemplo, with Bobby Gaffglione in the saddle, rallied today to win the $25,000added Florida Turf Cup at Calder Race Course.

title: Home Improvement
description: PIECES of furniture that are scratched, nicked or burned can often be repaired by simple home treatments that will rejuvenate them satisfactorily without need for a complete refinishing jobalthough sizable defects and serious blemishes may still call for the services of a professional. However, in many cases even these can be repaired sufficiently to make them almost unnoticeable to all but those who are actually looking for them.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11The World War ended 54 years ago today. It was not called World War I at that time. People were not very well in= formed in those days. The polls as late as Nov. 9,.1918, showed that fewer than 29 per cent believed in the inevitably of a.World War II.

title: CHOU QUESTIONS SOVIET SINCERITY
description: PEKING, Nov. 11 (Reuters)Premier Chou Enlai apparently has doubts about the Soviet Union's sincerity in wishing to see the Vietnam war end, diplomats said here today, but he says that the question of settling the conflict should be the first problem President Nixon deals with following his election victory.

title: Don't Start Is Victorious In Novice Hunter Division
description: READINGTON, N. J., Nov.11 Don't Start, owned by Ed Wells of Mendham, N. J., and handled. by Lisa Robertson, won the novice working hunter championship today at the first of Four Seasons Farm's winter indoor horse show series.

title: S.I. Students Attack Graffiti
description: Students at the new Tottenville High School in the Staten Island community of Huguenot traditionally sing the school song, chant the school cheers and attend Saturday football games. And now they have acquired something unconventional: a school railroad station.

title: Gridiron Club Admits Black
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) Carl T. Rowan, the syndicated columnist, was elected tc membership yesterday in the Gridiron Club, an organization of Washington newsmen. He is the first black member of the club, which was founded in 1885.

title: Students Lose Bid to Vote
description: STONY BROOK, L. I.About 111 students from the State University here were challenged by. the Board of Elections when they registered to vote. On Election Day, after legal battles that lasted as long as two years for some, fewer than one out of five succeeded in voting.

title: The Saigon Follies, or, Trying to Head Them On at Credibility Gap
description: SAIGON: Not long ago, a key officer in the military office of information told a newsman that his previous job in Washingtonhe had come from a high information post at the Pentagonhad been much harder. In Washington, he explained, there were continual leaks from Capitol Hill that had to be reacted to and denied quickly so as to get the denials into the next morning's newspapers, whereas in Vietnam things were simpler because there's no competing line.

title: Syracuse Power Routs Army in Rain, Mud, 276,
description: SYRACUSE, Nov. 11  The quagmirelike turf at Archbold Stadium turned Army's football Cadets black and Syracuse turned them blue by thoroughly thrashing the hopeful visitors, 276, today.

title: World News Briefs
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 11Rhodesia has been sorely tested by sanctions but 1972 will be remembered as a turning point in the country's struggle for international recognition, Prime Minister Ian Smith told Rhodesians in nationwide radio address tonight.

title: By LETTY COTTIN POGREBIN
description: Once upon a time there was such a thing as a typical teenage girl. She lived in a warm loving family. Mom made her chocolate pudding and cableknit sweaters. Daddydear gave her permission to stay out until midnight for special occasions. She wore powderpink lipstick, learned to use an eyelash curler and got a permanent for her 16th birthday.

title: How Eric Blair became George Orwell
description: In her introduction to the fourvolume edition of George Orwell's Collected Essays, Journalism and Letters (1968) Sonia Orwell wrote that in his will he asked that no biography be written. He gave no reasons for this but his friends felt that his request was probably in part due to his natural reticence but also came from the knowledge that there was so little that could be written about his lifeexcept for psychological interpretation  which he had not written himself... with these present volumes the picture is as complete as it can be.

title: Preps
description: WALLINGFORD, Conn., Nov. 11Paul LaRochelle scored on runs of 1 and 5 yards today to pace Deerfield to a victory over victoryless Choate, 198. It was the seventh loss for Choate in the 54th anniversary game. Deerfield has a 321 wonlosttied record.

title: Minnesota 3529 Victor
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 11 (UPI)John King rushed for a career high of 188 yards, scored two touchdowns nad broke six school records today in a 35.29 Minnesota victory over Northwestern.

title: Scientists Fly to Moscow
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UPI) Seven American cancer scientists flew to Moscow today to begin a twoweek exchange of information with leading Soviet scientists about viral causes of cancer. The exchange is part of the health agreement signed in Moscow last May during President Nixon's summit meeting there.

title: BRUINS BOWL BID DIMMED BY LOSS
Rockland
description: The longest winning streak ever in the Public Schools Athle tic League was extended to 25 yesterday when North Rockland bested its chief rival, Nanuet 170. Chuck Maze scored from the 8 in the first period and returned an interception 30 yards for another touchdown. A 264yard field goal by Scott Keyser completed North Rockland's scoring before halftime and sent Nanuet to its second defeat.

title: Whalers, Trailing 52 in Third Period, Come Back to Defeat Raiders, 65
description: BOSTON, Nov. 11 (AP) Tommy Waster scored the second of his two goals with 40 seconds remaining as the New England Whalers overcame threegoal deficit in the third period to beat the New York Raiders, 65, in a World Hockey Association game today.

title: GARDINER KLINE
description: AMSTERDAM, N. Y., Nov. 11 (UPI)Gardiner Kline, president of the company that publishes The Evening Recorder here, died today at his home. He was 94 years old.

title: Local
description: Brooklyn Tech and Far Rockaway vaulted into the final round of the Public School Athletic League championship playoffs yesterday, slipping past tough semifinal opponents.

title: Flyers Triumph, 31
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 (UPI)Rick MacLeish scored twice, including the 1,000th goal of the Philadelphia Flyers, as they beat the Buffalo Sabres, 31, tonight.

title: Eastern Indoor Title Tennis Seeks Sponsors for Event
description: The annual Eastern men's indoor tennis championship will be held March 9 at the Stadium Tennis Center in the Bronx. Last March the tournament was won by Vitas Gerulaitis of Howard Beach, Queens.

title: Rockets Fall, 114112
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 11 (AP)John Block led Philadelphia to a fourthquarter spree that broke a 16game losing streak as the 76ers beat the Houston Rockets, 114112, in an N.B.A. game tonight.

title: U.S. EDUCATION CHIEF SEES A TIGHT BUDGET
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 Sidney P. Marland, the Assistant Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare for Education, predicts that the Nixon Administration's Spartan attitude to ward Government spending will include education expenditures.

title: On the road with a bedbug hauler
description: At 5:15 P.M. on Saturday, Aug. 12, Al Trafford drives a tractortrailer slowly away from a warehouse in Carlstadt, N.J., and heads for California. Trafford, a 52yearold native New Yorker, has been driving trucks of one kind or another for most of the last 35 years. He owns a tractor, which he leases, along with his services, to Bekins Van Lines, the country's fifth largest interstate household goods moving carrier. On this particular Saturday his tractor is pulling a semitrailer loaded with 13,700 pounds of furniture and household goods belonging to a family that is moving from Short Hills, N.J., to La Canada, Calif.; 1,720 pounds of furniture and household goods owned by people going from Ironia, N.J., to Winnipeg, Man. (Trafford wilt set the 1,720pound load off at the Bekins Van Lines terminal in Hillside, Ill., and another Bekins driver will take it from there to Canada while he continues west); and four U.P.I. teletype machines, weighing 600 pounds, bound for Skokie, Ill., also to be offloaded at Hillside. I am in the cab of the tractor because for a long time I have been curious about the lives of the drivers of the big trucks that go thundering down the highways, and Bekins has given me permission to accompany Trafford on a coasttocoast run.

title: Child to Mrs. Halpern
description: A daughter was born Oct. 22 to Mr. and Mrs. Kevin Halpern of the Bronx at the Albert Einstein Hospital there. Mrs. Halpern is the former Miss Marlene Abrams, whose brother is Bronx Borough President Robert Abrams.

title: Article 17  No Title
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Nov. 11 (AP)  Florida State's quarterback, Gary Huff, threw for three touchdowns today as the Seminoles beat Tulsa, 2321, despite a hurricane passing attack in the final quarter that netted two touchdowns.

title: RISE ASKED IN FEES FOR INSPECTIONS
description: The city's Board of Health has proposed 49 increases in fees for operating businesses undergoing inspections or taking qualifying tests under its control.

title: Haig Leaves Saigon for Pnompenh After Two Days of Talks With Thieu
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Nov. 12After concluding two days of secret talks with President Nguyen Van Thieu, Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. left Saigon this morning for meetings with President Lon Nol of Cambodia and President Park Chung Hee of South Korea, a United States Embassy spokesman said.

title: The Theater: Sam Shepard's The Tooth, of Crime
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 11 Sam Shepard is a young American playwright of pure brilliance and imaginative fantasy. And yet there were times when his talent seemed to be cheating his genius. His picaresque and smokefilled imagery, while having a time and tempo of their own, seemed to hold back his attempts at epic theater. Here in his latest play, The Tooth of Crime, which had its American premiere tonight at the McCarter Theater, Mr. Shepard has gathered his forces and produced a splendidly provocative play.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The DowJones industrial average dwelt briefly last Friday in the promised land above 1,000, only to fall back in late profit taking in a memorable session.

title: Brown Brothers Quits Midtown for Poconos
description: Brown Brothers, which during seven decades in New York created one of the largest commercial collections of photographs and negatives, moved last week from its midtown offices to a hamlet in the Poconos.

title: Nancy K. Bierce, 66 Debutante, Betrothed to William C. Alden
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Nov. 11Mr. and Mrs. Thurber Hoffman Bierce of Englewood and Point O'Woods, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy King Bierce, to William Carver Alden of Newfane, Vt. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hollis Emery Alden of Worcester, Mass.

title: Glassblowers'
description: FLANDERS, L. I.  The least likely place one would expect to find finely sculpted glass or an oldworld teardrop candlestick being made for Tiffany's would be on rural Flanders Road here between Riverhead and the Hamptons.

title: How we got into the messiest war in our history
description: The Best and the Brightest; Pulitzer Prize winner David Halberstam's latest, most important and impressive book, sets out to discover why America got involved in the worst and messiest war in our history. What was it about the men, their attitudes, the country, its institutions and above all the era which had allowed this tragedy to take place? They were, after all, the best and the brightest, so why did it happen?

title: NEW FUND ABUSES BY GROSS CHARGED
description: Seventyfour improper payments of expenseaccount items totaling nearly $4,000 and made to former Youth Services Commissioner Ted Gross during a oneyear period were disclosed yesterday by Controller Abraham D. Beame.

title: Grambling Wins, 396
description: GRAMBLING, La., Nov. 11 (AP)Grambling struck for two quick scores in the first quarter, as it crushed Norfolk State today, 396. Grambling rushed for 308 yards and passed for 152 yards.

title: Eight Defeats for W. &
description: WASHINGTON, Pa. Nov. 11 (AP)  Demery Brandon concluded his Bethany College career by rushing for 143 yards and two touchdowns today in a 346 victory over Washington & Jeffesron. Brondon boosted his career rushing total to 2,081 yards. W & J finished the season with a 081 wonlosttied record.

title: Bonnie Bryant Married to Neil W. Hiller
description: Miss Barbara Anne Bryant, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emmons Bryant of New York, was married here yesterday afternoon to Neil Warren Hiller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren C. Hiller of Milwaukee. The Rev. Dr. James S. Stewart performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Brick Presbyterian Church.

title: Queens Nursing Home Develops Techniques for Aiding Victims of Nazi Horror
description: At first glance, the Kew Gardens. Nursing Home in Jamaica, Queens, looks little different from other cheery, wellmaintained homes for the aged. But it is different because nearly half of the 120 patients were in some way touched by the Nazi holocaust.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Winifred Allwork Plans Bridal To George Harry Treadwell Jr.
description: Miss Winifred Allwork, president of the Women's Architectural Auxiliary of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects, plans to be married here Nov. 24 to George Harry Treadwell Jr. of Tucson, Ariz., vice president of the Treadwell Realty Corporation of Memphis.

title: ENVOY BIDS U.N. MEET IN PANAMA
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11  Panama, unhappy with United States negotiating terms for revising the 1903 Panama Canal Treaty, is pressing for a Security Council meeting In Panama to present her grievances.

title: MT. SINAI OBTAINS $22MILLION GIFT
description: Mount Sinai Hospital announced yesterday that it had received $22million in gifts from the Murry and Leonie Guggenheim Foundation. It was the largest contribution in the hospital's 120year history.

title: TENNESSEE FIGHT HINGES ON BLACKS
description: NASHVILLE, Nov. 11As result of Republican gains in the elections last Tuesday, blacks now hold the balance of power in the Tennessee legislature an dare in a position to exact a high price for supporting Democrats or Republicans for key state positions.

title: Fairleigh Routs Brooklyn; DiMaggio Paces Offensive
description: Tom DiMaggio passed for two touchdowns and ran for one as Fairleigh Dickinson University concluded its club football season yesterday by defeating Brooklyn College, 227, at the loser's field. The victory was the third in seven games for the Knights.

title: Education
description: Compared with a couple of years ago, college campuses generally have been peaceful. Student rebellion has subsided.
