description: BATON ROUGE, Nov. 16 Two young blacks were killed and one was wounded today in a day of violence that led Gov. Edwin W. Edwards to close the Southern University campus here.

title: Amtrak Reports' 13% Rise In Revenue for 3d Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UPI)Amtrak, the nation's railroad passenger corporation, reported today a 13 per cent in crease in revenue for the third quarter of this year compared with 1971.

title: A Coast Guard Cutter Is Rescued in Heavy Seas
description: JUNEAU, Alaska, Nov. 16 (AP)The Coast Guard cutter Jarvis, one of the newest and largest of the highendurance cutters, hit a reef or a rock yesterday near Dutch Harbor in the Aleutian Islands.

title: About Pro Football
description: The undefeated Dolphins, going for their 10th straight victory, will open up Sun day's six hours of televised pro football (Channel 4, 1 P.M.) playing the Jets in Miami. The Dolphins are favored by 8 points. Then come the favored Giants against the Cardinals from St. Louis (Channel 2, 2 P.M.) and as soon as their game ends the same channel will pick up the VikingsRams contest in progress from Los Angeles. The Monday night game is Atlanta at Washing ton (Channel 7, 9 o'clock). With five games to go, 15 of the 26 teams remain in contention for the eight post season playoff positions. Here is a preview of all con tests with wonlosttied rec ords in parentheses:

title: Union Asks Inquiry on Rancher's Link to U.S. Aides
description: A union of Federal immigra tion employes called yesterday for the empaneling of a Fed eral grand jury to investigate the activities of a Texas ranch erbanker and his relationship with high officials in the Cus toms Bureau and the Immigra tion and Naturalization Service.

title: U.S. CARGOES KEEP SAIGON FIELD BUSY
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 16No. 59397, a four engine C141 jet cargo plane of the Air Force's 63d Military Airlift Wing, rolled to a stop on the tarmac at Tansonnhut Air Base at 10:42 A.M. after a 3hour40minute flight from Kadena Air Base on Okinawa.

title: Rise at Dow Chemical
description: The Dow Chemical Company announced yesterday it would increase the price of all grades of impact polystyrene resins 1 cent a pound, effective Dec. 1. The company said the new prices would not exceed list prices, which range from 15 cents to 17 cents a pound.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In response to the Nov. 9 letter from Professors Bard and Kurlantzick regarding Israel's expulsion of Meyer Lansky, I wish to remind them that the major concept of traditional Jew ish morality in times of relative peace does not square with their implied admonition as to Israel's heartless act toward a fellow Jew with a criminal record. The concept in the Talmud, The law of the country [where the Jew lives] is law, must be obeyed as a social responsibility as long as the obedience is in consonance with uni versal morality. The concept cannot be violated under the pretext of Israel's Law of Return, which is granted to every Jew as a historic right.

title: N.B.A. Fines the Sonics $10,000 for Signing Brisker
description: The Seattle SuperSonics have been fined $10,000 and their firstround draft choice in 1973 has been awarded to Philadel phia for having violated Na tional Basketball Association regulations in the signing of John Brisker, a star forward in the American Basketball As sociation until this year.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The 479th anniversary of the discovery of Puerto Rico was commemorated yesterday by Mayor Lindsay at City Hall with the issuance of a proclamation setting this week aside in honor of the event.

title: Rogers Says U.S. Is Ready For Direct Talk With Cuba
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16Sec retary of State William P. Rogers asked the Swiss Ambas sador today to inform Cuba that the United States was will ing to take any steps, including direct negotiations, to obtain an agreement to halt the hijacking of airliners to Havana.

title: Flow of Funds Among Banks Increases
A Family of Plain People Is Seeking Still Plainer Life
description: A year ago September, when the first chill of autumn touched the Pennsylvania countryside, Eil Garber put his family in a boxshaped covered wagon, hitched up his two horses. Ned and Bill, and set out on a long, weary ing search.

title: MORRIS MILSTEIN, LED CIRCLE FLOOR
description: Morris Milstein, founder of the Circle Floor Company, Inc., which became the largest floor contracting concern in the worm and is now a subsidiary of the National Kinney Corpo ration, died yesterday at the Presbyterian Hospital. His age was 75 and he lived in Scars dale, N. Y.

title: To be or not to be President troubles me very little.
description: QuestionThis time, General, this is the great return?

title: JERSEY REJECTS EDUCATION CHIEF
description: TRENTON, Nov. 16  The State Senate today rejected the controversial reappointment of Dr. Carl L. Marburger as New Jersey's Commissioner of Edu cation by a margin of one vote in what was seen here as a ma jor victory for opponents of busing in the state.

title: Irrelevant, US. Aide Says
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16A key Administration official dis missed the statements made by the North Vietnamese and Viet cong representatives in Paris today as irrelevant to the efforts to conclude an Indo china settlement.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Nov. 16 (AP)  Florida State Athletic Director Clay Stapleton said today the Seminoles would be, invited to Atlanta's Peach Bowl on Dec. 29 if they beat South Carolina on Saturday.

title: Hesburgh Quitting Rights Panel At Request of the White House
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  The White House said tonight that the Rev. Theodore M. Hes burgh was resigning as chair man of the United States Com mission on Civil Rights and that President Nixon would ac cept the resignation.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: Bruins Rout Blues, 40
description: BOSTON, Nov. 16 (UPI)Phil Esposito scored one goal and assisted on another to lead the Boston Bruins to a 40 victory over the St. Louis Blues to night in an N.H.L. game.

title: Aqueduct Feature Goes To Determined Cosmic
Experts on Troop Cuts Do Things Hard Way
description: BONN, West Germany, Nov. 16  Aides of Foreign Minister Walter Scheel dis closed today that the West ern powers asking Eastern European countries to partic ipate in troopreduction talks had made the invitation a total of 29 times with the same written text.

title: War Foes Planning Protests Tomorrow In 20 Major Cities
description: Spokesmen for two antiwar groups said yesterday that peaceful demonstrations would he held tomorrow in 20 major cities.

title: Haitian Radio Says Duvalier Dismissed a Key Minister
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Domini can Republic, Nov. 16 (UPI) President for Life JeanClaude Duvalier has ousted his Minis ter of Interior and Defense, Luckner Cambronne, considered the real power in the Haitian Government, according to a broadcast monitored here late yesterday.

title: RUSSIANS TO GET PEPSICOLA PLANT
description: PepsiCola next year will be come the first American con sumer product manufactured and sold in the Soviet Union.

title: DR. HUGO MUENCH JR., PUBLIC HEALTH AIDE
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 16 Dr. Hugo Muench Jr., former assistant dean and professor of biostatistics at the Harvard School of Public Health, died today in the Stillman Infirmary. He was 78 years old.

title: Kosher Poultry Ruled Subject to Inspection
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UPI)Kosher poultry is not exempt from Federal inspec tion, the Agriculture Depart ment said today.

title: Hesburgh Quits Rights Panel At Request of the White House
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 The White House said tonight that the Rev. Theodore M. Hes burgh had resigned as chair man of the United States Com mission on Civil Rights and that President Nixon would ac cept the resignation.

title: Scholar Seeks to Limit Pentagon Papers Queries
description: BOSTON, Nov. 16A Har vard professor facing jail for contempt stipulated in Federal Court today that he would an swer grand jury questions on the release of the Pentagon papers under the assumption that they would deal only with conversations with his fellow scholars.

title: U.S. SUED ON PAY OF AIDES TO NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 Ralph Nader and his reformist citizens group, Public Citizen, Inc., sued the Treasury Depart ment today to force it to re cover thousands of dollars paid to top White House officials while they were working for the reelection of President Nixon.

title: PLAN WOULD AID PRIVATE PUPILS
description: A program whereby pupils in parochial and private schools could take certain courses in public schools was proposed yesterday by the State Board of Regents, which made public its projected 197374 budget of $3 billion.

title: ROCKEFELLER URGES ONETERM MAYOR
description: Governor Rockefeller, assert ing that the idea of a biparti san fusion candidate for Mayor of New York City next year was a live one, feels that such a candidate should be commit ted to only one term in office to do a job that would be less than fully popular.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Nov. 16 (AP) Governor Cahill today ap pointed Malcolm S. Forbes Jr. of Springfield, Theodore J. Labrecque Jr. of Red Bank and Anthony M. Surano of South Orange to the Organized Crime Study Commission.

title: Scribner Asks the School Board Whether It Intends to Extend His Contract
description: School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner has askea the mem bers of the Board of Education to let him know as soon as possible whether they intend to extend his threeyear contract, which expires next June 30.

title: Imprisoned Press
description: The jailing of a Los Angeles reporter after Supreme Court rejection of a plea to review his contempt sentence for refusing to disclose the source of a news story provides fresh evidence of the speed with which Consti tutional protections for freedom of the press are being hacked away.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: The manager of the Walt Whitman Bridge, which connects Camden and Philadelphia, was indicted yesterday by a state grand jury in Trenton on perjury charges arising out of an investigation into alleged misappropriation of Delaware River Port Authority resources.

title: Kodak Votes Wage Dividend
description: ROCHESTER, Nov. 16 (AP) Directors of the Eastman Kodak Company voted today a wage dividend of $109.7mil lion to be paid to 70,600 em ployes across the country March 16. Eligible employes will receive $34.36 for each $1,000 earned in the last five years. The 1971 dividend totaled $103.1million at a rate of $34.16 for each $1,000 earned in the previous five years. The program was begun in 1912.

title: Music: Series With Intriguing Title
description: Thomas Scherman wins this season's prize, hands down, for Most Intriguing Title of a Concert Series. But his Masterpieces of the Moderns Unmasked, which he unveiled at Town Hall on Wednesday night, proved dis appointing from just about every aspect.

title: Two BankHoldup Suspects Wounded by Police in Chase
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 16 (AP) The police wounded two men late this morning during a chase following the robbery of a branch of the First New Haven National Bank.

title: 4 FOOD DEALERS HELD AS BRIBERS
description: Operators of a cafeteria and three bakeries were arrested by city investigators yesterday on charges of offering bribes to health inspectors to avoid the notoriety of appearing on the dirty restaurant list that warns the public of health vio lations, according to the com plaint.

title: Rail TonMileage Up 19.8%
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week was an estimated 16.4 billion tonmiles, 19.8 per cent above the corresponding 1971 week. Traffic in the comparable week of 1971 was affected by coal and dock strikes. The A.A.R. also announced that rail load ings last week totaled 540,776 cars, 21.6 per cent above last year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage last week was 8.4 per cent above last year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Times reporter Leslie Oelsner has provided an indepth description of the frustrations present in the New York criminal justice system.

title: Stage: Dear Oscar Tries to Set Wilde to Music
description: Dear Oscar, the musical that opened last night at the Playhouse Theater, would probably be dear at any price. However, no theatri cal representation of Oscar Wilde can be totally without value, and this new musical with book and lyrics by Caryl Gabrielle Young and music by Addy O. Fieger, struck me as a failure of interest.

title: F.T.C. in Accord
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) The Federal Trade Commis sion today announced an agree ment with Pepsico, Inc., under which Pepsico agreed not to take any steps to assume or exercise actual control of the Rheingold Corporation before Dec. 4.

title: Van Buren Runners Win
description: Van Buren High clocked 19 minutes 9 seconds yesterday to capture the Queens Public Schools Athletic League four mile relay at the St. John's University allweather track in Jamaica.

title: U.S.I. Renews Golf Classic
description: SUTTON, Mass., Nov. 16 (AP) United States Industries Inc. announced today it would sponsor the $200,000 U.S.I. classic golf tournament again next year at Pleasant Valley Country Club. The 72hole tour nament, with a $40,000 first prize, will be held Aug. 16 through 19.

title: Aid to Poor Lands Held AKey TradeTalk Issue
description: The head of the Common Market Commission and Presi dent Nixon's chief trade nego tiator acknowledged here yes terday that there was pressure to improve relations between industrialized nations and de veloping countries.

title: H.D.A. UNDER FIRE ON HOUSING AIDES
description: The number of people em ployed in housing functions by the city more than doubled be tween 1969 and 1972, from 4,167 to 8,992, yet services and production have become less efficient and more costly, ac cording to testimony before a City Council Committee yes terday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The City Correction De partment conducted a tour of the Queens House of Deten tion in Long Island City, which was one of the sites of inmate riots in October, 1971. The department pointed out, among the many changes that had taken place, a newpaint job, a reduction in the prison population and new educa tional programs.

title: State Seizes 50 Coats Made of Illegal Furs
description: Agents of the state's De partment of Environmental Conservation yesterday seized 50 fur coats and other gar ments made from the skins of spotted cats identified in state law as endangered species. The garments were illegally on sale at fur shops in New Rochelle, N. Y. and Freeport, L. I.

title: Bush Assails Soviet Stand In U.N. Debate on Dues
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 16The United States and the Soviet Union clashed angrily today as the United States opened a major effort to reduce its contribution to the United Nations budget.

title: Suffolk Legislators Vote for the Seizure Of Home in Montauk
description: HAUPPAGE, L. I., Nov. 16 The Parks Committee of the Suffolk County Legislature to day voted to seize the property of a 53yearold Montauk wom an who had offered to give the county her home in the midst of a 900acre park in the hope that she would be allowed to live there.

title: KHEEL IS TO RESUME MASSTRANSIT FIGHT
description: Theodore W. Kheel, a lawyer and a masstransit advocate, said yesterday that he would renew legal efforts in New York State courts to challenge the validity of a 1962 state law that forbids the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to construct masstransit fa cilities.

title: Union Carbide Completes Petrochemicals Complex
description: William S. Sneath, president of the Union Carbide Corpora tion, said yesterday that earn ings of the company's new pet rochemicals complex in Puerto Rico could generate 20 to 25 cents a share next year.

title: Former Coast Housing Chief Is Sentenced for Embezzling
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 16 (AP)The judge praised the defendant for doing a mar velous job as Sacramento's housing chiefthen sentenced him to spend one to 10 years in prison for misappropriating public funds.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The late Adlai E. Stevenson once declared in a speech at Harvard that what America needed was a better hearing aid in order to gain an un derstanding of the outside world.

title: Anniuersaries
description: RAELucky is rue to have thee on this our wedding anniversary. Dear Husband Louis Gordon.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Nov. 18  The Senate voted unanimously to day to reinstate a program of 13 weeks of extra unemploy ment benefits to longterm unemployed who recently ex hausted their 26 weeks of standard jobless benefits or did not receive the full 13 weeks of emergency benefits under a temporary compensation pro gram that lapsed on Nov. 4.

title: Kaye to Cue the Young on Opera
description: Danny Kaye has been named to serve as host and master of ceremonies for two programs in an experimental Metropolitan Opera project aimed at introducing young people to opera.

title: Abuse of Children
description: Under the auspices of the University of Colorado Medical Center, a new organization has been set up to deal with a shocking fact of American societythe abuse and willful neglect of some 60,000 children a year. The hope is not merely to discover instances of abuse and to effect the separation of these pitiful victims from their parents, though that is often necessary for a time, but to go to work on the parents themselves. A team made up of a pediatrician, a psychiatrist, a nurse, a social worker and possibly a lay therapist will work with the involved parent, not punitively but with the aim of rehabilitation.

title: MassTransit Movement
description: Tens of thousands of commuters daily ride as many as six separate trains in order to reach their work in New York City. The brutal inconvenience of such multiple transfers is compounded by the uncomfortable antiquity of much of the rolling stock. The trains that commuters from New Jersey and elsewhere must ride are often a dilapidated disgrace.

title: Police Reservist Killed
description: BELFAST, Friday, Nov. 17 (UP)A police reservist was killed early today when a hid den bomb in his car exploded as he turned on the ignition, the British army said.

title: Blind Workers Picket
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Nov. 16 (UPI)Blind workers, demand ing a wage increase form their present rate of 80 cents an hour, picketed the government's Blind Industries Corp. yester day. Twenty of them, the police said, were cited for blocking traffic.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Nov. 16Rutgers will meet Morgan State at New Brunswick Saturday in the second Urban Classic football game. All receipts will go to summer recreation programs in the greater Newark area, but it now appears that the game will gross less money than last year's contest.

title: Squires' Late Rally, Sparked by Barr, Tops Stars, 131127
description: NORFOLK, Va. Nov. 16 (AP) Mike Barr, a rookie, sank a field goal and two free throws and assisted on another basket in the last two minutes tonight as the Virginia Squires rallied and defeated the Utah Stars, 131127, in the American Basketball Association.

title: First Sale of U.S.Made Item Negotiated at Canton Fair
description: BOSTON, Nov. 16 (AP) Sobin Chemicals, Inc., said to day it had negotiated the first sale of any Americanmade product at the Canton Trade Fair.

title: Sports of The Times
description: In boxing, it quickly has become known as the Jamaica Affair, a heavyweight championship fight casting shadows of intrigue on the island in the sun.

title: Large Mud Slide Wrecks Heart of Town of Big Sur
description: BIG SUR, Calif., Nov. 16 (UPI) Several families were strand ed today by mud and rocks that slid from a mountain burned bare by fire and soft ened by rain. The mud slide wiped out the heart of this tiny coastal community.

title: Music: Miss de los Angeles's Special Kind of Magic
description: First there was the ex pected ovation. Victoria de los Angeles on the concert stage is America's sweet heart. Then the soprano snuggled into the bow of the piano, propped her right el bow on the lowered lid of the instrument, made herself comfortable and started the Haydn group of her Phil harmonic Hall concert on Wednesday night.

title: Business Briefs
description: The New York State Banking Board, acting on the recommendation of State Superintendent of Banks, Harry W. Albright Jr., approved yesterday the acquisition of two small banks upstate by the Manufacturers Hanover Corpo ration. Separately, the Chase Manhattan Corporation said that it had agreed to acquire the tiny Lincoln National Bank in downtown Buffalo in an exchange of shares worth about $2.3million.

title: The Talk of Argentina
description: BERISSO, Argentina, Nov. 15  The Peronist hymn boomed, free and unopposed, through the main street of Berisso for the first time in 17 years.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: PATERSON, Nov. 16  A Passaic County judge ruled today that a 39yearold Pas saic woman was not denied her constitutional rights when her infant daughter was adopt ed last year while she was in prison.

title: Tenace Tops Hickok Poll
description: Gene Tenace, a man who once appeared the least likely candidate to share a power hitting record with Babe Ruth, was named yesterday as the October winner in the monthly balloting for the 23d annual S. Rae Hickok professional athlete of the year award. Tenace won easily in the voting by the nation's sports writers and broadcasters, gathering 83 firstplace votes and 263 total points.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: Multimillion dollar contracts have been awarded by the Swedish State Power Board to TRW, Inc., and its Swedish partner, ASEA, for a totaly in tegrated data system for elec trical power production and power system control. The part ner is the prime contractor. TRW will handle its portion of the $15.5million contract, in volving about $3million, through its Houstonbased sub sidiary, the TRW Controls Cor poration.

title: Ford Bars 4Day Holiday
description: DETROIT, Nov. 16 (AP) United Auto Workers union members at Ford plants will not be getting a fourday Thanksgiving weekend. In turn ing down a union request to switch the Dec. 17 paid bonus holiday to Nov. 24, Ford cited strong product demand.

title: MESKILL SCORES TALK OF PRESS PRIVILEGE
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 16 Gov. Thomas J. Meskill as serted last night that there was serious talk of a law that would give newsmen the same right of privileged communica tions now enjoyed by clergy men, doctors and lawyers.

title: Bridge: Athletes Spotted a Long Peek Before Bidding Against Aces
description: LANCASTER, Pa., Nov. 16 The major event in the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here last night was unexpectedly overshadowed by a minor one.

title: SHOP TALK
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an aster isk are followed by a recipe.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Andrew Grima has gone to the seashore for inspira tion and materials for his new collection, Supershells.

title: Mrs. Westwood Is Firm
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) Mrs. Jean Westwood said to day that every Democrat had a right to his opinion, but she repeated that she would not step down in the face of a move to oust her as Democratic National Chairman.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 1.1 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and in dustrial materials rose to 125.3 from 124.2 last week.

title: Advertising:
description: During an excellent and highly competitive sales pitch for spot TV yesterday morning at the WaldorfAstoria, Norman B. (Pete) Cash, president of the Television Bureau of advertising, departed from his script to take a shot at those who are splitting their 30second commercials. It brought him the loudest round of applause from members.

title: SUITS SEEK OPENING OF HISS, P.O.W. FILES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) Twin suits filed in Federal Court today seek to force the Government to open its Alger HissWhittaker Chambers files and its records on the forced return to the Soviet Union of antiCommunist Russian prison ers of war after World War II.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Nov. 16 (AP) Legislation has been introduced in the State Assembly to alter the focus of police attention from victimless crimes to crimes of violence.

title: Notes on People
description: Among the things Queen Elizabeth II may have on her mind as she prepares to cele brate her 25th wedding anni versary Monday is what has been happening in her fami ly lately. On Wednesday, the police disclosed that her daughter, Princess Anne, has been charged twice this month with speeding in her Scimitar sports car and might have her license sus pended.

title: U.S. Aid to Segregated Schools Held Unlawful by District Court
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 A United States District Court ruled today that the Depart ment of Health, Education and Welfare had unlawfully refused to cut off Federal aid to many state and local educational agencies that have failed to comply with school desegrega tion policies.

title: Books of The Times
description: Although this study by a captain of the British navy, now retired, concentrates on Nelson's performance as a sea captain, it does not skirt what might be called the Shakespearean side of the man. Nelson's passion for Emma Hamilton must have been equal to that of Antony's for the Queen of Egypt, though the results, for tunately for England and her admiral, were not as disastrous. The author's inter est in the topic is not a gossipy one. Nelson's private life would normally lie outside the scope of his paper. But, as the author shows, his attachment inter fered for almost two years with his han dling of his duties.

title: Olin Leaving Aluminum Industry
description: The Olin Corporation an nounced yesterday that it had decided to get out of the aluminum business. It also said that it plans to get rid of certain chemical and defense related ordnance facilities, al though it would not elaborate.

title: Desegregation Plan For Boston Schools Is Devised by State
description: BOSTON, Nov. 16 (AP)  The Massachusetts Board of Education, rushing to meet a courtordered timetable, adopted a shortterm plan to day to reshape Boston's school districts and reduce racial im balance.

title: Flying Skier Grounded As a Show Opens Here
description: Something new was added a featured ski performer with a broken legat the annual winter sports show  dubbed Expowinter 72opened its fourday stand at the New York Coliseum yesterday afternoon.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Nov. 16Assem blyman Benjamin H. Mabie an nounced today that he had changed his mind about. re signing his seat in the Legisla ture. The Ocean County Repub lican said that he had agreed to remain at the request of the Republican leadership in the lower house.

title: In This Election Germans Wear Buttons
description: BONN, Nov. 16In the three years since the last country wide elections West Germans have become more aware and engaged politically, less afraid to show partisan sympathies or to identify themselves with DeutschlandGerrnany.

title: Day Care in Crisis: Without the Money, Ideals Are in Peril
description: Day care: In the Depression it served to provide jobs for teachers  in World War II it was used to free mothers for the labor market  and today, still built on a practical foundation, it is also the repository for many of a pressureridden society's ideals and hopes.

title: McGovernism: R.I.P.
description: WASHINGTON  Much has already been written about the way in which George McGovern bungled a great op portunity to turn America leftward. People who were always far more in terested in McGovernism than they were in McGovern are doing their best to pin the blame for a ruinous campaign on the head of the ticket. Surely there is enough of it to be shared.

title: Music: Harpsichordist Offers Glowing AllPurcell
description: The Sylvia Marlowe Con cert at Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday found the ?? and her asso ciates of the evening in feli citous musical territory, that of Henry Purcell, the short lived English genius who died at 36 in 1695.

title: Morris Plane on Coast To Get F.T.C. Complaint
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 16 (UPI)The Federal Trade Commission has told the Morris Plan of California it proposes to issue a complaint alleging the loan company has violated the Truthin Lending Act. Morris Plan of California, which operates 88 branch offices there, can sign a consent order or submit to a hearing, which would be held in San Francisco.

title: Thomas Jefferson Teachers Cancel Classes to Protest Violence
description: Teachers at the Thomas Jef ferson High School Annex in the East New York section of Brooklyn canceled classes and sent all 800 students home yes terday morning to protest ram pages by youth gangs and other acts of violence there.

title: Mortgage Loans Placed
description: Ten loans totaling $22.6 million for projects in Cali fornia, Nevada and Georgia have been placed by the Brent wood Mottgage Corporation. The projects include eight apartment communities, a mobile home park and a shop ping center

title: The Dow at 1,000
description: Confetti fluttered, champagne corks popped and stock brokers cheered this week when the DowJones industrial average closed above 1,000 for the first time in history. But bullish economists could ask why not only the Dow but the whole stock market had lagged so far behind the economy. The business outlook is strong. Corporate profits after taxeswhich the stock markets tries to dis countset a new record in the AprilJune quarter of this year and have gone on rising to new peaks.

title: Richardson Aide Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) The resignation of Rodney H. Brady as an Assistant Secretary of the Health, Education and Welfare Department was an nounced today by Elliot L. Richardson, secretary of the department. Mr. Brady has served two years as chief man agement and administrative officer in the department.

title: CoasttoCoast Auto Race Breaks Laws, But Ends With Winner and Absolution
description: REDONDO BEACH, Calif., Nov. 16 (UPI)The rules are quite simple for the Cannon ball Baker SeatoShiningSea Memorial Trophy Dash, a clandestine, coasttocoast automobile race over public highways.

title: Merger News
description: The Boise Cascade Corpora tion announced yesterday that two of its engineering and con struction subsidiaries are to be sold to the Halliburton Com pany for $65million.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: DENVER, Nov. 16 (AP)A Colorado sheep rancer and a Wyoming deputy sheriff were fined a total of $2,300 today in United States District Court for shooting 62 golden eagles from helicopters. Dean Visin tainer, a rancher, was fined $1,700. Deputy Sheriff Joe Evans of Carbon County, Wyo., was fined $500.

title: Jets Gird for Trouble: 2 Encounters in 5 Days
description: Like a general preparing for two battles at the same time, Weeb Ewbank glanced up from a stack of scouting reports yesterday in Shea Stadium and conceded that his New York Jets were about to try the neatest trick of the week.

title: A Family of Plain People Is Seeking Still Plainer Life
description: A year ago September, when the first chill of autumn touched the Pennsylvania countryside, Eil Garber put his family in a boxshaped covered wagon, hitched up his two horses, Ned and Bill, and set out on a long, weary ing search.

title: Kidnaped Child Found Safe In Paris and Uncle Is Held
description: PARIS, Nov. 16A 4year old girl who was kidnapped from her mother's arms in a Paris street yesterday was re covered unharmed by the police today. Her 22yearold uncle was arrested as one of the abductors.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 16 (UPI) Churchill Downs paid the highest $2 win price, $383.40, returned at any North American track this year to bettors who wagered on Norton, the winner of the first race today.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Office of Emergency Preparedness yesterday warned that the refinery industry must act to increase fueloil production to deal with a tightening supply situation. A study by the Government agency disclosed that fueloil demand this winter would be 8 per cent higher than a year earlier while heatingoil inventories as of Nov. 3 were 31 million barrels under a yearearlier levels.

title: Odom of A's Fined $500 For Misconduct in Series
description: Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn announced yes terday that he had fined Oak land pitcher John Blue Moon Odom $500 for the Oakland pitcher's conduct during the World Series.

title: PRICES POST DIP ON OTC AND AMEX
description: Prices in the overthecoun ter market and on the Ameri can Stock Exchange finished lower yesterday in slower trad ing.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, Nov. 16 (AP)The price of freemarket gold slumped on the London Bullion Exchange today to its lowest level since early summer amid speculation that Soviet stocks of the metal are coming up for sale. Gold closed at $60.85 a fine ounce, down from $61.44 at the afternoon fixing. The former low figure was $60.60 at the morning fixing of June 19.

title: TWO MEN WORKING IN EXCAVATIONS DIE
description: Two men were killed in sepa rate excavation accidents in Queens yesterday, according to the police.

title: Davis Cup Team Received $4,200 Each in Final Round
description: Stan Smith, an Army spe cialist fourthclass at the time, and his teammates were paid $4,200 each for defending the Davis Cup last month in Ru mania.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: PAWTUCKET, R.I., Nov. 17 (AP)A mother and five of her children perished early today when a fire engulfed their singlefamily wood cottage while they were asleep. The father, a daughter and a step son survived. The police iden tified the victims as Mrs. Joseph Blogref, 37 years old, and her children, Arthur, 11; JoAnne, 9; Carol Ann, 6; Teresa, 5; and Michael, 3.

title: GIMBELS EMPLOYE ACCUSED IN KILLING
description: An employe described by the police as disgruntled over his work assignments at the Gim bels Department Store ware house annex in Long Island City, Queens, was accused of shooting and killing his imme diate superior there yesterday and of critically wounding a supervisor.

title: Story of Melanie R.
description: Melanie R. was buried in a green Long Island cemetery yesterday, 7,500 miles from the primitive, dusty city where she died 12 days ago at the end of an unaccomplished search for nirvana, as she once put it.

title: World Is a Carousel
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 13The world (was) (is) a cotton kandi carousel, all the people (were) are the orna ments, & and as it floats by, bubbles & bounces, all i can do is watch in amazement, or gaze with a blank look on my countenance & let it all happen let it whirl, twist or turn, let it spangle & bangle, let each piece take its turn being man, but i cease to be on it for the moment & all i can do is watch it all pass or float by  the color of clowns in the circus.

title: WEYERHAEUSER HEAD DENIES PRICE CHARGE
description: George H. Weyerhaeuser, president of the Weyerhaeuser Company, of Tacoma, Wash., issued a flat denial yesterday of charges made Tuesday in Miami by Stanley Waranch, president of the National Asso ciation of Home Builders.

title: MARJORIE HUTCHENS, A MAGAZINE WRITER
description: RYE, N. Y., Nov. 16Marjo rie Hutchens, a magazine writer and wife of John K. Hutchens, a writer and BookoftheMonth Club judge, died of cancer to day at the United Hospital in Port Chester. She was 48 years old, and lived at 307 Milton Road here.

title: U.N. UNIT DEPLORES THE USE OF NAPALM
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 16  The General Assem bly's main political committee today approved a resolution deploring the use of napalm in armed conflict.

title: MORRIS BLUMBERG
description: Morris Blumberg, former chairman of he Illinois Zinc Company and of Hydrometals, Inc., died yesterday in St. Ag nes Hospital, White Plains. He was 75 years old, a former resi dent of Manhattan, residing with his daughter, Mrs. Ade laide Reisfield, at 80 Oxford Boulevard, Great Neck. L. I.

title: MUSKIE SUGGESTS CHAIRMAN LEAVE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine gave Jean Westwood, the embattled Democratic party chairman, another gentle nudge toward resignation to day.

title: 10 HIGH POLICEMEN DIRECTED TO QUIT OR FACE DEMOTION
description: Ten highranking police of fieialsinspectors and deputy inspectorshave been told they lack the leadership qualities re quired for their rank and should retire from the department or face demotion.

title: BOMBING IN NORTH CONTINUES HEAVY
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Nov. 17 (AP)United States planes kept up intensive bombing of North Vietnamese supply lines yesterday, and pi lots reported having knocked out 68 trucks loaded with am munition.

title: House Unit's Head Urges A Separate Health Agency
description: Representative Paul G. Rog ers, Democrat of Florida, said yesterday that President Nix on's proposed reorganization of the Department of Health, Edu cation and Welfare should in clude the creation of a separate Department of Health with Cab inet rank.

title: Freehold Gets More Dates
description: TRENTON, Nov., 16 (UPI) Freehold Raceway has received state permission to open its harness season Aug. 6 next year, one week earlier than pre viously scheduled. The New Jer sey Racing Commission grant ed the extension yesterday and also gave Atlantic City Race way five extra days at Freehold this year, from Nov. 30 through Dec. 5. The commission extend ed the Freehold 1973 season after hearing protests from Freehold, Atlantic City and the Standardbred Breeders and Owners Association.

title: Heath, in Ulster, Warns the Extremists
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 16Prime Minister Heath told militant Ulster Protestants today that any attempt to seize independents from Britain would bring a bloodbath and poverty for Northern Ireland.

title: Catholic Bishops Ask End of Bombing in Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  Quoting their exhortations of a year ago for an end to the Vietnam war with no further delay, the Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States expressed hope today for a suc cessful outcome of the present negotiations and appealed for an end to bombing and ter rorism.

title: $250Million Surplus In State Budget Forecast
description: New York State will take in from $250million to $300mil lion more than it spends this year, Controller Arthur Levitt reported yesterday, but he de clined to say whether the sur plus should provide New York ers with a tax cut.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: BONN  All sides agree that the United States is completely neutral in next Sunday's West German elections. Helmut Schmidt, Finance and Econom ics Minister in the Social Democratic coalition fighting to hold power, adds the interesting comment that Wash ington only became impartial in this country's politics after President Nixon's inauguration in 1969.

title: Personalities: Rangers' Park Disabled; Patriots Suspend Garrett for Season
description: Brad Park, the Ranger de fenseman, will be on the sidelines for at least four weeks because of an injury suffered Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: MAYOR NAMES HEAD OF ECOLOGY PANEL
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday the appointment of Ruben S. Brown, now principal staff officer of the National Academy of Sciences Commit tee for International Programs, Environmental Studies Board, as the new director of the Council on the Environment of New York City, effective in early January.

title: JERSEY REJECTS EDUCATION CHIEF
description: TRENTON, Nov. 16  The State Senate today rejected the controversial reappointment of Dr. Carl L. Marburger as New Jersey's Commissioner of Edu cation by a margin of one vote in what was seen here as a ma jor victory for opponents of busing in the state.

title: WEST ASKS SOVIET AND BLOC TO TALKS ON CUTTING FORCES
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 16 The United States and several of its European allies have in vited the Soviet Union and some of its bloc partners to begin ex ploratory talks Jan. 31 on re ducing military forces in Cen tral Europe, the State Depart ment announced today.

title: Gorman 64, 64 Victor
description: LONDON, Nov. 17 (AP) Ilie Nastase of Rumania played spectacular tennis tonight to beat Jim Connors of Belleville, III., 63, 64, for a place in the Dewar Cup indoor final.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Met Discounts for the Aged
description: The Metropolitan Opera has extended its student rush ticket service, begun this season, to senior citizens. Upon presentation of transit identification cards 30 minutes before curtain time, elderly persons may buy unsold seats for $4. Information on the day of the performance, may be gotten by calling 5956700.

title: LOUISIANIAN HINTS ERROR IN KILLINGS
description: BATON ROUGE, Nov. 17  Two young black men killed in a campus confrontation yester day were possibly shot by a policeman who mistakenly loaded a buckshot shell instead of a teargas shell, Gov. Edwin W. Edwards said today.

title: SALE OF UNITS PART OF GULF WRITEOFFS
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation, in a prospectus filed with the Se curities and Exchange Commis sion yesterday, disclosed that its previously announced 1972 writeoffs of about $250million would include some 3,500 serv ice stations and related facili ties in the upper Middle West and northwestern sections of the United States.

title: Miss Mary V. McCloskey Married
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17  Miss Mary Virginia Mc Closkey and Alexander Eu stace Wolfington of New York were married here this evening by John Cardinal Krol, Archbishop of Philadel phia, in the Roman Catholic Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul.

title: 2 Witnesses Held As a Murder Alibi Is Found Untrue
description: Two witnesses in a murder trial whose testimony won a holdup man a hung jury in a murder trial were arrested yes terday on perjury charges after the man for whom they testi fied was convicted in his sec ond trial.

title: Detonator Truck Crashes
description: OKEMAH, Okla., Nov, 17 (UPI)  A truck loaded with 41,000 pounds of detonator fuses slammed into a bridge on Interstate 40 early today, burst into flames and exploded. The driver escaped serious iniury. The authorities said the fuses were exploding almost three hours after the crash.

title: Editorial Writers Elect
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Nov. 17 (UPI)  Lloyd Armour, asso ciate editor of The Nashville Tennessean, was unanimously elected president of the Na tional Conference of Editorial Writers yesterday.

title: O. B. ANDREWS JR., 68, CONTAINER OFFICIAL
description: CHATTANOOGA, Nov. 17 O. B. Andrews Jr., a retired vice president of the Container Corporation and former rewrite man and foreign correspondent for The New York Times, died here yesterday at the age of 68.

title: KISSINGER LEAVES TOMORROW TO SEE TNO ON CEASEFIRE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 The White House announced today that Henry A. Kissinger would return to Paris on Sun day to resume on Monday ne gotiations with North Vietnam that the Administration hopes will produce an Indochina set tlement within weeks.

title: CAMBODIANS REPORT FREEING SEA ROUTE
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 17 (Reuters)Cambodian troops have reoccupied the highway from Pnompenh to the sea after a twoweek closing halted the flow of imported food and United States military supplies to the captial, the Camodian military command reported to day.

title: DeJesus Outpoints Duran, Lightweight Titleholder
description: Roberto Duran is the world lightweight champion and the uncrowned streetfighting cham pion of his native Panama City. But he is not the master of Puerto Rico's Esteban DeJesus.

title: LoyaltyOath Stay Extended
description: AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 17 (AP)A Hampshire County Su perior Court judge continued indefinitely today a temporary restraining order granted to 18 University of Massachusetts staffers who had refused to take the state loyalty oath. Judge Samuel Tisdale stipu lated that no punitive action be taken against the 17 faculty members and one student em ploye for not signing the state required oath.

title: Stage: Robert Coover's The Kid Opens
Parents Seek More Police at School
description: yesterday security conditions in a Manhattan elementary school where a cleaning woman was raped on Wednesday, but they

title: Business Briefs
description: BONN, Nov. 17 (Agence FrancePresse)The Soviet Union has just placed a multimilliondollar order with the West German iron and steel industry, a spokesman for the Ministry of Economy confirmed here today.

title: Thieu Presses Formation Of a New Political Party
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 17  President Nguyen Van Thieu and his top aides are rushing to complete the organ ization of a new mass political party, with membership of 100,000 that Mr. Thieu hopes will enable him to compete ef fectively with the Communists under a ceasefire.

title: F.B.I. Chief Rebuts Critics in Hijacking
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17  Fifteen agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation were directly underneath a hijacked Southern Airways jet when they carried out orders to shoot out the plane's tires, L. Patrick Gray 3d, the bureau's acting director, disclosed tonight.

title: WINE TALK
description: PARIS, Nov. 16  It was like the land rushes of pio neer days.

title: Artificial Sight for Blind Sought
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 17A pioneer in the development of the artificial kidney has made what he describes as major progress in the development of artificial sight for the blind.

title: Notes on People
description: It wag just one of those unavoidable vacation mixups, said Senator Hubert H. Hum phrey, but the former Vice President was quite polite to the Vice President, and vice versa. Mr. Humphrey gave this account of the confusion in a telephone interview from Caneel Bay in St. John, V. I.: The former Vice President, his wife and their son and daughterinlaw were relax ing at Caneel Bay's cottage No. 7, overlooking the Carib bean. Normally, No. 7 is re served for incumbent Presi dents and Vice Presidents.

title: 3 Upstate Men Are Indicted On FloodAid Fraud Charge
description: ROCHESTER, Nov. 17 (AP) A Federal grand jury has in dicted three Elmiraarea men on charges of submitting fraudu lent applications for disaster loans following the June 25 flood.

title: Kent State Appeal Rejected
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 17 (AP) The Sixth United States Cir cuit Court of Appeals declined today to overturn the dismissal of $11million in damage suits brought by parents of three Kent State students killed by National Guardsmen on May 4, 1970. The court said that the suits are in substance actions against the state and that suits against the state are pro hibited by the 11th Amend ment.

title: Welfare Reform: Try Again
description: President Nixon's family assistance plan, three years debated, seems now to be dead. Welfare officials should not be blamed for this debacle. How ever laboriously, in Washington and across the country, they were prepar ing for salvation. The family assistance plan, however, was a White House con game from the beginning. It promised savings to conservatives and liberaliza tions to liberals. When each saw what the other might get, all turned on the program.

title: Peronism Offers the Young a Doctrine; For the Mature It Recalls the Old Days
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 17 Perhaps half the 25 million Ar gentines still call a fine sunny day or a lucky day in business or in love a Peronist's day.

title: Donald S. Hostetter Dies at 64; ExF.B.I. Agent Headed S.L.A.
description: HEBER SPRINGS, Ark., Nov. 17Donald S. Hostetter, a for mer special agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who re tired as chairman of the New York State Liquor Authority two years ago, died here today in the Cleburne County Hospital after a long illness. He was 64 years old and had lived here since his retirement.

title: Issue of Saigon Newspaper Seized Over Nixon Cartoon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 17 (Reuters)The Gov ernment seized today's issues of four Vietnameselanguage dailies, one of them, Trang Den, for printing a cartoon critical of President Nixon.

title: St. Louis Mayor Appeals Life Magazine Libel Suit
description: ST. LOUIS, Nov. 17 (UPI) Mayor Alfonso J. Cervantes has appealed his libel suit against Life magazine to the United States Supreme Court, his of fice said today.

title: Cholera Cases Are Traced To Bahrain Airport Kitchen
description: GENEVA, Nov. 17 (Reuters) A meal prepared at Bahrain's airport was the probable source of cholera cases in Australia, New Zealand and Britain ear lier this month, the World Health Organization said here today.

title: Rhodesia Plans New Curb on Blacks
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 17 (Agence FrancePresse) The Rhodesian Government in troduced legislation in Parlia ment today requiring every black over the age of 16 to carry a registration certificate or identity card at all times.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Nov. 17  The Newark Housing Authority brought the leaders of the city's longrunning public hous ing rent strike to court today to try to pick up their $94,000 strike fund, but the agency came away emptyhanded.

title: A Lindsay Aide Resigns
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday ac cepted with a great sense of personal regret the resignation of Harvey Rothenberg, his $1 ayear confidential assistant and a longtime friend. Mr. Rothenberg a wealthy busi nessman who played a key role in Mr. Lidsay's 1965 and 1969 mayoral campaigns, said he was relinquishing his post to devote more time to his family and business.

title: Police Enlisting Blockwatchers to Get Instant Tips on Crime
description: About 100 Brooklyn resi dents left a community meet ing in Bay Ridge as enrolled members of the Police De partment's new citizen crime reporting network.

title: Strike Involving 19 Bakeries Here Enters 18th Day
description: A bakery strike and lockout continutd yesterday for the 17th day, with 19 specialty bakers unable to reach an ac cord with the union represent ing striking driversalesmen

title: Carnation Company Reports Increases in Its NineMonth Sales and Earnings
White Jury Urges Death for a Black In a Fatal Robbery
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 17 (UPI)An allwhite jury, ig noring the recent decision of the United States Supreme Court virtually outlawing the death penalty, went beyond a prosecutor's request for a mil lionyear prison sentence yes terday and recommended that a black defendant die in the electric chair.

title: Mylai Figure Seeks to Bar His Discharge by the Army
description: COLUMBUS. Ga. Nov. 17 (UPI)  S. Sgt. Kenneth L. Hodges, who was accused in the Mylai slayings in Vietnam, appealed yesterday in United States District Court for a per manent injunction to stop the Army from discharging him.

title: Call of the Caftan: Begun in Mideast, Now It's Being Heard Everywhere
description: Consider the caftan (or djel laba, or burnoose or djiba). Originally a loose garment that protected the denizens of North Africa or the Le vant against the onslaught of sun, sand and wind, it has been transplanted intact to some of the most fash ionable drawing rooms of the Western world. And now for spring, it threatens to be come even more popular.

title: Antiques: The Bed Rug
description: HARTFORDThere are a lot of people who didn't know there were so many bed rugs. Indeed, there are even more who didn't know there were any at all.

title: Thieu Presses Formation Of a New Political Party
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 17  President Nguyen Van Thieu and his top aides are rushing to complete the organ ization of a new mass political party, with membership of 100,000 that Mr. Thieu hopes will enable him to compete ef fectively with the Communists under a ceasefire.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: PNOMPENH, Nov. 17 (AP) The Cambodian command said today that its troops had re opened the road from Pnom penh to Cambodia's ricegrow ing area in the northwest.

title: JAPAN IS REDUCING TARIFFS ON IMPORTS
description: TOKYO, Nov. 17The Jap anese Government adopted to day measures for a 20 per cent acrosstheboard cut in tariffs on industrial and processed ag ricultural products. The reduc tions will go into effect tomor row.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: William Clarke, 48yearold professional from the Hillandale Country Club in Phoenix, Md., is the new president of the Professional Golfers Association. He was elected at the organization's convention, which ended in Los Angeles yesterday. Frank Cardi of Cedarhurst, L. I., was runnerup in the balloting.

title: A BOLD APPROACH BY WILSON AT PIANO
description: As a pianist who takes a bold, forthright approach to his tasks, Laurence Wilson was heard to best advantage in Mussorgsky's colorful Pictures at an Exhibition at his Car negie Hall recital Thursday night. The other works on the program required shades of subtlety and pianistic refine ment that Mr. Wilson does not now command.

title: COLOMBIAN AUTHOR IS AWARDED $10,000
description: NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 17  The Colombian novelist Gabriel Garcia Marquez has been awarded a $10,000 prize for literature by the literary jour nal Books Abroad, it was an nounced here today.

title: CRUSADERS DOWN NEW ENGLAND, 30
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 17 (AP) The Cleveland Crusaders scored three lastperiod goals to defeat the New England Whalers, 30, tonight. Gerry Cheevers recorded his third World Hockey Association shutout.

title: COURT UPHOLDS BAIL FOR MURDER CASES
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 (AP)The State Supreme Court ruled today that murder sus pects in Pennsylvania had a right to bail.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 17 One hundred delegates to the New Jersey State League of Municipalitiesmayors, coun cilmen and municipal officials today urged the Legislature to readjust the taxexempt status of state, county and other publicly owned properties with in municipalities to ease local tax burdens.

title: Music: A Weber Rarity
description: Two novelties were on the Thursday night New York Philharmonic program, and one of them was welcome. Malcolm Frager at the piano and ?? Maazel on the po dium collaborated to present a splitsecond account of Carl Maria von Weber's Piano Con certo No. 2 in E flat.

title: Art: 19thCentury Italian Work
description: The exhibition Ottocento Painting in American Collec tions, which opened this week at the New York Cul tural Center, 2 Columbus Cir cle. is one of those shows a critic feels duty bound to cover. Comprising 56 works by 31 artists, the exhibition provides a survey of a gen erally neglected area of mod ern art history19thcentury Italian painting.

title: AGENCY HOLDS UP PESTICIDES BAN
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP)  The Environmental Protec tion Agency, completing a courtordered review, has de cided not to impose an imme diate ban on remaining uses of the pesticides aldrin and dieldrin, an agency, official said today.

title: Opera: Debut of Soyer
description: The arrival of a firstrate Don Giovanni on the scene is rare enough to be worth celebrating, and the Metro politan Opera is therefore entitled to break out the champagne. The newcomer is Roger Soyer, a rapierslim French bass who made an impressive debut on Thurs day night in the season's seventh Don Giovanni.

title: TV: Irish Island Drama Is No. 100 on Hall of Fame
description: Beginning its 22d consecu tive season on the National Broadcasting Company, the Hallmark Hall of Fame last night offered The Hands of Cormac Joyce as its 100th television production. Adapted by S. S. Schweitzer from a novel by Leonard Wibberly, and directed by Fielder Cook, the story was set in the Aran Islands, off the west coast of Ireland. This being tele vision, however, the story was filmed on Phillip Island, off the coast of Australia.

title: U.S.Russian Talks About Grain Rates Remain Deadlocked
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 United States and Soviet nego tiators remained deadlocked today after two days of dis cussions on how to define the world charter rate under which American ships are to carry grain purchased here to the Soviet Union.

title: WOMAN TRAINER HAS $59 WINNER
description: Sally, you're the best train er in the United States, said the horse player at Aqueduct yesterday. I just had $50 on your horse.

title: Devastating Effects of OTB On Tracks, Tax Intake Cited
description: Offtrack betting has had a devastating effect on race track attendance and state parimutuel tax revenue but little or no effect on illegal bookmaking, two City Uni versity of New York econo mists told the Delafield Com mission here yesterday.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Nov. 17 (UPI)It was a dark day for baseball players from the States in Caribbean winter league play.

title: Olin Seeks to Ease Fears of Employes Of Aluminum Group
description: The Olin Corporation sought yesterday to allay the fears of employes of its aluminum group by assuring them that it intends to keep up operations until it can find a buyer.

title: U. S. CURBS IMPORTS OF SMALL TURTLES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UPI) Federal officials or dered major restrictions today on the importation into the United States of small turtles. They estimated that about 280, 000 persons a year catch a dis order known as salmonellosis from the reptiles.

title: Man Is Killed and 14 Arrested In Narcotics Raids in Brooklyn
description: One man was killed and 14 others were arrested yesterday as some 35 narcotics detectives armed with noknock warrants carried out a series of simul taneous drug raids in the Bush wick section of Brooklyn.

title: Fred Dickson, 43, Who Sought Columbus's Santa Maria, Dead
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 17 (AP)Fred Dickson, who spent the last five years seeking the wreck of Columbus's flagship, the Santa Maria, died yesterday during a diving expedition off the coast of Haiti, associates reported here. His age was 43.

title: Cooks Call Strikes at 80 Places, But Many of Them Remain Open
description: The chefs and cooks union announced yesterday that it was striking at 80 or more restaurants affiliated with the Restaurant League, but a check disclosed that many of the es tablishments were operating as usual last night.

title: Miss Pamela Cady Schaeffer Wed to G. Nicholas Buffington
description: The Fifth Avenue Presty terian Church was the set ting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Pamela Cady Schaeffer to G. Nicholas Buffington. The Rev. Kenneth Jones per formed the ceremony.

title: Kodak Drops Plan To Market Films For Polaroid Use
description: The Eastman Kodak Com pany announced yesterday that it had changed its mind and no longer planned to market its own selfdeveloping film for use in Polaroid Corporation cameras.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Nov. 17Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson scoffed to day at reports that he is being pressured to drop the 38year old executive director of the city's High Impact AntiCrime Program because of delays in getting it under way.

title: SYRACUSE'S BUDGET IS HELD TO BE LEGAL
description: SYRACUSE, Nov. 17 (AP)A State Supreme Court justice ruled today that a city budget amended and passed by the Syracuse Common Council is a legal spending plan.

title: Dr. Edward B. Willingham Dies; Aide of Baptist Mission Society
description: The Rev. Dr. Edward B. Willingham, general secretary of the American Baptist Foreign Mission Society from 1955 to 1965 and a past western treas urer of the World Baptist Alli ance, died Thursday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 15 Clare mont Avenue.

title: Recount Shows Peyser Winner, But Ottinger Refuses to Concede
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 17  An official recount completed late today showed that Rep resentative Peter A. Peyscr had won reelection in the 23d Con gressional District over former Representative Richard L. Ot tinger.

title: Price Changes
description: The United States Steel Cor poration said yesterday that it planned to raise prices on a va riety of products on Jan. 1 and Feb. 16.

title: Personalities: Time Out For Bronco Linebacker
description: When Don Parish played for the St. Louis Cardinals as a National Football League rookie two years ago, he was considered a promising out side linebacker. After having been named to various All America teams and voted the outstanding senior in the Pa cific Eight as a Stanford star, Parish became a starter with the Cardinals and was named their rookie of the year.

title: CHESS TOURNAMENT DRAWS TOP PLAYERS
description: Sixteen of the world's strong est chess players, including former world champion, will meet tomorrow in San Antonio, Tex., for the Fried Chicken Tournament.

title: F.B.I. Asked for 3
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 17 Three Frenchmen expelled from Brazil on charges of drug traffic connections were sent to the United States rather than France at the request of the United States Federal Bureau of Investigation, a spokesman for the Brazilian federal police said tonight.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two college students and a 16yearold girl have been arrested and charged with setting fire to an interracial church in Forest Hills, District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens announced yesterday.

title: U.S. OFFERS TO LIMIT CHICAGO 7 CONTEMPT
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (UPI) The Federal Government of fered today to limit possible punishment of Chicago Seven trial defendants on contempt charges to 177 days in an ef fort to avoid jury trials in the cases.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Nov. 17 (AP) More than a year after Peter Stewart, a Democrat from Caldwell, was elected as an Assemblyman, the Appellate Division of Superior Court up held his election. The court to day rejected the appeal filed by Mr. Stewart's Republican opponent, John F. Trezza, and other unsuccessful G.O.P. can didates. They had asked a lower court to count all absen tee ballots received by the Es sex County Election Board after the polls closed but post marked before then.

title: Sports of The Times
description: In the sixroom suite of offices that the New York Raiders occupy in the Statler Hilton Hotel, pennants of the other World Hockey Association teams decorate one wall, but there is no Raider pennant. Nearby the symbol of the new league, Bobby Hull, skates furiously on a poster, wearing the uniform of the Chicago Black Hawks, not the Winnipeg Jets, his W.H.A. team. In a back room, unsold stacks of orange tickets, blue tickets, red tickets, yellow tickets and green tickets betray the club's financial situation. Behind the general manager's desk, the chair is empty. It has been empty for three weeks, ever since Marvin Milkes resigned abruptly. There is no player per sonnel director. There is not even a scout on the payroll. Short money has the Raiders in trouble. But through the office windows, across Seventh Avenue, towers 2 Penn Plaza, the office building of the Madison Square Garden complex. And the Garden is the subtle reason why the Raider franchise is for sale. When the Raiders got the Garden as their landlord, they didn't realize they were getting an undertaker, too.

title: Police Pilot Project in Brooklyn Successful in Cutting Car Thefts
description: A pilot police project in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn to place luminescent decals on car windows detail ing their owners by age, sex and residential area seems promising, a patrolman who started the program said yes terday.

title: New Flu Strain Turns Up At Air Base in Colorado
description: DENVER, Nov. 17 (UPI) The Colorado Department of Health said yesterday that it had discovered a new strain of influenza virus known as A2England at Lowry Air Force Base east of Denver.

title: The $45 Cat Bite
description: One of the best ways to test the quality of medical care in your friend ly neighborhood emergency room is to get bitten by an illtempered, impul sive Siamese cat. That is precisely what happened to me when I was tak ing care of said cat for a friend who was out of town.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 (AP)The Pennsylvania Su preme Court upheld today a lower court ruling allowing the Continental Racing Association to keep its license and conduct thoroughbred racing at Liberty Bell Park. The original action was brought by the Valley Forge Racing Association, which held that Continental had not met licens ing conditions set by the state's Horse Racing Commission.

title: British Price Index Up
description: LONDON, Nov. 17 (Reuters) The retail price index last month rose 2.3 points, its high est jump in 18 months, ac cording to figures released to day by the Department of Employment. The department put the index at 168.7 on Oct. 17 against 166.4 on Sept. 19. (Jan, 1962 equals 100).

title: Letters to the Editor
description: It is hardly surprising that the ques tion of civilian prisoners has emerged as a key stumbling block to peace in Vietnam. Inasmuch as most neutral ist leaders in South Vietnam have either been driven into exile or are in prison, the release and return of many of these people will obviously be necessary for the realization of any tripartite administrative council pro posed by the ninepoint plan.

title: Please Stand By,' a Parody of Activism
description: "Please Stand By," which opened yesterday at the Bleecker Street Cinema, is the first feature movie of Jack and Joanne Milton, a pleasant young couple, both teachers, who have been variously involved in TVcommercial production and magazine publishing. Though shot in 16-mm, and, I should think, on a fairly tight budget, "Please Stand By" has about it such an air of professional public relations that I can't help feeling that its creators' backgrounds have something to do with the failure of an ambitious but ultimately very bad-movie.It is a fantasy fiction film about a group of young New York activists led by one Freemont Zappata (the street singer David Peel) and his girl, Marian (Wendy Appel), who hijack special equipment with which they can interrupt network television for brief periods in order to broadcast their own counter-culture messages.They succeed for a while, but a spy in their midst betrays their location, and Freemont is captured by the Feds, who transport him to an island detention center off the coast of New Rochelle. But after a trial, conviction and much tedious film time, Freemont is sprung by his friends, who then go back to their noncommercials. Alone, and dressed in black, Freemont rides off on horseback along a Pelham Bay bridle pathan El Topo of the Bronx.There is a certain amount of specific movie parody in "Please Stand By," most extensively and depressingly of the eating-seduction sequence in "Tom Jones." But the whole film is really dependent on parody from beginning to endparody sex, parody adventure, parody politics, even parody radicalismand it is saddening to see a movie ostensibly committed to freedom of thought and expression so tied to the superficial repetition offormulas.I think there is much to be said against any revolutionary movement whose primary aim is to put itself on television. But the media freaks in "Please Stand By" seem especially reprehensible because their subversive messages turn out to be little collage-animations attacking war and consumerism, and supporting peace, love and ecological sanity. There is nothing here that might not do, say, for a public-service spot during the "Joe Franklin Show." This is the kind of rebellion that might secretly hope for a contract with C.B.S. next year.But the Miltons obviously posses the executive skills necessary to make a movie, and there are moments in "Please Stand By" that are technically impressive if nothing else. The cast, when it is performing rather than rapping, seems competent, and Wendy Appel, a very beautiful woman, gives the impression that she may also be an actress of real interest.

title: Bullets Down Suns
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 17 (AP) Phil Chenier and Elvin Hayes led a secondhalf Baltimore comeback tonight as the Bul lets defeated the Phoenix Suns, 117106. Chenier scored 18 points and Hayes 17 in the final two quarters.

title: 76ers End Sonic Slump
description: SEATTLE, Nov. 17 (AP) Seattle's SuperSonics rallied late in the third quarter tonight to whip the Philadelphia 76ers, 10592, and break a ninegame losing streak.

title: BIG SUR WORRIED OVER ERE SLIDES
description: BIG SUR, Calif., Nov. 17 (UPI)Despite a break in the rain, deep fissures in the moun tainside today threatened this Pacific Coast community with a third devastating mud and rock slide.

title: Police Alcoholism Aid Fought in a Suit Here
description: A 24yearold city patrol man sought in State Supreme Court yesterday to nullify a Police Department ruling that required him to enroll in a departmental program to combat alcoholism.

title: Books of The Times
description: Seldom has the search for commitment, the choice of a way been more painful and more difficult than for the generation of East European Jews in the years leading up to World War I. To the Poles and Russians among whom they lived, the Jewish community must have seemed a monolithic enclave, though strange and exotic. Few of the outsiders knew, or understood if they did know, of the forces that were tearing at the community, of the appeals made to the intellect, to nationalistic pas sions, to old faiths, to that solidarity without which Jews could not survive. Stifled and threatened in the ghetto, each individual sought a way out. Could one retain the old beliefs, adhere to ancient practices and be emancipated? Or was secularization the way out? And if so, what road did one take: world revolution to set all people free, personal advance ment through emigration and trade in the new world, assimilation by embracing foreign and Western cultures, nationalistic striving to restore a lost homeland to a scattered people?

title: Evers Will Seek Reelection As Mayor of Fayette in '73
description: JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 17 (AP)Charles Evers, the black leader, said this week that he would seek reelection as May or of Fayette next year, and that unless he was persuaded otherwise, he would run for Governor in 1975.

title: British Post Office Stops Letter Bomb Sent to M.P.
description: LONDON, Nov. 17 (Reuters) Special British postal security stopped a letter bomb from reaching the House of Com mons, Scotland Yard disclosed today.

title: Brewster Guilty of Accepting a Gratuity
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17  Former United States Senator Daniel B. Brewster was found guilty today of accepting an unlawful gratuity from a Wash ington lobbyist to influence his Senate vote on postal rate legislation.

title: Ford Recalls 11,725 Autos And 31,660 Trucks in Check
description: DETROIT, Nov. 17 (UPI) The Ford Motor Company has announced the recall of 11,725 cars and 31,660 trucks to re pair suspected brake or car buretion defects in 2,600 of the vehicles.

title: KISSINGER LEAVES TOMORROW TO SEE THO ON CEASEFIRE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 The White House announced today that Henry A. Kissinger would return to Paris on Sun day to resume on Monday ne gotiations with North Vietnam that the Administration hopes will produce an Indochina set tlement within weeks.

title: C.I.A. MYSTERY: PERU'S ANCHOVIES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17The Central Intelligence Agency's thirst for worldwide intelligence has turned to Peruvian an chovies and a mysterious warm current in the Pacific that made the fish disappear this year.

title: Man in the News
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 17 The proud statues of Argen tina's 24th President, which used to cover the country, are all gone, toppled by his enemies. But the man, Juan Domingo Pern Sosa, has tried to make himself into a monument.

title: Defeat in New Jersey
description: In voting down the reappointment of Education Com missioner Carl L. Marburger, the New Jersey State Senate has surrendered to pressure by the conservative education establishment and the antibusing constituency. The rejection of a forwardlooking leader in a field overstocked with unimaginative bureaucrats is a harsh blow to the public education system of a state that has only recently begun to catch up with modernity.

title: O'Melia Outpoints Houston In the Battle of Teachers
description: NORTH BERGEN, N. J., Nov. 16 (UPI)Brian O'Melia, 197 pounds, Jersey City, outpointed previously uneaten Jerry Hous ton, 218, Bedford, Mass., in an eightround bout tonight at Em bassy Hall.

title: BIG HEROIN RINGS SMASHED BY U.S.; LEADERS INDICTED
description: The reputed leaders of two international heroinsmuggling rings were indicted yesterday on charges of conspiring to smuggle more than 1,100 pounds of heroin, valued at $250million, into the United States between January, 1968, and April, 1971.

title: Opera: Met's Siegfried
description: The third in the Metropoli tan's yearslong Ring cycle was presented last night when Siegfried came to the stage. This was the produc tion scheduled two seasons back and canceled because of labor difficulties. It is the so called Karajan version for the Salzburg Festival.

title: Afghans Look Other Way As Drug Outflow Expands
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 13Steady streams of opium and hashish flow over the unpatrolled and porous borders of this landlocked kingdom and through its two airports, aided by a largely indifferent Gov ernment and many of its offi cials and employes.

title: First Out
description: It is distressing but not surprising that the Rev. Theo dore M. Hesburgh has now become the first victim President Nixon's loudly proclaimed housecleaning the upper reaches of the Federal establishment.

title: A Deserter, Yes, But a Coward and Criminal?
description: My son Keith is a victim of the Vietnam war as surely as if he were missing in action. It is nearly two years since I have seen or heard from him, and when next we shall meet, if ever we do, is problematical. For Keith is one of those numberless young Americans (how many? no one knows) who, caught in the trap of military service, found no answer but deser tion.

title: Onlookers Greet Amish Travelers
description: CHESTER, N. Y. Nov. 17 From dawn to dusk today, Eli Garber's horsedrawn wagon creaked westward through rural villages past scores of onlookers who poured out of stores and houses to wish him well on his journey to Pennsylvania.

title: A Policeman Is Sentenced In Lyons ViceRing Scandal
description: PARIS, Nov. 17A court to day found police officer Jean Simonnin guilty of procuring in a case growing out of a Lyons police scandal.

title: JERSEY COLLEGES SEEK BUDGET RISE
description: TRENTON, Nov. 17  New Jersey's Board of Higher Edu cation recommended today a 13 per cent increase in spend ing for the state's institutions of higher learning in fiscal 1974. This year the actual in crease was 20 per cent, and the year before, 22 per cent.

title: G. M. Warns Its Executives To Improve Auto Quality
description: DETROIT, Nov. 17John Z. DeLorean, a General Motors vice president, has warned other executives of the corpora tion that poor quality threat ens to destroy us and that warranty repairs now cost the company nearly $500million a year.

title: Soviet Denies Terrorists Fit Robin Hood Image
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 17The Soviet Union, in its strongest statement on ter rorism, warned today that in dividual terrorists must be stopped before their destruc tive power got any greater.

title: President's Proclamation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UPI)Following is the text of President Nixon's Thanksgiving Day proclamation, is sued by the White House today:

title: SHELLING REPORTED IN GOLAN HEIGHTS
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 17 (Reuters) Fire was exchanged briefly across the SyrianIsrael cease fire line in the Golan Heights today, Israeli military sources reported.

title: TV: The Last Journey, Tolstoy's Twilight Years
description: Who's afraid of Leo Tol stoy? Not his wife.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Aleksander Leyfell (letter, Oct. 25) makes a valid criticism of the fail ure of some Western intellectuals to protest the denial of intellectual free dom in Communist countries. It is unclear, however, why he feels it is necessary to direct this charge against the members of the Ad Hoc Committee for Intellectual Freedom.

title: SoftDrink Detente
description: Somewhere out there on the steppes an underground poet may be scrawling the forbidden words, It's the Real ThingCoke Is! But the Iron Curtain is still down for CocaCola now that a deal has been made between the Ministry of Trade and PepsiCola for exclusive bot tling and distribution rights in the Soviet Union. The Pepsi Generation is about to explode with a fizz from the Ukraine to Siberia.

title: Exchange Scanning Royal Dutch Trades
description: The New York Stock Ex change said yesterday that it was looking into the possibility that certain information con cerning the Royal Dutch Petro leum Company and affiliated concerns might have been im properly used to profit in the stock market.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 17 (AP)Gary Player, using his sand wedge to perfection, shot a oneunderpar 68 today and held a twostroke lead after two rounds of the $24,000 Brazil open golf tournament. The South African called the beachside and mountainous Gavea Country Club course one of the toughest short courses I've ever seen. Steve Melnyk of Jacksonville, Fla., was fourth at 140.

title: Oilers Beat Cougars
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, Nov. 17 (UPI)The Alberta Oilers exploded for three goals in the third period to beat the hap less Chicago Cougars, 3.1, to night.

title: Culkin Dismisses Two Perjury Charges
description: State Supreme Court Justice Gerald P. Culkin has dismissed perjury charges against two former detectives indicted in connection with an investiga tion by the Manhattan District Attorney's office into murder and possible corruption by offi cials.

title: Drive on Smut Aims at Building Owners
description: The city broadened its anti smut campaign in the Times Square area yesterday, moving against owners of buildings where peep shows operate. Heretofore, the city has acted only against the operators of peep shows.

title: SQUIRES TOPPLE COLONELS, 122116
description: HAMPTON, Va., Nov. 17 (AP) Julius Erving poured in 45 points and Virginia hit all of its 26 freethrow attempts tonight as the Squires rallied from a 15point deficit in the second quarter and defeated the Ken tucky Colonels, 122115, in an American Basketball Associa tion game.

title: Police in Connecticut Searching For the Car of Slain Professor
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 17  The police were searching today for the automobile of a University of Bridgeport profes sor found slain earlier this week in his apartment here.

title: Market Place: Real and Ideal In C.P.A. Audits
