description: Judging from increasing concern voiced by some of those dealing regularly with certified public accountants, it is perhaps fair to ask whether audits conducted by C.P.A.s are always as inde pendent as they might be.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Thanksgiving is a traditional festive family holiday for most of us. But it would be a holiday of extra loneliness and isolation for close to 300 elderly, were it not for the Senior Citizens program of Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association.

title: LOUIS C. ZAHNER, 79, TAUGHT AT GROTON
description: GROTON, Mass., Nov. 17  Louis C. Zahner, chairman emeritu's of the English Depart ment at Groton School, where he taught from 1920 to 1959, died here yesterday. He was 79 years old.

title: MRS. GILES ST. CLAIR
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Nov. 17 Mrs. Florence Penick St. Clair, widow of Giles St. Clair, a former vice president of S. B. Penick & Co., a drug manu facturing concern, died yester day at her home here. She was 53 years old and also lived in Ocean Reef, Fla.

title: Bruins, With Orr Back, Face Islanders Tonight
U. S. Jets Aid Saigon Units Near Quangtri
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Nov. 18 (AP)Mili tary sources reported yester day that some United States planes that had been bombing North Vietnam had been as signed instead to give dose sup port to South Vietnamese troops in increasingly sharp ground action around Quangtri.

title: BIG HEROIN RINGS SMASHED BY U.S.; LEADERS INDICTED
description: The reputed leaders of two international heroinimuggling rings were indicted yesterday on charges of conspiring to smuggle more than 1,100 pounds of heroin, valued at $250million, into the United States between January, 1968, and April, 1971.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: About 200 patrons of a Pennsauken bar that featured topless gogo dancers dashed from the place yesterday into the face of television news cameras that were covering a lunchtime raid by the state police. A police spokesman said that 18 persons were arrested, including four dancers, who were charged with lewdness. The others were all part of the management of the bar, the Club Lido, and were charged with aiding and abetting lewdness.

title: Governor Holds Lively Town Meeting
description: It's a lively meeting, ladies and gentlemen, Governor Rockefeller said yesterday as his fifth town meeting this week verged on its third hour.

title: Hanoi Aide Lands in Paris And Asks a Speedy Peace
description: PARIS, Nov. 17  Le Duc Tho arrived here today for an other round of negotiations with Henry A. Kissinger and said his aim was the rapid con clusion of the agreement on ending the war and restoring peace in Vietnam.

title: Scattered Demonstrations Score Killing of 2 on Southern Campus
description: Scattered demonstrations were held around the country yesterday to protest the shoot ing deaths of two blacks Thurs day at Southern University in Baton Rouge. The National Education Association offered to send a team to investigate the incident.

title: Liquor Strikes Threaten to Make Local Thanksgiving Dinners Dry Ones
description: Thanksgiving holiday liquor buyers may be drinking brands they never heard of or nothing at all if strikes by local liquor wholesalers' employes and truck drivers continue into next week. Both strikes entered their 18th day today.

title: Cunard Line Will Add New Cruise Ship in '75
description: The Cunard Line announced heer yesterday that it had placed an order for a new cruise liner.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: FREEHOLD, Nov. 17 (UN) A Superior Court judge denied motions today to dismiss the briberyconspiracy convictions of Secretary of State Paul J. Sherwin and two codefendants.

title: Reed and Jabbar Will Duel Tonight
description: The old and dramatic duel between Willis Reed and Ka reem AbdulJabbar, the domi nant offensive center in the National Basketball Association, will be renewed tonight at Madison Square Garden when the Knicks meet the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: Strike Involving 19 Bakeries Here Enters 18th Day
description: A bakery strike and lockout continutd yesterday for the 17th day, with 19 specialty bakers unable to reach an ac cord with the union represent ing striking driversalesmen.

title: Yugoslavia's WelltoDo Are Targets of Informers
description: BELGRADE, Nov. 17  A surge of accusing, anonymous letters by informers and a rush by the welltodo to sell shops and villas appear to reflect a sense of public insecurity as the Yugoslav Communist party steps up its campaign against ideological backsliding and the accumulation of wealth.

title: Talks Renewed
description: A sense of relief greets the news that Henry Kissinger will be on his way to Paris tomorrow for that long awaited and, hopefully, final meeting with North Viet nam's peace negotiators.

title: HESBURGH FORCED FROM RIGHTS POST
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17The White House retreated today from its contention that the resignation of the Rev. Theo dore M Hesburgh as chairman of the United States Commis sion on Civil Rights had been instigated by Father Hesburgh rather than by the Administra tion.

title: CHARLES I. SCHWAT
description: Charles I. Schwat, a former advertising director of the New York WorldTelegram and The Sun, died Thursday in Hallan dale, Fla., where he lived. His age was 73.

title: Ashe and Okker Reach Dutch Net Final; Nastase Vanquishes Connors in London
description: ROTTERDAM, The Nether lands, Nov. 17 (AP) Serving better than he had in recent weeks, Arthur Ashe of New York defeated Mark Cox of Britain, 63, 26, 75, to advance to the final of the $50,000 World Championship Tennis tour tournament today.

title: Art: Show on Print Buyer's Hazards
description: The public swan song of the Martin Gordon Gallery at 1062 Madison Avenue, near 81st Street, which is going to close down and become one of those private byap pointment  only establish ments, is an exhibition cal culated to show you how much we are about to lose in good shows. Called Buy er Beware, it is an outline of the hazards in the path of the mere art lover rather than art specialist when sets out to buy an etching, engraving or other print.

title: SECRETARIAT 15 AT GARDEN STATE
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., Nov. 17 (AP)Meadow Stable's Sec retariat may go off as the shortestprice favorite in the 20year history of the rich Gar den State Stakes tomorrow.

title: Afghans Look Other Way As Drug Outflow Expands
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 13Steady streams of opium and hashish flow over the unpatrolled and porous borders of this landlocked kingdom and through its two airports, aided by a largely indifferent Gov ernment and many of its offi cials and employes.

title: Merger News
description: Pepsico, Inc., announced yes terday that, according to pre liminary results, it had received in excess of 2.4 million com mon shares of the Rheingold Corporation, or about 76 per cent of the common shares out standing, in response to its tender offer.

title: Almost All Jefferson High Annex Teachers Back, as Parents Assail Day's Walkout
description: All but one of the 59 teach ers at Thomas Jefferson High School Annex returned to work yesterday as parents voiced criticism of the walkout on Thursday that dramatized de mands by the teachers for more protection against roving youth gangs in the school's East New York area.

title: Heath Sees Ulster Backing His Course
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 17Prime Minister Heath said tonight at the end of a twoday visit to Northern Ire land that he had encountered a general confidence that his Government would produce a fair political settlement for the province.

title: $2Billion Is Raised At Treasury Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 The Treasury raised $2bil lion with the auction today of 147day taxanticipation bills for which bidding ap peared quite aggressive. The average rate of discount ap proximated 4.722 per cent, equivalent to a price of 98.072.

title: Heller Sees No Tax Rise in '73
description: TORONTO, Nov. 17 (Reuters) The economist, Walter W. Heller, said today he did not foresee a tax increase in the United States in 1973, but one could come in 1974most likely a surtax on corporations.

title: Reforms Are Urged In the Penal System By Justice Burger
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 (UPI)Chief Justice Warren E. Burger said yesterday that an improved penal system  not stricter prison sentences or larger police forceswas the answer to America's rising crime rate.

title: Miss Skiba Is Bride of Gavin Hadden 3d
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Nov. 17 St. Thomas's Roman Catho lic Church here was the set ting for the wedding of Miss Patricia Elizabeth Skiba, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Skiba, to Gavin Hadden 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hadden Jr., also of Fair field. The Rev. Stephen De Luca, pastor of the Holy Name of Jesus Roman Catho lic Church in Stratford, per formed the ceremony.

title: CELTICS BEATEN BY BUCKS, 9588
description: BOSTON, Nov. 17 (AP)The Milwaukee Bucks, led by Kar eem AbdulJabbar, rallied from a 15point halftime deficit to night and handed the Boston Celtics a 95.88 defeat, their second loss of the season in the National Basketball Asso ciation. A crowd of 15,316 watched at the Garden.

title: A Lindsay Aide Resigns
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday ac cepted with a great sense of personal regret the resignation of Harvey Rothenberg, his $1 ayear confidential assistant and a longtime friend. Mr. Rothenberg, a wealthy busi nessman who played a key role in Mr. Lidsay's 1965 and 1969 mayoral campaigns, said he was relinquishing his post to devote more time to his family and business.

title: HESBURGH FORCED FROM RIGHTS POST
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17  The White House retreated to day from its contention that the resignation of the Rev. Theodore H. Hesburgh as chair man of the United States Com mission on Civil Rights had been instigated by Father Hes burgh rather than by the Ad ministration.

title: Health Policy Paradox
description: Not since enactment of Medicare and Medicaid in 1965 has there been such major change in the Government's medical care program as that provided in the Social Security Bill signed by President Nixon. As, there was relatively little public attention to these provisions while the multifaceted bill was going through months of consideration in Congress, special interests were able to exert maximum pressure. The result is a health policy paradox, a law which goes charging off in several direc tions at the same time.

title: The Promise of Amnesty
description: SALINAS, Calif.The Nixon Admin istration has loaded the news media with militarygame words that roll off of political tongues like buttered pop corn. The simple word that they choke on is amnesty. First used by the Athenians to patch up their rebellion torn city in 403 B.C., it could be used again in 1972.

title: CocaCola Confident On Deal With Soviet
description: The CocaCola Company told its top officers yester day to be confident that CocaCola as the world's most popular soft drink in due course will be available in the Soviet Union.

title: SouthernSanta Clara Is Off
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov, 17 (UPI)The scheduled Nov. 25 charity football game at Can dlestick Park between South ern University and Santa Clara was officially canceled today. Southern was to have met Grambling tomorrow and that game already had been can celed because of the disturb ances on Southern's campus.

title: Business Briefs
description: Harvard Industries, Inc., has filed a petition under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act in the United States District Court of New Jersey.

title: PLYWOOD PRICES TAKE A TUMBLE
description: Plywood futures prices have been tumbling recently, per haps because winter is here and construction has slowed, especially in the Middle West where there have been snow storms.

title: Mare Bought for $47,000; Sales Total $13.2Million
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 17 (AP)Coral Dream, a 3year old brood mare, brought the top price of $47,000 as Keene land closed its breeding, stock sale.

title: MitchellLama Tenants Oppose Proposed Project Regulations
description: Three hundred tenants in MitchellLama housing jammed the Board of Estimate Chamber in City Hall yesterday to de nounce proposed new regula tion of their projects.

title: Diplomats Are Honored
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP)  Two veteran diplomats, Charles E. Bohlen and H. Free man Matthews, were honored today in an observance of For eign Service Day attended by 300 retired diplomats at the State Department.

title: News Analysis
description: TRENTON, Nov. 17Many New Jersey officials here agreed today that the State Senate's rejection of Education Commis sioner Carl L. Marburger was a result of an emotional reaction against the racially charged issue of school busing.

title: FOUR SEIZED IN CHASE ON KIDNAPPING TIP
description: NEWBURGH, N. Y. Nov. 17, (UPI)  The State Police were trying today to unravel a bi zarre series of incidents that included a man allegedly being kidnapped, a telephone tip, a highspeed chase and the arrest of four persons.

title: STEINKRAUS WINS WITH MAIN SPRING
description: TORONTO, Nov. 17  Bill Steinkraus, who retires tomor row night after 21 years with the United States equestrian team, rode Main Spring to vic tory in the Rothman's interna tional stake tonight at the Royal Winter Fair horse show.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Governor Rockefeller held the fifth in his series of town meetings at the Inter national Hotel at Kennedy International Airport. He was deluged with dozens of sug gestions and requests, many of them on issues that more properly would be handled at the city rather than the state level.

title: JOB RIGHTS ROLE OF U.S. DISPUTED
description: A major Jewish agency criti cal of the Government's super vision of the way universities hire minorities and women clashed yesterday with the ad ministrator of the Federal pro gram over the definition of nu merical goals.

title: William A. Coblenz Dies; Newsman and U.S. Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 William A. Coblenz, a former newspaperman who was active in Federal Government affairs, died today in George Washing tion University Hospital. He was 75 years old.

title: Drive on Smut Aims at Building Owners
description: The city broadened its anti smut campaign in the Times Square area yesterday, moving against owners of buildings where peep shows operate. Heretofore, the city has acted only against the operators of peep shows.

title: Foe Said to Take Saravane
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 17 (Agence FrancePresse)  Offi cial sources reported today that North Vietnamese and Pathet Lao forces had reoccupied the southern Laotian town of Sara vane.

title: Trade Needs Are Listed by East German
description: A highranking official from East Germany offered yesterday a long catalog of goods that he thought his country could ex change with the United States. He also implied strongly that East Germany was in no rush to obtain American credits or investments.

title: Corporate Profits Before Taxes Spurt
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17  Corporate profits before taxes spurted $4.2billion to an an nual rate of $95.8billion in the third quarter, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: WINE TALK
description: It is that time of year again: the new Beaujolais is back. The arrival of this young, partially fermented wine, unheralded two or three years ago, has become another New York event and like many others is al most entirely the product of public relations and clever promotion.

title: Prison Reform Program Pushed Under Bay State Reform Law
description: BOSTON, Nov. 17  In the wake of nearly a year of agi tation and rebellion behind prison walls, the Massachusetts Department of Corrections is pushing ahead with a major program of penal reform.

title: P.B.A. Suit for Slander Planned Against Murphy
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association announced yester day that it would file a $12 million slander suit against Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy on behalf of 12 Brook lyn patrolmentwo of whom were charged with accepting an unlawful gratuity and 10 others with failing to take proper police action.

title: LOUISIANIAN HINTS ERROR IN KILLINGS
description: BATON ROUGE, Nov. 17  Two young black men killed in a campus confrontation yester day were possibly shot by a policeman who mistakenly loaded a buckshot shell instead of a teargas shell, Gov. Edwin W. Edwards said today.

title: MELLON'S PRIME TO RISE TO 6
description: The Mellon National Bank and. Trust Company of Pitts burgh, which is Pennsylvania's largest bank, announced yester day that it would suspend use of the floating prime rate should that formula produce a rate in excess of 6 per cent.

title: British Dispute Over Thalidomide Cases Intensifies
description: LONDON, Nov. 17  Ten yearold Martin Wale at in the living room of his pleasant brick row home in southeast London last night, watching Tom and Jerry cartoons on television and wondering whether he passed the morn ing test that would win him entry to a new school. He is legless because, as he explains to new friends, my mummy took a pill when I was in her tummy and my legs stopped growing.

title: State Bank Aide Will Study Loan to Democratic Party
description: Because newspapers have been publishing articles about a $140,000 bank loan to the deficitridden Democartic party in New York State, the state's first deputy superintendent of banks, Eliot Vestner, said yes terday that there would be an inquiry into the loan.

title: Ireland's Situation Reflected in Songs Of Clancy Brothers
description: Since the freedom and folk musichappy days of the early 1960's, the Clancy Brothers have come virtually alone to represent Irish music and cul tural style to many Americans. In their current engagement at Brandy's II, the Clancysno matter that they are the same old rollickers  are perceived against the greater backdrop of Northern Ireland's present civil warfare. Thus, such freedom songs as The Rising of the Moon, growled passionately by Tom Clancy, and the 1920's I.R.A. song Johnson's Motor Car hold special significance.

title: MAC BENOFF, WRITER OF DUFFY'S TAVERN
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 17 (UPI) Mac Benoff, who won two television Emmy awards and created radio's Duffy's Tav ern, died last night at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 57 years old. Mr. Benoff created the format for Duffy's Tavern in the 1940's and the show became one of radio's longestrunning hits. He also wrote the movie version of the show.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 17 (UPI)Mayor F. Edward Biertuempfel's code is sim ple: Just take care of the people and you'll get elected.

title: SYRACUSE'S BUDGET IS HELD TO BE LEGAL
description: SYRACUSE, Nov.17 (AP)A State Supreme Court justice ruled today that a city budget amended and passed by the Syracuse Common Council is a legal spending plan.

title: Three More Points and Gogolak Has the Giants' Scoring Record
description: If Pete Gogolak kicks a field goal Sunday in St. Louis, or three extra points, he will become the highest scorer in the history of the New York Giants.

title: Equity Financing
description: Illinois Central Industries yesterday announced that directors had approved a plan to retire 9.5 mil lion common shares, 146,475 of first preferred stock and 22 shares of second preferred stock. The shares are all currently held in the company treasury. They were issued in connection with the merger earlier this year of Illinois Central and Gulf Mobile & Ohio Railroads to form Illinois Central Gulf Railroad. The share retirement requires stockholder approval. The action was taken, the company said, to simplify the corporation's capital structure. The company's com mon stock closed at 29, up 1 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: People and Business
description: Got any complaints about Scotch tape? The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company has named Fred M. Metcalfe, 59 years old, as its first vice president for consumer affairs.

title: Financial Follies Mixes Barbs With Love Theme
description: Love was the theme last night at the 1972 Financial Follies but the barbs at the leaders of business, finance and government were as sharp as ever. Appearing be fore a group of about 1,000 businessmen, brokers, bank ers and government officials, members of the New York Financial Writers' Associa tion presented their annual musical parody show of the events of the year in the financial world.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 A research supervisor for E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. was granted a patent this week on working fluids that can be used in the external combustion, Ran kinecycle engine the company has developed. Poten tial uses are in automobiles and air conditioners. The power fluids for which Max F. Bechtold of the Wilmington, Del., plant received Patent 3,702,534 are perhalogenated benzenes, members of the fluorcarbon family. Specifi cally mentioned are isomers of trichlorotrifluorobenzene.

title: Some German journalists Are Also Candidates for Election
description: RHAUNEN, West Germany, A wiry, silverhaired candi date in a neat gray suit is talk ing to a grizzled peasant in a tavern.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The damaging and somewhat in temperate letter from one of any com patriots, Barbara Northcliffe MacDon ald (which you published Oct. 20) may, as you say in the heading, represent a British view on the Common Mar ket. May I present another, more ra tional view?

title: Sweet on Sweethearts
description: Where unions operate as fronts for racketeers selling labor peace, it would seem axiomatic that they ought not have the rights and protections guaranteed by law to bona fide labor organizations. The New York State Labor Relations Board, under the chairmanship of Jay Kramer, has operated on that principle for more than a decade. It has repeatedly refused to accord union recognition to groups with a history of sweetheart contracts.

title: Court Backs ExAide to Hughes In Dispute on Nevada Records
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Nov. 7 The Nevada Supreme Court has ruled, 3 to 2, that Robert A. Maheu, former chief of the Nevada operations of Howard R. Hughes, the billionaire in dustrialist, may retain certain records involving his employ ment.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Business has been involved with supportive or rehabilitative work with the disabled for some time. This con cern has manifested itself in a va riety of ways.

title: HAVANA STRESSES DESIRE FOR TALKS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 17Cuba today under lined her desire for immediate negotiations with the United States to end air hijackings. She did so by circulating at the United Nations a diplomatic exchange on the matter be tween the two countries.

title: FRANCE INCREASES LOAN REQUIREMENTS
description: PARIS, Nov. 17 (Reuters) The Bank of France said today it was raising to 33 per cent the reserve requirement for out standing credits granted by banks and other financial es tablishments with effect from Nov. 21.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Nov. 17Lawyers for North Ward residents at tempting to block the Kawaida Towers highrise project today broadened their attack to in clude the City Council and the State Community Affairs Com missioner, Lawrence F. Kramer, as defendants.

title: Tams Win in Overtime
description: MEMPHIS, Nov. 17 (UPI) George Thompson had 31 points as the Memphis Tanis downed the Utah Stars, 123117, in overtime tonight. The score was deadlocked 108108, at the end of regulation play after each team failed to score in the final minute. Darel Carrier came off the bench to hit 4 points in the overtime period on two con secutive steals.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: SYRACUSE, Nov. 17  The police conducted air searches today for a Syracuse University student who has been missing since last Friday after accept ing the offer of a ride to Mon mouth College in West Long Branch, N. J., with a stranger.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Nov. 17  The Russian State Choir performed the other night in the Queen Elizabeth Hall, London. On the pavement outside there was a counterperformance: Victor Yoran, a Soviet Jew in exile, played works for unaccompanied cello by Bach and Ravel.

title: Curfew Ruling Fought
description: SALISBURY, Nov. 17 (Reu ters)Blacks packed bars in white areas last night after the High Court ruled that Gov ernment regulations restricting their drinking in such bars were illegal.

title: Mechanic,' About a Professional Killer:Bronson Plays Role in Winner Movie Director Concentrates on Chase Spectacles
description: "The Mechanic," which opened yesterday at the Victoria and other theaters, is about Arthur Bishop (Charles Bronson), a cool professional killer who lives in lonely splendor in the Hollywood hills, with a pool in his living room and an ache in his heart. Although Arthur is a genius at planning the accidental deaths of others (including an old associate, on whom a contract has been let), and although he spends a lot of time keeping fit (jogging, handball, karate, flying a plane), something is awfully wrong in Arthur's life.He suffers such fits of acute anxiety that he sometimes faints, and he can make it with his call-girl friend only when she creates elaborate fantasies about his sex appeal. Arthur even looks funny: he has the face and physique of a man of 50 who takes immense care of himself, but his hair is of a blackness and a consistency that suggest that Arthurfor the sake of vanitydunks it in pitch.There are indications in Lewis John Carlino's screenplay that this effect is intentional, that "The Mechanic" is meant to be something more than the solemn, rather spurious action melodrama that Michael Winner, the director, has made of it.The center of the film is the relationship between Arthur and the rich young punk Steve (Jan-Michael Vincent), whom Arthur takes on as his apprenticewith not too surprising results. However, while Carlino's screenplay suggests a fatal fatherson rivalry between the pair, and sort of hints at a latent homosexual bond, the film that Winner has directed is one of non-stop, mostly irrelevant physical spectacle, of complicated chases (in automobiles, on motorcycles), of shootouts, and of various explosions (buildings, cars, yachts). It's quite possible the same movie could have been put together by the special effects men and the stunt coordinators.Because Winner, an Englishman whose first Hollywood-based film this is, is the sort of director who can never resist a flashy effect, no matter what it does to the point of the film, I found myself even mistrusting the dcor in "The Mechanic."Is that over-designed, over-decorated house of Arthur's really meant to be as failed-Playboy as it seems, or is it supposed to be chic? For that matter, is Arthur supposed to look grotesque, like an aging Hollywood agent, in his fancy bell-bottoms and leather jackets, or is this a mark of his hipness?I couldn't tell from the film, though I suspect that another, tougher director might have made something quite interesting of the same script.

title: Postel Becomes First Candidate In Next Year's Race for Mayor
description: Robert I. Postel, who has gained wide publicity as a mav erick member of the City Coun cil, said yesterday that he was going to run for Mayor next year.

title: Peron Back Under Tight Argentine Security
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 17 Juan Domingo Pern returned to Argentina today after 17 years of exile, saying he seeks to unite a country that has been divided since the end of his authoritarian rule.

title: Dance: Ailey Revives Shawn Molpai
description: Upon Alvin Ailey's initia tive, his company revived Ted Shawn's Kinetic Mol pai of 1935 Thursday night at the City Center.

title: Pistons Defeat Bulls, 10996
description: DETROIT, Nov. 17 (AP) Dave Bing sparked Detroit dur ing a 162 scoring surge in the final five minutes of the first half tonight and the Pistons coasted to a 10996 victory over to Chicago Bulls.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The tribute to Eleanor Roosevelt by Adlai E. Stevenson (OpEd Nov. 7), the tenth anniversary of her death, has reminded me of what I feel sure is an unrecorded example of her courage and compassion to which I was wit ness.

title: Archibald Scores 40
description: KANSAS CITY, Nov. 17 (AP) Nate Archibald and the Kan sas City Omaha Kings over powered the Cleveland Cava liers, 11596, for their seventh victory in eight games. Archi bald scored 40 points and had 11 assists. He shot 16 for 23.

title: AFTRA to Honor Strike on Tuesday
description: The American Federation of Television and Radio Artists (AFTRA) yesterday ordered its members at the Columbia Broadcasting System to begin honoring, at 6 P.M. next Tues day, the picket lines of the net work's striking cameramen and other technicians.

title: Outrageous Invention in Samaras's Art
description: At least it looks remark ably alive and well in the large retrospective exhibition devoted to the work of Lucas Samaras opening today at the Whitney Museum of Ameri can Art. This show boasts precisely the kind of out rageous invention and inflam matory taste that once char acterized the more scandal ous surrealist group. It is full of wild visual jokes and un ashamed exploitations of the self, for all of which Mr. Samaras has at his disposal an apparently inexhaustible inventory of forms.

title: Peron Back Under Tight Argentine Security
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 17 Juan Domingo Pern returned to Argentina today after 17 years of exile, saying he seeks to unite a country that has been divided since the end of his authoritarian rule.

title: Rarely Heard Works Offered At Orpheon Chorale's Concert
description: When the Orpheon Chorale, founded and conducted by Dino Anagnost, made its de but three years ago, it made a generally favorable impres sion. ln theory, it should have done just as well in its con cert in Tully Hall on Thurs day night. The program had been chosen with taste and ingenuity. It was full of rarely heard works. There was the individual profes sionalism of the 27 singers in the ensemble to count on for technically able perform ances.

title: Brewster Guilty of Accepting a Gratuity
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17  Former United States Senator Daniel B. Brewster was found guilty today of accepting an unlawful gratuity from a Wash ington lobbyist to influence his Senate vote on postal rate legislation.

title: Blazers Upset Warriors
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 17 (AP)Sidney Wicks and Geoff Petrie scored 25 points each tonight as the Portland Trail Blazers won their third straight contest, upsetting the Golden State Warriors, 10597.

title: Democrats Are Divided on the Idea of a Fusion Mayor
description: The Republican proposal to run a fusion candidate for May or next year was assailed yes terday by some of the Demo crats expected to seek the post. but other top Democrats indi cated they might be receptive to the idea.

title: POPKIN LOSES PLEA IN CONTEMPT CASE
description: BOSTON, Nov. 17 (AP)The ?? States Court of Appeals ?? the First Circuit rejected ?? a limited agreement offered by Samuel Popkin, a Harvard assistant professor, by a which he would answer ques tions before a grand jury in vestigating the disclosure of ?? Pentagon papers.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: CLIFTON, N. J., Nov. 17Even though they had dominated the disbanding AllAmerican Football Con ference, the Cleveland Browns had to prove themselves all over again when they joined the National Football League in 1950. Cynics said that the Browns had been defeating inferior teams and would meet their match in the tough N.F.L., but they won the N.F.L. title in their first year.

title: Roosevelt Raceway Triple Produces $976.80 Payoff
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 17 A Little Chip, 151; Noble Gal, 51, and Gay Blossom, 31, fin ished 1, 2, 3 in the fourth race at Roosevelt Raceway tonight and produced a big triple pay off of $976.80. It was a wireto wire victory for the 6yearold A Little Chip, clocked in 2:04 for the mile, Carmine Abbatiello brought the winner home three quarters of a length ahead of the runnerup.

title: Bridg: Two Unknown Local Experts Candidates for World Tourney
description: LANCASTER, Pa., Nov. 17 Two young New York ex perts previously unknown on the national scene captured the prestigious Blue Ribbon pair championship title here last night and thus became candidates to represent the United States in the 1974 world pair championship.

title: DAYCARE CENTER SCENE OF PROTEST
description: Black and Puerto Rican dem onstrators got into an angry shoving match with the police yesterday outsid a publicly fi nanced daycare center in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn that has an allHas sidic enrollment.

title: Nassau Correction Officer Convicted of Bribe Charge
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 17 A Nassau County correction of ficer was convicted by a County Court jury last night on charges of having received a bribe, of ficial misconduct and promot ing prison contraband.

title: Most Wanted Art Posted by Interpol
description: Interpol's first list of the world's 12 most wanted stolen paintings, a sort of rogue's gallery of art, was made public yesterday to let the public in on the art com munity's sleuthing and to focus attention on a few of the growing number of stolen works, hopefully to raise the dismally low recovery rate.

title: JOHN W. LUDEWIG, A WOODWARD AIDE
description: MAYWOOD, N. J., Nov. 17 John W. Ludewig, who was trustee of the trusts left to the Woodward family by William Woodward, bankersportsman, and his son, William Jr., who was shot to death accidentally in 1955, died today at his home here. He was 78 years old.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: KANSAS CITY, Nov. 17 (AP)Lee Evans, the Olympic runner, accused the Amateur Athletic Union and Olympic committees today of looking for reasons to disqualify you from the Olympic Games.

title: Braves Oversight Costly
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 17 (AP) Jerry West's free throw and his 18foot jump shot with 36 seconds left lifted the Los An geles Lakers over the Buffalo Braves, 103100, tonight. West's free throw broke a 9898 tie. After the Braves failed to take a shot in the next 24 seconds, West hit the clinching basket.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: When James MacGregor Burns, de scribed President Nixon as an enig nostic figure (OpEd Nov. 5), I asked myself: Is this construction an oxy moron or a portmanteau word?

title: U.S. ARMS DELEGATE ARRIVES IN GENEVA
description: GENEVA, Nov. 17Gerard C. Smith, the head of the Amer ican delegation to the talks with the Soviet Union on limit ing strategic weapons, arrived here today for the second phase of the negotiations.

title: Business Briefs
description: VIENNA, Nov. 17 (AP)Seven West European coun tries expressed their determination today to continue the European Free Trade Association despite the withdrawal of Britain and Denmark, which will join the European Common Market on Jan. 1.

title: JACK HURLEY DIES; BOXING MANAGER
description: SEATTLE, Nov. 17 (AP)  Jack Hurley, the ring promoter whose irascible wit was famed in boxing circles around the world, died in his Olympic Ho tel room yesterday. He would have been 75 years old on Dec. 9.

title: French Ski Resorts Shift Attention to Housewives
description: Annie Famose, the pert 28 yearold French star, who retired from ski racing after last seasonbecause I think I'm too oldmade an ap pearance at the Winter Sports Show yesterday at the New York Coliseum and mar velled over the impact skiing has been making on the French housewife.

title: Prices Advance on the Amex and OTC
LAWRENCE KOLB, PSYCHIATRIST, 91
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18Dr. Lawrence Kolb, an early authority on the medical ap proaches to the treatment of narcotic addiction, died yester day in the naval hospital here after suffering a heart attack. He was 91 years old.

title: Gallup Study Finds Greater Tolerance Of Mixed Marriage
description: The attitude of American so ciety on interracial and inter faith marriages is becoming more tolerant, according to a comparison of the results of a recent Gallup survey with find ings from a survey conducted four years ago.

title: Doing Something About Europe's Depressed Areas
description: PARISThe Common Mar ket is Starting to do some thing, about its West V irgin iasItaly's Calabria, north east England's Tyneside and other regions that lag behind in economic development.

title: Chess: Snap, Crackle, Zap! Young Meet Old for Fried Chicken
description: The new, freshly hatched group of grandmasters takes on the older generation to day when the socalled Fried Chicken International Tour nament begins in San Anto nio, Tex. Three of the young worldbeaters will face a roster of established top play ers.

title: Ezra Pound On Visitors' Day
description: THEY kept Ezra Pound in the Chestnut Ward, amid slippered derelicts, every face vacant but his. In bad weather that was where you visited. Eliot had vis ited, Marianne Moore, MacLeish, Harvard and Yale professors, foreign ers on Fulbrights, lots of queer people too. One story had a resplendent T. S. Eliot, striped trousers, even a gold wacchchain, singled out by an inmate whose passion was ridding the floors of dirt. Through that big locked door from the Great World, Eliot's feet had brought dirt. The inmate plied his Bissell, and Eliot sat through the lat ter half of a visit to his old friend with his feet high in the air. After that, chairs in the window alcove where Pound received his visitors were kept drawn in close.

title: MICHIGAN STARTS A STATE LOTTERY
description: LANSING, Mich., Nov. 18 Michigan, following the lead of six other states in the north eastern and northcentral Unit ed States, is starting a state sponsored lottery in quest of more revenue through what supporters call painless tax ation.

title: PRISONHEADSREPORT ON ADDED FACILITIES
description: A bobsled run, ski jumps, ice hockey and a junior chamber of commerce unit were some of the newly added prison fea tures described yesterday by the superintendents of the Clin ton and Auburn State Correc tional Facilities.

title: If the Met Won't Sing Her Tune, Goodbye Scotto
description: RENATA SCOTTO has an amusing habit of prefacing something wicked she is about to say with a very girlish, gig gly and Italianate, Oh, I want not to be naughty. Confession completed, she poises herself and strikes. The soprano's aim is well nigh perfect. Her target is the Metropolitan Opera where she vows, she will sing no more unless.

title: Judge Warns Virginians On Maternity Leave Plans
description: RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 18 (AP)  A Federal judge says that he will void all the Vir ginia school systems' mater nity leave policies that con flict with Federal laws banning sex discrimination in employ ment.

title: Study on Freeway Links Exhaust Fumes to Angina
description: By driving 10 men with heart disease through heavy morning Los Angeles freeway traffic, a team of doctors has found compelling evidence that small amounts of carbon mon oxide from automobile ex haust aggravates their pre existing cardiac condition for at least two hours thereafter.

title: LETTERS
description: As one who has observed corporate management for a number of years, from both the inside and the outside, I could not agree more with Arthur J. Goldberg's analysis of the impotence of outside directors in the decision making process. [Debate on Outside Directors, Oct. 29.]

title: DEERFIELD CRUSHES MOUNT HERMON, 210
description: DEERFIELD, Mass., Nov. 18  Deerfield used a powerful ground attack in trouncing Mount Hermon today, 210. in the 31st meeting of the schools. Deerfield holds the series lead, 1513, and there have been three ties. Deerfield completed its season with four victories, two losses and a tie, Mt. Her mon finished at 16.

title: Bogus Money Recovered
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 18 (UPI) Skin divers from a volunteer rescue unit, working under the Secret Service, recovered a cache of counterfeit $10 bbills believed to total several hun dred thousand dollars in sub urban Dundalk today. The bills had been discovered yesterday by a professional diver working at a bridge construction site.

title: Nuclear Plant Makers Scored ByCon Ed for Many Promises
description: Consolidated Edison, in an unusual public complaint last week, placed most of the blame for the lack of electricity being produced by nuclear energy on the makers of the nuclear gen erating plants.

title: LEGISLATURES DUE TO LOOK YOUNGER
description: There will be a younger look In state legislatures across the nation as a result of the Nov. 7 elections.

title: FIVE GIRLS MISSING NEAR FLORIDA BEACH
description: ORMOND BEACH, Fla., Nov. 18 (AP)Five girls aged 2 to 12 wandered away from a neighborhood birthday party today and vanished, triggering a massive search of dense, marshy woods, the police said.

title: Dean at Queensborough Heads Advisory Council
description: Benjamin Wieder, an asso ciate dean of evening and general studies at Queens borough Community College, has been elected chairman of the Council of Community College ?? and Directors of Evening, Continuing Edu cation and Summer Session for the City University of New York.

title: Sue Solinger Wed To Douglas Benach
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Nov. 18Miss Sue Rose Solinger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Solinger of Scarsdale, and Douglas Benach, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Benach, also of Scarsdale, were mar ried here this evening in the Jewish Community Center. Rabbi Maurice Davis of the White Plains Jewish Commu nity Center and Norton Shar gel of the Harrison Jewish Community Center performed the ceremony.

title: Community Board That Hired Fuentes Issues Report Clearing Him of AntiSemitism
description: Community School Board 1, which appointed the controver sial Luis Fuentes as its commu nity superintendent, has sub mitted a report to Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner upholding Mr. Fuentes's character and asserting that he is opposed to racism in any form.

title: Legislative Notes: Amended Parole Bill Set for Senate Vote
description: TRENTONThe Cahill Ad ministration is having a tough time convincing lawand orderminded legislators that prisoners should have an easier time getting paroled. But after one false start last week, an amended Adminis tration bill was cleared by the Senate Committee on In stitutions, Health and Wel fare for a floor vote in the Upper House, possibly this week.

title: Art
description: AT 73, sculptor Louise Nevelson is still going strong. Her latest exhi bition  a stunning show of sculptures and col lages  at the Pace Gallery, 32 East 57th Street, through November, has the inevitable clat one has come to ex pect from her exhibitions over the years. The new show is comprised of individ ual pieces, modelsized en vironments of a sort: dolls' houses, towers and cabinets with doors and windows  some closed, some partially opened, revealing new sculp tures within. Having dallied, in the late fifties, with en vironmental structures that were painted pure white, and, in the late sixties with crys talline plastic sculptures, Mrs. Nevelson has returned to her basic blackthe paint ed wooden structures that first brought her into promi nence in the midfifties.

title: Revenue Service to Monitor Tax Preparation Industry
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 18 (UPI) The tax preparation industry collected more than $600mil lion in fees for helping taxpay ers with their 1971 returns, Commissioner Johnnie M. Wal ters of the Internal Revenue Service said this week.

title: Hobart Gains in Soccer
description: CORTLAND, N. Y., Nov. 19 (AP)Rich Searre scored the winning goal with 2 minutes 40 seconds left as Hobart downed Cortland State. 32, in the East ern College Athletic Conference upstate regional soccer tourna ment today.

title: World News Briefs
description: ATHENS, Nov. 18  Greece and the Soviet Union have signed an $89million accord to produce electric power from peat. The agreement will bring dozens of Soviet technicians to northern Greece, a strategic ally sensitive area of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Man in the Middle of Dispute in Canarsie
description: Since September, Harvey Garner, the acting superin tendent for District School Board 18, which represents the communities of Canarsie and East Flatbush, has been trapped in the middle of the controversy surrounding the busing of 31 black and Puer to Rican children from Brownsville to Junior High School 211 in Canarsie.

title: Army Plans a 25% Cutback In Vehicles to Save Money
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) The Army, which now has one car or truck for every four men, has announced that it will cut back its fleet of vehicles by 25 per cent over the next five years to save money.

title: U.S. SUIT CLOUDS INDIAN PROBLEM
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18A little noticed Federal court suit could further complicate the Government's effort to carry out its trust responsibilities to American Indians.

title: In the Last Reel, the Indians Win on Thanksgiving Day
description: A FEW days before Thanksgiving I set out at dawn for the Black Hills with my friend Abraham Afraid ofHorse, a lay preacher at our mission chapel on the Standing Rock Res ervation in South Dakota. We were to drive more than 200 miles to the south western part of the state to collect some buffalo meat and bring it back for a Thanksgiving feast.

title: JUDGE JAMES ROSEN OF U.S. CIRCUIT COURT
description: WEST NEW YORK, N. J., Nov. 18Judge James J. Ro sen of the Third Circuit Court died today, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 6600 Boulevard East. He was 62 years old.

title: SCHOOL FOOTBALL
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Nov. 18  Tony Capozzoli, who catapulted to fame by winning a national puntpass kick tournament a few years ago, played like anything but the freshman he is in leading St. Dominic's to a 3414 vic tory over Locust Valley today.

title: WESLEYAN IS VICTOR OVER TRINITY, 3328
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 18Capitalizing on three turn overs in the second half, Wes leyan defeated Trinity, 3328, today in the final game of the season for both teams. Each finished with a 44 wonlost record.

title: Kerr Off Broadway
description: MORE and more often these days our younger dramatists seem to be trying to make plays out of unused bookends. There is an open ing statement. There is a closing statement. And there is nothing at all in between. Two examples:

title: BusingThe Supreme Court Goes North
description: Sometime in the next few months the Supreme Court will decide the case of Keyes v. School Dis trict No. I. School District No. 1 is in Denver, Colo., and the Keyes case deals with racial segre gation in the Denver schools. The Court may decide the case on narrow grounds that have no clear implications for other Northern cities, but this seems unlikely. In all probability the Keyes decision will tell us whether the Court intends to launch a major attack on school segregation in the North.

title: Medicine
description: WASHINGTONLife on earth be gan, and has prospered through the eons, in the midst of a faint but steady drizzle of radiationan un seen, unfelt rain of energy and nuclear particles from rocks and outer space. This natural radiation can kill cells and change the course of heredity of all living things.

title: Stuart Freedman to Wed Miss Nathanson
description: Miss Nancy Sue Nathan son, a teacher, and Stuart J. Freedman of Edgewater, N. J., corporate secretary and counsel with Cadence Indus tries Corporation, a photog raphy and photofinishing firm in New York, will be married Dec. 17 at the St. RegisSheraton.

title: Peace may finally come to ShangriLa
description: SRINAGAR: Jawaharlal Nehru loved Kashmir. A Kashmiri Brahmin himself, the land of his fore fathers was always in his dreams. Once, exploring it, he fell down a crevasse. Fortunately he was hauled up again. He tells the story in detail in his autobiography, and well he might, for it was sym bolic. No sooner had he become free India's first Prime Minister, than he got himself into a hole in Kashmir from which he did not escape till the end of his life.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18The gods have their equals at malicious whimsy in the buses, the buses that bumble and snort through the streets of al most every accursed city In America, taking on desperate human accretion at one street corner, ejecting it at another, clanking, grinding, spewing out foul black stenches. Those buses! Those buses! They have been the same for thirty years. Forty years for cer tain. No wonder America abandoned them and took a hundred million cars downtown.

title: HARVARD VICTOR OVERBROWN,2111
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 18 Rod Foster's touchdown runs of 84 and 29 yards led Harvard to a 2114 football triumph over Brown today.

title: Africans Are Wary
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Af rica, Nov. 17  Black leaders who seek an independent and unified SouthWest Africa crit icized today as unacceptable the proposals that the Republic of South Africa has made to the United Nations on the future of this territory.

title: Cuozzo Seen as LongBall Threat
description: ST. LOUIS, Nov. 18The Giants are hoping to maintain a pattern in tomorrow's game against the St. Louis Cardinals here. They have not lost a game this season in which they were favored, and they are expected to win this one by something less than a touchdown.

title: Social Security Tax Is Viewed as Unfair To Working Poor
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) A Brookings Institution study says that the Social Security tax is not only rising faster than any other Federal tax but is also increasingly unfair to lower income workers.

title: Letter Bomb in Liverpool
description: LIVERPOOL, England, Nov. 18 (AP)A letter bomb mailed in India was intercepted by post office workers in this north western port city today and detonated by bomb disposal ex perts, the police reported. A spokesman said the envelope had been addressed to prem ises occupied by a Jewish com pany.

title: The Nation
description: HARTFORDThey would go by and stick theft tongues out, said veteran toll collector Chester Nerkow ski. They just didn't care.

title: Criminals At Large
description: One SjwallWahl book tends to read much like the oth er. Then why their continued popularity? Partly because of identification. Each book pre sents the same characters: Mar tin Beck and the others of the Stockholm Police Department. Partly because their lives are in continual progress: they get divorced; they find new inter ests; but always there is a con tinuity. Mostly because this husbandwife team performs so well. The people in their novels are real.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: 30 DAYS OUT: Miracle Lick (Reprise MS 2085). 1967 Cal ifornia rock groups had a particular sound and a special appeal. They played music for the body and the soul  up music  as strong in mel ody as in rhythm and high spirits. That was a particular ly optimistic time and place in rock culture, and one to be savored. Moby Grape was probably the best of those groups, and if it weren't for a quirk of chronology and geography, 30 Days Out would be the second best.

title: Third of Middlesex Is of Foreign Stock
description: Nearly onethird of Middle sex County's residents either were born in a foreign coun try or are native Americans having at least one foreign born parent, according to the Census Bureau.

title: New Regents Plan Would Aid Needy L.I. School Districts
description: Long Island school dis tricts, which have been in the forefront of the move ment to win more equitable financing of public education, would be among the leading recipients of new state aid in a program that has been developed by the State Board of Regents.

title: Karl Hollingsworth To Wed Miss Browne
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 18Miss Cheryl Adri enne Browne, a graduate of Luther College in Decorah, Iowa, plans to be married here Dec. 17 to Karl E Hol lingsworth of Waterloo, Iowa, a Luther senior. Their engagement had been an nounced by Mr. and Mrs. Carl A. Browne, parents of the bridetobe.

title: Engineer Marries Miss Ishbel Jordan
description: Miss Ishbel Jordan of Brooklyn and Carl O. Charles of Lexington, Ky., were mar ried at noon yesterday in the Concord Baptist Church in Brooklyn by the Rev. Dr. Wilbert McKinley.

title: Collected Poems 19511971
description: WITH these Collect Poems a lag in reputation is overcome. A. R. Ammons's 400 pages of poetry, written over the space of a generation, manifest an energy, wit and an amaz ing compounding of mind with nature that cannot be overlooked. Even with the ommission of Ammons's longest continuous work, Tape for the Turn of the Year (1965), this is a remark able book, enriched by three long poems (together almost 80 pages) that must have been composed since Up lands (1970) and Briefings (1971). Indeed, with Hibernaculum, 112 stanzas in length, a high point of the poet's delayed career is reached. His first book, Ommateum (Com pound Eye), caused no stir when it appeared in 1955; and even the mid sixties' explosion of Expressions at Sea Level (1964), Corson's In let (1965) and Northfield Poems (1966) did not make of him an in escapable presence. Ammons snared some academic admirers, but many remained suspicious of this prolific nature bard who kept turning it out like prose. His distinction as a major American poet will now be evident.

title: Big Bluffer Captures Hurricane Handicap for Vasquez's Fourth Triumph
description: MIAMI, Nov. 18A signifi cant change of venue marked today's start of Florida racing season, but the new surround ings did not bother Jacinto Vas quez in the least.

title: Brandt Drive's Finale: Cheers and Tear Gas
description: BERLIN, Nov. 18 (Reuters)  Chancellor Willy Brandt ended his election campaign ing tonight amid clouds of tear gas and to cheers from thousands of supporters here.

title: Marking Valuables Is an Aid to Police
description: FAIR LAWN  A local service organization and the borough Police Department are working together to com bat burglaries.

title: Sarah E. Stowell Plans Nuptials
description: ANNANDALE, Va., Nov. 18 Capt. Ralph Henry Stowell, U.S.N., and Mrs. Stowell of Oakland, Me., and Annandale have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Sarah Elizabeth Stowell, to Stuart Hamilton Malone. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick R. Malone of Ma plehurst, Oxford, Md., for merly of Haverford, Pa.

title: Maria Bagatta Is the Bride of Prof. William Odum
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., Nov. 18Miss Maria E. Bagatta, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Bagatta, was married here today to William E. Odum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene P. Odum of Athens, Ga. The Rev. Philip Hill per formed the ceremony at a nuptial mass in St. Hugh of Lincoln Roman Catholic Church.

title: Audubon President Details U. S. Environment Tasks
description: Major environmental tasks confronting the nation are landuse planning, energy policy planning and transporta tion policy reform, members of the National Audubon So ciety heard last week.

title: $40,000 in Coins, Stamps Stolen From Subway Rider
description: Forty thousand dollars worth of United States and Canadian coins and stamps and $850 in cash were stolen from a sub way passenger by two young men on an Eighth Avenue train approaching the Dyckman Street station, the police re ported yesterday. They gave this account of the incident:

title: Raiders Turn Back Nordiques, 71, and Snap FiveGame Losing Streak
TRANSPORTATION
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 18Shortly after midnight last Saturday morning, commercial airline operations here were moved to the new, quarterbilliondollar Kansas City International Airport that had been carved from the rolling farm lands of rural Platte County.

title: Alta Rae, Coloratura, Sings With Insight
description: Ordinarily, coloratura so pranos are not interesting recitalists. Preoccupation with the mechanical aspects of singing and concentration on the ornamentation rather than the substance of music do not lead naturally to significant lyric communication, and few coloraturas make the extra effort needed to get there.

title: Unsecular Man
description: Andrew Greeley possesses what is probably the sharp est tongue in American so ciology (rather refreshing in a field where most writ ing seems to consist of translations either from com puter language or from Fed eralese). Perched on his some what improbable pinnacle at the National Opinion Research Center in Chicago, he has for several years been busy send ing out books and articles, most of them broadside attacks on prevailing views both inside and outside his own field.

title: Texas Tech in Sun Bowl
description: WACO, Tex., Nov. 18 (AP) Texas Tech, with Lady Luck wielding the scalpel cut down its Southwest Conference rival, Baylor, 137, today and headed for a Sun Bowl date with North Carolina.

title: Schools Vie for Name Of Jackie Robinson
description: When Jackie Robinson died last month the students and teachers of Intermediate School 320, which is adjacent to the old site of Ebbets Field, decided to name their school in his memory.

title: Social Announcements
description: Weddings

title: Five Men Convicted In Drug Smuggling; 2 Are From France
description: Three New York men and two Frenchmen were convicted yesterday by a Manhattan Fed eral Court jury of participating in an international heroin smuggling conspiracy.

title: NOISE MEASURED FOR ROAD INQUIRY
description: BEDFORD, N. Y., Nov. 18 A shiny white box measured trucknoise levels on a sixlane superhighway in Westchester County last week, recording evidence for the state's first environmental hearing on a road already built.

title: The World
description: BUENOS AIRES  Juan Domingo Pern left Argentina 17 years ago, a dictator toppled by a military revolt, bound for exile on a Paraguayan Navy gunboat that had given him asylum. He returned last Friday on a chartered jetliner, tanned and looking fit de spite his 77 yearsand still the leader of the largest political force in Argen tina.

title: The World
description: RECIFE, Brazil  In normal times, municipal elections in Brazil are un important, since municipal councilors have little power and mayors are sub ordinate to governors, who are ap pointed by the Government. But the municipal elections held last week were different.

title: City Budget Study Gets Muted Reaction
description: We knew it all along, said Queens Borough Presi dent Donald R. Manes. We are dismally behind.

title: Afghans Striving to Aid Famine Areas
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 13 Countless Afghans are still dying of hunger and many more will perish in the months to come. But under strong Ameri can guidance, Afghanistan is carrying out a major effort of bringing food to the hungry, and many lives are being saved.

title: Period styles and period pieces
description: IT'S not my story, says Archibald MacLeish in his fore word, it's the poems': what they think they know when they put themselves together. The disclaimer is whimsical, yet holds a grain of truth: his book has indeed been arranged to show how poems from the separate chapters of a career can influence one another. Richmond Lattimore does not wait upon prologue, but simply rehearses the concerns of some 30odd years. MacLeish finds new categories for old themes and motifs; Lattimore adds some new poems to three ear lier volumes and lets chronology speak for itself.

title: The Talk of Tenafly
description: TENAFLY  There was doortodoor canvassing for funds here yesterday, prob ably for the first time in the history of this borough. The canvassing, which ended a weeklong drive to raise $45, 000, was held to solicit funds to send the 161member Tenafly High School band to the Tournament of Roses M. Pasa dena, Calif., on New Year's Day. For many resi dents in this community of 15,000, the invitation for the school band to participate in the Rose Bowl activities marks a be ginning, an opportunity to join neighbors for a common purpose, something that some people here contend is lack ing in this affluent town. There is high regard for the school system, but that is one of the few subjects that resi dents talk about.

title: A Colored Girl Like You Can't Play in Hollywood Bowl
description: WHEN Natalie Hinderas was soloist with the Los Angeles Philhar monic in Hollywood Bowl last summer, she felt particularly good about it. Why? She could remember the time that a manager told her: You know, Natalie, a little colored girl like you can't play in Hollywood Bowl. That was said when she was well into a professional ca reer as a pianist.

title: LAPLANDER TAKES LAUREL FEATURE
description: LAUREL, Md., Nov. 18Lap lender, the oddson favorite from the Buckingham Farm, moved from last to first round ing the final turn and posted a onelength victory in the $23, 950 Constellation Handicap at the Laurel race course today.

title: Bay State Jurist Deplores Judges' Forced Retirement
description: BOSTON, Nov. 18 (AP)  Chief Justice Walter H. Mc Laughlin of Superior Court here says the recently approved referendum requiring the retire ment of judges over the age of 70 will leave the court in chaos.

title: A masterpiece from Fernand Point
description: The late Fernand Point (below) is almost universally regarded as the prime mover in modern French cook ing. His great contribution was to purify the classic cuisine of some of its stodgy Victorianisms. But he also created new dishes and at least one new sauce. That sauce he named after the brothers Lumiere, the pioneer French film directors. They dined one evening at Point's Restaurant de la Pyramide in Vienne near Lyon. And in their honor, the patron invented a light, airy fish sauce. Here it accom panies an American fish with simple and appropriate garnishings.

title: Some Restaurants Left Chefless As Cooks Walk Off Their Jobs
description: Cooks and chefs began a walkout at major New York City restaurants yesterday as negotiations on a new contract between their union and the Restaurant League, which rep resents more than 80 restau rants here, were broken off.

title: 2 Storms Erode Rockaway Beach
description: Galeforce winds whipped the Atlantic Ocean into a frenzy last week, causing con siderable erosion damage along Rockaway Beach.

title: SYRIANS WILL GET MIG'S FROM EGYPT
description: KUWAIT, Nov. 18  Meas ures to strengthen the defenses of Arab countries bordering on Israel, including the transfer of a squadron of Egyptian MIG fighters to the Syrian Air Force command, have been adopted by Arab League countries meet ing here.

title: Miss Simmons, Mark S. Butler Plan Marriage
description: FRANKLIN LAKES, N. J., Nov. 18Mr. and Mrs. John W. Simmons of Franklin Lakes and East Hampton, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Paula Johnston Simmons, to Mark Smith Butler, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Butler of Tenafly and Amagansett, L. I. The cou ple plan to be married in East Hampton on June 9.

title: The Q has a twoandonehalfinch tail
description: No child is going to learn his ABC's on Hosie's Alphabet and I bet Hosie didn't either. When the little boy was 3, his father  the renowned artist Leonard Baskin  created this alphabet for him. Hosie helped choose the drawings and his mother and older brother helped him with the big words. The result is an intriguing book for adult ad mirers of Baskin and children who are already thoroughly familiar with the shape and sounds of the letters of the alphabet.

title: Woman, 69, Wins Town Job Easily
description: HIGHLAND PARKWhen Highland Park Democrats ap proached Helen Hurd to run for the Town Council, she laid it on the line: I told them that the important thing was to win on all levels and that perhaps the town wasn't ready for a 69year old woman, even if she did have all her own teeth.

title: U.S. EQUESTRIANS TAKE TEAM TITLE
description: TORONTO, Nov. 18The United States Equestrian Team Bill Steinkraus, Frank Chapot, Neal Shapiro, Kathy Kusner and Mac Conewon the interna tional team championship of the Royal Winter Fair horse show otnight. It was the third victory in three fall indoor events for Coach Bert de Nemathy's riders.

title: TV Mailbag
description: ABC shows That Certain Summer, a movie dealing with homosexualityand a pretty good one, too, as Merle Miller points out in his Nov. 5 review, A Man Who Tried to Play It Straight and the legions of gay libera tionists are dissatisfied with it. And not just dissatisfied but disgusted and downright hostile. This may puzzle some of those who thought that That Certain Summer was a breakthrough; but if you're familiar, as I am, with a certain set of fashionable attitudes bred and nourished by the Gay Liberation move ment, it's not so difficult to figure out what has caused the wrath of my gay brothers and sisters.

title: News of the Rialto
description: THOSE charming concocters of amusing fantasies, Gretchen Cryer and Nancy Ford, are at it again. The last time they were in town they entertained us with their musical. The Last Sweet Days of Isaac. one of the major hits of the 196970 Off Broadway season. In that one their hero was trapped in a stalled elevator, with a girl for company. Now they're about to make their Broadway debut with another fanciful tale called Shel ter, in which the hero lives in a house that's part of the setting in a TV studio, with a computer for company. The show, under the aegis of Richard Fields and Peter Flood with Julie Hughes as associate producer, should be at the Golden Feb. 1.

title: Bitter Big Sur Residents to Rebuild Despite 2d Landslide Since October
description: BIG SUR, Calif., Nov. 18 The bright afternoon sun had dried the mud on the Cabrillo Highway yesterday to a point where the passing trucks raised clouds of dust.

title: GRAY PLANS CHANGES TO IMPROVE F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) L. Patrick Gray 3d said today that he expected to continue making changes at the Federal Bureau of Investigation to im prove and enhance its quality.

title: Massachusetts Wins Title By Routing New Hampshire
description: AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 18 (AP) Peil Pennington scored one touchdown and passed for two others and Paul Metallo and Steve Schubert tallied twice apiece as Massachusetts trounced New Hampshire, 427, to clinch the Yankee Confer ence football title today.

title: The Sounds Of Wedding Now Taped
description: We are speaking to you from just outside St. Ignatius Cathedral where the nuptials of Mary Smith and John Doe will shortly take place  as the cars fill up the area, we are swept up in the glow it is a grand and glorious day  as the bridal party ascends the steps and enters the vesti bule, a hush falls about us  looking about us, we can't help but admire the serene atmos phere and dignity

title: City Plans Computerized System To Monitor Claims for Medicaid
description: A new computerized system for monitoring Medicaid claims by physicians and other nonin stitutional providers of health services is being set in motion by the Health Services Admin istration.

title: A Debut on Classic Guitar
description: TuranMirza Kamal made his New York debut playing the classic guitar Friday night at the Spanish Insti tute. Twenty years old and of KazanBukharan Tatar des cent (although born in Cal ifornia), Mr. Kamal has stud ied with the best, including Segovia, Pujol, Bream and Williams.

title: OnceProud Newcastle Stirs the Embers
description: NEWCASTLE  UPON TYNE, England  This hard working city of the stony North country, once a sym bol of Britain's industrial leadership and now a center of mass unemployment and dying enterprises, is gearing up for a new age of great ness.

title: Citizens' Group Urges Board to Retain Scribner
description: The Citizen's Committee for Children of New York has urged that the Board of Educa tion extend Dr. Harvey B. Scribner's contract as School Chancellor when it expires next June 30.

title: SEGRETTI APPEARS BUT KEEPS SILENT
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov, 18  Donald H. Segretti, whose whereabouts had been un known, returned to his home ?? this week but refused to discuss allegations that he had organized a campaign of disrup tion and harassment against Democratic Presidential aspir ants.

title: City Panel Bids U.S. Seek More Visitors At Monuments Here
description: Charging that five federally run historic monuments in Manhattan were failing to make contact with the local urban dweller, the Mayor's Council on the Environment of New York. City urged the National Park Service yester day to mount a publicity drive to attract more residents as visitors to the monuments.

title: Seton Hall Beats Fordham On Two Late Scores, 137
description: Seton Hall scored two touch downs in the first four min utes of the final quarter to register a 137 victory over Fordham yesterday before 2,398 fans at Jack Coffey Field.

title: Ruth Mitchell a Bride
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 18Miss Ruth Mary Mitchell was married here this after noon to James Reginald Proctor of Chappaqua, an architect for the Federal Gov ernment in New York. The Rev. Mark S. Sisk perform ed the ceremony in Christ Church Episcopal. The bride is a graduate of Barnard Col lege. Her husband is a grad uate of the University of Manitoba.

title: ErSenator's Will Said To Cut Off Wife, Child
description: HANNIBAL, Mo. Nov. 18 (AP)Edward V. Long, for mer United States Senator from Missouri, left his wife and their only child $10 each, The Kansas City Star, in copyright article, has quoted sources close to the family as saying.

title: WALL STREET
description: Utility stocks as glamour issues? Utilities leading the market into new high ground? Utility indexes out performing the industrial av erages?

title: Sports of The Times
description: The kind of football I like, said Larry Csonka, a believer in the direct approach, is straight up the gut and everyone gets a black eye.

title: Bonn Will Pay $31Million To Poles From Nazi Camps
description: GENEVA, Nov. 18The West German Government has agreed here to pay $31million in final settlement of compensation claims by Polish victims of pseudomedical experiments in Nazi concentration camps dur ing World War II.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: With Juan D. Pern returning to Argentina to attempt a political come back after seventeen years of exile in Spain, it has become fashionable for the press to exhume the memory of Mussolini and compare Pern's every move and supposed intention with those of the Italian Fascist leader. This is at best a facile and simplistic approach to a man whose nearly thirty years of hemispheric in fluence has never been seriously stud ied or appraised in the detail assigned to Mussolini, and, at worst, it is an un pleasant example of the public's re ceiving only those opinions and pre conceived images of Pern which the editors choose to publish.

title: Rep. Chisholm Emerges With Power
description: When Representative Shirley Chisholm won reelection in Brooklyn's 12th Congressional District, she consolidated her leadership in BedfordStuyves ant and added to her creden tials as a politician who could play an important role in the reorganization of the Demo cratic party.

title: AUSTRALIAN RACE OFF TO LOUD START
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 18 Campaigning for the Austral ian parliamentary elections on Dec. 2 got off to a boisterous start this week, with rival supporters of Prime Minister William McMahon and his chal lengers for the top Government post, Gough Whitlam of the Labor Party, repeatedly trying to shout each other down at public meetings.

title: Glassboro State Defeats Montclair State by 2813
description: GLASSBORO, N.J., Nov. 18 Scoring twice in the fourth period, Glassboro State cap tured a share of the New Jersey State College Conference foot ball championship by downing Montclair State, 2813, today.

title: Independents Fighting Pathmark on Ads for Drugs
description: TRENTONThe 1,700 in dependent drugstores in New Jersey have launched a $50, 000 newspaper advertising campaign to retain their com petitive position against the strong challenge mounted by a large supermarket chain that operates 22 pharmacies in the state.

title: SYRACUSE ROUTED BY WEST VIRGINIA
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Nov. 18 (AP)Danny Buggs scored three times today, twice on flanker reverses, and West Vir ginia routed Syracuse, 4312.

title: A letter
description: I have known you rather less than a semester, but I feel that I have known you a long time. This is undoubt edly because, in a great many universities of the United States, in universities in Australia, New Zealand and Singapore, and even (when I have been permitted to visit them) one or two of the newer universities of England, I have met people like you. I don't mean solely people like you in col lective terms; I mean rather that each one of you has a counterpart in more than one place. There is the redhaired Irishman who has lost his faith; the earnest Germanic with the beer belly; the crisp sweet Chinese girl who is reading Beowulf'; the frantic Zionist who sees Talmudic symbols even in Shakespeare; the distrustful black; the dowdy girl who has already had a divorce; the Greek girl whose father runs a restau rant but who yearns back to Homeric Hellas; the May flower girl whose East Ang lian surname no longer exists in East Anglia; the quarrel some Sicilian who has for gotten the language of Dante; the very white boy who wears an Afro hairdo as an earnest of his regret that he was not born black. And so on.

title: Estimate of a Million Prostitutes in ItalyOr One in 10 Young Women  Stirs National Controversy
description: ROME, Nov. 18A million prostitutes in Italy?

title: The Nation
description: At the height of his reelection cam paign in 1969, Mayor Lindsaygazing into the television lightsannounced that there had been a dramatic slow down in the growth of New York City's welfare rolls. Not long there after, the growth resumed.

title: Gay Liberation
description: Reading the gushy reviews, especially Merle Miller's, one would suppose that ABC's movie, That Certain Sum mer, was a masterpiece in stead of the predictable yawner I saw. Everything about it was very caring, as Miller says, and Hal Hol brook and Martin Sheen as the lovers (off camera, any way) epitomized television's idea of decent men. It was, however, just this sort of treatment (meant to gain sympathy from TV movie watchers) that seduced Miller and others and blinded them to how mediocre the whole production really was.

title: TOWNS ENVISIONED AS LABS FOR CITIES
description: A private study sponsored by Laurance S. Rockefeller calls for the formation of national policy to create new towns as laboratories for mak ing the nation's cities more liv able.

title: Nixon Orders Trailer To Shelter Newsmen
description: THURMONT, Md., Nov. 18 (UPI)President Nixon has had a trailer installed just in side the electric fence that surrounds Camp David for the use of newsmen reporting his activities at the retreat, near here.

title: MICHIGAN STARTS A STATE LOTTERY
description: LANSING, Mich., Nov. 18 Michigan, following the lead of six other states in the north eastern and northcentral Unit ed States, is starting a state sponsored lottery in quest of more revenue through what supporters call painless tax ation.

title: Music: Reissuing Old Recordings of the Black Country Blues
description: GLEN COVE, L. I.Some time in the next month, the final stage in making cur rently available all the re corded evidence of a special ized but influential area of American music  black country blueswill be com pleted by a man who has gone from one musical quest to another over the last 25 years.

title: Education
description: Usually citizens fight to hold down taxes. But a proposal by the New York State Board of Regents last week could produce the oppo site effect among some taxpayers.

title: About Pro Football
description: The National Football League's 53d season is in the stretch now with 15 of the 26 teams realistic contenders for the eight playoff posi tions. Today, 13 of the 15 teams are involved in 10 games, three of which match one contender against an other: Pittsburgh at Cleveland, Minnesota at Los Angeles and the Jets at Mi ami. The last two games will be shown on television here in addition to the Giants' game at St. Louis. Two other contenders, At lanta and Washington, meet tomorrow night.

title: The World
description: TOKYOShortly after 6 P.M. last Monday, the Chief Cabinet Secretary of Japan, Susumu Nikaido, marched into the House of Representatives of the national Diet bearing a black lacquer tray. On it was an imperial order wrapped in purple silk and signed by Emperor Hirohito.

title: The Lessons of Teaneck
description: TEANECKIn the Long fellow School lunchroom, a white boy strides over to a table where two black youths sit and casually drapes an arm around the one nearest him. Out in the play yard, two girls share a hoop. One is black, the other is white.

title: Mr. Republican
description: This is the year of the political Liliputians, and it is easy to be nos talgic about 1952; Stevenson was a a model statesman, elegant, cour ageous, brilliant; Eisenhower (as Garry Wills describes him) played his variations on a theme by Machiavelli; and then there was Robert A. Taft. I remember watch ing that scene in the Hilton Hotel when Eisenhower came to meet with his defeated rival: fury, frustration, weeping and the unrec onciled bitterness of those to whom Taft was a latterday Arthur, and Taft amid it all, calm, dignified, and reserved.

title: Two Air Polluters Fined $800
description: TRENTONThe New Jer sey Department of Environ mental Protection has an nounced fines of $800 each against two companies for continued violations of the airpollution code during the last two weeks of October.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: ST. LOUISHis three chil dren call him fossy, a description concocted from the words fussy and bossy.

title: Miss Hopkins Plans Bridal
description: MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Nov. 18Mr. and Mrs. David L. Hopkins Jr. of Mount Kisco have made known the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Cassandra Ewing Hopkins, to Robert Chatfield Richardson. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Richardson of Anchorage, Ky. A wedding next June is planned.

title: The Nation
description: The telephone rang last Tuesday evening in the Manhattan apartment of Bernard J. Lasker, a broker and former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange. President Nixon was on the line. The Dow Jones industrial average had just closed over the 1,000 level for the first time in history and Mr. Nixon wanted a first hand report from a close friend in the financial community.

title: VIGILANCE URGED IN EAST GERMANY
description: BERLIN, Nov. 18  East Germany has opened an in doctrination campaign and tak en other protective steps de signed to halt the spread of Western ideas in the wake of improved relations between the two Germanys.

title: The Summer After the War
description: This thoroughly unpleasant, gawky, inept and almost to tally unredeemed bit of fiction divides roughly into two un equal portions. The first and mercifully shortest one is an attack on the Breadloaf writ ers' conference that succeeds in being vicious, crass and in competent in roughly equal measure. It would be of little interest to us here except that I cannot for the life of me imagine why any publishing company in its right mind ever let such unmitigated nonsense see the light of day.
