Cover the pile with burlap, more soil or hay to retain the heat. By spring, it should be well on the way to decomposition. Turn the pile every three months. (Over the winter months this is almost impossible.) So early next spring, give the pile a turn, keep it moist, and by planting time, compost will be ready for sifting out and use as nature's own soil improver.

title: Mojacar, Sadly, Plays Big City Rome, Just Before the Fall
description: MOJACAR, SpainCharley, pour me a drink like you were sitting on this side of the bar, Cheap Pete said. Yes, as I was saying, I love to collect thingsstuffed birds, animals, blackamoors, things like that. And the houses around here are so full of stuff, well it's just a collector's dream. Now, me, I'm an expert on carpets and pictures. And diamonds. I can tell you the quality of a diamond across the room.

title: Rice Beats Texas A.&M.
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Nov. 18 (UPI)Mark Williams kicked field goals of 45, 44 and 35 yards in the final quarter to complement the passing of Bruce Gadd and give the Rice Owls a 2014 victory over Texas A.&M. today.

title: Twelve is a macabre time of life
description: This is at once a psycho logical novel, a roman policier and an instructive examination of the arbitrary chance that throws together unlikely com binations of people. Its classifi cation as a book for juveniles seems to be based on its omis sion of explicit amatory content  a refreshing change in any category of fiction  and the clarity of its story line.

title: U.S. Aides Call Pollution Funds Available Despite Nixon's Stand
description: Federal environmental offi cials are bearing a message of hope for funds from the $24.6 billion Federal Water Pollution Control Act of 1972 despite President Nixon's irritation at its passage over his veto last month.

title: Question for College Basketball Opening Saturday: Who Will Stop U. C.L. A.?
description: The college basketball season will begin Saturday night, but unlike last ?? there is no tendency to write off ?? national title (they have won ?? in a row) for the University of Cali ?? Los Angeles. Rather, most of the ?? speculation deals on whether ?? can break the record 60 straight victories set by the University of San Francisco which dominated the col legiate scene in the 1950's with Bill Russell as its leader.

title: WILKES IS DEFEATED BY KINGS POINT, 1710
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., Nov. 18 Dave Buzanoski, quarterback for the United States Merchant Marine Academy, broke his 1970 season record for pass completions and passing yard age as Kings Point defeated Wilkes College, 1710, today.

title: James Stafford Jr. Weds Sara Crocker
description: NORTON, Mass., Nov. 18 Miss Sara Lynne Crocker, a 1972 graduate of Wheaton College, was married in the Cole Memorial Chapel on the Wheaton campus here this morning to James Jerome Stafford Jr., art director of Lawrence & Brooks, an ad vertising agency in Provi dence, R.I. The Rev. Norman Levinson performed the Prot estant ceremony.

title: A Novice Woodsman at 52 (With Some Help From His Friends)
description: EXCERPT from my trail notes: 8:10 P.M., first day. What a great joy to sit down on a pine needle carpet, drink a pint of spring water, smoke a cigarette.

title: Education
description: Pledging allegiance to the flag long has been traditional in Ameri can schools. In New York State, education law stipulates that the flag ceremony be performed daily in all public schools.

title: Letters To the Travel Editor
description: Peter Range's cutesiepie article may have been great fun to write, but it did The Times and the readers of the Travel section a disservice particularly those who might be Civil War or railroad buffs or interested in antebellum houses.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: My reaction to the arti cle Women Demanding Equal Treatment in Mort gage Loans [Oct. 29] is that any mortgagor would be foolish to grant a mortgage on a woman's salary unless she is a widow or a spinster of middle age.

title: Tests Seek To Find Out If Sludge Is Fertilizer
description: TOMS RIVERThe most extensive tests yet to find a beneficial use for processed sewer sludge are about to get under way in nearby ru ral localities.

title: 3 MURDERS WORRY BOSTON CAMPUSES
description: BOSTON, Nov. 18  While the police continue to investi ?? the recent murder of ?? Reich, an Emerson Col lege coed, two more attacks on young women have increased concern among the large aca demic community here, already worried by the unsolved kill ings of two Boston University women.

title: NADER UNIT BUDGET PUT AT $1.1MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) Ralph Nader reported today that his Public Citizen, Inc., was operating on a budget of about $1.1million a year col lected from some 62,000 con tributors.

title: Theater in Prineeton
description: THE McCarter Theatre on the Princeton cam pus is an 1,100seat Gothic pile, built in 1929 for the hairyleg musi cals of the student Triangle Club. For many years it housed, in addition to the Triangle and a wide array of other musical and theatrical phenomena, a professional repertory company that slogged its way through the standard repertory on a low budget and not much re hearsal time. Two years ago, however, the university de cided to close out this opera tion; now, after a year's hia tus, an entirely new profes sional theater program has set shop at McCarter.

title: TV Mailbag
description: Watching That Certain Summer, I was struck by its atypicality. No reference was made to the most obvious characteristics of the gay life: its promiscuity, rootless ness, irresponsibility, ano nymity and lack of stable re lationships. No film can do everything, of course. One should perhaps be grateful that this time another side of the picturealbeit a rare one was explored.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: SCRANTON, Pa., Nov. 18The con game of selling the Brooklyn Bridge is an old joke, but there is a man here who wants to sell a bridge made by the man who designed the Brooklyn Bridgeand he isn't kidding.

title: ANTIQUES
description: ELIZABETH  Antique dealers who live over the shop have probably always outnumbered those who do not. But an increasing num ber of dealers also live, as it were, in the shopwatch ing television from the Queen Anne wing chair someone will cart away on the back of his station wagon tomor row, and dining from a Sher aton table destined to be shipped to California.

title: Nassau South
description: Levittown Memorial whipped West Hempstead, 2412, to cap ture the Division III champion ship of the South Shore yester day while Elmont players sat in the stands and watched New Hyde Park trim Valley Stream South, 120, to give Elmont the Division IV title.

title: On Directing
description: Harold Clurman is unique. Unique and singular. For there is only one man like him in our theater today. In this age of criticism in which the crea tive and critical faculty are more frequently wedded than at any other literary moment, the theater has rarely produced those who function famously in both realms. Walter Kerr, Kenneth Tynan, Robert Brustein, yes, each in his own way, has been both. But in our time no director who has had a major career directing major plays has also functioned as a major critic at the same time. Harold Clurman has had the true stay ing power: as founder of the Group Theatre, director of plays of moment (spanning virtu ally 40 creative years) such as Awake and Sing, Golden Boy, The Member of the Wedding, Bus Stop, The Autumn Garden, Tiger at the Gates, A Touch of the Poet, The Waltz of the Toreadors, Heartbreak House and Un cle Vanya, and as drama critic for The Nation, he has been for many years one of the illus trious in the American theater Establishment.

title: Kidney Aid To Be Given At a Center In Brooklyn
description: A kidney disease center, where treatment with the ar tificial kidney will be pro vided, will soon open in Brooklyn near Grand Army Plaza. The center, represent ing a joint effort by seven major hospitals and teaching centers in the borough, will be able to treat 120 out patients a week with 20 ar tificial kidneys.

title: SOVIET EXCHANGES VIRUSES WITH U.S.
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 18Soviet and United States cancer spe cialists exchanged viruses and laboratory mice today as they signed an agreement expanding joint efforts in the fight against cancer.

title: Sorrow, betrayal, confusion
description: At its bestand it is fre quently at its bestthis beau tifully written little novel is as fragile and precise as a per fectly arranged vase of flow ers and as mercilessly imper sonal as nature or truth. At once cruel, lovely and very calm, very quiet, it is the story of the emotional destruction of an 8yearold boy in the months immediately following his par ents' separation. Like L. P. Hart ley's The GoBetween it is narratedfar more in sorrow than in angermany years af ter the fact by the protagonist himself. And like Hannah Green's The Dead of the House, it is the sort of book that defies synopsis in the usu al sense of the word, not be cause it lacks a coherent plot, but because the bald facts of the story are meaningless with out the unique, intensely pri vate, and superbly modulated

title: Why Is Trotsky Dying?
description: FILMS of style, intelligence, orig inality and true historical interest are so rare that one can only be gloomy wondering why The As sassination of Trotsky, Joseph Losey's very fine film shown first at the New York Film Festival, barely made it through a threeweek firstrun at the Coronet Theater before it was yanked in favor of Ken Russell's Savage Mes siah, which is a piece of junk jewelry. Fortunately the Losey film is now in second run at theaters around the city. If you hurry, you may still be able to see it before it's carted off to a tele vision graveyard. If you don't, you de serve all that moviemakers throw at you in the forms of things like Savage Messiah, Young Winston and even lesser claptrap.

title: World News Briefs
description: OSLO, Norway, Nov. 18  Norwegian air and naval forces have been hunting an unidenti fied object, believed to be a submerged submarine, in the Sogne Fjord, about 50 miles north of Bergen, for the last week.

title: Bus Overturns
description: IDALIA, Colo., Nov. 18 (UPI) A Continental Trailways bus went out of control on icy U.S. 36 near the ColoradoKansas border and overturned today injuring 10 passengers.

title: Recordings
description: SOME exciting newcom ers, a few reminders of artists now performing at their peak, and sev eral glances at the past these constitute the range of this week's singles round up.

title: Englewood Pupils Get a Happy Place to Go After School
description: ENGLEWOODThey come bursting through the doors, shouting and laughing. They hang up their hats and coats, and then race for the juice and cookie room.

title: TOPRANKED SIDES BEATEN IN BRIDGE
description: LANCASTER, Pa., Nov. 18 Almost all the topranked teams were eliminated here last night from the Reisinger board amatch team championship, the concluding major event in the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals.

title: A kind of Jungian primer
description: A conjuror named Magnus Eisen grim is conducting a magic act at The Royal Alexandra Theater in Toronto, floating on stage a brass like head that will answer questions from the audience. David Staunton, son of the wealthy rake, Percy (Boy) Staunton, in an irrational moment shouts to the head: Who killed Boy Staunton? He is so excited by his own outburst that he runs from the theater while the head gives a mysti cal answer. Soon after, David is in Jungian analysis in Switzerland.

title: LETTERS
description: In my article The Cost of Being a Citizen (Nov. 12) the figure given for the aver age change in the Consumer Price Index for the period from 1965 to 1971 should have been 3 per cent in stead of 1 as published.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: Awhile back, your pageproof readers allowed me to refer to Topsy as he. (It was she in my copy.) As a result, I got a nasty letter, suggesting I reread Uncle Tom's Cabin. This I ignored, hoping that others would realize it was a typo.

title: Penn Rallies to Top Columbia by 2014
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 Columbia's Lions roared into Franklin Field today as though bent on taking full advantage of the docility for which Quakers are noted. The visitors swept to a 140 secondquarter lead over favored Pennsylvania.

title: Suffolk
description: Elwood and Sayville captured conference titles and Linden hurst and West Islip played a 16all deadlock in champion ship games yesterday.

title: Joshua Tobin Weds Mrs. Walker on L.I.
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., Nov. 18  Mrs. Char mion Kineon Walker, widow of Alexander Walker Jr. of Quogue and Key Colony Beach, Fla., was married here this afternoon to Joshua Tobin of East Quogue.

title: A Schooner Eludes Salvage
description: WILDWOODAnother epi sode in man's struggle against the seas in unfolding in this resort community. This time, it is an attempt to salvage the schooner At lantic from her watery grave and return her to a place of eminence among great sail ing vessels.

title: UNEXPECTED DEATHS INCREASE FOR WOMEN
description: DALLAS, Nov. 18 (AP) Women are catching up with men in the incidence of un expected death from heart attack, an increase that seems to be related primarily to a higher, rate of cigarette smok ing, a New York researcher said today.

title: A.A.A. Urges U.S. To Drop '76 Rule For Car Air Bags
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI)  The American Auto mobile Association urged the Government today to drop its requirement for an air bag safety device on 1976 model cars, asserting the air bag was being irresponsibly and pre maturely sold to the public.

title: Soviet Publishes a Document On 1689 Treaty With China
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 18  The Soviet Union, in an apparent attempt to bolster its negotiat ing position in stalemated border talks with the Chinese, has dug back into 300yearold archives and come up with a documentary record of the first boundary pact concluded be tween Russia and China in the late 17th century.

title: The World
description: ROME  Italians, who have a rich experience in adapting to emergen cies, are learning to live without mail service. The red mailboxes at street corners are still emptied occasionally, and the postino (mailman), his heavy bag filled to overflowing, still makes his rounds once in a while. But the letters he delivers were as likely as not mailed last summer. It is a gam ble to send a letter. The rule is: If it's important, don't mail it.

title: German Vote Today
description: Public opinion polls fore cast extremely close results in the West German parlia mentary elections todays, in which Chancellor Willy Brandt's coalition Govern ment is at stake. An inter view with Mr. Brandt appears on Page 24.

title: Gardens
description: AS THE days of fall short en and daily tempera tures drop, it is time to tuck in the garden for winter. But be not too hastythere is still time ahead to complete many out dour chores.

title: Dance
description: THE first time I encoun tered French ballet was in London on April 8, 1946. It hasn't changed. The occasion I will never forget. It was at the Adelphi Theater in the Strand. The company was one that had been formed just a year earlier. It was called Les Ballets des Champs Elyses, the artistic director was Boris Kochno, a former close asso ciate of Diaghilev, and the principal choreographer was Roland Petit, a man of about 24, then on the brink of world fame.

title: Shopping Centers Geared for Holiday Customer Invasion
description: PARAMUS  The clay after Thanksgiving heralds the start of the preChrist mas rush, and with it comes a host of headaches that are all too familiar to shoppers: densely packed roads, end less cruising in search of a parking space, sometimes even the disappearance of packages from the car or the temporary loss of a child.

title: Scientists Plan Series of Tests to Assess the Impact of Supersonic Air Traffic on Life and Climate
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 18 An initial round in the na tionaland to some extent in ternational  effort to assess the impact on lite and climate of supersonic air traffic was debated here this week with no general agreement, but also with a minimum of rancor.

title: How Douglas, Eddie, Kevin, Jonathan and Julie discovered comradeship
description: Eleanor Craig's book came just as I'd gotten back from Canada. The last thing I re member about Canada is Edgar Friedenberg telling me that it seemed to him impossible to write about schools any more, since everyone in America al ready knew everything, quite possibly understood everything, and most certainly wasn't plan ning on doing anything about anything. I agreed. Going back to work in September, I could see my own school getting ready for a classic year: last year's strike and teachersolidarity forgotten, the experimental programs over with, the coun ty Mental Wealth sensitivity programs gone, the exaddicts rapping about dope vanished. Instead, we had legislative ac countability, frightening every one, more students tracked, faculty letters home about how students don't do homework, have no study habits.

title: Weapons and Supplies From U.S. Continue to Arrive in South Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 President Nixon interrupted his stay at Camp David today to return to the White House for final consultations with Henry A. Kissinger, who leaves tomor row for Paris to resume nego tiations with North Vietnam on Monday.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: OAKLAND, Nov. 18 (AP) Led by Jeff Mullins, who scored his 10,000th career point in N.B.A. play, the Golden State Warriors trounced the Buffalo Braves, 12092, tonight.

title: Front Page 4  No Title
description: Much Ado About Nothing Shakespeare's Newest Hit. Matinee Today at 3. Winter Garden Thea. Tickets Avail. Call 245 ?? Advt.

title: LETTERS
description: I can only hope that Mr. Goldberg would have given short shrift to any protago nist who might have pre sented as potently weak a case to him while he was a Supreme Court Justice as he himself appears to have done in his article.

title: Stamps
description: JUNIOR stamp collectors are going to have their own stamp show next year. The Stroudsburg chapter of the American Phi latelic Society's Junior Writ ers Unit 30 will be host, in association with the Junior Philatelic Society, for the First National All Junior Stamp Exhibit and Bourse on April 6, 7 and 8, 1973, at the PennStroud Hilton Motor Inn in Stroudsburg, Pa.

title: New Mexico Head And U.S. Officials Clash Over Indians
description: SANTA FE, N. M., Nov. 18 Gov. Bruce King made public here today a stinging letter sent to two members of the United States Civil Rights Commission, demanding that they publicly apologize to the people of New Mexico for the injustice you have done to them by an as sertion that the plight of In dians in this state was the worst in the nation.

title: State Courts Unit Backs Federal Aid Without Federal Controls
description: DENVER, Nov. 18An or ganization of state supreme court judges and administrative officers tentatively accepted to daywith reservationsa pro posal that could lead to mas sive Federal financial support of state courts.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The DowJones industrial average held center stage on Wall Street last week as it closed above 1,000 for the first time in history.

title: HAWKS WIN, 53, FROM CANADIENS
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 18 (UPI) A 70foot goal by Bill White, a defense man, helped the Chi cago Black Hawks defeat the Montreal Canadiens, 5.3 to night.

title: Customer and Holdup Man Wounded in Bar Robbery
description: RONKONKOMA, L. I., Nov. 18A customer and a holdup man were critically wounded here late last night during the armed robbery of a tavern on Rosedale Avenue.

title: Torn by diverse loyalties
description: These last eight years since the Berkeley Free Speech move ment and the Vietnam escala tion have surely been the most convulsive in the history of American higher education. Caught between political pres sure from its students and younger faculty and the finan cial revenge of alumni and government, the university reeled into the spotlight of a whole nation's agony and be came the battleground for every problem from war and racism to sexism and inflation. Nor has the crisis abated now that public confrontation has given way to student apathy and frustration, faculty attri tion and unemployment, and the fiscal desperation of har ried administrators, some chosen mainly to manage crises of a different sort.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: BONNWhether or not Willy Brandt remains West German Chancellor after today's elections, he has already made his mark.

title: Bridgeport Streak 20 With Rout of Springfield
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass. Nov. 18 (AP)Roy Ferreira, a 5 foot8inch senior quarter back, passed for four touch downs and ran for another today as Bridgeport ended a perfect regular season with a 428 rout of Springfield.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: It would seem as if the proponents of the domino theory in Southeast Asia are determined to prove them selves correct. In the past several weeks, the Administration has seen fit to send into South Vietnam a seemingly unending stream of ma triel. This represents, without doubt, the biggest gamble on the part of the United States since our military escalation in 1965.

title: TEACHER TRAINING CRITICIZED IN OHIO
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 18An independent commission study ing education in Ohio has is sued a report that is sharply critical of whit it called crip pling deficiencies in teacher preparation in Ohio.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: In a recent Book Review essay, Mavis Gallant states that French children are numb with boredom in their schools, ignore their language and lit erature  yet can pass the baccalaureate exams without having read any volume of prose, let alone poetry.

title: APPEAL OF RULING ON H.E.W. HINTED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI) Government attorneys indi cated yesterday that they would appeal the ruling of a Federal judge directing the Department of Health, Education and Wel fare to cut off funds to school districts still practicing segre gation.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: THE AMAZING SPIDER MAN: From Beyond the Grave (Buddah BIDS 5119). The tor tured lad is wrenched from nightmareridden sleep. The telephone! No! What is this voice saying? Aunt May, kid napped! And what is this im possible task set for her ran som ?! Oh well, it's just another day in the life of America's favorite schnook of a superhero, The Incredible Spiderman.

title: UNBEATEN DELAWARE TOPS BUCKNELL, 203
description: NEWARK, Del., Nov. 18 The strong running of Scotty Reihm and Roger Mason led the University of Delaware to a hardfought 203 victory over Bucknell today before a record Delaware Stadium crowd of 22,648.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThe real masters of the McGovern campaign were hap pily out of town last week as the search for a scapegoat closed in on Jean Westwood, Chairman of the Democratic National. Committee for the past four months.

title: Chrysler Head Asks Delay For Research on Emissions
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP) John J. Riccardo, president of the Chrysler Corporation, be lieves that engineers, with ad ditional time, can find a way to meet Federal automotive emission standards without the use of equipment that would be very expensive to motorists.

title: 4 Youths Hold Woman, 84, Through Five Days of Terror
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 (AP)  An 84yearold widow living on the 16th floor of a North Philadelphia publichous ing project is recovering from five days of terror during which she was beaten with a broom stick, stripped, raped, tortured, burned and robbed of her sav ings, about $229, by four youths, the police said.

title: Janet Sabatelle Wed
description: Miss Janet Marie Sabatelle, a teacher at Public School 104 in Brooklyn, was married yesterday afternoon to Alfred Roland Maresca, vice presi dent of the Arista Carting Corporation of Woodside, Queens. The Rev. Alfred Sepe performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in St. Anselm's Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn. Dr. Charles Sabatelle, a den tist, and Mrs. Sabatelle and Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Maresca are the parents of the duple. Both families are of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.

title: Panel to Urge NoFault
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Nov 18 (AP) An insurance study commis sion will recommend to the 1973 legislature passage of a nofault auto insurance bill that provides for compensating the insured up to $2,000 for an accident.

title: Union Tops Hamilton, 30, On Field Goal by Mitchell
description: CLINTON, N.Y., Nov. 18A 46yard field goal by Bob Mitchell gave Union College a 30 victory over Hamilton to day in their 77th football game.

title: Mrs. Kleier Has Child
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Ian Kleier on Nov. 13 at Beth Israel Hos pital. The child has been named Samantha Kendall. Mr. Kleier is assistant vice president of advertising for Loews Hotels.

title: MIDLIFE VIEWED AS CRISIS PERIOD
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18  A man or a woman often suffers in his thirties a life crisis that is at least as severe as that of his teens or old age, a psy chologist has concluded from studies in the United States and Britain spanning several decades.

title: The corn is green again
description: If Robert Crichton walked down to the drug store to buy a cigar, when he returned to tell of the trip it would sound like Homer's Odyssey. Such is his reputation as a storyteller, and we have The Secret of Santa Vit toria (1966) as supporting evidence. Now after several years of trips to drug stores and many more journeys back to his memories of Crichton family legends, yarns and fantasies, we have the longawaited result of his labors, his second novel. It's named for the Scottish family that controls, rides or simply survives the novel's waves of events.

title: RANGERS TRIUMPH OVER BLUES BY 31
description: ST. LOUIS, Nov. 18Despite a slow start, the absence of Brad Park and Vic Hadfield, a tough opposing goalie and a flurry of fights, the New York Rangers posted a 31 victory over the St. Louis Blues tonight before a crowd of 18,542 and urried home for a game against Pittsburgh tomorrow night.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 Car owners getting ready to winterize the family auto may gauge the quality of an antifreeze brand by checking the label on the container, according to the Federal Government's chief purchasing agency.

title: Eased Rent Control Is Being Challenged In Court and Council
description: A major change in the local rent stabilization law that makes it easier for owners to evict tenants is being chal lenged in court, in the City Council and by tenant groups.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: Fifteen dollars for the new edition of To the Finland Station! What would Marx have said?

title: Federal Attorney Asserts Sherwin Should Resign
description: NEWARK, Nov. 18  United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern said today that New Jersey's, Secretary of State, Paul J. Sher win, should resign from the office he has so abused and misused.

title: Two Youths Are Held in Bridgeport Professor's Death
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.; Nov. 18 Two youths were charged this morning with the hatchet slaying last Monday night of Charles F. Evans Jr., a 35 yearold assistant professor of speech at the University of Bridgeport.

title: Exurbia: SplitWeek LifeStyle
description: THE SPRINGS, L. I.Un til they moved to this East End hamlet two months ago, Roseanne and Howard Leb with had seldom been sepa rated in almost seven years of marriage. Now they are apart two nights a week ev ery week, and as little as they like the arrangement they are learning to live with it.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: WENTWORTH LOCATION, N. H. Deerhunting camps are a little like Christmas packages you never know what youre going to find.

title: City Welfare Unit Scored on Handling Of I.D. Card System
description: Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx said yes terday that thousands of elder ly welfare recipients were in danger of having their assist ance cut off because of weak nesses in the city's current phasing in of photo identifica tion cards.

title: C.A.B. Proposes to Drop All Affinity Charter Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP)  The Civil Aeronautics Board has proposed to suspend affin ity charter rules, widely used for air travel by clubs and as sociations, so long as the newly approved travel group charters are in effect.

title: RISE IN SOVIET AID IN ARMS REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18A United States Government in telligence study reports that in 1971 the Soviet Union supplied $1.1billion worth of military assistance to the less developed countries.

title: Brandt Assesses Chances: A Small Majority Would Be Workable
description: BONN, Nov. 17Stressing that it is impossible to solve the problem of divided Ger many except within a European framework, Chancellor Willy Brandt has pledged himself to continue working slowly to make life easier for the Ger man people and hope that con ditions will improve with change. He seemed confident of victory, and a continued mandate in tomorrow's election.

title: No bed of roses, even in the good old days
description: Being president of a college or university is undoubtedly one of the most difficult jobs in America. I know one saintly man  selfless, hardworking, universally popular before leaving the classroom who was so shaken by his experi ences as president of two col leges that he seriously consid ered abandoning the academic profession. Anotherno saint returned to teaching after less than a year, convinced that continuation in his high office would have led him to an early grave.

title: City Will Act on Dispute Over a DayCare Center
description: Eleanor Holmes Norton, Chairman of the city's Com mission on Human Rights, said yesterday that she would take immediate action to settle the racial and ethnic aspects of the conflict involving a day care center in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn.

title: IN THE NATION
description: The Supreme Court ruled last week that despite the Government's wire tapping of a member of the Daniel Ellsberg defense team, the trial of Mr. Ellsberg and his friend, Anthony Russo, could continue. But it does not seem to be widely recognized that the charges against these two men, if sus tained, will provide the Government with far more sweeping powers of secrecy and censorship than it has ever had.

title: Guide, 79, Expects Good Duck Season
description: HAMPTON BAYS, L.I.  With the opening of the duckshooting season here to morrow, Frank Downs Sr. will again be on hand, as he has been for the last 60 years, to show sportsmen how it is done.

title: LETTERS
description: Ebasco Services' figure for increases granted by states or local jurisdictions to inves torowned utilities for the first nine months of 1972 is $492,550,126 [Utilities Win ning Huge Rate Increases, Nov. 12].

title: Michigan Field Goal Tops Purdue, 96, With 1:04 Left
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 18 Mike Lantry, who earlier had missed a key extra point, kicked a 30yard field goal with 1 minute 4 seconds re maining today to give unde feated Michigan a 96 football victory over Purdue.

title: COLLEGE QUINTETS IN BENEFIT CONTEST
description: For the benefit of a scholar ship fund, the New York chap ter of the WinstonSalem (N.C.) State University Alumni Asso ciation will sponsor a basket ball game between Winston Salem and Howard University on Saturday night.

title: 7 Years of Lobbying Finally Brings Chiropractic Under Umbrella of Medicare
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 After seven years of ceaseless lobbying, chiropractors have finally succeeded in getting themselves included in the multibilliondollar Medicare pro gram through a series of events that offers a view of the workings of Washington in microcosm.

title: JOSEPH ROGOFF
description: BALDWIN, L. I., Nov. 18 Joseph Rogoff, a salesman for the General Electric Company for 29 years, died yesterday of a heart attack in South Nassau Communities Hospital in Ocean side. He was 49 years old and lived here at 764 Washington Street.

title: Earl Schenck Miers Dies at 62; Wrote on Civil War and Lincoln
description: EDISON, N. J. Nov. 18Earl Schenck Miers, an author and editor best known for his writ ings on the Civil War and Abraham Lincoln, died yester day at his home. His age was 62.

title: The Nation
description: In the hamlet of Monroeville, astride United States Route 20 between Toledo and Cleveland, fiscal crisis threatens when the Police Department's radar set breaks down.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Hurry along chores postponed by rainy weekends,  Do not overfeed house plants; there is less sun now Oil tools Check stored tender bulbs.

title: Information Folders Available to Skaters
description: The Parks Administration has issued a free folder that lists the locations, prices and skatingsession schedules at each of its seven ice skating rinks. The folder also gives information about the free skating sessions for young sters at each rink, as well as transportation suggestions.

title: Heard Scores a Career High of 31 Points as Bulls Vanquish Bullets, 95 to 79
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP) Garfield Heard, who substituted for the ailing Chet Walker, scored a career high of 31 points and played a key de fensive role today to lead the Chicago Bulls to a 9579 Na tional Basketball Association triumph over the Baltimore Bullets.

title: The Guest Word
description: Martin Duberman's Black Mountain: An Exploration in Community leaps be yond the discipline of history in its sig nificance. It challenges traditional ways of doing history but does not dodge cus tomary scholarly requirements. It sur passes, rather than bypasses, traditional scholarship; and its approach to the writ ing of history is so deeply subversive of things as they are that the profession will never be the same.

title: Evelyn Lerch Married Here
description: In the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration here yes terday afternoon, Miss Eve lyn Lerch became the bride of William B. Halsted, a wid ower, of New York and Bell port, L. I. The Rev. Joseph P. Frary performed the cere mony in the chapel.

title: Dagbury, a Pekingese, Named Best of 1,516 Dogs at Sussex Hills Fixture
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., Nov. 18 When Ch. Dagbury of Cal artha, a red Pekingese coowned by Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords Jr. of New York and Michael Wolf of North Babylon, L. I., was named best of 320 toy dogs at the progressive show in New York on Oct. 29, Wolf hurried to the phone to relay the good news to Mrs. Jeffords in Paris.

title: Letters: Dixie Kitsch
description: You broke my heart by publishing the article by Peter Range on Georgia's Stone Mountain memorial to the Con federacy, The Pinnacle of Kitsch, SouthernStyle (Travel section, Oct. 29). You should apologize to the editor of The Atlanta Constitution and to your readers for an indefensible piece of journalism, if one might call it that.

title: Police report on the TV cop shows
description: This is the season of the cop shows. There are dozens of them. They are all around us. The only thing they all share is heroes carrying shields and guns. That plus an incredible collection of prime time halftruths, illusions, stupidities and outright lies.

title: Miss Lisa Bennett
description: Mrs. Elizabeth Chew Ben nett of Radnor, Pa., and Ed win Eversley Bennett of Manchester, Vt., have an nounced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lisa Eversley Bennett, to McKin ley Campbell McAdoo. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Campbell McAdoo of Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: Transparent Things
description: Vladimir Nabokov, having spent his life building the Taj Mahal, has de cided at the age of 73  for his own amusement and incidentally for our pleasure  to construct a small mock replica. The miniature is not flawed, no, but the most splendid features of the great model have been just slightly parodied, out of playfulness almost. You see, the past is something of a joke, he seems to be saying; and those whose pro fessional lives consist of literary de tective work are going to be kept busy with Ada, Lolita, and The Real Life of Sebastian Knight, try ing to discover if he means it.

title: $75,000 Prize Is Created For Research in Chemistry
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 18 (AP) The Robert A. Welch Founda tion has announced the crea tion of a $75,000 prize for basic chemical research, open to any chemist in the world.

title: MRS. CHARLES HERMAN
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y. Nov. 18 Mrs. Hannah Rudey Herman, wife of Charles Herman, presi dent of the J Chemical Works of New York City, died Thurs day at New Rochelle Hospital.

title: House to Get Its Electronic Voting System Jan. 3
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 When Congress convenes Jan. 3, the House will have the use of a $1million timesaving device  a computeroperated electronic voting system.

title: Old Testament, new appraisal
description: Scripture as dealt with in this book consists of what Christians call the Old Testa ment and Jews call Tanak, meaning the Law, the Prophets and the Writings; the apocry phal and New Testament writ ings are excluded. Samuel Sandmel, a distinguished Jewish scholar, says at the beginning that he does not know of an other book quite like this one a purely literary appraisal of the Bible. The claim is too strong. Many other writers have done substantially what he does, though few have done it well.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: While the loss of the Executive branch of the Federal Government in the election has crushed many Demo crats, perhaps they should consider whether the election of a Democratic Congress in the face of an opposi tion of Republicans, Wallaceites and turnedoff Democrats was not actually a startling victory. Analysis of the re sults might well show that the per centage of the electorate committed to social change and concern for the underdog has actually risen since 1968.

title: City's Health Department Tightens Its Regulation of MiniAbortion Procedure
description: A medical procedure for ear ly intervention in possible preg nancy, less expensive than standard abortion and consid ered by some physicians and women to be less traumatic physically and emotionally, has been declared by the city's Health Department to be sub ject to the same rules that gov ern other abortional ??.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Bob Wise's letter [Nov. 5] is selfcontradictory. He men tions the premium rates that are collected from the deteriorated Times Square hotels, which we have been closing, as an indication of our greed.

title: The High Priests Of Waste
description: Choose one of the following: A. Ernest Fitzgerald is (1) A modern day Gulliver who suddenly found himself among greedy, weak and dis ingenuous Lilliputians in a place commonly known as the MilitaryIndustrial Complex.

title: Queens Unit Acts to Bar Job Exodus
description: Last March, 25 Queens busi nessmen, bankers and labor leaders, along with city offi cials, were invited by Queens Borough President Donald R. Manes to form a council to help reverse the exodus of industry out of the borough.

title: CHARTER REFORM STALLED UPSTATE
description: ALBANY, Nov. 18  An ap parent Election Day victory for Charter reform in Niagara County is being questioned by state officials here who cite a provision of the State Constitu tion requiring a double major ity for the legal approval of new County Charters.

title: TV Mailbag
description: That sappy, plastic Tab and Sympathy soap opera, That Certain Summer, succeeded in making homosexuality as pertinent and interesting as a dead bromo fizz. If I were young and searching for an swers and had to choose between heterosexuality and homosexuality and my choice was based on exposure to that melodrama and Merle Miller's crybaby review that followed, I would choose Australia.

title: Taliaferro Cut by Bills
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 18 (AP) The Buffalo Bills of the National Football League waived their backup quarterback, Mike Talia ferro, today and activated Leo Hart. Hart was obtained from the Los Angeles Rams recently and moved up from the Bills' taxi squad.

title: India Adopts the Tiger As Her National Animal
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 18 (AP) The Indian Wildlife Board today adopted the tiger as India's national animal and announced a largescale cam paign to save the animal from extinction.

title: Tellier Helps Connecticut Beat Rhode Island, 4221
description: STORRS, Conn., Nov. 18 (AP) Ray Tellier scored two touch downs and Eric Torkelson rushed for 112 yards today to lead the University of Connecti cut to a 4221 Yankee Confer ence victory over Rhode Island.

title: News of Boating
description: The world outboard cham pionships, with a new name and a new rule, will be held in the old setting. Lake Hav asu City, Ariz., next Saturday and Sunday. The name is now the PepsiCola outboard world championships, and the rule change limits drivers to single engines. At least 105 entries were re ported by Robert P. McCulloch Jr., director of the $60,000 race. The breakdown went like this: 34 makes of tunnel hulls, topped by Molinari with 25 and followed by 10 Scot tis, 10 Schulzes and seven SidSons.

title: Columbia Cuts Its Deficit By $1Million Under 1971
description: Columbia University's aus terity program combined with a tuition increase has reduced the university's deficit this year to $9.9million, more than $1million less than last year's, according to Dr. William J. McGill, the university president.

title: He remains incurably great
description: In his Introduction to this fourth and final volume of George Wash ington, James Thomas Flexner writes: During twelve years I have on most mornings waked up antici pating association with an endlessly complicated and various individual who, so I became convinced, was one of the greatest men in all history. This is a privilege hard to relin quish.

title: Issues Are Lacking In New Zealand Vote But Antics Are Not
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Nov. 18  New Zealand votes a week from today in an elec tion in which the greatest prob lem has been to find any issue to arouse public interest. So devoid has the campaign been of questions to engage the emo tions that people have turned for light relief to the antics of a candidateleader of the Mad Hatter's Tea Partywho changed his name to Mickey Mouse, and a wouldbe candi date who says his name is Jesus Christ.

title: Namath vs. Morrall in Super Rematch
description: MIAMI, Nov. 18The last time Joe Namath met Earl Morrall in the Orange Bowl, the New York Jets quarterback guaranteed a victory and the Jets went on to win Super Bowl III and turn the pro football world topsyturvy.

title: Penn State Trounces Boston College and Will Go to Sugar Bowl
State Checking Petitions for Public Employes' Union Elections
description: TRENTONNew Jersey's Employment Relations Com mission, which deals with publicemploye labor prob lems, is currently processing petitions for representation elections involving 11,000 nonsupervisory administra tive and clerical employes of the state and nearly 3,000 faculty members at eight state colleges.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The article Noise Issue Must Not Halt Project by Clara Fox [Nov. 5] misses the point. Ms. Fox suggests that somehow it is all right for people who live on the Lower East Side to go deaf from motorvehicle noise while people who can live in the suburbs have the privi lege of living in quiet.

title: U.S. Effort to Cut Its U.N. Dues Backed by Canada
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 18Canada today gave strong support to a United States effort to reduce Wash ington's contribution to the United Nations budget. But it was apparent that the United States initiative faced an up hill battle.

title: WHALES UTILIZED IN BLOOD STUDIES
description: Medical scientists are taking small samples' of blood from four white whales at the New York Aquarium in Coney Island, in a hunt for clues to some of the mysteries of human blood disorders.

title: New & Novel
description: Margins is full of unusual perspectives and bizarre urban vignettes. Unfortunately, what goes on in the midst of all this imagery diminishes in sig nificance till the novel be comes almost an arty shaggy dog story.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: During an 18month period that ended last June, the City Commission on Human Rights received 150 complaints from women charging sex discrimination, according to a commission report issued yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In the matter of these skyjackings, I have never understood why it is thought better to risk the lives of everybody in the air rather than those of only a few on the ground. It would seem to me that there would be no question about using any means to keep an airliner full of people on the ground once it landed.

title: MRS. C. G. THOMPSON
description: TAMWORTH, N. H., Nov. 18 Mrs. Alice Bemis Thompson, wife of Charles Goodrich Thompson, a retired New York lawyer, died at their home here yesterday.

title: Eleanor Page Is Married in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 18Mrs. Eleanor Page MacDonald, who as Eleanor Page is so ciety editor of The Chicago Tribune, was married here this afternoon to Frank E. Voysey of Winnetka, a vice president in Chicago of Kid der, Peabody & Co., stock brokers. The Rev. Dr. William Lea performed the ceremony in St. Chrysostom's Episcopal Church.

title: 2 Hearings Scheduled By Council Committees
description: The following open hear ings are scheduled at City Hall this week by City Coun cil committees:

title: Cortlandt Van Rensselaer, ExInsurance Underwriter
description: BEDFORD, N.Y., Nov. 18  Cortlandt Schuyler Van Rens selaer, a member of one of New York's oldest families and a re tired insurance underwriter, died yesterday at the Northern Westchester Hospital after a long illness. His age was 72.

title: Kent State Wins, 279; Accepts Tangerine Bid
description: KENT, Ohio, Nov. 18 (AP) Eddie Woodard, a 5foot 7inch, 164pound running back, broke loose for a 95 yard touchdown run and Larry Poole scored two touchdowns today to give Kent State University a 279 victory over Toledo and the MidAmerican Conference championship.

title: She Gave Archie His First Comeuppance
description: TALLULAH BANKHEAD called her the divine Beatrice, but didn't think she had the bone structure for a leading lady. No matter, Beatrice Arthur always knew that someone even tually would see beyond mere flesh and bones, beyond her Lane Bryant figure and waft her off to Hollywood where she would emerge as her true inner self, a tiny blonde sex object.

title: COLUMBIA NAMES BRITON ARCHITECT
description: Columbia University has created the post of campus architect, and named a Briton, Douglas Dean Telfer, to fill it.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTON  One of the last coldwar theaters to survive the di plomacy of the Nixon era centers on 90 miles of blue water between the United States and Cuba. Last week it seemed possiblejust possiblethat the spirit of dtnte had found a new opening in the Caribbean. Administra tion spokesmen led by Secretary of State William P. Rogers uttered the first kind words to be publicly ad dressed to the Castro Government since diplomatic relations between Washington and Havana were broken nearly 12 years ago.

title: P.E.N. to Meet in Israel
description: BERLIN, Nov. 18 (AP)The international P.E.N. writers club will meet in Israel in 1973, a spokesman has announced.

title: BOMBING OF NORTH DECLINES SHARPLY
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Nov. 19American air strikes against North Vietnam fell off sharply yesterday, and ground fighting in South Viet nam continued the decline be gun two weeks ago, allied mili tary spokesmen said.

title: ExAide to Nixon Heads Bible Week Observance
description: National Bible Week, an in terfaith event sponsored annu ally by the Laymen's National Bible Committee, begins today.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: With the approach of 1973, textile and apparel execu tives are scrutinizing pros pects for profits in the new year. So far it looks pretty good, but there are some pit falls that should be avoided.

title: Stamps
description: POSTAL historians don't turn a page of old doc uments or scrap books without a thorough in spection. Robson Lowe of London, a premier postal his tory scholar, with long years of research into American lo cal posts, in perusing a scrapbook of 19th century letters, came across a remind er of what the postal service was like even before the ad vent of postage stamps.

title: Beadleston Slated To Head Senate
description: TRENTON  With only three recorded exceptions in this century, the annual shift of legislative leadership in New Jersey is played like a game of musical chairs. The Senate and Assembly leader ship posts are very much like revolving doors, with Senate Presidents and Assembly Speakers generally in one year and out the next, even if the party in power re mains in power.

title: Letters
description: There was a flurry of ex citement at the end of the summer in our building when Anthony Burgess moved in. His apartment, contrary to his statement in Anthony Bur gess meets New York (Oct. 29), is not on Broadway and 93rd Street, but in an older cooperative middle  class building on West End Avenue and 93rd; his windows face West End Avenue between 92nd and 93rd, not a cotton mill nor a sidewalk littered with broken bottles. And there are many tenants who would be glad to help solve his cockroach problem.

title: Miss Wendy McCrary Fiancee of Henry Breck
description: Miss Wendy McCrary, a junior at the New School for Social Research, plans to be married Jan. 20 to Henry Reynolds Breck, a partner in Lehman Brothers, investment bankers here. The ceremony will take place in St. James' Episcopal Church here.

title: Letters To the Travel Editor
description: I am a Northerner with no Southern connections at all, yet I was shocked at The Times for printing the psychotic article on Stone Mountain. The author is obviously sick. He is also a poor writer who has not learned that if you scream with rage in every single sen tence the impact diminishes markedly.

title: Japanese Setting Up U.S. Goodwill Visits
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18At a time when its relations with the United States are emerging from one of the most difficult periods in recent years, the Japanese Government is hoping to speed the recovery of good feeling through an ambitious new program of educational and cultural exchange aimed chiefly at improving the coun try's image here.

title: EXHIBITION DEPICTS JEWISH RESISTANCE
description: An exhibition of more than 100 photographs that depict the Nazi reign of terror and the resistance of Jewish under ground groups opened yester day at 515 Park Avenue.

title: Two Phony Phone Calls Bilk Couple of $95,000
description: LAFAYETTE, La., Nov. 18 (AP)  A man telephoned Mrs. Charles Boudousequie at home yesterday, told her he was a telephone repair man and asked her to take her phone off the hook for an hour, which she did.

title: John J. Rowlands Dead; Led News Service at M.I.T.
description: BOSTON, Nov. 18 (AP)John J. Rowlands, a former news paperman and director of news service at Massachusetts Insti tue of Technology, died Thurs day at Massachusetts General Hospital. He was 80 years old.

title: G.M. IS TOLD TO PAY $600,372 IN ACCIDENT
description: CONCORD, N. H., Nov. 18 A jury ordered the General Mo tors Corporation this week to pay $600,372 in the 1969 car crash deaths of a Nashua, N. H., attorney Thomas Leo nard, and his wife, Martha.

title: Africans at U.N. Are Suspicious Of Vorster Plan for Trust Area
description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 18 The results of the latest United Nations effort to obtain selfdetermination and, ulti mately, independence for the South Africanruled territory of SouthWest Africa have not satisfied key black African delegates here, despite several apparent concessions by South Africa.

title: An Opening to Cuba
description: Now that President Nixon has opened up a speaking relationship with Communist China, developed a commer cial and economic dtente with Communist Russia and indicated a policy of peace and reconstruction for Com munist North Vietnam, it would logically follow that he miss no opportunity to begin what may well be the most touchy of all such maneuvers visavis the Communist world: an unfreezing of United States relations with Cuba. Although in comparison to China, Russia or even Hanoi, Castro's Cuba is not much more than a roaring mouse, it is stillgeographically, politically and emo tionallya major disturbing factor in the foreign policy spectrum of the Americas, particularly of the United States.

title: CITY WASTE USED IN COMPOST STUDY
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 18 Large amounts of municipal wastes that have been ground up can be safely used as com post on commercial pine plan tations in sandy, overly drained soil, a governmentsponsored study has found.

title: New & Novel
description: Dr. Able Pike, a thriving up state psychiatrist, is another of those doctors acutely in need of healing. He is dogged by personal doubts. (It was fatal for a depressed patient to sud denly feel the despair of the therapist, for an Oedipalfix ated woman to sense the shim mering of tabooed love  across the polished desk.) In spite of his wobbly attitudes, Pike's relationship with his family belongs to the bullin theChina shop syndrome. The crux of this novel finds all ties strained.

title: Television
description: IN covering voting re turns on election night, the American Broad casting Company, Co lumbia Broadcasting System and National Broadcasting Company spent a total that hovered around $9million, give or take a few hundred thousand dollars. The next morning NBC announced that some part of the pro ductions was seen by 120 million viewers.

title: Dr. Alexandre Goldblat Is Dead; Anesthesiologist at Mt. Sinai, 56
description: Dr. Alexandre Goldblat, at tending anesthesiologist at the Mount Sinai Hospital and clini cal professor at its school of medicine, died Friday, appar ently of a heart attack, at his home, 210 Central Park South. His age was 56.

title: A FRIEND OF POOR DIES OF MUGGING
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 18A Westport psychiatrist died last night, a week after he was mugged during a visit to a lowincome housing project whose residents he had be friended.

title: DECLINE CONTINUES IN READING ABILITY OF PUPILS IN CITY
description: The reading ability of city pupils continued to decline last year, according to a report sent to the Board of Education by School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS CITED AS RACIST
description: Children's books and text books were cited at a confer ence yesterday as purveyors of white supremacist and colonial ist attitudes, with results far beyond the mere publication of misinformation of ethnic stere otypes.

title: NonFederal Taxes Rose $33 Per Person in 1971
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP) The average taxpayer in the United States contributed $33 a year more to state and local governments during the fiscal year 1971 than in the previous year, a study has shown.

title: SOPHOMORES PACE AUBURN'S VICTORY
description: AUBURN, Ala., Nov. 18 (AP) Randy Walls and Chris Linder man, a pair of sophomores, ac counted for three touchdowns today as 11thranked Auburn defeated Georgia, 2710, in the Southeastern Conference.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTONFor the first time in many years, the United States and Cuba have a common problem, which may lead to reappraisal of the rela tions between the two countries. President Nixon doesn't want Ameri can commercial airplanes to be hi jacked to Havana and Fidel Castro, ac cording to the Swiss, doesn't want them to land there, and this is now under the most careful if oblique dip lomatic discussion.

title: Train Kills 3 Youths
description: FAIRFIELD, Ohio, Nov. 18 (UPI)A Penn Central train struck and killed three boys who apparently thought the on coming freight was on an op posite track, the engineer said today. The victims were David Fields, 15 years old, Sherman Napier, 14, and Mark southe land, all of Maud.

title: TV Mailbag
description: THAT Certain Sum mer, by Richard Levinson and Wil liam Link, perpetu ated a double standard that is highly offensive to a gay liberation viewpoint.

title: World News Briefs
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 18 The military Government's Al liance for National Renovation won widespread victories, as expected, in Brazil's municipal elections against the single op position party permitted to en ter candidates, it was reported today.

title: REFORM IS URGED ON POWER PLANS
description: The creation of two new Fed eral agencies to replace the Federal Power Commission and the Atomic Energy Commission, has been proposed, along with other reforms, by a committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, fol lowing a year's study of the nation's energy needs.

title: Law
description: At the time the speech seemed routine. Among many another Senator, Daniel B. Brewster, a Maryland Demo crat, was speaking out in favor of low thirdclass mail rates.

title: 500 in the U. S. Change Sex In Six Years With Surgery
description: Six years ago, it was dis closed that American doctors had been performing one of the most radical forms of surgery  the operations that change one's sex. Since then, an estimated 500 persons have undergone surgical sex change in this country, and hundreds more have applied for such surgery.

title: Levitt Charges Relief Workers Nap, Play or Exercise on Jobs
description: A picture of idyllic working hours among some city welfare employeswith time out for naps, for exercise, chess or cards, or for fixing each other's hair was sketched yesterday in a report by State Controller Arthur Levitt on personnel nonproductivity.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I read, with interest, the Nov. 13 letter from Charles F. Luce, chairman of Consolidated Edison.

title: Three Children Left Alone Die In a Tenement Fire in Brooklyn
description: Three children in a Brooklyn family died and three others were injured, one critically, when fire destroyed their third floor tenement apartment at 492 Henry Street, near DeGraw, in the South Brooklyn section, early yesterday.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE DEATH OF THE AUTOMOBILE. By John Jerome. Drawings by Robert Osborn. 288 pages. Norton. $6.95.

title: BRUINS WIN, 65, GAIN THIRD PLACE
description: BOSTON, Nov. 19 (UPI) Mike Walton and Greg Shep pard registered two goals apiece while Ken Hodge and Phil Esposito had one each to night as the Boston Bruins topped the Toronto. Leafs, 65, in a ational Hockey League game.

title: Study Finds City's Future Very Much Alive
description: A group of Columbia Uni versity social scientists, after delving into the problems of New York City and predic tions of its approaching death, has produced a book, bolstered with statis tics and historical perspec tive, that insists the city has a bright future.

title: Daughter's Book Calls Truman Loath to Run in 1944
description: Harry S. Truman wrote his family in July, 1944, that he would rather not become Vice President or President, ac cording to a new biography written by his daughter, but he accepted the VicePresidential, nomination later that month after President Roosevelt said that to refuse it would be to break up the Democratic party in the middle of a war.

title: Lisa Pesko's Horse Wins Tewksbury Hunter Title
description: POTTERSVILLE, N. J., Nov. 19 Macchu Picchu, a 4yearold bay gelding owned and ridden by Lisa Pesko of New York, captured the Limit Working Hunter championship and fin ished as reserve champion in the novice Working Hunter competition yesterday at the Tewksbury Farms horse show.

title: Cables Will Truss the Tower of Pisa
description: PISA, Italy, Nov. 19  The Leaning Tower, that elegant ly ?? structure that evokes the image of Italy in the remotest corners of the world, will soon be trussed into a harness of steel cables to keep it from falling down.

title: Flames Edge Flyers, 32
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 19 (UPI) Larry Romanchych of Atlanta scored the first two goals of his N.H.L. career and assisted as Bob Leiter knocked in the gamewinner tonight as the Flames beat the Philadelphia Flyers, 32.

title: New RushHour Bus Zone Set for Downtown Brooklyn
description: To expedite rushhour trans portation, a special bus zone will be introduced at 7 A.M. today on Fulton Street from Flatbush Avenue to Adams Street in downtown Brooklyn. Traffic Commissioner Theodore Karagheuzoff announced yes terday.

title: Dance: Love Songs
description: Alvin Ailey's newest chore ography for the Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Theater is an extended version of the solo he created last spring for Dudley Williams.

title: Israeli Chief Rabbi Acts on a Dispute Involving Marriages
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 19  Chief Rabbi Shlomo Goren put an abrupt end today to a religious controversy over a brother and sister who have been prevented by a rabbinical court from mar rying their fiances.

title: Jets Lose, Giants Win
description: The undefeated Dolphins clinched their division title yesterday with their 10th football victory, a 2824 de cision over the Jets in Miami. The Giants beat the Cards, 137, in St. Louis. (Page 51.)

title: City Sees No Need For a Rise in Taxes
description: City Finance Administrator Richard Lewisohn said yes terday that New York would have no need for increasing taxes if the economy con tinues its upward trend.

title: BRANDT COALITION IS SWEPT BACK IN FOR SECOND TERM
description: BONN, Nov. 19West Ger mans gave Chancellor Willy Brandt's coalition Government a resounding vote of confidence today with 54 per cent of the total in federal elections.

title: Nathan M. Ohrbach Dead at 87; Built Stores on Profit in Pennies
description: Nathan M. ?? who be gan selling women's coats in a corner of a friend's millinery store in Brooklyn and went on to found and build the Ohr bach's store chain, died here yesterday in the Mary Manning Walsh Home. He was 87 years old and lived in Hampshire House.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Nov. 19About 75 members of the Newark Museum took to the hills to day to examine at first hand the source of their high grade water in the historic Pequannock Watershed, a 35,000acre area being pro posed for partial develop ment into a yearround rec reation area.

title: Hard Drugs Fade on Campuses, But Use of Soft Drugs Is Wide
description: Heroin has virtually disap peared and the popularity of most other hard drugs is fading rapidly this year on college campuses in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Choosing a Man Who: I
description: Now that the 1972 Presidential elec tion is over, I believe it would be in the national interest to initiate a public dialogue designed to bring about a number of badly needed changes in the present outmoded procedures by which a President and Vice President are elected.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Nov. 19 (UPI) The Democratic State Assembly leader, John Horn, called yes terday for the defeat of the $650million masstransit pack age proposed by the Port Au thority of New York and New Jersey, which comes before the lower house tomorrow.

title: U. S. C. Leads Big Parade to Bowls; Three Stay in Race for Ivy Title
description: Southern California displayed a strong defense and powerful, varied offense while beating the University of California, Los Angeles, 247, Saturday, to re main undefeated and earn the Rose Bowl spot as the cham pion of the Pacific Eight Con ference. The Trojans will also continue to be ranked No. 1 in the nation following their 10th straight victory this year and 15th consecutive game without a loss.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Nov. 20Heavy shell ing hit South Vietnamese ma rines and armored cavalry troops Saturday as they con tinued their fourdayold push north of Quangtri city, South Vietnamese military spokesmen reported yesterday.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Hearings on Dock Concern Starting

title: Canarsie Boycott Risk Recedes As All Sides Await Zoning Plan
description: The threat of a new school boycott in Canarsie receded yesterday as all sides in the dispute agreed to wait until the release, expected later this week, of a preliminary rezon ing plan to Improve integration.

title: M'GOVERN'S AIDES BACK MUSKIE ALLY AS HEAD OF PARTY
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 Close associates of Senator George McGovern are united behind George Mitchell, a 39 yearold lawyer from Portland, Me., and a political intimate of Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine, to be the next chair man of the Democratic National Committee.

title: ALICE POLLITZER, 102, EARLY SUFFRAGIST
description: Mrs. Alice Kohn Pollitzer, a former suffragist who was ac tive in civic work past her 100th birthday, died yesterday at her, home, 215 West 88th Street, at the age of 102. She was the widow of Dr. Sigmund Pollitzer, a dermatologist.

title: Sessions Wins Sprint Title
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Nov. 19 (UPI)Sam Sessions of Nash ville, Mich., won the United States Auto Club sprint car championship today when the final race of the season was canceled because of rain.

title: Q's Defeat Rockets
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 19 (AP) Stew Johnson hit two quick baskets at the start of overtime tonight, helping the San Diego Conquistadors beat the Denver Rockets, 122116.

title: State Banking Chief Will Assist Consumers
description: Harry W. Albright Jr., who took office as New York State's Superintendent of Banks in a swirl of controversy last May following Governor Rocke feller's ouster of his predeces sor, William T. Dentzer Jr., is plotting an independent, con sumeroriented course for his agency.

title: Inquiry Hints at Corruption Among Immigration Aides
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 19  The United States Attorney's office here is conducting a nationwide investigation into alleged cor ruption in all echelons of the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

title: Rubble Cleared in Big Sur, And Highway Is Reopened
description: BIG SUR, Calif., Nov. 19 (UPI)The sun came out to day and the last rubble was cleared from a highway closed for four days, by mud slides washed from the side of a fire denuded mountain onto this community.

title: Transsexual Tries to Build a New Life
description: Robert is a slight but well built 26yearold man with a deep, resonant voice and eyes that flash with intelligence. He spent more than 20 years of his life as a confused and unhappy female. Now he is trying to build a new life for himself as a male. He decided to tell his story to help those who may feel as he once did.

title: M'GOVERN'S AIDES BACK MUSKIE ALLY AS HEAD OF PARTY
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 Close associates of Senator George McGovern are united behind George Mitchell, a 39 yearold lawyer from Portland, Me., and a political intimate of Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine, to be the next chair man of the Democratic National Committee.

title: Levitt Charges Relief Workers Nap, Play or Exercise on Jobs
description: A picture of idyllic working hours among some city welfare employeswith time out for naps, for exercise, chess or cards, or for fixing each other's hair  was sketched yesterday in a report by State Controller Arthur Levitt on personnel nonproductivity.

title: Stage: Four by Kvares
description: Through choice or circum stance, many individuals re main in noncommercial the ater, but few have the stay ing power or the productivity of Donald Kvares. Forty plays have passed through his typewriter, and in the last 10 years many of them have been stagedall over the Off Off Broadway map. But until last night, Kvares had never been produced Off Broadway.

title: Japanese Yacht Still Missing
description: TOKYO, Nov. 19 (UPI)The missing yacht of Kenichi Horie, who 10 years ago made a transPacific voyage alone, was reported still missing today after an aerial search by Japan's Maritime Safety Agen cy. The yacht left a port near Osaka last Sunday, on another roundtheworld voyage but was caught in a storm due south of Shizuoka Pre fecture in central Japan.

title: I.R.A. Chief of Staff Arrested by Dublin
description: DUBLIN, Nov. 19  Scan MacStiofain, chief of staff of the militant Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army, was arrested near here today and held at a police station for questioning.

title: FRENCH RUFFLED BY BRITISH DEALS
description: PARIS, Nov. 19In French the word for tidal wave is raz de melee. It was used to de scribe the victory of Richard Nixon a few days ago. It is still being used to describe the rush of British companies to the Continent, and particularly to France, on the eve of member ship in the Common Market.

title: ST. LOUIS CHOSEN FOR STUDY OF AIR
description: BOULDER, Colo., Nov. 19 (AP)St. Louis is being put under a microscope for the benefit of the world.

title: Judge Backs Motorist Who Warned Speeders.
description: A Bergen County District Court Judge has ruled that it is not against the law for someone to warn motorists of a speed trap.

title: Southern U. Chief Ousts 2 Who Advised Dissidents
description: BATON ROUGE, Nov. 19Dr. G. Leon Netterville Jr., presi dent of Southern University, has quietly dismissed at least two professors, including a de partment head, for advising students who had been demon strating in the last three weeks.

title: Group Names Karpatkin
description: Marvin M. Karpatkin, long a civil liberties lawyer here, has been named chairman of the board of directors of Com munity Action for Legal Serv ices. He said he would aim to strengthen its efforts for the city's poor, and to defend legal services programs from those individuals and forces which seek to attack or undercut them.

title: Chiefs' Hopes Dimmed, 27 to 17
description: The Kansas City Chiefs, a strong preseason selection for an eventual berth in the Na tional Football League's Super Bowl, continued their mysteri ous slide into mediocrity yester day. The San Diego Chargers ended a fivegame losing streak to top the Chiefs, 2717, at Kan sas City.

title: BRANDY COALITION IS SWEPT BACK IN FOR SECOND TERM
description: BONN, Nov. 19West Ger mans gave Chancellor Willy Brandt's coalition Government a resounding vote of confidence today with 54 per cent of the total in federal elections.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Nov 19To put New Jersey's mayors on an equal footing with private lob byists, the Mayor of Trenton has written a 214page hand book explaining the fine and sometimes secretive art of leg islative persuasion.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: A Bergen County District Court Judge has ruled that it is not against the law for someone to warn motorists of a speed trap.

title: KISSINGER ARRIVES IN PARIS TO RENEW TALKS WITH HANOI
description: PARIS, Nov. 19Henry A. Kissinger and a team of aides arrived here tonight to start another round of negotiations on a ceasefire in Vietnam. The talks start tomorrow.

title: Miss Morrison Wed To Kenneth L. Davis
description: SYOSSET, L.I., Nov. 19 Miss Bonnie Jeanne Morri son, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Morrison of Sy osset and West Palm Beach, Fla., was married here this afternoon to Kenneth Leon Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Davis, also of Sy osset. Rabbis Bernard Ruben stein and Daniel Fogel per formed the ceremony at the Midway Jewish Center.

title: 10 in Row for Lakers
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 19 (AP) The Los Angeles Lakers went on a shooting spree in the first half tonight and easily won their 10th game in a row, beat ing the Philadelphia 76ers, 135 95. It was the Lakbrs' 15th victory in the last 16 games.

title: Newspaper Says Greek Regime Plans General Elections in 1973
description: ATHENS, Nov. 19A well informed Athens newspaper said today that the Greek Gov ernment planned to hold gen eral elections next year for the first time since 1964.

title: Hull Tallies Twice
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 19 (AP) Bobby Hull got his fourth and fifth goals of the W.H.A. season tonight, enabling the Winnipeg Jets to beat the Los Angeles Sharks, 43. Hull tallied both times in the second period.

title: Machinists Delay Strike At T.W.A., Citing Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UPI)  The machinists union temporarily postponed today a strike against Trans World Air lines and negotiators said some progress was being made on working out a new contract.

title: 2d Nuclear Site on Lake Ontario Recommended by State Agency
description: A 1,000acre tract in the Town of Yates on the southern shore of Lake Ontario was des ignated yesterday as suitable for nuclearpower development, the second such Lake Ontario site decided on by the New York State Atomic and Space Development Authority.

title: The Second Generation
description: Two Septembers following Brezh nev's brutal suppression of the lib eral Dubcek Government in Czecho slovakia, novelist Gunter Grass and other leaders of Europe's youthful left met at the Frankfurt Book Fair; there to conduct an in memoriam service of sorts by reading from the works of Czech writers who were being perse cuted under the newly imposed Stalin ist regime.

title: No U.S. Job Losses Found At Multinational Concerns
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19The most exhaustive survey yet made by the Government of the operations of large multination al companies supports a central conclusion of various private surveysthat domestic employ ment and exports of these com panies have continued to grow relatively rapidly despite their foreign investments.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: A story in The Times of Nov. 12 by Robert Lindsey and a Nov. 15 editorial grossly misrepresented my views and those of the Institute for Rapid Transit in what was described as a dispute over safety rules on U.S. railroads.

title: Miss Hoverkamp Bride Of Raymond Prescott
description: ISLIP, L.I., Nov. 19Miss Melissa Sanders Hoverkamp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Kent Hoverkamp of East Islip, was married this afternoon to Raymond Wil liam Prescott, son of Mr. and Mrs. William James Prescott of Brightwaters. The Rev. William Wagner performed the ceremony in St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

title: Violinist, 12, Soloist With Young Peoples Unit
description: Leon Thompson, director of educational activities for the New York Philharmonic, con ducted the Cosmopolitan Young Peoples Symphony Orchestra in the concert it gave Saturday afternoon at Philharmonic Hall.

title: Bunker Meets With Thieu
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 19 (AP)Ambassador Ellsworth Bunker met for 30 minutes to day with President Nguyen Van Thieu, the United States Em bassy announced. They were believed to have discussed the coming round of private peace talks in Paris.

title: North Stars Down Hawks
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 19 (AP) The Minnesota North Stars made the best of only 19 shots on goal tonight and defeated the Chicago Black Hawks, 51. Gary Smith was in the Chicago nets.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: 4 Die as Car Hits Tree on L.I.

title: NADJARI CHECKING JUDGES' RECORDS
description: The state's new anticorrup tion prosecutor disclosed yes terday that he was checking the court records of more than 20 of the city's 130 Su preme Court justices to see if favoritism was being shown to defendants in narcotics and or ganizedcrime cases.

title: Trade Names Come and Go and Now There's  Exxon
description: Popular usage it a leveling brew, defying the ukases of law and the strictures of marketing man.

title: Paper Says President Opposes ValueAdded Tax as a Danger
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) President Nixon has rejected the possibility of a valueadded tax to raise revenue because he feels such a program might break down discipline over Fed eral spending, according to The Washington StarNews.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Quotation of the Day in The Times of Nov. 14 gives the clue to Senator McGovern's defeat. You quote him as having said that the Presi dent may have had his thumb closer to the public pulse than I did. The Senator evidently did not realize that when he took the public pulse with his thumb he was feeling his own pulse. He should have had his finger on the pulse.

title: Parade Broken Up
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 19 (Reuters)British sol diers fired rubber bullets to dis perse stonethrowing Catholic youths tonight after an anti Government march to the city center was turned back by cor dons of riot troops and police men.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: MARLBORO, Nov. 19Fid dler on the Roof, Broadway's recordsetting musical, played to a new kind of Off Broadway audience today250 patients at the state's Marlboro Psychiatric Hospital here in Monmouth County.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Unions, Owners Set Restaurant Talks

title: Unbeaten Team Clinches Title With Rally
description: MIAMI, Nov. 19The Miami Dolphins scored a comeback 2824 victory over the New York Jets today, extending their undefeated string to 10 games and becoming the first team in the National Football League to clinch a division title and thus insure themselves of a playoff berth.

title: Personal Finance: ClosedEnd Funds
description: Millions of people today own shares in investment companies, but if you asked a random sampling of them what kind of fund they own  open or closedend  the chances are that you would get a quizzical look.

title: FASHION TALK
description: The spring fashion show ings are ending on an up beat note, in a freewheeling whirl of colors and patterns. The Missonis, that Italian couple whose clothes have overshadowed Pucci as world wide status symbols, work their wizardry in knits in new ways. Stephen Burrows, the inventive American who sparked a whole school of imaginative design here, has grown more subtle and so phisticated. The new look of the nineteenseventies seems to be taking shape.

title: Theft Grounds 3 Texans' Dream of Air Service
description: Three men from Texas with visions of their own flying service came to the city on Saturday with $30,500 in cash to buy an airplane, but lost $12,500 of it early yesterday the police said, to two of three bewigged young women who took them to a midtown hotel for a party.

title: Nathan M. Ohrbach Dead at 87; Built Stores on Profit in Pennies
description: Nathan M. Obibach, who be gan selling women's coats in a corner of a friend's millinery store in Brooklyn and went on to found and build the Ohr bach's store chain, died here yesterday in the Mary Manning Walsh Home. He was 87 years old and lived in Hampshire House.

title: DilworthLeslie Plays Phoenix by Moevs
description: Right after intermission at his Tully Hall recital yesterday afternoon, Samuel Dilworth Leslie gave the first New York performance of Phoenix, a piece written for him by Rob ert Moevs, a fellow professor at Rutgers University. While there was no program indica tion that it was intended that way, the fiveminute score could stand nicely as a musical portrait of the pianist: It was mildmannered, orderly and musically affable within its own distinctly limited sphere of color and dynamics, and so was Mr. DilworthLeslie's play ing throughout the concert.

title: KISSINGER ARRIVES IN PARIS TO RENEW TALKS WITH HANOI
