description: Joseph Acanfora 3d was grad uated from Pennsylvania State Uni versity last June and went to work teaching earth sciences to eighth graders in Rockville, Md. But he had not been long on the job before he was transferred out of the classroom to the school district's curriculum department.

title: Beth Jacowitz Betrothed
description: EASTON, Pa., Nov. 25 Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Jaco witz have made known the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Beth Lise Jacowitz, to Jonathan E. Glixon, son of Mr. and Mrs. David M. Glixon of Ardsley, N. Y. Miss Jacowitz and her fiance are seniors at Brandeis Univer sity. Her father is president of Concrete Deck Systems, Inc., in Bethlehem. The fu ture bridegroom's father is the editor and art director of the Limited Editions Club in New York.

title: Israel Closes Eichmann File With $10,000 Reward to Argentine Informant
description: HAIFA, Israel, Nov. 25 (AP) Israel has finally closed her file on Adolf Eichmann with the payment of a $10,000 re ward to the informer who told Israeli secret agents where to find the Nazi.

title: Music
description: Friday evening's perform ance by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center at Tully Hall was a beauty, another happy fulfillment of what the society is supposed to he all about.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: There has been much discussion and various proposals have been urged to ease the work of the Supreme Court, which faces a very heavy docket of cases constantly growing in numbers.

title: HanoiBangladesh Ties Set
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Nov. 25 (Agence FrancePresse)  North Vietnam and Bangladesh have decided to extend diplo matic recognition to each other, Foreign Ministry sources said here today.

title: BOLD PLACE WINS HANDICAP BY ROSE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 Splitting the leaders deep in the stretch with a bold move, Bold Place won by a nose in the fourth running of the $23, 325 Mill Race Handicap today before a crowd of 15,497 at Liberty Bell Park.

title: Foreign Stock High in Queens
description: Queens has the highest proportion of foreign stock residents in the 19county tri state metropolitan area, Half of its two million residents were either born in a foreign country or had a foreign born parent.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: INVESTORS and businessmen had special reasons for thanksgiving this year. They had shed their worries of early fall and became increasingly optimistic economic activity and the stock market showed convincing evidence of their inherent strength.

title: KISSINGER AND THO RECESS SESSIONS; MEET AGAIN DEC. 4
description: PARIS, Nov. 25The current series of talks on a ceasefire in Vietnam ended today with the announcement that they would resume on Monday, Dec. 4.

title: Art
description: THE truth is, I have never been able to take reincarnation very seriously as something you can depend on, but as a safety measure I would like to get my appli cation on file to do my en core as Heinrich Schliemann, preferably on a limemachine arrangement by which I could go back and discover the ruins of Troy, as he did, but if that is impossible, then on any conditions imposed by the authorities in charge of personality transfers. I feel that Schliemann could be depended on to take me to an interesting dig or two at any time.

title: Retarded Trained to Fill Jobs
description: MOUNT HOLLY  John was 37 years old and men tally retarded when he first came to the Occupational Training Center of Burlington County.

title: Coins
description: THE New International Numismatic Conven tion, another newcom er to the calendar, lends promise of being one of the year's biggest and most colorful shows in this area. The event will be held in Albert Hall at the Ameri cana Hotel on Dec. 8, 9 and 10.

title: Headliners
description: Call it a victory: In the eighth round, as spectators sipped cocktails in the gaudy theater of a Nevada hotel, Muhammad Ali sent Bob Foster crashing to the canvas. Down and out. But for 30yearold Ali, the handsome, prideful masterboxer, the match last Tuesday left its scar. For the first time in his 41bout professional career, his face had been cut and bruised. In his dressing room after the fight, speaking to his wife on the telephone, he ex plained: Couldn't do more better, girl. Gettin' old.

title: Report or a Mutiny
description: LONDON, Nov. 25 (AP) Britain's Defense Ministry said today it was investigating a re port that a submarine reported in a Norwegian fjord was Rus sian and that there had been a mutiny aboard.

title: JUDGE HERE URGES PRISON REFORMS
description: Comprehensive reform of the nation's prison system has been advocated by Judge Irving R. Kaufman of the United States Court of Appeals for the Sec ond Circuit.

title: Big Growth Predicted In Suffolk Colleges
description: GREENVALE, L.I.A spec tacular growth in Suffolk County's college population is forecast in a report issued last week by the recently formed Nassau Higher Educa tion Consortium.

title: Slayer of Taxi Driver Is Hunted Here
description: An intensive search was on yesterday for a holdup man who shot and killed a 56year old taxicab driver, Friday in South Ozone Park, Queens.

title: Israel Warns Egypt
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 25 (Reuters) Israel asked the United Na tions tonight to tell Egypt not to draw false conclusions from today's military activities on the Golan heights, which she said were Syrian provocations.

title: Mary Wolfe Betrothed
description: BAY VILLAGE, Ohio, Nov. 23Miss Mary Wolfe, a graduate of Marymount Col lege in Tarrytown, N. Y., plans to be married in Jan uary to Philip A. Russotti, a Columbia University grad uate who is in his final year at St. John's Law School in Jamaica, Queens, New York. Mr. and Mrs. William T. Wolfe have announced the engage ment of their daughter to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip A. Russotti of Saddle River, N. J.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Regarding your Nov. 13 editorial Supreme Court Logjam, there is, of course, a great need for all good men to come to the aid of our overworked Supreme Court.

title: Rhode Island Prison Guard Held Hostage but Is Freed
description: CRANSTON, R. I., Nov. 25 (AP)  Inmates at the Adult Correctional Institution, some of them armed with scissors and pipes, held a guard hostage fora short time today, but freed him unharmed after officials agreed to eight demands.

title: Letters To the Travel Editor
description: My husband and I recently vacationed for three weeks on the Caribbean island of St. Maarten. The beaches, bays and lagoons, hills and mountains and other natural features surpassed in beauty all the claims of the travel ads and brochures, and we found a variety of modern hotel and tourist accommoda tions suited to all tastes and needs. However, this is only half of what we saw in St. Maarten. The other face of the island is not so comelyin fact, it is ugly.

title: Hurricane Hunters
description: Flying into the eye of a tropic storm has never seemed an appealing idea to me, and this adventure novel confirms my worst convictions. Onetime commander of a hurricane hunter squadron in the Air Weather Service, the author celebrates the courage of men who fly into force 12 winds in converted cargo planes, to re trieve meteorological data for the rest of us.

title: Foreign Stock in Somerset
description: The 1960's saw a substan tial drop in the proportion of Somerset County resi dents of foreign birth or parentage, Census Bureau figures show.

title: Walker Scores Twice in Final Minute as Bulls Turn Back Hawks, 100 to 99
Music
description: AT the risk of giving support to the horrid charge that the Metro politan Opera is a museum, I wish to urge the company to adopt a new policy of not scrapping a truly distinguishes production once it wears out. Instead of setting a match to it on the Jersey flats, the Met should have it refurbished  or even recre ated, much as a curator would have a great painting or statue cleaned and restored and, above all, displayed for another generation to savor. The Met has one such production in its repertory now, and the present season is reported to be its last. To say it was the finest of the 87 Sir Rudolf Bing introduced in his checkered 22year reign would be scant, drastically qualified praise. To sit back and say nothing while its fate is being sealed would be the rankest in gratitude.

title: Mrs. Ryan Married
description: Mrs. Kathleen O'Driscoll Ryan of Seattle, a social gerontologist, and Warren L. Schnur, executive vice presi dent of Fields Plastics and Chemicals, Inc., in Lodi, N. J., were married here last night in the sanctuary of the So ciety for the Advancement of Judaism by Rabbi Alan W. Miller. The bride, daughter of Mrs. James Ryder of Tacoma, Wash., has worked in pre retirement research and counseling programs spon sored by the University of Washington Seattle Commu nity College and industrial and business concerns. Her husband is a former partner in the law firm of Schnur, Kupferman & Price.

title: The Nation
description: Something had to break.

title: Alice Schwartz Wed to J. S. Levinson
description: ARMONK, N. Y., Nov. 25 The marriage of Miss Alice Joan Schwartz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Schwartz of Great Neck, L. I., and Miami Beach, to James Scott Levinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Levin son of Great Neck, took place here this evening.

title: Through her delicate femininity ran a vein of iron
description: On June 20, 1837 an 18yearold girl, hitherto brought up in strict sec lusion by an anxious mother and a jealous German governess, performed her first official acts as Queen of England. At 6 o'clock that morning, she had heard the news of her uncle King William IV's death from the Archbishop of Canterbury and the Lord Chamberlain. At 9, she had re ceived Lord Melbourne, her Prime Minister, whom she saw (she noted in her diary) of COURSE quite ALONE as I shall always do all my Ministers. At halfpast11, she entered the Red Saloon of Ken sington Palace to hold her earliest Privy Council.

title: LETTERS
description: Dr. Pierre A. Rinfret states that the record of Richard Nixon is one of tax cuts not tax increases. [In Sup port of Nixonomics, Oct. 29.] It would appear to me that this statement is not entirely correct.

title: Fire on ExCunard Queen Led 1st Quarter Ship Losses
description: LONDON, Nov. 25 (Reuters) The sinking or the 82,998 ton former Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth in Hong Kong harbor accounted for more than 25 per cent of the gross tonnage of ships lost throughout the world in the first quarter of this year, according to Lloyd's Register of Shipping.

title: Frankfurt Police Kill Plane Gunman
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Nov. 25 (Reuters)The police today shot to death a middle aged gunman and freed the stewardess he had held hostage for 24 hours aboard a Cana dian airliner at Frankfurt's air port.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25The edi tors of America have a new darling. Is is Prof, Henry Kissinger. He is the biggest thing to hit the wordandpic ture business since Jacqueline Kennedy sailed away to become Mrs. Onassis, Editors cannot give us enough of him.

title: SteelEquipment Famine
description: PITTSBURGH  At a time when industrial activity across the nation is ap proaching boom proportions, the men who sell equipment to steel mills are feeling left out.

title: Heart Transplants Fell Into Disrepute
description: CAPETOWN, South Africa IN December, 1967, the human heart was transplanted for the first time at Groote Schuur Hospital in Capetown, South Africa. Literally within hours of the last suture being tied, the routine of the hospital and the lives of all concerned with the operation were disrupted by an influx of press, television and radio men, unprecedented in the history of the country. They came from every major news net work in the West, bringing with them all the sophisticated technology of contemporary mass communication. Groote Schuur Hospital was totally unprepared, and for several clays some thing close to chaos prevailed. It became, in fact, necessary to seek police intervention to secure the welfare of the recipient and the personal pri vacy of many of the medical and nursing staff.

title: Winter
description: November frays away and December, the last leaf on the calendar, comes to hand. Winter, regardless of the solstice and the almanac, has its foot in the door. Day light will be shortened only another twenty minutes or so before the turn, when the sun begins its long, slow climb back toward the zenith of June. We have already tasted snow, felt the frosty fang.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 25A year ago, on Thanksgiving Eve, a slightly built and rather shy man using the name D. B. Cooper hijacked a Northwest Orient 727 jet liner between Portland. Ore., and Seattle and parachuted out of it with $200,000 in ransom money.

title: Michigan State Vanquishes Northwestern, 2414
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 25 (AP)  Michigan State's junior quarterback, Mark Nie sen, passed for two touchdowns in less than a minute of play today in leading the Spartans to a 2414 victory over North western in a Big Ten Confer ence game.

title: Gardens
description: THE form and color of vegetables and edible fruits are seldom en joyed to their fullest. Why not use them for din ner table arrangements?

title: Toys of Old On View in Bloomfield Library
description: BLOOMFIELD  Comes Christmas time, and the in terest of many people, young and old alike, turns to toys. With this in mind, the His torical Society of Bloomfield has prepared a special holi day exhibit of dolls, games and other playthings; all are geared to bring pleasure to visiting children and nostal gia to their elders.

title: What's So Hot About Heat?
description: IN HIS early films, Andy Warhol investigated the notion that there might be something esthetically interesting about boredom. Well, it's hard to imagine a better piece of corroborating evidence for that view than Heat, the fourth feature film by Warhol disciple Paul Morrissey and the latest ad dition to a canon that began nearly a decade ago with a sixhour study of a man sleep ing. Heat is by far the slickest and most coherent specimen of Warholian cin ema to date; it is also, for me, the least interesting. If it lacks the harshness and distraction of previous War hol Factory productions, it also lacks their sense of ser endipity and thorny life. Without being boring, it's a bore.

title: North Carolina Triumphs
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Nov. 25 (UPI)North Carolina, with Ike Oglesby scoring three touchdowns, crushed East Caro lina, the Southern Conference champion, 42,19, today in a biting cold drizzle.

title: Colleges: A Stress on Quality
description: TRENTONJudging by its latest budget request, the state's college system is pass ing from an adolescence of mushrooming growth into maturity in which the accent will be on quality and scope.

title: Rollyn G. Osterweis Married to Cleric
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 25 Miss Rollyn Gay Osterweis, daughter of Rollin G. Oster weis, professor of history and oratory at Yale University, and Mrs. Osterweis of New Haven, was married here this evening to the Rev. Daniel Kirchbaum of Detroit, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Kirchbaum of Salem, Ohio.

title: Rain Curbs Astronauts
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Nov. 25 (AP)Rain today forced the Apollo 17 astronauts to cancel plans to fly T38 jet planes on proficiency flying runs over south Florida.

title: THUGS RAPE WOMAN, SHOOT HER AND TWO
description: DALLAS, Nov. 25 (AP)Two masked men tricked two men and a woman into opening the door of their motel room early today, raped the woman, shot all three in the head and es caped just before the police ar rived, authorities said.

title: Survey of Students Shows Most Find Value in Literature
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 25 (AP) Literature apparently is turn ing on more high school stu dents than it is turning off, ac cording to a report on a na tional study.

title: AEROBEE ROCKETS GOING STRONG AT 25
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25  The Aerobee family of rockets, a little publicilzed transportation sytem that boosted the first liv ing things into space and helped open new vistas in astronomy, modestly marked its 25th anni versary this week.

title: CHILDREN OFFERED NEW HEALTH CARE
description: ALBANY, Nov. 25A pre ventivecare program that makes available medical exam ination and treatment for chil dren before poor health be comes chronic is under way in New York Stale, according to the Social Services Commis sioner, Abe Lavine.

title: News of Boating
description: Sailing news has a British. accent this week. Still smart ing a bit over placing sec ond last year in the Admiral's Cup series, the North Ameri can Yacht Racing Union took its first step to regain the coveted yachting prize by appointing H. Irving Pratt the chairman of a committee to select next year's threeboat team. The Ad miral's Cup in cludes four races conducted in con junction with Britain's Cowes Week, commencing with a race across the English Chan nel on Aug. 3, followed by two day races in the Solent and finishing with the famous Fastnet Race on Aug. 11.

title: Hugh Moore, Industrialist, Dies; BirthControl Crusader Was 85
description: Hugh Moore, cofounder and former board chairman of the Dixie Cup Company and a wide ly known crusader for world peace and population control, died yesterday at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 85 years old and lived in Easton, Pa.

title: Columbia Loses in Soccer
description: Brown's Bill Frost scored four goals and George Kepner and Robert Gorgone added one apiece to propel the Bruins' soccer team to a 61 victory over Columbia at Baker Field yesterday. Pete Bosanara tal lied the Columbia goal. The victory gave Brown a 52 won lost record in the Ivy League and an 114 mark over all. The defeat left Columbia with an 07 conference mark and an overall record of 410.

title: A funny horror story about falling in love with the wrong people
description: In the five books now available in English by the Argentine novelist Julio Cortazar, we are offered a par ticularly appealing experiment in the subversion and renewal of novelistic form. Readers of Cortzar's remark able Hopscotch (published here in 1966) will remember that several chapters consist of passages from the notebooks of the writer Morelli. In Chapter 62, Morelli imagines a book in which the reader would see life trying to change its key by demon strating its indifference to psycho logical causality. Morelli postulates a human group that thinks it is re acting psychologically in the classic sense of that tired old word, but Which merely represents an instance in that flow of animated matter, in the infinite interactions of what we formerly called desires, sympathies, wills, convictions  [These interac tions would appear] as something irreducible to all reason and all de scription: foreign occupying forces, advancing in the quest of their free dom of the city; a quest superior to ourselves as individuals and one which uses us for its own ends

title: Judge Dismisses 2 Counts For Trial of Michell Magee
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 25 (AP)A judge this week re duced the list of charges against Ruchell Magee, whose trial is set to start Monday in the 1970 Marin County court house shooting case.

title: Letters:
description: Your article, Summing Up: What Travel Abroad Meant to 5 Young Amer icans (Travel section, Oct. 8) had my head bobbing slowly up and down, as well as violently from side to side. My husband and I (ages 45 and 40 respec tively) have recently returned from a year spent traveling by van in 27 coun tries in Western and Eastern Europe (including the Soviet Union), North Africa (including Algeria), and the Mid dle East nations of Israel and Egypt.

title: New &Novel
description: In a Sicilian village, the local doctor is about to operate on a man who has been shot by an irate husband. Suddenly, the local Mafia enforcer appears with his mistress, who is about to go into labor. What would Hippocrates have done? If il dottore attends to the wounded man, the enforcer will kill him. If he ministers to the pregnant woman, the man will die.

title: The Nation
description: The Labor Department gave Amer icans some reverse holiday cheer last week. To wit: Consumer prices during October rose threetenths of 1 per cent. Which meant that prices are continuing to increase at a rate some what above the President's antiinfla tion goal.

title: Let's Just Say it's My Inning
description: RIGHT after a particularly rainy Saturday matinee, actor Paul Sorvino, one of the stars of That Championship Season, took off his shoes, reclined on a couch in his dressing room at the Booth Theater and prepared to be interviewed. He was dressed for the occasion in a voluminous blue and white silk robe and navy socks.

title: The Nation
description: CHICAGO  It seemed appropriate that, even as the jury retired to be gin considering its verdict in the Chi cago conspiracy case in February, 1970, Federal Judge Julius J. Hoffman began meting out contempt sentences to the defendants and their lawyers for their behavior in the courtroom: For embracing the Rev. Ralph Aber nathy, six months. For yelling at a witness, Do you believe a word of that? three months. For calling the judge a disgrace to the Jews, five days, For calling him Mister, six months, For laughing, seven days, 14 days, one day, six months .

title: Germany
description: BONNChancellor Willy Brandt was talking last week of a new political center in West Germany. His Govern ment coalition had just won a com fortable parliamentary majority in the federal elections, and the Chancellor's reaction, some observers thought, re flected a refreshing willingness to change and a new quality of self assurance.

title: Soviet Lofts Cosmos 537 After a 22Day Hiatus
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 25After an unusual 22day hiatus in its space program, the Soviet Un ion launched another of its Cosmos series of unmanned satellites today.

title: Revolution of Rights
description: WASHINGTONOur system of con stitutional implementation is unique. Our Constitution has survived because it states ethical principles which rep resent the ultimate aspirations of man, So did the Ten Commandments. But the Ten Commandments would have been relatively ineffective with out the institutions of religion. It was these institutions that, directly and through their ripple effect, resulted in the constant evolutionary redefini tion and expansion of the meaning of the great Commandments.

title: the traveler's world
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev.It is 180 miles as a penniless crow might fly from the roulette tables of Las Vegas to the middle of the Grand Canyon of the Colorado, but to the tourist who rides in one of the ninepassenger planes of Scenic Airlines, the distance is 220 miles. The difference that makes this a thriller of a flight is that extra 40 miles, 40 miles of twisting and bank ing over and into the Grand Canyon, of flying with the canyon walls standing off both wingtips high above the plane, of looking up to the rim and straight down a mile or more onto the trickle of muddy water that is the Colorado River. The difference is also a new appreciation of the Grand Canyon, much more moving than staring down into from either the North or South Rim, al though nothing has come along in the last few million years to displace the Canyon seen from the ground as one of the world's wonders.

title: SINGAPORE LEADER THREATENS PRESS
description: SINGAPORE, Nov. 25 (UPI)  Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew has warned that he will be the judge of what news is fit to print in Singapore.

title: Heavens Open Wider On Plea From Earth
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Nov. 25 (UPI)The Rev. Michael Gannon, a Catholic priest, gave the invocation before today's Louisiana StateFlor ida football game, and added after a pause:

title: Issel, Gilmore Spark Colonels In 115111 Defeat of Cougars
Searches of Air Travelers Stir Fears for Civil Rights
description: The growing number of air port arrests of air travelers on drug and other charges, as a byproduct of searches to dis cover potential hijackers, has stirred a rising clamor among civil libertarians.

title: Strike Threat Clouds Baseball Trade Winds
description: HONOLULU, Nov. 25  Critical labor trouble, per haps even another strike, was building up on the baseball scene today as the owners and managers of the 24 ma jorleague teams gathered for their annual business meet ings.

title: White House Aide Silent On Report About Colson
description: Ronald L. Ziegler, the White House press secretary, refused yesterday to comment directly on a published report in The Washington Post that Charles W. Colson planned to leave his post as Special Counsel to President Nixon.

title: Montessori School Grows in Fort Lee
description: FORT LEEA newcomer to the growing number of Montessoriinspired schools in New Jersey is the Went worth School, which was opened here in September. It is situated in a converted church (circa 1888) at 178 Washington Avenue.

title: Music Mailbag:
description: Having just returned from a few days of theatergoing in New York, I was inter ested to read Harold Schon berg's piece on amplification in the theater. He did, how ever, neglect to point out one positive aspect of amplified sound: its capacity to drown out the audience.

title: State Loses a Round in Pornography Fight
description: TRENTONWhen a Fed eral court overturned New Jersey's new law against pornography last week, most members of the nowdefunct State Commission to Study Obscenity and Depravity in Public Media might well have said: We told you so.

title: Art
description: ONE of the most inter esting aspects of the current art scene, and yet one of the least remarked upon, Is the vir tual collapse of that absolute sense of art history that monomaniacal belief in a sin gle idea dictated by histori cal circumstanceswhich has governed so many schools of modern art. This devotion to an absolute has been re sponsible for a great deal of what we most admire in the history of modern art. Artists as different as Mon drian and Duchamp would be unthinkable without it. Yet there was always an ele ment of myth at the heart of this devotion to the ab solute, There was always a voluntary surrender of intel ligence in regard to the sheer plurality of styles that had proved themselves artistical ly viable. The very concept of a museum specializing in modern art implied, without ever openly acknowledging, an ecumenical attitude to ward the many separate, contradictory absolutes con tending for attention and in fluence.

title: Meany Released by Hospital After Stay for Observation
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Nov. 25 (UPI)George Meany was re leased from a hospital in Tarry town, N. Y., this morning after two days of observation for chest pains.

title: C.A.B.
description: When an airline wants to begin a new service, it submits a com prehensive brief listing in precise fashion all the elements of the proposed service: where it's going, how much it costs, how many miles are covered, what the amen ities en route will be, what ground service will be involved and all other details. If the C.A.B. judges the proposal favorably, then the airline's program does in effect become a C.A.B. regulation.

title: Letters To the Travel Editor
description: Violet Richardson Lowe's story of horses, trains and moving (To the Thinking Horse in 1910, It Was O Temporal O Mores!, Travel Section, Oct. 15) is a happy report of days gone by. I wonder what a report 50 years from now will say. Let us hope our grandchildren's memories of jet planes and moon shots will sustain them.

title: FloodControl Plan Gains in Senate
description: TRENTONRepublican leg islative leaders reported here this weekend that Governor Cahill's controversial proposal for state control over the de velopment and land use of New Jersey's lowlying flood prone regions now appears to command substantial sup port in the Senate. They said that the measure could clear the Legislature as early as tomorrow's fourth meeting of the postelection session.

title: LETTERS
description: As Michael C. Jensen indi cates in his article Musical Chairs in Business and Gov ernment (Nov. 12), quite specific statutes28 United States Code, Sections 207 and 208deal with the ob vious conflicts of interest po tentially arising from such movement.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  In late September in Washington, Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz unveiled at the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund a thoughtful, fairly detailed set of United States proposals for world monetary reform.

title: Labor Party Wins Upset In New Zealand Election
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Sunday, Nov. 26In an unex pected victory, the Labor party swept into office in New Zea land's general election yester day, ousting the National party Government that had held power for the last 12 years.

title: World News Briefs
description: MANILA, Nov. 25  The Philippine Government to day announced the arrest of an American Vietnam war vet eran in connection with what it called a rightist conspiracy involving top Philippine politi cians to assassinate President Ferdinand E. Marcos and stage a coup d'etat.

title: PENN BOWS, 31171
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25  Dartmouth won the Ivy League football championship with a thrilling 3117 uphill victory over Pennsylvania on the final day of the league season today at Franklin Field.

title: A Brahmin In Brooklyn Performs Hindu Rites
description: Om sahana vavatu, Saha nau bhunuktu, Sah viryam karavahu vahi, Om Shanti, Shanti, Shanti.

title: U.S. Cuts MailOrder Cigarette Trade
description: Steppedup antismuggling ef forts have all but stopped the illegal flow of cigarettes through the mail from North Carolina to taxevading custom ers in other stales, Federal and New York State authorities said yesterday.

title: Ellen Rouse Fiancee of Winthrop Brown Conrad Jr.
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 25  Mrs. Willard G. Rouse has an nounced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ellen Bailey Rouse, to Winthrop Brown Conrad Jr., son of Mr. Conrad of Rosemont, Pa., and the late Dolores Millard Conrad.

title: The New York Public Library
description: From an international as well as from a national point of view the New York Public Library is a unique institution. Nowhere else in the world does there exist a modern, free pub lic library which serves both as an important library for the scholar and, in its main circu lation department and its nu merous branches throughout the city, for the popular read er. This unique institution has a unique history, which is of profound interest not only to the library specialist, but also to anyone interested in the growth of New York City into the most important cultural center of the Western world, and therefore also for the stu dent of American culture in general.

title: White Pupils' Rolls Drop As Families Flee the Cities
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 25White enrollment in the public schools of this bustling, boastful oil town has declined 20 per cent in the last two years, reflect ing a nationwide white flight to the suburbs that has in creased dramatically in the last three or four years.

title: Norwegians Decide Submarine Is Real and Drop Depth Charges
description: OSLO, Norway, Nov. 25 The Norwegian Government is convinced that the unidentified object that has eluded an air and sea search in the Sogne Fjord north of Bergen for the last two weeks is a foreign submarine.

title: Miss Kraus Fiancee Of Bruce Wintroub
description: Mr. and Mrs. Louis Kraus of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marya Kraus, to Dr. Bruce Wintroub, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Win troub of Omaha. The wedding is planned for Jan. 20 at the National Arts Club here.

title: Peggy Robbins Engaged
description: VALLEY STREAM, L. I., Nov. 25The engagement of Miss Peggy Robbins to Ray Jacobson of Belleville, Mich., son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Jacobson of Las Vegas, Nev., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Harvey A. Robbins.

title: MEDAL HAILS CITY AND FEDERAL HALL
description: Federal Hall National Memo rial, on the site where George Washington was inaugurated in 1789, and the city's role in the American Revolutionary War era are commemorated in a medal issued by the New York City Bicentennial Corporation.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The State Attorney General, Louis J. Lefkowitz, called to Mayor Lindsay's attention a law that would permit the city and other municipalities to beef up law enforcement forces by hiring retired policemen and other retired public officers.

title: New &Novel
description: A reader of fiction must have a dj vu feeling when he comes upon another story of an advertising man who chucks it all to Write. And yetthere are fresh things in The Great Canadian Novel that help to justify this familiar scaffold. Among them, a strong whiff of regional air and an authentic warty protagonist.

title: Penn State Gets 4 SecondPeriod Touchdowns on Way to 4927 Rout of Pitt
SHOP TALK
description: GARWOODLeather coats have crossed the age and personalitytype lines, at least here in Garwood. It is impossible to say how many people in this Union County borough wear leather coats, but the chances are that the total is more than in any other town of 5,200 people in the same latitude.

title: BUS LINES STRUCK IN CONNECTICUT
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 25 Drivers and mechanics of the state's largest bus company went on strike today, halting service for 110,000 daily pas sengers in Hartford, New Haven and Stamford.

title: Anthropology Or Fiction?
description: Paul Riesman's review of Carlos Castaneda's three books (The Teachings of Don Juan, A Separate Reality, and Journey to Ixtlan), while a re spectful and illuminating com mentary, left me more bewil dered than ever.

title: GUIDE IS PUBLISHED ON OILSOAKED BIRDS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) The American Petroleum In stitute has published a pam phlet on the rescue and care of water birds trapped by oil spills.

title: Horse Show News
description: The 1973 edition of the National Horse Show  the 90th anniversary of the event will be held in Madison Square Garden Oct. 30 through Nov. 6. Woody Gate house, the National's presi dent, made the announcement yesterday. He added that work already is under wayon special events to celebrate the milestone. The first National was held in the orig inal Madison Square Garden in 1883, the same year the Metropolitan Opera started and the Brook lyn Bridge was opened. The first Garden, in fact, was built for the National.

title: Huntington Looks at Its Past
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I.  Life here about 1900, which in chided winter carnivals and bobsled races down main street, will be recreated to morrow at a slide show using old photographs.

title: TENNESSEE BEATS KENTUCKY, 11 TO 7
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 25 (UPI)Ricky Towsend kicked a 46yard field goal, his long est of the year, and a tail back, Haskel Stanback, ran 30 yards for a touchdown today to give Tennessee a 177 tri umph over Kentucky.

title: Turnpike Is Ready For Snow and Ice
description: NEW BRUNSWICKThe 118milelong New Jersey Turnpike is ready to meet the snow and ice challenges of late autumn and winter.

title: ANTICRIME DRIVE FACING REVISION
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25  The Federal Government's mul tibillion dollar effort to make American streets safe from crime may undergo a thorough revision next year, Congres sional and Administration sources indicate.

title: Syria Calls for Fighting
description: BEIRUT, Nov. 25 (Reuters) The statecontrolled Damas cus radio today made an indi rect call to Arab countries to resume hostilities against Israel, saying that fighting was the only means of recovering oc cupied Arab territory.

title: Gallup Poll Backs President's Method Of Ending the War
description: A nationwide postelection Gallup Poll indicates that Americans approve of the way President Nixon is proceeding to bring the Vietnam war to an end. The poll shows almost as great a margin as Mr. Nixon's election victory over Senator George McGovern.

title: Gardens
description: AFLASH ofthe cardinal's red wings  the almosttame chicka dees who lose their fear of man and feed from his hand  even jays with a raucous call sounded from a magnificent cloak of blue and white feathers  the peculiar scratching and peck ing of mourning doves hunt ing on the ground for grain  these are some of the backyard pleasures treas ured by those who feed birds in winter.

title: HOLY CROSS BEATS UCONN TEAM, 2010
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 25 (AP)A freshman back, Dave Lyle, caught a 24yard touch down pass that put Holy Cross ahead en route to a 2010 uphill football victory over Connecti cut today.

title: Armstrong Purdue Star
description: WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind., Nov. 25 (AP)Otis Armstrong closed out his spectacular career at Purdue today, becoming the greatest rusher in Big Ten his tory as the Boilermakers defeat ed Indiana, 427, in the 48th renewal of the Old Oaken Bucket football rivalry.

title: Rain Curbs Astronauts
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Nov. 25 )AP)Rain today forced the Apollo 17 astronauts to cancel plans to fly T38 jet planes on proficiency runs over south Florida.

title: JOHNSON TAKES BOWLING HONORS
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 25 (AP) Don Johnson of Akron, Ohio, the defender, closed with a flurry of strikes today to cap ture first place and $12,000 in the $85,000 Brunswick world open bowling tournament.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Nov. 12 letter by Prof. Sheldon Penman needs some clarification.

title: DOUG BENTLEY, 56, HOCKEY STAR, DIES
description: SASKATOON, Saskatchewan, Nov. 25 (AP)Doug Bentley, a member of the National Hockey League's Hall of Fame, died in is hospital last night. He was 56 years old and had under gone two operations for cancer.

title: Martha Driscoll Fiancee of G. S. Karnas
description: EASTCHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 25Dr. Francis G. Driscoll, superintendent of schools in Eastchester, and Mrs. Driscoll have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Martha Anne Driscoll, to Gerald Stanley Karnas. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley W. Karnas of Colonia, N. J.

title: Yanks Obtain Matty Alou From A's in Gardner Deal
description: HONOLULU, Nov. 25 The New York Yankees beat every body else to the draw in base ball's winter trading market today when they acquired Matty Alou from the Oakland A's for Rob Gardner and a player who will be named next week.

title: WALL STREET
description: The American Stock Ex change is bulging with a wealth of new listings and Paul Kolton, the exchange's chairman, thinks it has some thing to do with the state of the overthecounter market.

title: ZaireChina Ties Announced
description: KINSHASA. Zaire. Nov. 23 (AP)President Mobuto Sese Seko announced today the establishment of diplomatic re lations with China. Zaire is the former Belgian Congo.

title: NASSAU TO EXPAND CHECKLESS RELIEF
description: Nassau County is planning to expand soon its pioneering checkless welfare pilot pro jectstarted 10 months ago in Rockville Centre and Lynbrook to Hempstead and West Hempstead.

title: Art
description: MICHAEL SNOW is an avantgardist's avant gardist. A 43year old Canadian who moved home recently after a nineyear slay in New York, he has the kind of fond un derground reputation that comes with doing uptothe minute work for a long time without ever becoming an in timidating public success. Snow is a doyen of Concep tual Art and a veteran work er in several media, including electronic music, photogra phy, video and, especially, film. Lately he has received a degree of public promi nence at least partly thanks to his nationality.

title: Music Mailbag:
description: I realize that Harold Schonberg is a music critic and makes his living and reputation listening to mu sical eventsoften theatri cally musical events. He may listen at the Met, where hardly anything theatrical ever happens. He may even listen at the N.Y.C. Opera, where he must struggle a little to contend with a more dramatic approach to opera as theater. On Broadway forget it! At Two Gentle men of Verona, poor Schon berg had to listen to a per formance that did not have pure sound.

title: NIXON GAIN FOUND FROM HIS TV ADS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 Evidence that Democratic vot ers who switched to President Nixon during the 1972 cam paign were held in their new allegiance by his television commercials has been devel oped by two political scientists at Syracuse University.

title: DUBLIN I.R.A. CHIEF GETS PRISON TERM
description: DUBLIN, Nov. 25Sean MacStiofain, leader of the mili tant Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army, was sentenced tonight to six months' imprisonment for be longing to an illegal organiza tion.

title: Risky Alibhai Pays Off
description: LINCOLN, R.I., Nov. 25 (AP) Risky Alibhai survived an in terconference claim and won the $7,500 Narragansett Bay Handicap today at Lincoln Downs.

title: Expos Schedule 10 Games For New Spring Quarters
description: MONTREAL (Canadian Press) The Montreal Expos will play 21 exhibition games against other major league teams next spring, all in Florida.

title: Syria Shells Israeli Bases In Occupied Golan Heights
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 25 Syrian artillery shelled two Israeli positions in the Golan heights today, a military com muniqu broadcast by the Da mascus radio said.

title: Brenda Badura Wed
description: YONKERS, Nov. 25Miss Brenda E. Badura and Peter J. Dowd, who are with Hill and Knowlton, a New York public relations consulting firm, were married here to day in St. John's Evangelical Lutheran Church by the Rev. F. William Wild. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl O. Badura and Mrs. Dowd's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Jerome A. Dowd of New York. Mrs. Dowd is an ex ecutive secretary and her husband is a vice president with Hill and Knowlton.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: The pilot of the doomed airliner was apparently trou bled by sudden distracting chest pains from a heart dis order. A violent argument about a threatened airline strike could have aggravated the pilot's heart condition. A number of facetiously ab usive scribblings, some crit ical of the pilot, were found on a cockpit pad after the crash. They were not in the handwriting of any of the plane's crew members.

title: U.S. STANDS ALONE ON ARMS PARLEY
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25The United States alone abstained this week when 111 countries voted in the Gen eral Assembly's Political Com mittee to examine prospects for a world disarmament con ference.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  You enter 1737 Cambridge Street, a nondescript brick building on the fringe of the Harvard University campus, through a basementlevel glass door. Up a creaky, dirty elevator to the fourth floor and down a drab, dimly lit corridor to Room 401, where a makeshift gummed label on the door identifies the occupant: Prof. Kenneth J. Arrow.

title: Chess:Opponents Who Refuse to Die Can Ruin the BestLaid Plans
description: One of the most ticklish problems over the board is coping with an opponent's sudden switch in strategy. This is likely to occur just when you have sowed the seeds of victory by very strong play and are looking forward to a methodical, re lentlessperhaps even a bril liantharvest.

title: Tribalism in Belgium
description: The fall of Premier Gaston Eyslcens' Belgian Govern ment after ten months in office provides another grim reminder that tribalism and ethnic fragmentation are in ascendancy in nearly every section of our world. It was the old feud between Flemings and Walloons that upended Mr. Eyslcens as it had so many of his prede cessors.

title: New &Novel
description: Regenesis is a compelling tour de force that traces con verging psychiatric and spiri tual crises. The novel follows an Albuquerque schoolteacher named Bob out of electroshock and then back into the vortex of profound depression. Neither chemotherapy nor analysis seem to retard Bob's disinte gration and his ballooning anx ieties, beautifully pinpointed in the novel.

title: Dr. R. E. Peterson Weds Miss Benny
description: Miss Beverly Anne Benny, daughter of Mrs. Catherine Benny of New York and John Benny of Valley Cottage, N. Y., was married here yes terday afternoon to Dr. Ralph E. Peterson, director of the division of endocrinology at the New York Hospital Cornell Medical Center. The Rev. Dr. Walter Donald Kring performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Unitarian Church of All Souls.

title: Barbara E. Cohen Bride in Brooklyn
description: Miss Barbara Ellen Cohen, daughter of Dr. Clifford Cohen of Brooklyn and the late Mrs. Shirley Lipton Cohen, was married last night to William Waldorf, son of Mr. and Mrs. Adrian Waldorf of Port Washington, L. I., and Miami. Rabbi Abraham B. Hecht performed the ceremony at Congrega tion Shaare Zion in Brook lyn.

title: The working class is still with us
description: Sooner or later, history imposes it self upon those who interpret it. Not so long ago, reliable authority assured us that class society had ended, that the working class was fundamentally transformed. The radicalism of the 1960's was not produced by that class and not directly concerned with its emancipation. The American working class of the past decade was not, of course, very radical. A compulsive revival of ethnicity, eager votes for Wallace and reluctant ones for Hum phrey, and violence in hard hats sug gested that a new epoch had indeed begun. No black humorist could have invented that placard brandished in the Wall Street demonstration in sup port of Nixon's Cambodian invasion, God Bless the Establishment. To suggest that Marxist notions were rel evant to recent American politics seemed as absued.

title: U.C.L.A. Five Wins, 9453
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 25 (AP) Bill Walton led the Univer sity of California, Los Angeles, to a 9453 seasonopening bas ketball victory over Wisconsin tonight for the Bruins' 46th tri umph in a row.

title: VA. TECH TRIUMPHS AS STROCK EXCELS
ILLINOIS SET BACK BY IOWA, 15 TO 14
description: IOWA CITY, Iowa, Nov. 25 (UPI)A freshman quarter back, Butch Caldwell, ran for a 2point conversion with 4 minutes 10 seconds left in the game today to lead underdog Iowa to a 1514 Big Ten upset over Illinois.

title: Arthur Levy Is Fiance Of Judith Anne Granet
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 25Mr. and Mrs. Mur ray Granet have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Anne Granet, to Arthur Levy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mac Levy of Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Con Ed Sees Emergency On Steam During Winter
description: ALBANY, Nov. 25 (UPI) The Public Service Commission warned today that emergency measures to conserve steam might be necessary in Manhat tan this winter when the tem perature falls below 30 degrees.The agency announced ap proval of Consolidated Edison's steamconservation plan for its 2,555 steam customers in Man hattan, Generally, the program seeks to hold down steam use during the peak hours of 6 to 9 A.M. in the institutions and apartment buildings with steams service.

title: The Turnbull Sagas: People of Character Form Plots
description: MAPLEWOOD  In the trade, it is said that Agnes Sligh Turnbull's publisher does not have to lift a finger to sell at least 20,000 copies of each of her novels. The reason is that Mrs. Turnbull has a large and devoted fol lowing that has made her one of the country's most popular novelists.

title: New York
description: Is the Democratic party in New York City up for sale to Republican Governor Rockefeller? The question, hovering in the wings for some time, was being debated with increased in terest last week following a comment by the Governor that the idea of a fusion candidate for Mayor had very real and interesting possibilities.

title: Enemy Military Leaders, to Show Respect, Bow to a King at a Fair in Laos
description: VIENTAINE, Laos, Nov. 25  There were furls wheels and Charlie Chaplin movies and horse races and canacn dancers and a onelegged American stunt pilot to entertain both royalty and revolutionaries at the That Luang Fair.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: ROME, Nov. 25 (AP)The Vatican said today it had no knowledge of assistance giv en by the Roman Catholic Church to Bormann to es cape to Latin America, The Daily Express said the Vati can had provided him with protection.

title: ECOLOGY SUIT LOST BY INDIAN BUREAU
description: DENVER, Nov. 25  A Fed eral appeals court here has ruled that the Bureau of Indian Affairs violated the law when it approved a subdivision devel opment in Pueblo Indian land 4 miles from Santa Fe. N.M.

title: Undefeated Penn Keeps Ivy League Soccer Title
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 (UPI)  The University of Pennsylvania capped its un beaten soccer season today with a 50 victory over Dart mouth to capture its second straight Ivy League crown.

title: Pontiac Busing Starts Quietly, but Problems Remain
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Nov. 25 We had the quietest school opening since '63, said John Perdue, the racial trouble shoot er for Pontiac's school system, adding that there had been so little tension it's even hard for us to understand.

title: 13YearOld Brooklyn Girl Is Slain While BabySitting
description: A 13yearold Brooklyn girl was stabbed to death yesterday while babysitting for a 3year old child, according to the po lice, who said the girl may also have been raped.

title: H.E.W. Office Here Reducing HealthCenter Budgets for 1973
description: A local office of the Depart ment of Health, Education, and Welfare has been cutting grants to community health centers in anticipation of cuts in Federal funding.

title: Twin Sons to Carmels
description: Twin sons were born Nov. 15 to Dr. and Mrs. Peter W. Carmel of New York in the Harkness Pavilion. Mrs. Car mel, the former Miss Ann Louise Erdmann, is a security analyst with L. F. Rothschild & Co. Her husband is assist ant attending neurosurgeon at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center and assistant professor of neurosurgery at the Columbia College of Phy sicians and Surgeons. Their children have been named David Alan and Jason Brant.

title: DR. HOUGHTON HOLLIDAY
description: Dr. Houghton Holliday, asso ciate dean of the School of Dental and Oral Surgery of Co lumbia University from 1936 to 1945, died Friday in Oakhurst, Calif. His age was 83.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25President Nixon is reorganizing the Federal Gov ernment again, and when Presidents retreat to Camp David and start draw ing little squares on yellow pads, you'd better put on your specs.

title: Canada's $5Billion Decision: Gas Pipeline?
description: TORONTO  Despite a groundswell of opposition, Canadian financiers and busi nessmen are forging ahead with plans to build a 2,507 mile pipeline to bring natural gas from Alaska and the Ca nadian Arctic to the United States and eastern Canada.

title: Johnson to Coach U.S. Six
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 25 (AP)Bob Johnson, coach at the University of Wisconsin, has been named as coach of a United States collegiate hockey team that will play in the World Cup tournament against Czechoslovakia, the Soviet Union and Canada. The tourna ment runs Dec. 2729 at Col orado Springs and Dec. 30Jan. 2 home.

title: Swiss Move to Aid FrenchSpeaking Minority Called Too Little, Too Late
description: GENEVA, Nov. 25The pros pects for a solution of Switzer land's one political problem appeared no brighter today de spite a new offical move to ward placating the Frenchlan guage minority in the over whelmingly Germanspeaking canton of Bern.

title: HEAVY B52 RAIDS ON NORTH REDUCED
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sun day, Nov. 26  United States B52 bombers yesterday main tained the intensive level of aerial bombardment of North Vietnam that began on Monday the day the peace talks re sumed in Paris.

title: RigidAirship Plan Advances
description: RIO GRANDEThe Laws ?? Corporation expects to start pouring concrete in January for a rigidairship hangar and office complex at Cape May County Airport. Robert A. Laws, Hiairman the company, formerly known as Airship Advertising, said the Southern Industrial Cor poration of Pleasantville would put up the buildings at a cost of almost $1million.

title: John Mayo Wins Fifth Term
description: John T. Maya has been elect ed to a fifth oneyear term as president of the 3,200member Transit Patrolmen Benevolent Association, union officials an nounced yesterday. The final tally of the mail ballots also gave reelection victories to Victory Augi, first vice vest dent; Floyd Holloway, second vice president; Joseph Cirrin cione, executive secretary; Jo seph Karney, financial secre tary; Amadeo Fasolino, record ing secretary, and Edward Burke, treasurer.

title: Air America Plane Lost
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 25 (UPI)A transport operated by Air America, which is support ed by the Central Intelligence Agency, was shot down by Communist antiaircraft fire, killing two American pilots and a Laotian, an Air America spokesman said today.

title: Two Panels Begin Inquiry Tomorrow Into Campus Deaths
description: BATON ROUGE, Nov. 25 (AP)Two separate investigat ing committees, one set up by Louisiana's attorney general, the other by blacks skeptical of the official inquiry, prepared today for a first look Monday at the three weeks of campus turmoil which preceded the deaths om two Southern Uni versity students.

title: JUDGE HERE URGES PRISON REFORMS
description: Comprehensive reform of the nation's prison system has been advocated by Judge Irving R. Kaufman of the United States Court of Appeals for the Sec ond Circuit.

title: Political Shifts Threaten Growth of Atomic Power
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 The atomic power industry, already the center of scien tific and environmental con troversy, now faces a new series of problems that threaten to cut further into its rate of expansion.

title: Strike Ends in La Paz But Curbs Continue
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 25 (AP)Tension eased here to day as thousands of workers ended a crippling twoday strike in return for the e lease of 18 arrested compan ions and a promise of wage negotiations.

title: Letters:
description: I mightily enjoyed your feature on that great hobo, Steamtrain Maury Graham. Hoboes deserve more credit than they get. They will share whatever they have with the less fortunate. They accept other hoboes without regard to race, creed, or color. They are ecolog ically sound since they do not add to pollution when they travel and because they recycle lots of things that other wise would be regarded as trash. They are individualists who believe in an oc casional day's work for an occasional day's pay.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Do not winter mulch unless the ground is frozen.  Watch indoor house plants kept near windows on cold evenings; too cool temperatures can retard proper growth. Sow oats for cats to discourage their nibbling on house plants.  Keep up cleanup.

title: World News Briefs
description: CAIRO, Nov. 25  A former Egyptian diplomat and Army officer has received a 10year prison term on charges of espionage, Cairo newspapers re ported today.

title: F.P.C. Aide to Be Professor
description: COLUMBIA. Mo., Nov. 25 (AP)Pinkney C. Walker, who has resigned as vice chairman of the Federal Power Commis sion, will return to the Univer sity of Missouri as a professor of economics, school officials said yesterday.

title: Futurist demiurge
description: If you mention Futurism to people, you will, in a surprising percentage of cases, get the same answer. Oh yes, they will say, Marinetti, as if that somehow explained every thing. Except for some of the most important manifestos and a few short plays, however, the writings of Filip po Tommaso Marinetti (18761944) poet, playwright, novelist, tract and essay writer, creator and demi urge of Futurismhave not, until now, been translated into English. Regardless of the selections involved, the mere fact that this collection makes a number of Marinetti's writ ings available in English marks it as a literary and historical contribu tion of the first order.

title: Zanzibar Reports Arrests
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Nov. 25 (UPI)President Aboud Jumbe of Zanzibar announced this week that policemen had arrested an unspecified number of persons on Pemba, Zanzi bar's sister island, on charges of trying to smuggle 48 million pounds of cloves worth $14 million from the island, Convic tion of clovesmuggling carries the death penally in Zanzibar.

title: Belgian Seeks New Cabinet
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 25 (Agence FrancePresse)  Joseph de Saeger, Public Works Minister in the outgoing Belgian cabinet, today agreed to try to form a new cabinet, Mr. de Saeger, 61 years old, is a Flemish member of the Social Christian party He undertook the task three days after Dr. Gaston Eyskens' coalition cabinet resigned be cause of an inability to cope with the tension between Bel gium's Frenchspeaking and Flemishspeaking communities.

title: World News Briefs
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 25The Indian Government has banned flights by the United States Mil itary Airlift Command except for those given special permis sion, an American Embassy spokesman here said today.

title: Black English
description: The point missed by Arthur Harris (in his parody of Hy man Kaplan English) is that immigrants to America learn English as another language hence the exsent American born blacks learn Black English as their original language. The two experiences are not com parable.

title: Ellen M. Firth Fiancee of Alan S. Russell
description: SALISBURY, Conn., Nov. 25The engagement of Miss Ellen Margaret Firth to Alan Stanley Russell, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Agar Russell of New York and Salisbury, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Leslie Firth of Boston and Salisbury.

title: COED IN CONNECTICUT RAPED BY BURGLARS
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 25 (AP) An 18yearold Trinity College coed was raped yesterday after she awakened during a robbery in her dormitory suite, the po lice said.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 25The Los Angeles International Airport has com bined television and radio in an experi ment designed to ease access to the airport by automobile.

title: SOME YOUNG CHINESE TERMED BOURGEOIS
description: PEKING, Nov. 25 (Agence FrancePresse)Certain youths in the countryside are easily influenced by bourgeois no tions, the Communist party newspaper Jenmin Jih Pao has charged.

title: 900 Miles on Chinese Train: Sheer Luxury for $22
description: PEKING, Nov. 25As Ex press No. 13 left Peking, the loudspeaker in our compart ment burst into life with a stirring rendition of Sailing Seas Depends on the Helms man. Making Revolution De pends on Mao Tsetung Thought.

title: Galbraith has seen China's futureand it works
description: Earlier this year the Federation of American Scientists arranged with the Chinese Academy of Sciences and the Chinese Scientific and Technical Association for a delegation of American econo mists to visit China for a look at the Chinese economy. The visit took place in September. As the current President of the American Economic Association I was the nominal chairman of the group. Completing it were my two predecessors in office, Prof. James Tobin of Yale, for many years a leader in macroeconomic theory and policy and a member of President Kennedy's Council of Economic Advisers, and Prof. Wassily Leontief of Harvard and inputoutput fame. From the 8th to the 22nd of September, the Chinese provided us with education of exceptional intensity on their economyseminars and discussion, visits to indus trial establishments, department stores, markets, schools, universities, hospitals, communes. The article following is the overall view of the economy which emerged, for me, from this cram course. The views are mine; at every point, however, I have benefited from the questions of my colleagues on the tripand, of course, from the answers of our Chinese hosts.

title: FAYE HENLE DIES; FINANCIAL WRITER
description: Faye Henle, a columnist, broadcaster and lecturer, who translated financial and busi ness information for consumer use, died Friday of leukemia in Mount Sinai Hospital. She lived at 49 East 96th Street and in Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: Run to Glory, $18.80, Wins By Five Lengths in Sprint
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 25 (AP)Bobby Breen booted Run to Glory home five lengths on top today to take the $10,000 Old Hickory Handicap at the Fair Grounds.

title: INQUIRY TO STUDY KITTY HAWK RIOT
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 25A House Armed Services subcom mittee, winding up four days of inquiry here into the racial troubles aboard the aircraft carrier Constellation, recessed its hearing today and decided to return here Dec. 5 to investi gate a midOctober riot aboard the carrier Kitty Hawk.

title: Letters To the Travel Editor
description: People (including Paul Friedlander) are always comparing Amtrak trains with the superb service in Europe. But I would like to report that our experi ence on a crack European train last summer was far from pleasant. The

title: A Jerseyan Offers a Gallery of Indians
description: LITTLE FALLSWhat did the original American Indian really look like? The stereo type is of a brave, in feath ered headdress and buck skins, stalking through the forest. But in reality, not only each tribe but also each man had his own distinctive mode of dress, especially the chiefs.

title: Spain Victor in Golf
description: LA ROMANA, Dominican Re public, Nov. 25 (UPI)  Jose Gancedo and Roman Taya of Spain combined for a 71 and 276 total today to defeat Chile and win the Americas Cup golf championship. Colombia was a distant third at 285.

title: BOLIVIAN TENSION TIED TO THE PESO
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 24 a 60 per cent currency devalu ation, the first here in 14 years, brought on the latest tension in South America's most vola tile republic.

title: Letters To the Travel Editor
description: Jack, the Park Avenue travel agent (A Day in the Life of a Travel Agent, by David Alpern, Travel Section, Oct. 29), obviously didn't do his homework: He describes Bruges as a lovely area

title: Adami Put in Solitary
description: LAREDO, Tex., Nov. 25 (UPI) Kenneth Adami, a 60yearold rancher being held as a suspect in the murders of five Mexican aliens, was put in solitary con finement today because of threats on his life from Mexican bellow inmates.

title: Luther Clark Fiance Of Camille Jackson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Archie M. Jackson of Jamaica, Queens, have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Camille Calleen Jackson to Luther T. Clark, son of Mrs. Princetta Mc Cant of Pal metta, Fla. The wedding is planned for June at the Springfield Gardens United Methodist Church, of which Mr. Jackson is a trustee.

title: News of Dogs
description: The Maryland Kennel Club, a pioneer on the show cir cuit, reaches a milestone to day when it holds its 60th allbreed fixture at the Fifth Regiment Armory in Balti more. It has drawn 1,921 dogs.

title: What's New in the Camera World
description: APEIRON Workshops, Inc., Box 551, Millerton, N.Y. 12546, will con duct a winter program similar to the summer work shops previously offered, ex cept that they will include a much more extended pro gram. Students will live and work together at the center for a minimum of one month and a maximum of four months, starting Jan. 10. Room, board (three meals a day), use of darkrooms and all chemicals, as well as a series of four, oneday visits from photographers of inter est to each group are included in the monthly fee of $425. The center is located on a large farm two hours north of New York City and has a main house, a six  bed room, twobath dormitory (two to a room), and a win terized barn with six dark rooms. Applicants are re quested to submit a small portfolio and a brief resume. For more information call (914) 7893507, or write to the address above.

title: After 66 Years, Hackensack May Get New Lake
description: HACKENSACK  After 66 years of talk, a plan to create a clean, freshwater lake from a stretch of the brackish and polluted Hack ensack River appears to be on the way toward becoming a reality.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In your Nov. 12 editorial you re viewed Mr. Nixon's interview with The Washington StarNews at some length and expressed astonishment at the authoritarian implication in Mr. Nixon's view that the average Ameri can is just like the child in the family. You will recall that in the same inter view projecting the next four years Mr. Nixon also called for future be havior of responsibility and self discipline on the part of these average Americans.

title: Treasury Agency Bars Checkoff Box On 1972 Tax Form
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UPI)  The Treasury Depart ment has decided not to pro vide a space on personal in come tax forms for taxpayers to check off $1 for Presidential campaign contributions to the political party of their choice.

title: Mourning Becomes Electra Doesn't Work
description: LITTLE as we wish to, I think we must take a good deep breath and face the fact that Mourning Becomes Electra doesn't work. Because of our just admiration for Eugene O'Neill and his effort, we keep postponing the deed, telling ourselves each time we see the play that there is another production coming, sometime, somewhere, that will catch up all the awesome overtones of Aeschylus's Oresteia and shower them like brimstone over the Civil War figures and the Freudian diagnoses O'Neill made use of in rearranging the Greek myth. Then shall have contemporary insight and an cient terror bound together in one great shiver, a true bloodline established be tween the dark inexplicable furies of the past and the ex plicable, but even darker, neurotic crises of the present.

title: CLEMSON DEFEATS SOUTH CAROLINA, 76
description: CLEMSON, S.C. Nov. 25 (AP)  Jimmy Williamson batted down a pass for an attempted 2point conversion late in the fourth quarter today that pre served a 76 Clemson football victory over rival South Caro lina.

title: World News Briefs
description: ATHENS, Nov. 25The com mander of the American air craft carrier Forrestal accom panied two of his sailors to court last night and later said that the Greek courts should have no jurisdiction over United States servicemen.

title: Elizabeth O. Johnson Plans Bridal
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 25 Miss Elizabeth Owens John son plans to he married May 26 to Jerry Joseph Fotherin gill of Washington, an ana lyst with the Central Intelli gence Agency.

title: Local Time Is Victor
description: The Saturday night feature, an open handicap onemile pace for a gross purse of $15,000, wound up with Local Time the victor in 2:01 4/5. He paid $14.60 for $2 in the top spot.

title: Interracial Business Unit Opens in Brooklyn Office
description: It is a long way between Harlem and BedfordStuy vesantnot in miles, but in worlds.

title: Train Bomb Found in Time
description: ROME, Nov. 25 (AP)The VeniceRome overnight express arrived 75 minutes late this morning after an anonymous phone call led to the discovery of a time bomb in a passenger coach. A few minutes before the train was to leave Venice, the police rushed the shoe box sized package from the train and dropped it beside a bridge where it exploded. Bombs have been found along rail lines in Italy twice in the past month.

title: Robert Polk Leidy Is Fiance Of Nicole von Gerloff Redfield
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 25  Mr. and Mrs. Story Close Redfield have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nicole von Gerloff Redfield, to Rob ert Polk Leidy, son of Mrs, Carter R. Leidy and the late Mr. Leidy.

title: Susan Swiger Engaged
description: RYE, N. Y., Nov. 25Mr. and Mrs. David A. Swiger have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Susan Wolfe Swiger, to Michael Eric Luftman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter A. Luft man. Both families are of Rye. Miss Swiger, an alumna of George Washington Uni versity, and her fianc, an alumnus of Dickinson Col lege, are planning a spring wedding.

title: Television
description: ON this week's episode, the third in 13 weekly installments of The Roads to Freedom, Daniel re duces Marcelle to one fat, stink ing, pregnant woman, the aging Lola sniffs cocaine as her love affair with the young Boris begins to founder, Ivich gets drunk at a nightclub and slashes the palm of her hand with a penknife, and Mathieu plunges the same knife through his own hand.

title: Ohio State in Bowl
description: Ohio State defeated Michi gan, 1411, yesterday and gained the Big Ten berth in the Rose Bowl against South ern California, the Pacific Eight champions. Dartmouth won the Ivy League cham pionship by beating Penn, 3117. Details in Section 5.

title: Personal Approach Is Success At College
description: Last Sunday Kurt R. Sch meller, president of Queens borough Community College, discovered the power of the personal invitation.

title: Sports Car Program Slated For Youth on Friday Night
description: Henryk Szamota, the Govern or of Area One of the Sports Car Club of America has ar ranged a Sports Car Night at Bishop Reilly High School, 6500 Francis Lewis Boulevard, Bayside, Queens for Friday night.

title: A Film to Feel Superior To
description: TERENCE YOUNG'S The Valachi Papers, the story of Mafia soldier Joseph Valachi adapt ed by Stephen Geller from Peter Maas's bestselling book, is one of those rare, really rotten movies that is never quite as boring as it should be, a movie whose idiocies might even lift the spirits. Almost anyone can feel superior to it. The per formances are uniformly secondrate and the dialogue isin the idiom of the fiction it represents  a veritable treasure trove of unintention ally comic lines: the senti ments expressed never man age to fit the situations that give rise to them. They're al ways too big or too small, as if they'd been stitched to gether in Hong Kong.

title: Julie Humphreys Is Bay State Bride
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass., Nov. 25Miss Julie de Frees Hum phreys, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Humphreys of Tucson, Ariz., was mar ried here this afternoon to Dr. Mihnea Andre Vasu, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mircea Vasu of New York. The Rev. Thomas Fuller performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church.

title: The Guest Word
description: Is it O that this too too solid flesh would melt, or O that this too too sullied flesh would melt? The question has been debated in scholarly circles ever since John Dover Wilson published his argument supporting the latter reading in The Times Literary Supplement of May 16, 1918. Solid, of course, seems right enough. Hamlet is calling, after all, for a dissolution of fleshly substance. Yet sullied, as Wilson rightly emphasizes, sheds a fresh light upon Hamlet's char acter: it provides a motive for his brooding melancholy. The complexities of Wilson's argumentwhich considers a third possibility: O that this too too sallied flesh are too intricate to recount here, but every modern editor of Shakespeare, whether he agrees with Wil son or not, must, at last, come to grips with his views in preparing a new edi tion of the play.

title: Guess Who Coming to Dinner Now?
description: LEE REMICK walks into the rehearsal room. And there's Joan Col lins. And Don Knotts in a far corner. Buzz Kulik, who made Brian's Song which won Emmies last year, is directing them. But where's  and the question is an swered by a rumble of laugh ter from behind a pillar on the left; there's Orson Welles, shaking with mirth, sitting massively in a kingsize wheelchair. A wheelchair? Yes, but only for the role he has in The Man Who Came to Dinner, to be pre sented by Hallmark Hall of Fame, Wednesday night at 8:30 on NBC.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: READING Lindsay Pat terson's review of Sounder, I found myself agreeing with his questions about the film's authenticity. Yes, the Morgan family should have been able to scavenge a living off the land. I, too, kept looking for the scrawny chickens peck ing in the yard, the penned up meat hog fattening for fall, and Cicely Tyson's turnip patch or hill of sweet pota toes out back.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: In his article on Sounder, Lindsay Patterson chastises the black establishment for its wholehearted endorsement of this beautiful movie. So what if the times in a Depres sion  scarred Louisiana are different in this movie from what Patterson remembers them to be? Could it not be that some Black folks had things a little different from what he thinks it was like?

title: Article 8  No Title
description: AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 25 (UPI)Paul Metallo ran for two touchdowns, one of 73 yards, today as Massachusetts upset Boston College, 287. Piel Pennington threw two touch down passes for the Yankee Conference champions, who built a 280 halftime lead.

title: Hospital Provides
description: HACKENSACK  Hacken sack Hospital has taken over visiting nursing care services in five Hudson County towns that were left without a lo cal homenursing agency last Sept. 30.

title: LOUIS F. TIMMERMAN, BANKER, WAR HERO
description: Louis Felix Timmerman, a former vice president of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, now the Manu facturers Hanover Trust Com pany, died Wednesday at his home in Brookville, L. I. He was 76 years old and had a home also at 239 East 61st Street.

title: Opera: Die Walkure Returns to Met
description: What with the hazards of scheduling, Wagner's Die Walkre received its first seasonal performance Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera, coming after the Siegfried of last week. Perhaps it is just as well. This Herbert von Karajan version is a production of surpassing unloveliness, with all the clichs and bad traits of the Bayreuth style and few of the good ones.

title: FARRELL SETS BACK TOTTENVILLE BY 227
description: Monsignor Farrell, trailing 76 at halftime, turned back Tottenville, 227, yesterday to win the Staten Island High School Football League title, Farrell finished with an 81 wonlost record. Tottenville was 63.

title: Soviet Scientist Is Here To Address Law Schools
description: Valery N. Chalidze, a founder in the Soviet Union of the Com mittee on Human Rights, ar rived here on Thanksgiving Day for a monthlong visit that will include a series of lectures be fore the law facilities of Georgetown and New York Universities.

title: Notes: Cable Cars Or Cattle Cars?
description: SAN FRANCISCO'S celebrated cable cars are rolling along toward their 100th anniversary and the ques tion has been raised whether they shouldn't be accorded more respect in their old age. The cars, which began their long uphill climb in 1873, have been designated a National Historic Landmark, but according to some ob servers they're being treated like cat tle cars.

title: New York
description: Aristotle Onassis was reduced to eating a hot dog. It came with mus tard, a bottle of beer, coffee and dessert and cost $10 at the 21 Club last Wednesday.

title: Iowa Agrees to Search For a Confederate Flag
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 25 (UPI)Iowa will try to determine if it has a Con federate flag taken from an Alabama infantry regiment during the Civil War, an aide to Gov. Robert D. Ray said today.

title: Bypassed and Burned Up
description: In dozens of corporate suites this year a painful scenario will be acted out.

title: Leslie Jordan Plans Bridal
description: LITTLETON. Colo., Nov. 25 Mr. and Mrs. Noel L. Jor dan have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Leslie Jordan, to Lieut. Comdr. Jonathan A. Cohen, Navy Medical Corps, son of Mrs. Irvin J. Cohen of Shef field, Mass., and New York and the late Mr. Cohen.

title: 350,000 Students In Research Groups Reported by Nader
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) Some 350,000 students at more than 50 schools in 13 states have enrolled in public interest research groups, Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, said today.

title: Essex Is Expanding Program To Bar Delinquency by Girls
description: ORANGE  A twoanda halfyearold program forpre venting delinquency among girls in this city is being extended to other Essex Coun ty communities, with the aid of a $100,000 grant from a state agency.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY NOW SEEN STABLE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) Social Security benefits have increased more than 30 per cent in the last three years, in the biggest advance in history, but specialists say that there may never again be such an increase.

title: Kathleen A. Schneider Betrothed to David O. Pratt
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Nov. 25Mr. and Mrs. Edwin F. Schneider have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathleen Anne Schneider, to David Offutt Pratt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richardson Pratt Jr. of Cold Spring Harbor. A June wed ding is planned.

title: The Arias Of G. & S. Linger On In Bergen
description: RIDGEWOOD  When a Gilbert and Sullivan opera company was formed here in 1937, Iolanthe was the first production and there were 16 men and 16 women in the chorus. And now, 35 years later, the Ridgewood Gilbert and Sullivan Opera Company is presenting, as its anniversary production, Iolanthe, and the ?? chorus will number 32, just as it did in 1937.

title: POVERTY UNCLEAR AS A SEX FACTOR
description: An analysis of sexual experi ence among unmarried young women in the United States indicates that poverty by itself does not account for the fact that black women are more likely than whites to have pre marital sexual intercourse in their teen years.

title: Movies
description: WELL, Tuesday, I really thought you had it made this time: a juicy starring role in a movie based on a prestige best sell er, conspicuous prerelease publicity, a fancy East Side booking, Here it was at last, I had hopedthe bigtime rec ognition that you've worked so hard to avoid, what with turning down scripts like Bonnie and Clyde and Bob & Carol & Ted & Alice because you knew they'd be smash hits and you didn't want any part of them.

title: Missing Bronx Girl Is Found Unharmed With Mother of 2
description: A 2yearold Bronx girl ta ken from a welfare station Wednesday noon was found unharmed yesterday afternoon and her alleged abductor was taken into custody, according to the police.

title: LETTERS
description: H. Erich Heinemann's ar ticle Revolution Ahead For U.S. Savings (Nov. 12), con cerning the transformation of mutual savings and loan as sociations to capital stock companies, fails to bring up a simple, short method of solving the funds problem in the nation's savings and loans.

title: The sexual revolution and the young
description: The gradual liberalizing of sexual codes, ethics and standards of appropriate behaviorwhat some have called the new morality or the sexual revolutionhas, to many observers, transformed young people into wholly promiscuous adolescents. Too often overlooked, however, are those young persons for whom the new morality causes a spe cial sort of insecurity and hurt.

title: Israeli Who Seeks Nazis Is Skeptical on Bormann
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 25 (Reu ters)Tuvia Friedman, who played a major part in track ing down Adolf Eichmann and other Nazi war criminals, ex pressed skepticism today at a report that Hitler's long sought deputy, Martin Bor mann, had been found alive in Latin America.

title: NIXONS VISIT HERE HITS FESTIVE NOTE
