But they treated it variously as the best hope for the city, a Balkanizing threat, a vehicle for beneficial patronage and a bad substitute for guts on the part of elected leaders.

title: SMITH STRUGGLES TO BEAT CONNORS
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Nov. 23 (UPI)Stan Smith overcame a nervous first set tonight and beat Jim Connors in the open ing match of the $50,000 Grand Prix masters tennis tourna ment.

title: Police Deny Trapping Graft Suspects
description: The top supervisor of the Police Department's anticorrup tion drive acknowledged yes terday that the department had been using what he described as simulated situations to catch crooked policemen.

title: Israel Preserving Animals of Bible
description: ELATH, Israel, Nov. 17  Two thousand years ago vast herds of longhorned ante lopes and gazelle and the nimble ibex roamed the rocky wastes of the Negev. In all some 120 species are mentioned in the Old Testa ment but many have dis appeared.

title: Maazel Conducts a Noble Verdi Requiem
description: One of the last largescale works that George Szell con ducted in New York with his Cleveland Orchestra was the Verdi Requiem. Perhaps it was not entirely by coinci dence that Lorin Maazel, making his first New York appearance as the new music director of the Cleveland Or chestra, should select the same work. Which he did, on Monday night in Carnegie Hall.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Nov. 28 (AP)  Edward B. McConnell of Prince ton announced today that he was resigning July 1 as admin istrative director of the New Jersey courts.

title: ExPolice Inspector's Conviction Overturned by Appeal Division
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court here re versed the contempt convic tion of Thomas C. Renaghan, former assistant chief inspec for of the city's Police De partment.

title: Mrs. Fenwick Named Jersey Consumer Chief
description: NEWARK, Nov. 25  As semblyman Millicent H. Fenwick, Republican of Somerset, was named by Governor Cahill today to be director of the State Division of Consumer Affairs.

title: RULING IS PUT OFF ON C.B.S. NEWSMEN
description: The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court yesterday put off at least until next Mon day a decision on whether news men at the Columbia Broadcast ing System should be forced to honor picket lines set up by a striking technicians' union.

title: Two Found Dead in Bathtub
description: The bodies of a man and a woman were found yesterday in the bathtub of an apart ment in East Harlem. The police estimated that they had been dead about a week. The dead man was identified as Felipe Sabater, 40 years old, of 250 East 124th Street, near Second Avenue, where the fullyclothed bodies were found. The woman was not identified.

title: About Pro Football
description: Late in the 1966 season, when the Giants were com piling their poorest record (one victory, 12 losses, one tie), Allie Sherman went on a wellpublicized inspection trip of the two best college quarterbacks. Steve Spurrier of Florida and Bob Griese of Purdue, with the idea of drafting one. In stead, the Giants traded four high draft choices to Minnesota for Fran Tarkenton; the San Francisco 49ers drafted Spurrier third in the first round (after Bubba Smith by Baltimore and Clint Jones by Minnesota), and the Miami Dolphins took Griese as the fourth player selected.

title: $148,050 Is Paid for Filly In Auction at Newmarket
description: NEWMARKET, England, Nov. 28 (Agence FrancePresse) A record figure of 63,000, ap proximately $148,050 for a filly at public auction was paid at Tattersall's Newmarket Decem ber sales today for the Aga Khan's unraced 3yearold Aliya.

title: Imprisoned I.R.A. Chief Breaks His 10Day Fast With a Cup of Tea
description: DUBLIN, Nov. 28The Irish Government announced tonight that Scan MacStiofain, jailed chief of the Irish Republican. Army's militant wing, had bro ken his 10day fast with a cup of tea.

title: Books of The Times
description: At the heart of most women's movement literaturebeneath the simplistic rhetoric that attempts to define women, as a po tential revolutionary force, what Joan Didion has called the attempted inven tion of women as a class  is the dogged attempt to carve an image with which women might identify in a humane and egalitarian man ner. Not surpris ingly, even with the effort, some women's libera tion tracts have stumbled into triv ial iconoclasm or sulk into that Manichean abyss where the equa tion simply reads: men=evil; wom en=good. Nor is it astonishing that dissenters have attacked those tracts with invec tive zeal, in some instances (Midge Decter's The New Chastity, for instance) taking reactionary stances and arguing that the movement is not a liberating force at all, but a repressive response to the burden of re sponsibly choosing among the numerous roles already open to women. The dialectic, then, goes on; and Into the fray, now, comes Ingrid Bengis's Combat in the Erogenous Zone.

title: CITY PLANS DRIVE ON HOTEL CRIME
description: Top city officials, headed by Deputy Mayor Edward K. Ham ilton and Human Resources Ad ministrator Jule M. Sugarman, will announce today a major drive against singleroomoccu pancy hotels ridden by crime.

title: Vandenburg Out at El Paso
description: El. PASO, Tex., Nov. 28 (UPI)The University of Texas at El Paso dismissed the track coach, Wayne Vandenhurg, a highpowered recruiter. The reason for the school's action was not made public. Vanden burg said he would make a statements in the near future. It is known that there had been a clash in personalities between Vandenburg and the athletic director, George Mc Carty.

title: Administration Pressure on Rates Cited
description: The First National City Bank, which a year ago pioneered the concept of a floating prime interest rate on business loans, announced yesterday that it was modifying the formula that it uses to calculate this key interest rate.

title: Rider Safety Program Set By Maker of Motorcycles
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28An educational program to reduce accidents among beginning motorcycle riders was an pounced today by the Yamaha International Corporation, a major manufacturer of motor cycles.

title: Key Gauge of Economy Up in October After Drop
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  The Government's composite index of leading indicators of the economy resumed its rise in October after a dip in September, the Commerce De partment reported today.

title: 3 PONTIAC YOUTHS HELD IN SHOOTING
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Nov. 28 Two black students were ar rested and another turned him self in today in connection with the shooting and wound ing of five students at the Cen tral High School here yester day.

title: East Europeans Discuss Trade
description: American business was in effect invited yesterday to explore some of the lesser known charms of Eastern Europe, such as profit.

title: Paint Up 4 Cents, Boy Writes, U.S. Sues
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 Prodded by a 13yearold Long Island boy who builds and launches model rockets, the Justice Department today accused the manufacturer of illegally raising the price of a paint used by the boy.

title: Park Plaza East
description: New York is the place where dreams go monumentally awry. The New York City Educational Construction Fund had the fine idea of getting money for badly needed schools by building schools with offices, stores or apart ments above them. Now plans for the fund's most ambi tious undertaking to datePark Plaza East, on what is known as the Asphalt Site at York Avenue from 90th to 92d Streetsis being bitterly attacked by its neighbors. Its opponents are calling it another Forest Hills.

title: Theater: A Stein Tribute at the Judson
description: The Judson Poets Theater is 10 years old, a fact of artistic importance not just to off Off Broadway but to the American theater. During its first decade Judson has presented some 130 shows even a current program is unsure of the exact numbers and not all of them, but many of the best of them, have been by At Carmines. It is Carmines's relentless productivity, his romance with the musical theater, that gives Judson its life spirit.

title: Fino to Leave Supreme Court And Return to Politics in Bronxi
description: Supreme Court Justice Paul A. Fino, the former Bronx County Republican leader, an nounced yesterday that he was returning to active politics and that one of his chief aims would be to oust Senator John D. Calandra, the present G.O.P. leader.

title: Vote Recount Is Called Off In Mrs. Hicks's District
description: BOSTON, Nov. 28 (AP)A recount of the Nov. 7 general election in Massachusetts' Ninth Congressional District the race in which Representa tive Louise Day Hicks lost her seathas been officially called off.

title: BERME IS CHARGED WITH FAVORITISM
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame was accused yesterday of fiscal mismanagement and political favoritism by a Repub lican City Councilman from State Island.

title: ARTHUR C. WEIMAR
description: SUN CENTER CITY, Fla., Nov. 28Arthur C. Weimar, a former partner in Dominick & Dominick, Inc., member of the New York and other stock ex changes, died yesterday in the Bradenton Hospital. He was 79 years old.

title: Laird Says Draft Will Call Fewer Than 10,000 in '73
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird declared today that few er than 10,000 young men would be drafted in the first half of next year before draft authority expires and the armed forces shift to an allvolunteer basis on July 1.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I read your Nov. 19 news article reporting that the last election cost over $400 million.

title: Squires Stem Rally, Beat Tarns, 120115, For Third Straight
BUS CRISIS STALLED IN HARTFORD COURT
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 28 (AP) Connecticut's bus crisis stalled in the courtroom today, and bus service remained cut off to 150,000 daily passengers in six of the state's major metropol itan areas.

title: 11,000 Pupils Stay Out as East Harlem School Boycott Widens
description: The boycott of East Harlem schools broadened yesterday as local efforts failed to resolve the complaints of protesting parents over school conditions in the largely Puerto Rican and black area.

title: Popkin Freedin a Surprise As U.S. Jury Is Dismissed
description: BOSTON, Nov. 28Prof. Samuel L. Popkin of Harvard was released from jail today after the Federal Government, in a surprise move, dismissed the grand jury investigating the distribution of the Pen tagon papers.

title: AMEX SALES SHIFT SEEN BY KOLTON
description: Paul Bolton, chairman of the American Stock Exchange, dis closed yesterday that a survey of 25 member firms indicated that the small individual in vestor was gradually withdraw ing from the stock market and that the brokerage business was becoming increasingly con centrated in a smaller number of firms.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (Reuters)The Federal Na tional Mortgage Association said today it had issued $36.6million in fourmonth commitments to buy Gov ernmentbacked home mortgages as a result of its latest auction. The average yield was 7.702 per cent against 7.723 per cent at the previous auction.

title: 42 on Jet Die in Soviet
description: At least 42 people were killed when a Japanese jet liner crashed shortly after taking off from the Moscow airport last evening. Fifteen survivors were taken to Mos cow hospitals. Page 13.

title: RICHARDSON TO BE DEFENSE CHIEF, WEINBERGER SECRETARY OF H. E. W. AND ROY ASH DIRECTOR OF BUDGET
description: THURMONT, Md., Nov. 28 President Nixon began re shuffling his Cabinet today by nominating Elliot L. Richard son to be Secretary of Defense and Caspar W. Weinberger to succeed Mr. Richardson as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: Four Arrested in Brooklyn On FoodStamp Purchases
description: The United States Depart ment of Agriculture announced yesterday the arrest of four Brooklyn men in a crackdown on the illegal purchase of Fed eral food stamps.

title: Mandate for Change
description: President Nixon's Camp David observations on the meaning of his reelection may have been too cursory to bear much weight, but such significance as they have is encouraging. He has repudiated the widespread inter pretation that his sweeping victory represented a national mandate to stand still and preserve the status quo. Mr. Nixon's own view, as set forth to reporters Monday, is that the country was saying it wanted him to continue to provide changein domestic policy as well as foreign.

title: Maidman Discovers Sex Shows Still Operating at His Properties
description: Irving Maidman, one of the largest realestate operators in midtown, found yesterday that several of his properties along West 42d Street that were sup posed to be free of sex theaters and film shows were not.

title: Bridge: Problems Faced by Defense In a Qualifying Competition
description: Those who rely on the old maxim that recommends leading up to weakness would have no chance to find the best defense on the dia gramed deal. But even play ers with a more open minded approach to the problems of defense would not find it easy to see the necessity to lead up to strength.

title: Notes on People
description: Nearly 10 years ago Nikita S. Khrushchev, then Soviet Premier, met Ernst Neizvest ny, a modernist. Russian artist, and berated his work publicly. The late Premier said Mr. Neizvestny's art was fit only to cover urinals with, that your prospects are nil and that one work looked as if it had been painted with a donkey's tail. After that, Mr. Neizvestny's work was virtually banned from public view in the So viet Union.

title: Rap Brown Codefendant Is Said To Have Told of 2 Who Escaped
description: A police detective testified yesterday that one of H. Rap Brown's codefendants once told him that a total of six men planned and carried out the robbery of a West 86th Street bar last fall that ended in a shootout with the police. Only Brown and three others are charged with robbery and at tempted murder.

title: Macy Net Up 16% as Sales Rise 9.1%
description: R. H. Macy & Co., Inc., the New York area's largest re tailer and operator of stores across the country, reported yesterday to its stockholders that its net earnings in the first fiscal quarter ended Oct. 28 were 16 per cent higher than in the corresponding pe riod a year earlier. Sales rose 9.1 per cent, Donald B. Smiley, chairman and chief executive officer, said at the annual meeting.

title: CONSUMERS UNION SCORES DRUG LAWS
description: The Consumers Union, after a fiveyear study of drugs, has recommended the immediate repeal of all Federal and state laws against marijuana, the es tablishment of experimental heroin maintenance programs and a nationwide ban on cig arette and alcohol advertising.

title: Business Briefs
description: A new $65million vitamin C plantthe largest in the worldwas dedicated yesterday in Belvidere, N. J., by HoffmannLa Roche, Inc. Computerzed and automated, the new facility utilizes a continuousflow process and in full operation has an annual capacity of 10,000 tons. Produc tion at that level would exceed present United States domestic consumption of bulk vitamin Cascorbic acid which amounts to about 7,000 tons a year.

title: Proposed Bridge on Sound Passes Environment Test
description: The Federal Government has approved and adopted a report indicating that the proposed Westchester CountyLong Island bridge would have limited ad verse effect on the human and natural environment of the metropolitan area.

title: Personalities: Ski Ball Is a Family Affair
description: See if you can guess which family will dominate tonight's Ski Ball at the Waldorf Astoria, the sixth annual af fair to raise funds for the United States Ski Team. Ex pected to attend are Barbara Ann Cochran, Susan Corrock, Bob Cochran, Sandra Poulsen, Lindy Cochran, Scott Berry, Marilyn Cochran, Dave Cur rier, Mickey Cochran, Jim Miller, Ginny Cochran and Earl Hanson.

title: Roy Lawrence Ash
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 Roy Lawrence Ash, who was named today by President Nixon as director of the Office of Management and Budget, commented on his new job by stressing the essentiality that any struc ture have built into it re sponsiveness to Presidential direction and accountability for what it is responsible for.

title: RUMANIA BAFFLES EAST BLOC ALLIES
description: BUDAPEST, Nov. 28  Ru mania's defiant role at Helsinki, where she has disrupted pre paratory talks for a European security conference by demand ing safeguards for small na tions, is causing considerable confusion and embarrassment among her Communist allies.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Nov. 28Patrol man Dominick Masi stood in front of a police van watching 300 demonstrators picketing the Kawaida Towers construction site this morning, occasionally saying hello or nodding to some of the marchers.

title: 58 ON PLANE DIE IN MOSCOW CRASH
description: MOSCOW, Wednesday, Nov. 29A Japanese airliner crashed last evening shortly after take off from Moscow's airport, and 58 of the 75 passengers were reported killed.

title: Huck Finn Put on Film In Soviet
description: MOSCOWSometime last summer, as an unusual drought scared the fields in the southern Ukraine, an Af rican geology student from Nigeria and an 11yearold flaxenhaired Moscow school boy were floating down the broad Dnieper River on a raft.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: While his egghead conservative com rade from the Nutmeg State, William Buckley, concedes it was a hollow victory, Lars Hedstrom's Nov. 23 let ter claims a landslide victory for a list of piously stated ideals.

title: JIMMY LYTELL, 67, BANDLEADER, DIES
description: RINGS POINT, L. I. Nov. 28 Jimmy Lytell, a wellknown bandleader and clarinetist of the jazz age and a prominent figure in radio, died Sunday after a long illness at his home here on Dock Lane. He was 67 years old.

title: Market Place: C.P.A.'s: Profit And Objectivity
description: Will investors in landde velopment companies be bet ter served in the future under accounting rules being put in final form after three years of deliberations by a commit tee of the American Institute of Certified Public Account ants?

title: INDIAN HEAD SET FOR DIVESTITURES
description: Indian Head, Inc., a diversi fied company in textiles, glass, metal and automotive products, plans to divest itself of mar ginally profitable operations, Richard J. Powers, chairman, and president, said yesterday.

title: Paik Excels in an AllRavel Program
description: A program covering all of Ravel's solo piano music has builtin hazards. It is doubt ful if such outstanding inter preters of these works as Walter Gieseking and Robert Casadesus would have at tempted such a recital, But Kun Woo Paik did, in Tully Hall on Monday night. The Korean artist gave the pro gram as part of his prize for winning the Walter W. Naumhurg Foundation Award last year.

title: AdCarrying Litter Baskets, First of of 60,000 Here, Set Up in Times Sq.
description: The city began installing 25 new concrete litter bas kets in the Times Square area yesterday in what En vironmental Protection Ad ministrator Jerome Kretch mer has said he hopes will be the first step in putting 60,000 such containers all over town.

title: About Pro Football
description: Late in the 1966 season, when the Giants were com piling their poorest record (one victory, 12 losses, one tie), Allie Sherman went on a wellpublicized inspection trip of the two best college quarterbacks, Steve Spurrier of Florida and Bob Griese of Purdue, with the idea of drafting one. In stead, the Giants traded four high draft choices to Minnesota for Fran Tarkenton; the San Francisco 49ers drafted Spurrier third in the first round (after Bubba Smith by Baltimore and Clint Jones by Minnesota), and the Miami Dolphins took Griese as the fourth player selected.

title: Dying Laughing
description: Beauty, as a concept, is meaningless without ugliness; goodness without evil. Each opposite is necessary for the existence of its companion, yet it is remarkable with what blindness we persist in shrinking from ugliness and evil as though they could or should not exist.

title: Mars: Cousin or Brother?
description: Ever since telescopes were invented people have won dered to what extent Mars resembles Earth. Now, for the first time, the existence of a reasonably comprehen sive picture of Mars provides a basis for comparison. It shows many prominent features of a type, or on a scale, unknown on this planet.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Nov. 28 (AP) The Campbell Soup Company and the Mobil Oil Company were fined $800 each for recent violations of airpollution con trols, the New Jersey Depart ment of Environmental Protec tion announced today.

title: French Argue Death Penalty Anew as 2 Are Guillotined
description: PARIS, Nov. 28Claude Buffet and Roger Bontems were guillotined in the cold, dark blanket of early morn ing Paris today, the first men executed in France in more than three and a half years. Their deaths at Sant Prison have stirred new debate over capital punishment.

title: WASHINGTON
description: The one predictable thing about Richard Nixon is that he is unpredict able. The man loves a surprise. Who, for example, could have guessed that his first major decision after winning a spectacular Middle America elec tion victory would be to appoint three Harvard men to his new secondterm Cabinet?

title: Marcos Says He Consulted God on MartialLaw Issue
description: MANILA, Nov. 28 (UPI) President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today he had decided to place the Philippines under martial law after consulting God and receiving several signs from Him to act.

title: Dance: Taylor Favorites
description: The Paul Taylor Dance Company, which opened a weeklong run at the Brook lyn Academy of Music last night, has brought back two old favorites in Mr. Taylor's repertory as well as two po tential new favorites that were local premieres.

title: UNION SAYS PLEA WENT TO MITCHELL
description: Officers of a union repre senting employes of the Immi gration and Naturalization Service said yesterday that former Attorney General John N. Mitchell and the head of the New York office of the Federal Bureau of Investiga tion were among the officials to whom they had complained of widespread corruption in the service.

title: Court Will Rehear Desegregation Suit From Chattanooga
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 28 (AP)  The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit said today that it would con duct an extraordinary rehearing of arguments concerning a court  ordered desegregation plan for the Chattanooga, Tenn., public schools.

title: Bank Bond Bid $5.5Million in Error
description: The city yesterday sold al most $700million of notes the largest amount it has ever borrowedin a financing that saw a bidding blunder that could have cost the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company $5.5 million.

title: ROMNEY SEES FIGHT ON REORGANIZATION
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 28 (UPI) George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Develop ment, praised President Nixon's new federalism today but pre dicted that Congress and spe cial interests would oppose it.

title: Racing Board Head Quits
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 28 (UPI) The Illinois Racing Board chair man, Alexander MacAthur re signed today after board mem bes voted to grant harness rac ing and thoroughbred racing dates to Balmoral Park, in which a principal stockholder is william S. Miller, who is under the Iillinois harness act, which forbids granting a license to a person under indictment.

title: Alexandra Churchill Wed in Italy
description: Miss Alexandra Churchill, daughter of Mrs. James L. Farley of Cornish, N.H., and Creighton Churchill of New York and Portland, Me., was married Monday to Massimo PabisTicci. The civil cere mony was performed in Florence, Italy, where the bride is associated with Casellini Libri, a publishing house, and her husband is with La Fondiaria Assicura zioni, a Romebased insur ance concern.

title: Queens Man Jailed in Acupuncture Case
description: A 62yearold Queens man yesterday became the first per son arrested in this states, and perhaps in this country, on charges of illegally practicing acupuncture.

title: Alexander's Bars Sunday Openings
description: Alexander's, Inc., has decided against a plan to keep its five stores in the city open on Sun days during the Christmas shop ping season.

title: QuarterCentury Later
description: Maybe the United Nations General Assembly was more prescient than it realized 25 years ago today when it voted, with uncertainty and misgiving, to partition the troubled land of Palestine into separate but closely linked Arab and Jewish states.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Displaying its old ingrained preju dice against chiropractic, The Times has again editorially attacked the pro fession, this time because of its recent inclusion in Medicare [Nov. 18]. With its obscurantist attitude toward the heating arts, The Times has failed to see the changes that have occurred in the chiropractic profession during the past thirty or forty years and still views us as we were during the 1920's and 1930's.

title: Wreckage of Plane Found
description: CHAMBERSBURG, Pa., Nov. 28 (UPI)The wreckage of a private plane that crashed in the Tuscarora Mountains in a thunderstorm June 18, killing its three occupants, was found yesterday by a deer hunter. The dead were Roy Von Nordeck, the pilot, of Cockeysville, Md., and Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Shuk of Dundalk, Md. The bodies were found in the wreckage, the state police said.

title: Taipei's Envoy Leaves Japan, Ending Relations
description: TOKYO, Nov. 28 (AP)  The Chinese Nationalist Am bassador to Japan, Peng Mengchi, flew home to Tai pei today, formally ending his Government's diplomatic representation in Japan. To kyo and Peking established diplomatic relations on Sept. 29.

title: COAST COURT URGED TO FREE REPORTER
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 28 (UPI)An attorney for William T. Farr asked the California Supreme Court today to release the jailed reporter on the ground that the judge in the case was too personally and passionately involved to be fair.

title: PROF. BORIS P. ALISOV
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 28  Prof. Boris P. Alisov, an authority one the world's climates, died here yesterday at the age of 81.

title: HARVARD 32 VICTOR IN SOCCER PLAYOFF
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 28 Chris Papagianis scored the winning goal after 20 minutes of the suddendeath overtime to give Harvard a 32 victory over Brown today in the final of the District 1 National Col legiate Athletic Association soccer playoffs. Harvard will face Cornell, the New York State champion, at Ithaca, N. Y., Saturday, with a trip to the N.C.A.A. semifinals at Miami on the line.

title: Tape on $1,150 Payment Heard at Bribery Trial
description: Tape recordings of conversa tions about cash payments for secret documents were played in Federal Court here yester day at the bribery trial of Edmund A. Rosner, a New York lawyer.

title: Paint Up 4 Cents, Boy Writes, U.S. Sues
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 Prodded by a 13yearold Long Island boy who builds and launches model rockets, the Justice Department today accused the manufacturer of illegally raising the price of a paint used by the boy.

title: BUDGET HEAD SEES LIMIT ON SPENDING
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  President Nixon's outgoing budget chief expressed con fidence today that the Govern ment would be able to hold this year's spending close to the $250billion target that President Nixon has set.

title: British Crime Compensation Board Sets Records in Grants to Victims
description: LONDON, Nov. 28A 29 yearold woman who was beaten on the head with a con crete block by a spurned man friend was left blinded, unable to taste and smell, with im paired hearing and with her powers of concentration and memory severely weakened.

title: PRINCESS SIBYLLA, 64, OF SWEDEN IS DEAD
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 28 (AP) Princess Sibylla, mother of Sweden's Crown Prince Carl Gustaf, died today, the royal palace announced, She was 64 years old.

title: Yemen, Southern Yemen Sign Unification Accord
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Nov. 28 (Reuters)An agreement on the unification of Yemen and Southern Yemen into a single state was officially signed here tonight.

title: Sandwich Machine Gives A Mix of Ingredients
description: For the first time, there is a sandwichvending machine that permits a customer to make a sandwich with choice of bread or roll.

title: Harge Quits Basketball
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., Nov. 28 (UPI)  The Carolina Cougars, who last week obtained Ira Harge from Utah, announced tonight that Harge, a center, was retiring from basketball. Harge plans to practice law.

title: Airlines to Open Gift Packages In Weapons Check of Travelers
description: The nation's airlines are warning travelers that gift packages they carry aboard jet liners this holiday season will be opened for inspection be cause they fear hijackers may attempt to smuggle weapons aboard concealed in Christmas packages.

title: 2 MORE COMPANIES RAISE STEEL PRICES
description: Two more of the nation's top 10 steel makers, the Inland Steel Company and the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company yes terday joined others in raising prices on a broad range of prod uctsgenerally plate, structur al, bar, pipe and tubular items as of Jan. 1, 1973, Tinmill price increases will follow on Feb. 16.

title: Westvaco Corporation Raises Earnings 161% for Fiscal Quarter
Letters to the Editor
description: I am incredulous at the spectacle currently being staged by the Demo cratic party over the matter of Jean Westwood's chairmanship. Not one of the numerous persons now calling for her resignation has offered an assess meat of her abilities. It seems that the sole reason for her proposed removal is that McGovern lost the election.

title: HENZE WORK PLAYED BY DAVID ENSEMBLE
description: An intriguing New York pre miere made more of an impres sion than a clutch of industri ous performances at the David Ensemble's chamber concert Monday night in Town Hall. The premiere was of Hans Wer ner Henze's Ariosi, heard in its scoring for soprano, violin and piano four hands, which Henze regards as equally im portant as the largeorchestra version.

title: PRESIDENT ORDERS $6BILLION SLASH IN POLLUTION AID
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  President Nixon has ordered the Environmental Protection Agency to allot to the states only $2billion of the $5billion authorized by Congress in the present fiscal year for waste treatment plants, and only $3 billion of the $6billion authorized for the fiscal year 1974.

title: Canadian Production Up
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 28 (Reuters) Canada's index of industrial roduction rose to 195.2 in September, up from August's 192.4, Statistics Canada re ported today.

title: RATTENNI SENTENCED FOR PLOT TO FIX JURY
description: Already appealing a three year prison term for a gambling protection scheme, Nicholas Rattenni, an operator of a Yonkers garbagetruck con cern, was given a fiveyear ad ditional sentence yesterday for conspiring to fix a Federal jury.

title: Mexican General Among 8 Held in Paris Heroin Raid
description: PARIS, Nov. 28 (UPI)Gen. Humberto Mariles Cortes, an internationally known horse man, was among eight per sons arrested by agents who smashed an international drug ring and confiscated 132 pounds of pure heroin at a Paris apartment on Saturday, the police said today.

title: ALL SIDES SCORED IN KAWAIDA FIGHT
description: NEWARK, Nov. 28Police Director John L. Redden lashed out today at the administration of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and at the City Council and selfserving community lead ers, saying they had set ele ments of the city's black and white populations at each other's throats.

title: White House to Close For Decorating Dec. 8
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP)The White House will be closed to the public Dec. 810 while it is being decorated for the Christmas holidays. The decorating will be supervised by J. Lidden Pennock, a Philadelphia hor ticulturist and floral decora tor.

title: YONKERS TO TAKE QUINIELA WAGERS
description: YONKERS, Nov. 28 When Yonkers Raceway opens its 1973 season on Jan. 3, the four exactas that had been offered there nightly since Oct. 19, 1967, will be replaced by five quinielas. The switch in the form of wagering was an nounced today by Timothy J. Rooney, the president of the Westchester County harness racing course, after permission to make the change was given to the raceway by the New York State Harness Racing Commission.

title: Ben May, 83, Industrialist Funded U. of Chicago Lab
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 28  Ben May, the Mobile (Ala.) business man who gave the University of Chicago its Ben May Labora tory for Cancer Research, where Dr. Charles B. Huggins became cowinner of the 1966 Nobel Prize for medicine, died in Mo bile on Wednesday. He was 83 years old.

title: Popkin Freed in a Surprise As U.S. Jury Is Dismissed
description: BOSTON, Nov. 28Prof. Samuel L. Popkin of Harvard was released from jail today after the Federal Government, in a surprise move, dismissed the grand jury investigating the distribution of the Pen tagon papers.

title: U. S. Planes, in Bombing Error, Kill 19 Civilians Near Danang
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Nov. 29The Unit ed States command reported yesterday that six American fighter  bombers supporting South Vietnamese troops killed at least 19 civilians and wound ed 29 in a misdirected attack in the northern part of the country.

title: PHILIP MEYERSON
description: Philip Meyerson, founder and president of the U. S. Electrical Supply Company, Inc., 55 War ren Street, died of a heart at tack Monday at Community, Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 72 years old and lived at 130 Exeter Street, Brooklyn.

title: U. S. Food Projects Are Said to Reach Only Half of Needy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) Federal food programs fail to reach more than half the needy because most are inadequately funded, are surrounded with bureaucratic red tape and are poorly administered, a report released today charges.

title: Multiple Horse Race Bets Banned in New Hampshire
description: PORTSMOUTH, N. H., Nov. 28 (AP) Timothy Connors, the New Hampshire Racing Com mission chairman, said today all forms of multiple wagering at New Hampshire's horse racing tracks would be banned as of Jan. 1 to protect the pub lic interest.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In school after school in New York, there is no education taking place. Learning has been replaced by what is called communicating; teachers have abandoned their roles as educa tors for the roles of psychiatrist, so cial crusader and friend. All stand ards, even the most minimal stand ards of literacy, have long ago been dismissed as irrelevant and elitist.

title: P.O.W.'s to Be Freed Friday
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 28 (Agence FrancePresse)The Indian Gov ernment announced today that it would release on Friday all 540 Pakistani prisoners of war captured on the western front during last December's war.

title: Head of Newark Police Scores All Sides
description: NEWARK, Nov. 28Police Director John L. Reddin lashed out today at the administration of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson, the City Council and selfserv ing community leaders who he said had set elements of the city's black and white popula tions at each other's throats.

title: HAVERGAL BRIAN, 96; BRITISH COMPOSER
description: SHOREHAM, England, Nov. 28 (UPI)Havergal Brian, often called the forgotten man of English music, died today. He was 96 years.

title: Prof. Elizabeth Casey, 86, Long on Brooklyn Faculty
description: FALL RIVER, Wis., Nov. 28 Prof. Elizabeth P. Casey, who helped found the department of speech and theater at. Brook lyn College in the early 1930's, died Sunday at her home. She was 86 years old.

title: India's Untouchables Search for a Way Up
description: SARNATH, India, Nov. 26 Dina Nath, a 30yearold Hindu untouchable, embraced Bud dhism here today along with 1,000 others of the caste after vowing never to tell a lie.

title: BURGER STRESSES COURT OVERWORK
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger disclosed last night that the nine United States Supreme Court Justices would have to pass on 247 petitions and other matters on a single day this Fridaysounding a new warning that the court was be coming overloaded.

title: Frenchman Scores Upset
description: BRISBANE, Australia, Nov. 28 (UPI)An unseeded French man, Thierry Bernasconi, upset the Australian Davis Cup play er, Colin Dibley, 75, 63, in the Queensland grass tennis cham pionships today.

title: LAOS PEACE TALKS SEEM TO REGRESS
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 28 The Vientiane Government and the Communistled Pathet Lao held another session of nego tions today, but when it ended they appeared further apart than they were seven weeks ago, when the talks began.

title: Bremer's Brother Acquitted In Florida Mail Fraud Case
description: MARIANNA, Fla., Nov. 28 (AP)William A. Bremer, elder brother of Arthur Bremer, the man convicted of shooting Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, was acquitted today of 19 counts of mail fraud.

title: TV Review
description: Tonight's Public Broadcast ing Service special on Popu lation Growth and the Amer ican Future has already stirred up its predictable share of controversy. As a filmed report of the Presi dent's commission study on population, presented to the President and Congress last spring, the program deals with recommendations for more sex education and more birth control, including the right to abortion in some in stances. Certain religious groups and right to life groups have voiced their strong opposition to the pro gram.

title: Japanese Trade Surplus at High
description: TOKYO, Nov. 28As the Jap anese Government announced a record trade surplus in Oc tober, Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, called on Japan today to reduce the im balance in United StatesJap anese trade.

title: Angels Get Dodgers' Frank Robinson
description: HONOLULU, Nov. 28  Frank Robinson and four other players were traded to the Cal ifornia Angels today in a seven man exchange that sent Andy Messersmith and Ken McMul len to the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Deferment of Wage Raise Completes Bakery Accord
description: The Pechter Baking Com pany, one of 19 specialty bakers struck by driversales men here earlier this month, announced an agreement yes terday increasing employe pay and benefits but permitting a six  month deferment of the pay rise.

title: Equity Financing
description: Commercial Solvents Corporation yesterday said it would apply to the Securities and Exchange Commission to withdraw the registration statement filed Oct. 5 in connection with a secondary offer ing of 214,632 common shares, The company said the action was taken at the request of the selling shareholders for whose account the stock was to be sold by an underwriting group managed by Blyth Eastman Dillon and Shields Securities. The company's stock was up  at 19 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Warriors Overtake Suns
description: OAKLAND, Nov. 28, (AP) Jim Barnett scored 6 tive points in the fourth quar ter to pace the Golden State Warriors to a 110102 victory over the Phoenix Suns tonight.

title: Warren Calls for Studies on Goodness
description: Earl Warren, the former Chief Justice of the United States, urged the Jewish Theo logical Seminary here yester day to undertake studies lead ing to a disciplined explora tion of ethical problems and the nature of the good man and the good society.

title: 3 Robbers Flee With $10,000 At Chinatown V.F.W. Post
description: Three gunmen invaded the Chinatown Post of the Veter ans of Foreign Wars Monday night, robbed more than 25 men of a total of $3,000, stole $7,000 from the safe and fled.

title: Designated PinchHitter Urged for Further Tests
description: HONOLULU, Nov. 28 a Baseball's playing rules com mittee strongly recommended today that the highest minor leagues experiment next sea son with the designated pinchhitter, who would go to bat for the pitcher with out forcing the pitcher out of the game.

title: Business Briefs
description: The flow of new deposits into the nation's savings and loan associations picked up in October, but most of the increase was accounted for by normal seasonal trends, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday. Net new deposits in associations totaled $1.9billion last month, the board said, up $400million from September. This represented a new record rate of deposit gain for the month of October, the report stated, was 25 per cent higher than the $1.5billion gain in October, 1971, and was the biggest monthly gain since last July.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 (AP)A threegoal flurry over an 8minute span gave the University of Pennsylvania a 31 victory over Penn State in a regional final of the National Collegiate soccer tournament tonight.

title: McClain Gives Jets Ray of Hope
description: Making forward progress while looking back over your shoulder has always been dif ficult in any walk of life. For Cliff McClain, the New York Jets running back, the habit is particularly disdainful. He tries hard to avoid it.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The agreement recently concluded among the Four Powers, guaranteeing support for the admission into the United Nations of the two Germanys, following closely on the signing of a treaty establishing normal relations between those two political entities, deserves world applause.

title: Frenchman Scores Upset
description: BRISBANE, Australia, Nov. 28 (UPI)An unseeded French man, Thierry Bernasconi, upset the Australian Davis Cup play er, Colin Dibley, 75, 63, in the Queensland grass tennis cham pionships today.

title: CITY PLANS DRIVE ON HOTEL CRIME
description: Top city officials, headed by Deputy Mayor Edward K. Ham ilton and Human Resources Ad ministrator Jule M. Sugarman, will announce today a major drive against singleroomoccu pancy hotels ridden by crime.

title: 6 Accused in Slaying
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 28 (UPI) Six men have been arrested and charged with firstdegree murder in the killing Nov. 11 of Thomas Jenkins, an 18year old freshman at Xavier Uni versity, during a robbery at the Student Union. The police to day identified the suspects as Danny Martin, alias Danny Cox: Ronald Amos. 23; Willis McNeil Jr., 26; Wendell Drake, 22; Vernon Childs, 18, and Stephen Lewis, 23, all of Cin cinnati.

title: U.S. Planes, in Bombing Error, Kill 19 Civilians Near Danang
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Nov. 29The Unit ed States command reported yesterday that six American fighter  bombers supporting South Vietnamese troops killed at least 19 civilians and wound ed 29 in a misdirected attack in the northern part of the country.

title: Business Briefs
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 28 (UPI)Two of the nation's three large railroad associations served notice today that they would seek permission to add a 2 per cent emergency surcharge to all freight shipments. Chief traffic officers of the Western and Southern Railroad Associations said they would file petitions with the Interstate Commerce Commission to add the extra charge to, from and within Western and Southern territories.

title: Editors' Group Backs Bill To Protect News Sources
description: ALBANY, Nov. 28 (AP)The board of directors of the Amer ican Society of Newspaper Edi tors has gone on record in sup port of an unqualified Federal shield law to guarantee news men's rights to keep their sources confidential, an official of the society announced to day.

title: Snag at Penn Station Halts L.I.R.R. Service for Hours
description: Service on Long Island Rail Road trains into and out of Pennsylvania Station was halted at 7:45 o'clock last night because of what the rail road said was a loss of air pressure in the lines that op wale switches and signals in the East River tunnels serving the station.

title: Advertising: Aiding Consumers
description: DORADO BEACH, Puerto Rico, Nov. 28As part of a program on consumerism at the meeting of the Associa tion of National Advertisers here, the Council of Better Business Bureaus gave a re port of its progress and un veiled a new public service campaign that should help make more knowledgeable consumers.

title: East Harlem Boycott
description: School boycotts, regardless of the goals they intend to achieve, inevitably hurt the children. Except where conditions are physically unsafe, keeping the children in school is more productive than keeping them out. The present boycott in East Harlem is no exception.

title: City Bars Business With Youth Agency Contractor
description: A consultant concern with $204,167 in city contracts awarded by Ted Gross, the for mer Youth Services Agency head who resigned recently under fire, was barred yester day from doing business with the city for five years.

title: U.S. Offers Details On Objective Test For Payments Ills
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  The United States has circu lated at the International Mon nary Reform negotiations a paper explaining in detail the view that there should be an objective test of when nations should take action to adjust their international balance of payments. The lest would be based on changes in monetary reserves.

title: Terrorists of I.R.A. Stage A Series of Rocket Attacks
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 28Terrorists of the Irish Republican Army staged their first coordinated series of rocket attacks today on targets throughout Ulster. The rocket attacks and other incidents to day claimed a total of four lives.

title: Key HeroinCase Witness Slain; Charges Against One Dismissed
description: A Queens man who was to enter a guilty plea and testify against two codefendants in a Federal narcotics case in Hart ford was shot to death early yesterday as he left his home here.

title: FIRE RULES VOTED ON OFFICE TOWERS
description: ?? in the bill for the officebuild ings are the following:

title: Kleinert's Fills Key Post
description: David Reich, who resigned as president and chief execu tive officer of the MerrittChap man & Scott Corporation, has been elected executive vice president and a director of Kleinert's, Inc., a maker of chil dren's wear and a variety of other products, and president of a subsidiary, the Pembroke Manufacturing Company. Be fore joining MerrittChapman & Scott in 1969, Mr. Reich was president of Tennessee Products & Chemical Corporation.

title: Italy's Socialists, Social Democrats Gain
description: ROME, Nov. 28Socialists and Social Democrats scored the strongest gains in munic ipal elections held in many places throughout Italy on Sun day and yesterday, final re turns showed today.

title: Army Gets Navy's SecondString Goat
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 28 Army has Navy's goat again in one of the longest and most successful kidnap ping capers in the annals of service shenanigans before the traditional football game.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: DEPTFORD, Nov. 28  An outbreak of deadly hog cholera in the pig farming capital of South Jersey has resulted in the federally sponsored slaugh ter of 9,400 animals in less than two weeks.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: The election of Dr. Ken neth C. Rogers as the fifth president of the Stevens In stitute of Technology was announced yesterday by the institute's trustees.

title: Rightist South African Unions Assail Racial Job Curb
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Nov. 28  Rightwing white unionists in the building trades have complained to the South African Government that laws reserving skilled jobs for whites have broken down and should be abandoned in favor of equal pay for equal work by blacks.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The recent decision of Fire Com missioner Robert Lowery to disband Engine Company 270 in the Rockaways is clearly the first step on the road of false economy and disaster.

title: Due Arrives in Capital; Talks With Nixon Today
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (Reuters)  Nguyen Phu Duc, the South Vietnamese envoy, arrived here tonight to con sult tomorrow with President Nixon on the peace negotia tions.

title: Dropout Lands at Head of Class
description: As usual. Tommy Wallis hopped out of bed at 5:15 A.M. yesterday for another leading apprentice jockey. At day's end, he would have his 29th and 30th winners of the Aqueduct meeting.

title: Two Measures on Terror Offered at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 28A group of nations fa voring forceful international ac tion against terrorism offered a resolution today that not only would condemn such accts but would ask the International Law Commission to draft with the highest priority a conven tion to prevent terrorism.

title: Safe Harbor Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28The Securities and Exchange Com mission moved today to re move uncertainties about pri vate placements of securities outside the accounting and registration requirement of public offerings.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Several years ago, when the Los Angeles Dodgers were in the midst of a National League pennant race. Maury Wills was talking with Wes Parker.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Suffolk County grand jury indicted the business manager of the Brentwood, L. I., school district yesterday and ordered misdemeanor charges filed against three present or former school board members who allegedly took their spouses to a national school boards convention in San Francisco last April, billing the district for all their traveling expenses.

title: 58 on Jet Die in Soviet
description: Fiftyeight people were killed when a Japanese jet liner crashed shortly after taking off from the Moscow airport last evening. Thirteen survivors were taken to Mos cow hospitals. Page 13.

title: Newcombe is Victor
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Nov. 28 (Agence France Presse)John Newcombe heat Allan Stone, 75, 62, in an all Australian quarterfinal of the $50,000 World Championship Tennis event today.

title: Hartford Assembly Cuts Sales Levy, but in Vain
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 28Con necticut's lameduck General Assembly voted today to cut the state's sales tax from 7 per cent to 6 per cent. A half hour after the vote, Gov. Thom as J. Meskill branded the measure financially and politi cally reckless and said he would veto it, probably tomorrow.

title: People and Business
description: Seymour Turk, 45, ex ecutive vice president of Si mon & Schuster, Inc., will become president and chief operating officer of the big book publishing house on Jan. 1, Succeeding him will be Richard E. Snyder, 39, di rector of trade publishing.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: DRESDEN, East GermanyBy its energetic reconstruction, this Saxon capital, famous for its fine buildings overlooking the Elbe, for its craftsmen and for the magnificent paintings in its art gallery, typifies the German Democratic Republic now rising like a small Phoenix in the Communist world.

title: Dublin Reviewing Link to Church
description: DUBLIN, Nov. 23The Irish Government has embarked on a delicate and possibly far reaching reassessment of its re lationship with the Roman Catholic Church.

title: SecondTerm Cabinet
description: President Nixon's first three appointees in his Cabinet reshuffle Elliot L. Richardson to Defense, Caspar W. Weinberger to Health, Education and Welfare, and Roy L. Ash to the Office of Management and Budgetare men of impressive personal attainments. What remains unclear is not their competence but the policies with which they will identify in their new posts.

title: Hockey Series Postponed
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., Nov. 29 (UPI)Gary L. Davidson, the president of the World Hockey Association, said today the first three games of the pro posed exhibition series be tween a W.H.A. allstar team and the world champion Czech oslovak national team has been postponed until May.

title: Rangers Rally to Tie Kings On Late Goal by Fairbairn, 22
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 29  Billy Fairbairn pushed through his second power goal of the season in the final period to night and salvaged a 2.2 tie for the New York Rangers against the aroused Los Angeles Kings.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two Public Service Commission examiners recom mended yesterday a temporary rate increase of $75million a year for the Consolidated Edison Company. It approved by the commission, monthly utilities bills for customers New York City and Westchester County would increase by about 6 per cent.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: You begin your Nov. 21 editorial with the rather startling words: As New York's antinoise campaign shifts we hopeinto high gear  From where I sit on weekdays44th Street near Fifth Avenue  I did not even hear it get into low or second gear. In fact, I did not even hear it start up. There was too much noise.

title: Analysts' Unit Favors Permitting Forecasts of Sales and Profits
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  The Financial Analysts Federa tion added its voice today to the growing consensus in favor of permitting corporations to publish forecasts of their earn ings and sales.

title: NIXON AIDES SEEK TO LIMIT RERUNS
description: Clay T. Whitehead, director of the White House Office of Telecommunications Policy, to gether with his top legal aide have quietly been calling on officials of the three television networks to get them to limit voluntarily the number of re runs on TV.

title: Newspaper Sues Union
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 29 (UPI)  The Kansas City Star filed suit against the Pressmen's Union, charging repeated work slowdowns, strikes and sabot age. The classaction suit against the Kansas City Web Printing Pressmen's Union No. 14 asked the Jackson County Circuit Court for both a pre liminary and a permanent ] junction.

title: Vesco Wins First Round In Fighting S.E.C. Suit
description: Robert L. VeSco, defending charges that he and 41 others had drained $224million from four mutual Funds he con trolled, won an initial victory in United States District Court here yesterday.

title: News Analysis
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 23The words that Koreans, North and South, are proclaim ing these days are from the vocabulary of diplomacy and peacereduction of tensions, improving relations, sincere negotiations and peaceful unification.

title: MONTEDISON VOTES A REFINANCING PLAN
description: MILAN, Italy, Nov. 29 (AP) The board of directors of Mon tecatini Edison, one of the world's largest chemical groups, today took a major step to reorganize the troubled com pany's finances. The move will permit the company to break even this year, at least on paper, after two years of losses.

title: Woman Santa Dismissed
description: HONOLULU, Nov. 29 (UPI)  Weldon Larsen, manager of a shopping center, said he hired a woman to play Santa Claus trying to follow the principles of equality, but that he had to dismiss her yesterday. The older kids could tell by her fin gernails, he said.

title: Buses From L.I. to City
description: Following is a list of bus services available to Nassau and Suffolk County commuters to subway stops in Queens:

title: Lawyer Cites Pressure to Buy Secret Documents
description: Edmund A. Rosner testified at his bribery trial yesterday that he was a respectable law yer who had been pressured into paying $2,000 for secret documents in a criminal inves tigation.

title: A Statewide Quarantine On Hogs Set by Jersey
description: TRENTON, Nov. 29  The New Jersey Agriculture Depart ment announced today that a quarantine on all 123,000 hogs in the state would go into effect Friday in an effort to pre vent the spread of a deadly hog cholera epidemic.

title: Sabres' Horton Sidelined
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 29 (AP) Tim Horton, defenseman for the Buffalo Sabres of the Na tional Hockey League, will be sidelined for at least a week with an injured shoulder.

title: BLACKS ASK TRIALS IN CAMPUS DEATHS
description: BATON ROUGE, Nov. 29 (UPI)An unofficial allblack committee of inquiry announced today that it had more than adequate basis for criminal prosecution of law enforcement personnel in the slaying of two black students on the Southern University campus Nov. 16.

title: Times Declares Dividend
description: Directors of The New York Times Company declared yes terday a quarterly dividend of 15 cents a share on the Class A and Class B common stock. It is payable Dec. 26 to stock holders of record Dec. 11. The current declaration will bring total dividends this year to 60 cents a share, the same as in 1971.

title: REMSEN IS TAKEN BY KINSMAN HOPE
description: Kinsman Hope of the Kin ship Stable registered a sur prise victory in the $30,075 Remsen at Aqueduct yesterday, The onemile race for 2year olds attracted a field of 13, and to the crowd of 15,289 on hand the only thing optimis tic about the horse's chances was his name.

title: F.P.C. Expects Shortage Of Natural Gas to Worsen
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29The Federal Power Commission re ported today that the country's shortage of natural gas this winter would be the largest on record and almost twice as large as last winter.

title: Nixon and Mills Expected To Delay on Tax Reform
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29The Nixon Administration and the key tax mail in Congress, Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, have decided independently that there is no urgency about tax reform in 1973.

title: OBSERVER
description: Wine has finally arrived in the United States. Last week on the cover of Time. Television executives predict that it will soon be almost as vital to American culture as snow tires.

title: People and Business
description: Yoshio Terasawa, a 41 yearold former Fulbright Scholar at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, has been named president and chief executive officer of Nomura Securities International, Inc. He succeeds Yukio Aida, 48, as head of the American sub sidiary of Nomura Securities Co., Ltd., Japan's largest brokerage firm.

title: L.I.R.R. STRIKE ON AS LATE EFFORTS BY MEDIATOR FAIL
description: Nonoperating employes of the Long Island Rail Road went on strike at 12:01 A.M. today, causing a shutdown of the line and forcing its 90,000 commut ers to seek other ways to get to work this morning.

title: Music: Earl Wild Plays
description: When Earl Wild sits down at the piano nobody laughs. Everyone knows that his technical facility is phenom enal and that anything he plays will get a respectable interpretation, Sometimes the matter seems to end just about there, and one leaves a performance admiring all that transpired without feel ing much personal response to it.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UPI)The United States is attempting to get Singapore, Thailand and Macao to agree to voluntary restrictions of textile exports to the American market, diplomatic sources said today.

title: Notes on People
description: The Weizmann Institute of Science announced in Reho vot, Israel, that Dr. Albert B. Sabin, discoverer of oral polio vaccine, was retiring as its president. The an nouncement said the 66year old Dr. Sabin would leave his post Jan. 1 because of ill health. Dr. Sabin, who became president of the in stitute in 1970, underwent openheart surgery three months ago. He is expected to spend the next year as a Fogarty Scholar at the Na tional Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md. Prof. Israel Dostrovsky, the Weizmann Institute's vice president, was named acting president and chief executive officer.

title: Mays Wants 20 Play For One More Season
description: HONOLULU, Nov. 29Wil lie would like to play one more season with the New York Mets before retiring, but a decision is being de layed because of uncertainty over his damaged knees.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: THANKS WIN 1050 FOR YOUR HE MAN HELP XEWEST HE MAN SHOP OPENS YOUNKERS SCARSDALE LUCKY FOR ALL BIG AND TALL MEN. Advt.

title: Government to Issue Rule Requiring Airport Guards
description: The Nixon Administration has decided to issue an emergency rule requiring all of the na tion's 531 airports with airline service to provide policemen or other armed guards to help in tercept potential hijackers.

title: LiveIn Chinese Chef: A Man to Treasure
description: For the family that has everything, the next step is to acquire a livein Chinese cook. And that is exactly what a surprising number of American house holds have done recently. They no longer go out for egg rollor peel their own grapesbut they also live in fear, fear that someone will snatch away their cook and put an end to all those effortless eightcourse banquets.

title: ATOMIC REACTOR WILL BE CLOSED
description: DETROIT, Nov. 29The na tion's first and only fast breeder nuclear power plant, generally considered to be a $135million white elephant, is to be closed.

title: Business Briefs
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Nov. 29 (AP)The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries established today a guar antee fund of $220million to protect its members from punitive actions by oil companies, qualified conference sources said.

title: Peron and Government Appear To Increase Their Differences
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 29 Recent signs of some goodwill between former President Juan D. Peron and Argentina's mili tary government appear to have faded under the pressure of Peronist demands that the mil itary leaders are not willing to accept.

title: A Joint Task Force Is Proposed to Coordinate Federal and State Systems of Criminal Justice
description: A Federalstate justice coor dination task force to improve the use of resources and to integrate policies on prosecu tions and sentences in the oftendiffering Federal and state systems here has been formally proposed by Federal Judge Jack B. Weinstein.

title: 19 Hurt in Bus Accident
description: TRINIDAD, Colo., Nov. 29 (UPI)A Greyhound bus hit an icy stretch of pavement, went into a skid and overturned yes terday, injuring 19 persons.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Nov. 29Gover nor Cahill announced this eve ning that Secretary of State Paul J. Sherwin had submitted his resignation. The Governor also announced that State Treasurer Joseph F. McCrane had submitted his resignation, and that it would take effect at the end of the year.

title: PRICE PANEL BARS FORD PROFIT PLEA
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 The Price Commission refused today to give the Ford Motor Company a ruling that would have granted the company more room to raise car and truck prices. It was an appli cation pending for an average increase of $92.

title: Woman Shot and Man Kills Himself in a Midtown Hotel
description: A 45yearold woman was critically wounded in the Taft Hotel yesterday by a compan ion who then killed himself with the revolver, according to the police.

title: Music: Jenkins in Clarion Concerts
description: The program Newell Jen kins had made up for his Clarion Concerts in Tully Hall on Tuesday night dwelt to a large extent on concertos of one sort or another. Of prime interest was a new work by Arnold Black, com missioned by the Clarion Music Society and called Clarion Concerto.

title: They Admit to a ProblemBut Don't Call Them Chubby
description: In the first place, the group's members said, they hate the word chubby. They hated it as babyish and ugly when they were chil dren, and they loathe it even more now that they're at least 11, and some as old as 16.

title: CLARK ASKS A CURB IN DECENTRALIZING
description: Confessing to a 180degree change on decentralization, Dr. Kenneth B. Clark has advised the City Charter Revision Com mission to beware of a sim plistic manipulation of the bu reaucratic structure as a hope for improving city government.

title: SAIGON REPORTS DRIVE IS SLOWED
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Nov. 30 (AP)Bad weather reportedly slowed fighting yesterday on the north ernmost front of South Vietnam where Government troops were trying to widen their control of territory before any ceasefire.

title: Al McGuire Accepts Post
description: MILWAUKEE, Nov. 29 (AP) Al McGuire, Marquette Uni versity basketball coach, said today he was accepting a job as school athletic director, ef fective Sept. 1. McGuire said he would continue to serve also as coach under a fiveyear contract that is in its second season.

title: Rebels Fighting in South, Marcos Says
description: MANILA, Nov. 29 (Reuters) President Ferdinand E. Mar cos said today that a group of rebels apparently armed from abroad was fighting Govern ment troops on Basilan Island in the south.

title: Jury Gives Doctor 16Million on Loss Of Research Pact
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 20A researcher whose project on ultrasonic detection of breast cancer was halted when two foundations withdrew their sponsorship of his Federal grant was awarded more than $16million from the founda tions by a county court jury today.

title: Hockey Series Postponed
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., Nov. 29 (AP)The first three games of a series between a World Hockey Association allstar team and the Czechoslovak na tional team have been post poned from January to May, the W.H.A. president, Gary L. Davidson, said today.

title: Cambodian War Enriches the Corrupt, Debases the Poor
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 29The sons of generals drive Alfa Romeos and Cougar fast backs. The governor of a prov ince is known to sell ammuni tion and drugs to the enemy, Other government officials can be seen selling automatic rifles and uniforms to wealthy mer chants, who in turn sell them to both sides. Lowsalaried colonels  some accused of pocketing the payrolls of their unitsbuild luxury villas here in the capital and rent them to Americans for $700 a month.

title: New Plan Slated for SexShow Raids
description: A new procedure to over come constitutional objections to the seizure of allegedly pornographic material, particu larly peepshow films, has been devised by city law enforce ment agencies.

title: Treasury Bill Sale Raises $2.5Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 The Treasury raised $2.5bil lion with the auction today of 199day tax anticipation bills dated Dec. 5, 1972, due June 22, 1973. The average rate of discount approximated 5.089 per cent, equivalent to a price of 97.187.

title: Personalities: Layer Bypassed
description: John Newcombe has agreed to play for Australia in the Davis Cup next year. Ken Rosman has been ap proached, but is undecided and Rod Lover has not been asked. These developments came about as a result of an announcement by the Esso (Australia) Oil Company that it would put up $30,000 as a contribution toward the Aus sies' effort next year to re gain the cup. The three stars had been haired from cup competition while under con tract with Lamar Hunt's World Championship Tennis organization, but with their contracts having been termi nated or being phased out, they were eligible again for cup competition. When they played for the cup, Australia was supreme. Ilie Nastase, the Rumanian tennis star, has withdrawn from the $75,000 Clean Air Classic here be cause he plans to be married in Brussels, Belgium, to Dom inique Grazia on Dec. 7. The tournament opens Monday at the Seventh Regiment Arm ory with an international field. Roy Emerson of Aus tralia will take Nastase's place in the field.

title: Parents and School Figures Relate Why of Boycott
description: At Public School 206 in East Harlem, parents con tributed the money that is being used to buy basic read ing materials and to pay for medicine to treat children in fested with lice. The money was raised in a candy sale.

title: Strike Activity Is Down
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UPI) Strike activity last month was the lowest for any Octo ber since the Government be gan keeping work stoppage sta tistics in 1946, the Labor De partment said today.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Nov. 29The yearbook of Doug lass College, the resident women's division of Rutgers University, may join the list of publications displaying male centerfolds, and the student government is not happy about the prospects.

title: State Is Considering Managing Medicaid
description: The state is considering tak ing over from New York City and all other localities the proc essing of claims and payments in the Medicaid program for the poora program now fore cast to cost. $1.99billion for the state's fiscal year starting next April 1.

title: PRICES ON AMEX FINISH DAY MIXED
description: Prices in the overthecoun ter market and on the Ameri can Stock Exchange finished mixed yesterday in moderate trading.

title: Farrell Tacoma Manager
description: HONOLULU, Nov. 29 (UPI) Kerby Farrell, former manager of the Cleveland Indians and a veteran of more than 30 years in baseball's managerial ranks, was named today manager of the Tacoma Twins in the Pacific Coast League.

title: 2 Cabbies Join Police to Rescue 3d Driver From Holdup Suspect
description: Two cabbies joined the police early yesterday to rescue another cab driver whose taxi had been commandeered by an armed robber fleeing with $280 from a midtown bar.

title: CARL L. STEARNS, 80, ASTRONOMER, DEAD
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 29Carl L. Stearns, Fisk pro fessor of astronomy and former director of the Van Vleck Ob servatory at Wesleyan Univer sity, died yesterday at Middle sex Memorial Flospital after a short illness. He was 80 years old.

title: COLLEGES SCORED ON HIRING WOMEN
description: SYRACUSE, Nov. 29  The Federal Governments program to enforce equal hiring and promotion opportunities for women and minorities on col lege faculties is losing ground to a growing rhetorical back lash from male faculty mem bers and administrators, the director of the Office for Civil Rights said here today.

title: SENIOR OFFICERS DEFEND ZUMWALT
description: NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 29 Senior officers of the Atlantic Command emphatically reject ed today suggestions from with in the service that Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr.'s reforms had encouraged loss of discipline and promoted racial strife in the Navy.

title: WHEAT FUTURES HIGHER AT CLOSE
description: Good export demand and talk that India might soon have to buy wheat here firmed wheat futures contracts yesterday. Traders also noted that some other nations, caught by a short rice output this year, might also have to increase wheat pur chases later.

title: The Proceedings in the U. N. Today
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: Galigher Could Become Jets' Enforcer
description: Ed Galigher didn't look too much like a killer sitting in the New York Jets' locker room yesterday waiting for the cast on his broken right thumb to harden.

title: Rockets Down Bullets
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 29 (AP)Jack Marin and Otto Moore started a late rally to pace the Houston Rockets to a 10294 victory over the Balti more Bullets tonight.

title: PHILIP BERRIGAN GRANTED PAROLE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 The Rev. Philip F. Berrigan, the Roman Catholic priest who has served a total of 38 months in prison for antiwar actions, was granted parole today effec tive Dec. 20, the United States Parole Board announced.

title: Nixon and Mills Expected To Delay on Tax Reform
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29The Nixon Administration and the key tax man in Congress, Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, have decided independently that there is no urgency about tax reform in 1973.

title: JERSEY TO IMPOSE A HOG QUARANTINE
description: TRENTON, Nov. 29  The New Jersey Agriculture Depart ment announced today that a quarantine on all 123,000 hogs in the state would go into effect Friday in an effort to pre vent the spread of a deadly hog cholera epidemic.

title: Woman Refuses to Testify
description: SCRANTON, Pa., Nov. 29 (AP)Letitia Reilly, who with her husband owned and oper ated two homes for retarded children where 21 deaths are being investigated, refused to day to testify before a special legislative committee here.

title: The Stage: Blue Boys
description: After about 10 minutes of Blue Boys, which opened last night at the Martinique Theater, I found myself whistling Dixie under my breath in an unfortunately successful effort to keep awake. It is a play about Union soldiers in the Civil War, and it was the kind of writing that could have made a Confederate out of Lincoln.

title: Nordwig Retires at 29
description: BERLIN, Nov. 29 (Agence FrancePresse)  Wolfgang Nordwig of East Germany, 29 yearold Olympic champion in the pole vault, retired from competition today to devote all of his time to his studies in physics.

title: F.P.C. Expects Shortage Of Natural Gas to Worsen
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29The Federal Power Commission re ported today that the country's shortage of national gas this winter would be the largest on record and almost twice as large as last winter.

title: Jersey Begins First Daily Lottery in U.S.
description: TRENTON, Nov. 29The na tion's first daily, stateoperated lottery got started here this afternoon in what promises to he the longestrunning daily giveaway show in the country's history.

title: Photos Said to Show Intestinal Virus
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  Scientists at the National In stitutes of Health have photo graphed and identified particles they believe are viruses that cause the socalled intestinal flu.

title: 3 IN SOVIET CRASH WERE AMERICANS
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 29The So viet Government informed the United States Embassy here to day that three Americans had been identified among the 60 known dead in yesterday's crash of a Japanese airliner shortly after takeoff from the Moscow airport.

title: U.S. AIDES REPORT YIELDING BY HANOI ON TRUCE ISSUES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  Wellplaced Administration of ficials reported today that a number of concessions were made by North Vietnam in the most recent phase of peace talks in Paris. But the officials, in various departments of Gov ernment, said at least two or three major differences re mained to be resolved before a ceasefire agreement was ready for signing.

title: PENN STATE TOPS PRINCETON, 6457
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 29 Four Penn State players scored in double figures tonight to lead the Nittany Lions to a 6457 victory over Princeton in the basketball opener for both teams at Jadwin Gymnasium.

title: Nordwig Quits Track
description: BERLIN, Nov. 29 (AP)East Germany's Wolfgang Nordwig, pole vault gold medalist at the Munich Olympics, announced today his retirement from com petition. I will not be seen again in a stadium as a com petitor, the 29yearold physics student said. Nordwig won a bronze at the 1968 Mexico City Olympics and he was European champion in 1966, 1969 and 1971.

title: National League of Cities Bids Nixon Revise Pollution Deadlines on Water
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 29  The resolutions committee of the National League of Cities urged the Nixon Administra tion today to revise its dead lines for complying with water pollution standards if Federal funds were not going to be provided for municipal water purification projects.

title: Bruno Zirato, 88, Caruso Aide Who Headed Philharmonic, Dies
description: Bruno Zirato, who was En rico Caruso's private secretary for the last seven years of the tenor's life and managing di rector of the New York Phil harmonic from 1956 to 1959, died Tuesday night in the Co lumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center after a long illness. He was 88 years old.

title: Squires Turn Back Tams by 128117 For Fourth in Row
description: NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 29 (AP) The Virginia Squires, with nine players scoring in double figures, won their fourth straight game with a 128117 American Basketball Associa tion victory over the Memphis Tams tonight.

title: Smith 3Set Victor Over Gimeno, Connors Defeats Kodes in Spain
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Nov. 29 (AP)Stan Smith and Ilia Na stase, cofavorites in the Grand Prix Masters tennis tournament, gained their second victories to night, but Jimmy Connors stole the show.

title: California Justices Reject Writer's Bid for Release
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 29 (AP)The California Supreme Court denied without comment today William T. Farr's petition for release from jail under a contempt sentence. Mr. Farr is a reporter for The Los Angeles Times.

title: FIRST TALKS END ON MONEY REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 The first round of negotiations on world monetary reform among deputy ministers of the new Committee of 20 con cluded today with no effort made yet to achieve a con sensus on the many issues in volved.

title: TAXI UNIT HONORS 55 CAB DRIVERS
description: Fiftyfive cab drivers, some as young as 19 years old and others 35year veterans, re ceived awards from the Taxi Commission yesterday for heroism and outstanding serv ice to the riding public.

title: Parents and School Figures Relate Why of Boycott
description: At Public School 206 in East Harlem, parents con tributed the money that is being used to buy basic read ing materials and to pay for medicine to treat children in fested with lice. The money was raised in a candy sale.

title: Sabres' Horton Sidelined
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 29 (AP) Tim Horton, defenseman for the Buffalo Sabres of the Na tional Hockey League, will be sidelined for at least a week with an injured shoulder.

title: Sears, Roebuck Given TV Ad Bureau Award
description: At its 18th annual mem bership meeting, the Televi sion Bureau of Advertising named Sears, Roebuck & Co. Advertiser of the Year.

title: DOW INDEX SLIPS AS VOLUME EBBS
description: Stock prices consolidated yes terday on Wall Street for the second session in a row as vol ume continued to ebb somewhat following the booming market performances of recent weeks.

title: Navy Calls West Point Ghost Ploy in Old Army Game
description: A midshipman has said that the apparition that is supposed to have appeared at the United States Military Academy was nothing but a Navy stunt, put together with a flashlight, a photo graphic slide and a fire ex tinguisher.

title: Danish Copiers Rescue 53 From British Oil Rig
description: AARHUS, Denmark, Nov. 29 (UPDThree Danish res cue helicopters flew through gale force winds over the stormy North Sea today, re moved 53 men from a ?? British oil rig and left half of them on a nearby Danish tanker before returning to land with the rest.

title: Cosmos Say They Are Returning to Hofstra for 1973 Campaign
description: The New York Cosmos, their players scattered from Toronto to Mexico City, announced yes terday that they would return to Hofstra Stadium for the 1973 season and unveiled plans for an extensive seasonticket campaign.

title: TV:
description: What could be more festiveor plain groovier than a fastflying television concert hour of vintage jazz experts headed by such peers as Benny Goodman, Ella Fitzgerald, Count Basie and Duke Ellington? Add about a dozen more names and various ensembles and you have The Big Bands and All That Jazz. The Na tional Broadcasting Company beamed this feast last night after The Man Who Came to Dinner.

title: PHILIP BERRIGAN GRANTED PAROLE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 The Rev. Philip F. Berrigan, the Roman Catholic priest who has served a total of 38 months in prison for antiwar actions, was granted parole today effec tive Dec. 20, the United States Parole Board announced.

title: White Sox Acquire Henderson And Send Bradley to the Giants
description: HONOLULU, Nov. 29  Baseball's busy trading market kept boiling along today when The San Francisco Giants traded Ken Henderson and Steve Stone to the Chicago White Sox for Tom Bradley.

title: DR. GEORGE NOBLE, HISTORIAN, DEAD
