description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  Dr. George Bernard Noble, di rector of the Department of State Historical Office from 1946 until his retirement in 1962, died of cancer yesterday at Sibley Hospital here. He was 80 years old.

title: 3 Leap to Death Fleeing a Fire In 16thFloor New Orleans Club
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 29 (AP) Three women leaped to their deaths today when fire trapped a crowd in a private club atop a 16story downtown office and apartment building. Eight persons were rescued by heli copters, but it was feared that others may have been caught by the flames.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The ability of a single construction craft union to hold the entire indus try as its idle prisoner, due to the interlocking relationships of the vari ous construction processes, while it negotiates its new contract is certain ly a major factor in the spiraling cost of construction.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Avery Brundage had been fighting a losing battle, a not unusual circumstance even before his retirement as president of the International Olympic Committee. He kept deploring the curse of gigantism that was smothering both the Olympic Games and the entire Olympic movement. He strongly advocated the abolition of the Winter Games and the elimination of most team sports from the Summer Games. If you think this led to art immediate truncation of the program, you are mistaken. In some totally inex plicable fashion, women's rowing was added to the list of events for Montreal in 1976. How silly can they get? There were dis quieting stirrings in Montreal recently, how ever. An item in the paper the other day revealed that opposition already was gather ing against what, has now become the most expensive of sport spectaculars. What encouraged the dissidents was the forthright way the perceptive Colorado electorate voted down the bond issue to finance the 1976 Winter Olympics in Denver.

title: Suns Beat Hawks, 10998. As Hawkins, Scott Excel
U.S. LISTS RULES ON '73 DIVIDENDS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  The Administration's Committee on interest and Dividends an nounced today detailed guide lines that will govern payouts by corporations to their stock holders next year.

title: Chile: It Is All in the Eyes of the Beholder
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn.If one were to rely solely on U.S. coverage of news from Chile for an understanding of current developments in that coun try, it would not be unreasonable to conclude that the Government of Sal vador Allende is vastly unpopular, ille gitimate, incompetent and repressive. One could further conclude that the Chilean left has been held in check only by the strength of the army rather than a commitment to democ racy. Such conclusions are fundamen tally erroneous and based upon a superficial understanding of the eco nomic and political struggles being waged by pro and antiGovernment forces in Chile. In our judgment, the U.S. press fosters misconceptions about Chile:

title: Blues Down Seals, 21
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 29 (AP)Jack Egers scored his sixth goal of the season in the second period to hand the St. Louis Blues a 21 victory to night over the California Golden Seals.

title: Soviet Proposes Security Talks in June
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 29 (Reuters)The Soviet Union proposed today that the pro jected European security con ference be held here beginning next June.

title: Freeze Lifted on Chile Copper Payments
description: PARIS, Nov. 29 (UPI)A Paris civil court today re leased a $1.33million payment made for a shipment of Chilean copper to France but frozen at the request of the American Braden Kennecott Company.

title: Two Leading Retail Chains Post November Sales Gains
description: Two leading retail chains, the DaytonHudson Corpora tion, Minneapolis, and Edison Brothers Stores, Inc., St. Louis, reported yesterday sizable gains in sales for November from the yearearlier month.

title: TireShipment Peak Seen
description: AKRON. Ohio, Nov. 29 (UPI) Tire shipments nevt year will rise to a record of 240 million, up 10 million from 1972, Ray mond Firestone, chairman of the Firestone. Tire & Rubber Company predicted today.

title: ExMental Patient Wins $38,500 Suit On Hospital Neglect
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Nov. 29 (UPI)A Federal court jury has awarded $38,500 damages to a former mental patient who charged he had been locked up in a state hospital for 15 years without proper treat ment.

title: Governor Laments Departure Of Meyer From Bench Dec. 31
description: Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he was con cerned at the imminent depar ture from the state's judicial system of Supreme Court Jus tice Bernard S. Meyer, a de feated DemocraticLiberal can didate for the Court of Appeals.

title: 464th Suicide Is Recorded From Golden Gate Bridge
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 29 (UPI)A young man whose wrists were still in casts from a previous suicide attempt jumped to his death yester day from the Golden Gate Bridge.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Nov. 29Regula tion and supervision of cable television in the state was vir tually assured today by passage in the Assembly of a bill cre ating an office of cable tele vision with power to regulate the industry.

title: TV:
description: Last night's Hallmark Hall of Fame production, pre sented at 8:30 on the Na tional Broadcasting Compa ny network, was based on the play called The Man Who Came to Dinner. The play, which opened on Broad way in 1939 and starred Monty Woolley as Sheridan Whiteside, was written by George S. Kaufman and Moss Hart. The TV production, which starred Orson Welles, was updated by Bill Persky and Sam Denoff, the special's producers. That was its first mistake.

title: U.S. Proposes a Standard On Furniture Flammability
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) The Nixon Administration took the first step today to de velop a Federal flammability standard for upholstered furni ture, with a target date of mak ing the standard effective in the latter half of 1974.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UPI)United States reserve assets rose $96million to $13.31billion in October, due chiefly to an increase in foreign currencies held by the Government.

title: SWITCH PAYS OFF FOR HARNESS MAN
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 29 George (Buddy) Regan, a jour neyman reinsman when he was doubling as a trainer driver of harness horses, rarely drives now.

title: A SCHOOLAID BILL BLOCKED IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Nov. 29A meas ure supported by the Cahill administration that would pro vide $40million in increased state aid to New Jersey's public schools was temporarily blocked tonight by Assembly Democrats, who said they wanted the measure amended to provide more aid.

title: Government to Issue Rule Requiring Airport Guards
description: The Nixon Administration has decided to issue an emergency rule requiring all of the na tion's 531 airports with airline service to provide policemen or other armed guards to help in tercept potential hijackers.

title: Issues in the L. I.R.R. Dispute
description: PARTICIPANTSThe Long Island Rail Road and 12 unions representing 5,000 carmen, teamsters, clerks, elec trical workers, sheet metal workers and other nonoperating employes, as well as some supervisors.

title: 19% Profit Gain in First Quarter is Reported by Gulf & Western
OwensIllinois Expanding
description: OwensIllinois, Inc., will build a multimilliondollar glass con tainer plant on a 47acre site south of WinstonSalem, N. C. The unit will employ about 200 persons. In yesterday's edi tions of The New York Times, the company was incorrectly identified as OwensCorning, Inc.

title: The TwoWay CopOut
description: Ever since General Motors created Ralph Nader as a public figure, more and more people have been getting into the confrontation act. Churches, institutional investors, financial re porters and even business school pro fessors have discovered relevance, and putting a corporation up against the wall has proved easier than trying to understand the complex social economictechnical issues involved.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Fiftyfive New York City taxi drivers received awards from the Taxi Commission for heroism and outstanding service to the riding public. Seven winners received the top merit awards along with savings bonds for aiding the police. The others were cited as a result of letters from happy passengers. The Taxi Commissioner, Michael J. La zar, urged that the men dis play their awards in their cabs and promised that the awards would be mentioned officially on their identifica tion cards.

title: WILLIAM WATTS, 58, OF IMPORT CONCERN
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Nov. 29 William C. Watts, senior vice president of Connell Rice & Sugar Company, importers and exporters with headquarters here, died Monday while on va cation at Freeport, the Grand Bahamas. His age was 58 and he lived in Scotch Plains.

title: Maryland Wins, 12782
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Nov. 29 (AP)John Lucas, a fresh man, scored 19 points and con tributed seven assists tonight as Maryland thrashed Brown, 12782.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Tom Wicker's Nov. 19 column The New Iron Curtain was a fine plea for the people's right to know and a clear warning of further encroach ments of the Executive into First Amendment rights. In considering the EllsbergRusso case, Thomas Jeffer son's impassioned remarks to Elbridge Gerry ring clear: Your fellow citizens think they have a right to full infor mation, in a case of such great concernment to them it is their sweat which is to earn all the expenses of the war, and their blood which is to flow in expiation of the causes of it.

title: CHADIEN RALLY TIES BRUINS, 33
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 29 (UPI) Guy Lafleur scored a power play goal with less than five minutes remaining tonight as the Montreal Canadiens battled the Boston Bruins to a 33 draw.

title: 3 Leap to Death Fleeing a Fire In 16thFloor New Orleans Club
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 29 (AP) Three women leaped to their deaths today when fire trapped a crowd in a private club atop a 16story downtown office and apartment building. Eight persons were rescued by heli copters, but it was feared that others may have been caught by the flames.

title: Pittsburgh '74 AllStar Site
description: HONOLULU, Nov. 29 (AP) Major league baseball did some future planning at its winter meetings today. Commissioner Bowie Kuhn announced that the AllStar game for 1974 has been awarded to Pittsburgh and the 1975 AllStar game will be played in Milwaukee. Kansas City previously had been an nounced for next season's game.

title: Rockefeller Urges Safeguards For Reporters' News Sources
description: Governor Rockefeller warned last night that the news media's serious investigative reporting will simply dry up unless re porters have the right to pro tect the confidentiality of their sources.

title: Saigon General Who Killed Servant Is Put on Probation
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 29 (AP)A military court sentenced the former deputy commander of Military Region II to five years on probation today for the fatal shooting of his army servant.

title: No Queen at Fresno State
description: FRESNO, Calif., Nov. 29 (UPI) A 39year traditionthe se lection of the Fresno State Uni versity campus queenhas been ended because of a lack of student interest. Only three girls applied for the title this year.

title: Nordwig Retires at 29
description: BERLIN, Nov. 29 (Agence FrancePresse)  Wolfgang Nordwig of East Germany, 29 yearold Olympic champion in the pole vault, retired from competition today to devote all of his time to his studies in physics.

title: Thrifty, if Illegal, Extension
description: Can you save money by buying an extension phone in a store and installing it yourself by means of a jack? The answer is yes, but it is also illegal, and if the telephone company finds out about your ad ditional phones, it can terminate your service.

title: LAUNDRIES, CARTERS FACE PACT DEADLINE
description: Dirty linen and garbage pile ups are in prospect for New Yorkers beginning tomorrow as laundry workers and private trash collectors approach con tract expiration deadlines to night at midnight.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Nov. 29The an tagonists in the Kawaida Tow ers housing dispute marked time again today as neighborhood demonstrators picketed peace fully and construction workers stayed away.

title: Golf Sponsors Are Seeking To Bolster Fields for 1973
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., Nov. 29  Sponsors of 41 major golf tournaments on the national pro circuit said today they were seeking means to strengthen fields for the 1973 tour.

title: Attack Near Pnompenh Field
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 29 (Reuters)Eight North Viet namese rockets hit an area near Pnompenh's international air port today, wounding eight per sons and destroying a house, the airport police said.

title: NICKLAUS SHOOTS FOR MAGIC FIGURE
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., Nov. 29In the fantasy land of Disney, where created lakes and castles form part of a magic kingdom, Jack Nick laus will complete a golfing year this week that seems somewhat unreal, too.

title: Personal Finance
description: Mrs. Goldberg has a prob lem. A working widow, she is 62 and hopes to retire in three years.

title: He Wants Wage Controls Ended and Unrestricted Bargaining Resumed
description: Peter J. Brennan, only hours after being designated Secretary of Labor, said at a hurriedly called news conference yester day that he hoped that current pay controls could be phased out in the months ahead.

title: Hanukkah Menorahs Illuminate Cultural History Over the Years
description: Mrs. Cissy Grossman picked up an 15thcentury German Hanukkah lamp fashioned out of embossed silver and pointed to two small, exquisitely carved fig ures on the sides.

title: Frenchmen Score Upsets
description: BRISBANE, Australia, Nov. 29 (UPI)French players again dominated the Queensland grass tennis championships to day, knocking out three seeded Australians.

title: Beatrice Foods Co. Seeks Finance Unit In $62Milion Deal
description: The Beatrice Foods Company announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to ac quire the Southwestern In vestment Company for stock valued at more than $62mil lion.

title: LARK STRIKE ON AS LATE EFFORTS BY MEDIATOR FAIL
description: Nonoperating employes of the Long Island Rail Road went on strike at 12:01 A.M. today, causing a shutdown of the line and forcing its riders to seek alternate means to get to work this morning.

title: Plans for Outlays By Manufacturers Up 20% in Quarter
description: The nation's 1,000 largest manufacturers have set aside $7.11billion for capital equip ment in the third quarter, The Conference Board reported yes terday. Appropriations for the quarter were 2 percent above the revised level of expendi tures in the second quarter and 20 percent above spending in the third quarter of 1971.

title: Baseball Talks Hit Snag as Players Reject Owners' Offer to Relax Reserve Clause
description: HONOLULU, Nov. 29In an effort to head off another devastating baseball strike, the owners of the 24 major league teams have offered to relax the disputed reserve clause for the first time in the game's history.

title: MRS. L. F. M'COLLUM
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 29Mrs. Leonard Franklin McCollum, wife of the retired chairman of the board of the Continen tal Oil Company, died today after a brief illness at the Methodist Hospital. She lived here and also had a home in Greenwich, Conn.

title: State Is Considering Managing Medicaid
description: The state is considering tak ing over from New York City and all other localities the proc essing of claims and payments in the Medicaid program for the poora program now fore cast to cost $1.99billion for the state's fiscal year starting next April 1.

title: Principals in Chicago Trial Still at Odds, but Some Are Less Active
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 29 Tom Hayden is as active as ever in the antiwar movement. Julius J. Hoffman, at 77 years of age, is semiretired, with the status of senior judge of the Federal District Court here. Lee Weiner reports that, as in the days be fore his brief national promi nence, he is engaged in active obscurity.

title: Countess Willaumez Dies; Was With House & Garden
description: Countess Margaret Willaumez died Monday at her home, Casa Lontana, Capri, after a long illness. She was 56 years old.

title: Man in the News
description: Peter Joseph Brennan, who was nominated to he Secre tary Of Labor yesterday, con fidently expressed the view one day this fall that organ ized labor could handle any battles it might race in the nation. But he said he was gravely concerned about any concessions or show of weak ness by this coun try toward the Communists in North Vietnam.

title: Washington Letter Brings $13,000 at an Auction Here
description: A collection of Albert Ein stein's scientific notes was sold for $12,500 and a letter from George Washington written in 1787 was sold for $13,000 at an auction at Sotheby Parke Ber net.

title: Dublin Opposition Is Bitter On Bill to Curb Terrorism
description: DUBLIN Nov. 29The Irish Government encountered a bit ter fight in Parliament today over its bill for wide powers to arrest and convict members of the outlawed Irish Republi can Army.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: A tight military control in Thailand, the declaration of martial law in the Philippines, abolishing opposition in South Vietnam, a selfmade dictator in Cambodia and voting an indefinite presidential term in South Korea present a serious blow to democracy in East Asia. The Republic of China on Taiwan is the only one of our allies (excepting Japan) in the Pacific that is steadily improving its democratic basis by enlarging the membership in both Legislative and Control Yuans and National Assembly.

title: MAFIOSO INDICTED IN CONTEMPT CASE
description: Carmine Tramunti, the re puted boss of one of New York's five Mafia families, was indicted yesterday on three counts of criminal contempt be cause of what was called his evasive, equivocal and spe cious testimony before a spe cial grand jury investigating organized crime.

title: Rutgers Downs Georgetown
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 29 Rutgers scored 21 points in the first five minutes of the second half tonight and went on to a 9883 victory over Georgetown University.

title: News of Skling
description: Now that Colorado's voters, by referendum have refused to sanction the finan cial outlay for the 1976 Winter Olympics that were to be held in the Denver area, the international classic suddenly finds itself without a home.

title: London Paper Says Argentina Staged Eichmann Kidnapping
description: LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 30 The installment of the con tinuing series on Martin Bor mann published today in The Daily Express says that it was Argentina's secret service that tracked down Adolf Eichmann, the mass murderer of German Jews.

title: Army Sees Balanced Attack As Key in Battle With Navy
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 29King Fink, entering his second ArmyNavy game as the Cadets' quarterback, said today, As far as I see it we will enter as usual with a balance on offense. If we find the run going we will stick to it, and if we have to pass we will do that a little more also. It's just what we expect of them in return.

title: Miss Zylis  Gara in Art of Lied
description: At first glance, Teresa Zy lisGara seemed a gambler's choice to open Carnegie Hall's new Art of the Lied series. The Polish soprano, a regular at the Metropolitan Opera in recent seasons, had never per formed as a recitalist in this country before her appear ance on Tuesday night. Fur thermore, she found herself making a debut with a sub stitute accompanist (Ryan Ed wards rather than Helmut Deutsch, listed as pianist in the program).

title: Washington Letter Brings $13,000 at an Auction Here
description: A collection of Albert Ein stein's scientific notes was sold for $12,500 and a letter from George Washington written in 1787 was sold for $13,000 at an auction at Sotheby Parke Ber net.

title: Illuminating Show Of Breuer's Work
description: It is probably the most photogenic architecture in the world, It occasionally promises more than it deliv ers, and sometimes lives up to its promises. It is build ing as artstrong, stylish and preoccupied with form, rich in dramatic contrasts, proudly insistent on struc ture as sculptureconcepts treated with extreme suspi cion by today's young cul tural philosophers who prefer a Salvation Army esthetic.

title: TEACHERS URGED NOT TO BOYCOTT
description: Angry parents maintained their boycott of schools in East Harlem yesterday, keeping 10 schools closed and sharply cut ting attendance at several others, but Albert Shanker, the head of the teachers union, urged its members to report for work today.

title: Construction Union Chief in New York Is Chosen to Succeed Hodgson
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  President Nixon today nominat ed Peter J. Brennan, president of the Building and Construc tion Trades Councils in New York City and New York State, to be the next Secretary of Labor.

title: Clark, in Full AboutFace, Calls For a Curb on Decentralization
description: Confessing to a 180degree change on decentralization, Dr. Kenneth B. Clark has advised the City Charter Re vision Commission to beware of a simplistic manipulation of the bureaucratic structure as a hope for improving city government.

title: Manhattan Crushes Marist
description: Charlie Mahoney and Henry Seawright led Manhattan Col lege to a 10165 victory over Marist College last night at the winner's Alumni Gymna sium.

title: Angela Davis Among Onlookers At Rap Brown's Court Hearing
description: Angela Davis, the black mili tant, was among the spectators yesterday at a State Supreme Court hearing at which a po lice detective testified that he had heard H. Rap Brown's three codefendants in a West Side holdup and gun battle make incriminating remarks 13 months ago.

title: Life Sentence of Hijacker Is Cut to 20Year Minimum
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 29 (AP) The life term of a hijacker who gave a rambling speech about the problems of Mexican Americans from aboard his pi rated airplane was reduced to day to 20 years by a Federal judge who said he believed the man's sincerity but con demned his method.

title: Lawrence Marshall Dies at 68; Former Chase Vice Chairman
description: Lawrence Clark Marshall, who retired in 1969 as vice chairman of the board of direc tors of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died after a long illness last night at the Sarasota Me morial Hospital in Sarasota, Fla. He was 68 years old.

title: Nixon Confers With Blacks
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) President Nixon met today with 37 black officials of his Administration and urged them to help recruit qualified blacks for Government posts.

title: Williams President Retiring in June
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 29John Edward Saw yer, the 55yearold president of Williams College since 1961, announced yesterday that he would retire next June 30.

title: HOUSE DISTRICTS WILL SET RECORD
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  The 93d Congress will have more House members from dis tricts with nearly equal popula tion than any Congress in his tory, according to a report re leased today by the Bureau of the Census.

title: R. L. Duffus, Editorial Writer, 84, Dies
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 29 R. L. Duffus, a retired edi torial writer and reporter for The New York Times, died of congestive heart failure yester day at his home here. He was 84 years old and had lived here since 1964.

title: Tips, Official and Otherwise, On How to Cut Phone Costs
description: The best way to save money on home telephone bills, according to the tele phone company and some consumer experts, is to keep a stop watch or timer handy each time you dial a number.

title: IN THE NATION
description: The good news is that President Nixon, in his remarks this week at Camp Davld, strongly denied that he Intended to increase the already swol len power of the White House within the executive branch, and promised to reduce the White House staff size.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: One of man's happiest achievements this year was the creation of a oneacre salt marsh on a small island in Chesapeake Bay.

title: Gregory Makes a Living Collecting Quarterbacks
description: The coach of the team the Giants play Sunday and the Giant that team's quarter back must fear most have something in commonboth began their pro football careers with the Cleveland Browns and both left the Browns in an unamiable atmosphere.

title: Films Made for Italy's TV Being Shown at Modern Art
description: An Italian film series pre sented by the Film Department of the Museum of Modern Art will offer, today through Dec. 28, works by such established directors as Roberto Rossellini, Robert Bresson, Pier Paolo Pa solini, Jean Renoir and Michel angelo Antonioni, Interestingly enough, however, all of the films were made for television, specifically for Radiotelevisione ltaliana, always referred to as RAI.

title: Business Briefs
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 29 (Reuters)The European Common Market's governing commission said today it was decided to fine an American company 100,000 units of account (about $102,500) for infringing community antitrust regulations.

title: U.S. in LastMinute Plea For Cut in Its U.N. Bill
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 29 (AP)  The United States made a lastminute plea today for a reduction in its share of the United Na tions budget, warning of se rious fallout consequences if the current General As sembly does not act.

title: Construction Union Chief in New York Is Chosen to Succeed Hodgson
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  President Nixon today nominat ed Peter J. Brennan, president of the Building and Construc tion Trades Councils in New York City and New York State, to be the next Secretary of Labor.

title: CALLEY LOSES BID TO ATTEND APPEAL
description: FORT BENNINGTON, Ga., Nov. 29 (AP)The command ing general of Fort Benning denied today First Lieut. Wil Liam L. Calley Jr.'s request to attend arguments in his appeal to the Army Court of Military Review to have his conviction overturned.

title: Texan's Backers Say Governors Favor Him as Democratic Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 Backers of Robert Strauss of Texas for the Democratic Party chairmanship claimed the sup port today of a majority of the 33 Democratic Governors and Governorselect who will con fer in St. Louis this weekend. Those who support Mr. Strauss, said to number 17, are mostly from the South and West.

title: Bridge: Psychology a Major Factor When a Partnership Is New
description: In tournament play the emphasis is largely on part nership effort: A good under standing in bidding and de fense is essential to success. But in rubber bridge, with a series of different partners, partnership understanding is necessarily limited, and adaptability and psychology are major factors.

title: 25 Years After Partition, U.N. Again Debates Mideast
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 29Twentyfive years after the partition of Palestine and the establishment of Israel by vote of the United Nations, the de bate on the Middle East issue, which has persisted ever since, resumed in the General Assem bly today.

title: Kings Win 11th in Last 14
description: KANSAS CITY, Nov. 29 (AP) Kansas CityOmaha posted a 110102 victory over the Port land Trail Blazers tonight for the Kings' 11th triumph in their last 14 games.

title: Crucial U.N. Vote
description: After prolonged and at times acrimonious debate, the United Nations Finance Committee faces a crucial vote today on a United States proposal that would reduce this country's share of the regular budget of the world organization.

title: Colonels on Top, 114113
description: DENVER, Nov. 29 (AP) Rick Mount's field goal with 19 seconds remaining lifted the Kentucky Colonels to a 114113 victory over the Denver Rock ets tonight.

title: FOOD PRICES DOWN AGAIN FOR OCTOBER
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) The retail cost of foods pro duced on American farms de creased twotenths of 1 per cent in October as consumers paid slightly less for beef, the Agri culture Department reported today.

title: Chess: No No Game Game Can Can Last Last Like Like This Th
description: Alexander Alekhine, the eccentric expatriate Russian who was world champion from 1927 to 1935 and from 1937 until his death in 1946, hated symmetrical positions.

title: High Peking Aide Assails U.S.
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 29 China expressed strong criti cism of the United States today as having failed to conclude a truce agreement with Hanoi.

title: Prostitute Arrests 2 As WouldBe Patrons
description: A businessman and an accountant were arrested and charged with patroniz ing a prostitute yesterday after they allegedly sought to engage a policewoman disguised as a prostitute in midtown Manhattan.

title: Chile Hails Action
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 29 (UPI)The Government said to day it had won the first round but not the whole bout in the ruling by a Paris court nullify ing the ban on payment for a $1.3million Chilean copper shipment.

title: Draft Charter Approved
description: QUEZON CITY, the Philip pines, Nov. 29  A draft con stitution providing for a par liamentary form of government to be headed for an indefinite initial period by the incumbent President was approved on the third and final reading today by the constitutional conven tion. The vote was 271 dele gates for the draft and 14 against it.

title: Unswerving Idealist
description: For a quarter of a century, until his retirement ten years ago, R. L. Duffus was a member of the editorial board of The New York Times, an unswerving idealist, an independent and human observer, half Vermont granite, half gentle dreamer. He came out of the reporting and reforming tradition in journalism marked by two of his mentors, Ida M. Tarbell and the famous Fremont Older of The San Francisco Bulletin, where Bob Duffus got his first real newspaper job.His range of writings for The Times was astonishing. His articles and editorials covered the United States and the world. Nothing human was foreign to him; what ever he wrote had charm, erudition and, when necessary, bite. He believed that language could be a weapon to improve the human condition.We can think of no better way to note the death of this wellloved colleague than to let his voice be heard again in an editorial, Dunkerque, published on June 1, 1940, in one of the darkest hours of World War II.So long as the English tongue survives, the word Dunkerque will be spoken with reverence. For in that harbor, in such a hell as never blazed on earth before, at the end of a lost battle, the rags and blemishes that have hidden the soul of democracy fell away. There, beaten but unconquered, in shining splendor, she faced the enemy.They sent away the wounded first. Men died so that others could escape. It was not so simple a thing as courage, which the Nazis had in plenty. It was not so simple a thing as discipline, which can be hammered into men by a drill sergeant. It was not the result of careful planning, for there could have been little. It was the common man of the free countries, rising in his glory out of mill, office, factory, mine, farm and ship, applying to war the lessons he learned when he went down the shaft to bring out trapped comrades, when he hurled the lifeboat through the surf, when he endured pov erty and hard work for his children's sake.This shining thing in the souls of free men Hitler cannot command, or attain, or conquer. He has crushed it, where he could, from German hearts.It is the great tradition of democracy. It is the future. It is victory.

title: J. ALBERT BALLIN
description: DEAL, N. J., Nov. 29 J. Albert Ballin, founder and president of the Ballmill Lum ber and Sales Company of Port Newark, died yesterday at his home, 48 Parker Avenue. He was 69 years old and lived also in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Equity Financing
description: An offering of one million shares of the NCNB Corporation, parent of the North Carolina National Bank, at 35 a share was made yesterday by Salomon Brothers. The company's stock closed on the overthecounter market at 3536, un changed.

title: News of Dogs
description: Gordon Caryill of East Greenbush, N. Y., has en gaged in almost every facet of dogshow activities. A breeder and exhibitor of dachshunds, he has also shot over dogs in the field, taught obedience, acted in adminis trative roles as the head of two kennel clubs and vice president of the Associated Dog Clubs of New York State, and judged from coast to coast. I al ways liked to hunt, he said, so 17 years ago I bought an English springer spaniel. Since a good hunting dog has to obey orders, that entails obedience train ing. I put one of my spring ers through his C.D. [com panion dog] and C.D.X. [com panion dog excellent] de grees.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: C. L. Sulzberger says (column Nov. 15) that America has begun to prune its military establishment. Some of the news in The Times itself reads differently.

title: Peddler Tells at Captain's Trial of a $300 Payoff
description: A street peddler testified at a Police Department trial yesterday that he told the former commanding officer of the First Precinct that he had paid a precinct sergeant $300 for all the boys that were working.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The hijacking of an airplane oper ated by a commercial airline should be treated the same as piracy on a vessel flying the American flag when the airplane is forced to land in a foreign country. The recent hijacking of a Southern Airways airplane and the $2million ransom extorted from this small company has placed the airline on the verge of fiscal ruin. I contend that the U.S. Government should reimburse the airline for the ransom paid to the hijackers, or at least make a longterm loan, at low interest, similar to the loans extended to victims of floods and other disasters.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I can appreciate Abraham Carmel's zeal, as a Christian joyously converted to Judaism, for the holy word and its dissemination throughout the land [letter Nov. 21]. But when he protests the injunction against prayer in the schoolroom. I would have thought all those arguments had long been laid to rest.

title: Life Sentence of Hijacker Is Cut to 20Year Minimum
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 29 (AP) The life term of a hijacker who gave a rambling speech about the problems of Mexican Americans from aboard his pi rated airplane was reduced to day to 20 years by a Federal judge who said he believed the man's sincerity but con demned his method.

title: Lansky Trial Scheduled
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 29 (UPI)The trial of Meyer. Lansky on charges of skimming profits from Las Vegas casino operations was set today to begin Feb. 5. Lansky is reported to be a financial adviser for the mafia.

title: Contention Rejected
description: The court rejected Codelco's contention that as a national, stateowned company it should enjoy judicial immunity. The ruling said the company had a judicial personality formally distinct from the state.

title: He Wants Wage Controls Ended and Unrestricted Bargaining Resumed
description: Peter J. Brennan, only hours after being designated Secretary of Labor, said at a hurriedly called news conference yester day that he hoped that current pay controls could be phased out in the months ahead.

title: Clarkson Six to Open Garden Festival Here
description: Clarkson, which has won the event three times, will take on St. Louis University to open the 12th annual Eastern College Athletic Con ference Holiday Hockey Festival at Madison Square Garden Tuesday night in the second game Notre Dame, last year's winner, plays St. Lawrence.

title: 76ERS DO IT AGAIN; GET VICTORY NO.2
Letters to the Editor
description: For those who think government publications are always dull, the banks in New York and elsewhere are now passing out a folder that begins, They said there was no God west of the Pecos and no Sunday west of Newton. Champagne and oysters in the saloons of Virginia City, Nevada. Hurdygurdy girls, Whiskey straight up.

title: Golf Sponsors Are Seeking To Bolster Fields for 1973
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., Nov. 29  Sponsors of 41 major golf tournaments on the national pro circuit said today they were seeking means to strengthen fields for the 1973 tour.

title: Women's Liberation Movement Is Seen Leading to SelfHatred
description: Midge Decter, who said she was happy to be identified as Public Enemy No. 1 of women's liberation, asserted last night that the movement does not belong to the history of femi nism but to the history of radi calism and predicted as its re sult a tidal wave of female selfhatred.

title: VIA GALACTICA ENDS SATURDAY
description: Via Galactica, the space age musical reported to rep resent an investment of almost $1million, is closing its run at the new Uris Theater, 51st Street, west of Broadway, on Saturday after seven perform ances.

title: A DAILY LOTTERY BEGINS IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Nov. 29The na tions first daily, stateoperated lotery got started here this afternoon in what promises to be the longestrunning daily giveaway show in the country's history.

title: Army Sees Balanced Attack As Key in Battle With Navy
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 29King Fink, entering his second ArmyNavy game as the Cadets' quarterback, said today, As far as I see it we will enter as usual with a balance on offense. If we find the run going we will stick to it, and if we have to pass we will do that a little more also. It's just what we expect of them in return.

title: ARTICLE ON JUDGE IS CALLED UNFAIR
description: State Supreme Court Justice John A. Monteleone of Brooklyn was unjustifiedly and incor rectly maligned in a magazine article last month on The Ten Worst Judges in New York, the New York State Trial Law yers Association and the Brook lyn Bar Association have con cluded in the first of a series of investigative reports.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NORTH BERGEN, N. J., Nov. 29A most happy and gratifying experience, said Joe Coviello after his team recently completed an undefeated season.

title: The Miners Choose
description: Union democracy has long been a stranger to the United Mine Workers of America. Even in the days when the mine union was a mainstay in bringing industrial democracy to the bastions of the open shop in steel, autos and other mass production industries, the miners' own internal processes were under ironclad dictatorship.

title: ROSEN SHOWS POISE IN A CELLO RECITAL
description: Nathaniel Rosen has toured with the Music from Marlboro ensemble, and the young cellist's poise, refinement and musicality should indeed make him an ideal chamber player. Less clear is whether he has the communicative intensity to be an equally persuasive recitalist.

title: Pan Am Sued on Turtles
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 29 (UPI) Pan American World Airways has been charged with violating the Federal endangered species act for accepting shipment of 100 pounds of hawksbill turtle shells. The United States At torney's office said charges were brought against the air line for accepting three ship ments of turtle shells from Haiti and Panama to Japan last summer.

title: Market Place: When Top Men Step Aside
description: Let's call him Sam, a pseu donymbecause identifying him by his real name could lead to lawsuits.

title: Kennecott Outlines Recourse
description: Kennecott said yesterday that its claim to payments for cop per from its expropriated El Teniente mine in Chile will be settled in the Paris Court of Extended Jurisdiction.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A NICE PLACE TO VISIT You may not want to live on West 47th Street, between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, but there arc few blocks in New York better geared for sightseeing during working hours, Mon day through Friday although it slacks off by early after noon on Friday. It is the one block that is best known for the diamond trade, and you can spend hours wandering through the various large diamond centers and ex changes, each crowded with booths occupied by individual entrepreneurs. You may kib itz the negotiations or watch artisans work on the wares, stringing pearls, burnishing diamonds or whatever they do to them.

title: Assembly Strikes a Compromise on Issue of Bangladesh Admission to U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 29The General Assem bly adopted a compromise on Bangladesh today, simultane ously approving resolutions urging United Nations member ship for the country and call ing for the release of Pakistani war prisoners captured there.

title: Books of The Times
description: EARS JUNGLE. By Pierre Boulle. Translated from the French by Michael Dobry and Lynda Cole. 224 pages. Vanguard. $6.95.

title: le Franklin Stamp Brings $27,000
description: A 1cent blue Benjamin Franklin stamp, part of an 186106 United States series and considered the rarest regularissue United States postage stamp, sold here for $27,000 yesterday.

title: British Oppose Bigger and Heavier Trucks
description: LONDON, Nov. 29With the kind of alarm the citizens of Lilliput felt over the en vironmental outrage com mitted by Gulliver, the Brit ish are trying to protect their narrow village streets and hedgelined roads from the monster European truck.

title: Rockefeller Urges Safeguards For Reporters' News Sources
description: Governor Rockefeller warned last night that the news media's serious investigative reporting will simply dry up unless re porters have the right to pro tect the confidentiality of their sources.

title: TRITT, AT THE PIANO, APPEALING IN DEBUT
description: With a little ripening and refinement, William Tritt could become an important artist. He is already a very appealing one.

title: Keene State Soccer Victor
description: DUNN, N. C., Nov. 29 (AP) Keene State of New Hamp shire defeated Harris Teachers of St. Louis, 10, and Davis and Elkins of West Virginia downed Earlham of Indiana, 80, in firstround games today of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics soccer championship.

title: WILLIAM KEARNS
description: ORANGE, N.J. Nov. 29 (AP) William Kearns, retired board chairman of the Sun Insurance Company of New York, died yesterday in Orange Memorial Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Maplewood.

title: Ulster Tactics a Divisive Issue for I.R.A.
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 29The Irish Republican Army, under grinding British military pressure and in disar ray over leadership losses, is in the midst of a critical struggle over future tactics in Northern Ireland.

title: Alan Gibson Horror Films Congeal Into Double Bill
Vera Koralli, Former Star Of Bolshoi Ballet, Dead
description: Vera Koralli, a leading ballerina with Moscow's Bol shoi Ballet before the Russian Revolution and a dancer with Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes, died last week in Baden, Austria, at the age of 81. The funeral took place last Thursday.

title: Interstate Unit Buys Trucks
description: NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 29 (UPI)  General Transportation Services Incorporated, an in terstate corporation subsidiary, said today that it had pur chased 707 Astro trucks from the General Motors Corpora tion for more than $16.3mil lion.

title: Bucks Beat Bulls, 10597
description: MILWAUKEE, Nov. 29 (AP) Oscar Robertson sank four free throws and Bob Dandridge scored two with 36 seconds left tonight to pace the Milwaukee Bucks to a 10597 victory over the Chicago Bulls.

title: News of Skiing
description: Now that Colorado's voters, by referendum have refused to sanction the finan cial outlay for the 1976 Winter Olympics that were to be held in the Denver area, the international classic suddenly finds itself without a home.

title: Celtics, Led by Sanders, Set Back Sonics, 12098
description: BOSTON, Nov. 28 (AP)  Tom Sanders entered the game midway in the second period and rallied the Boston Celtics to a 12098 National Basketball Association victory over the Seattle SuperSonics tonight.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: The unarmed guards of Rutgers University, demanding better wages and more manpower, picketed old Queens, the administration building. As 10 guards marched in front of the building, Bernard Cerebes, union steward of Local 888 of the American Federation of County and Municipal Employes, said: We learned a lot from the student pro testers, they got results. They're good teachers.

title: Gives S.E.C. Blueprint of 3Year PhaseIn for Membership
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 The PBW Stock Exchange to day offered to abandon its fight against the Securities and Exchange Commission's pro posed rule controlling exchange membership in return for a phasein period of three years in which its members could adjust to the new regulation.

title: Arvin Industries Files Suit Against Maremont
description: Arvin Industries, a maker of auto equipment parts, an nounced yesterday that it had filed suit in United States Dis trict Court in Indianapolis against the Maremont Corpora tion seeking triple damages of $60million and injunctive re lief for alleged antitrust viola tions. Arvin said Maremont had made numerous acquisitions of manufacturers, rehuilders, warehouse distributors and job bers since at least 1939 and engaged in numerous other unfair trade practices.

title: Grambling Students Arraigned
description: RUSTON, La., Nov. 29 Twentytwo Grambling College students were arraigned here today on charges in connection with campus protests and dis orders on Nov. 2.

title: TEACHERS URGED NOT TO BOYCOTT
description: Angry parents maintained their boycott of schools in East Harlem yesterday, keeping 10 schools closed and sharply cut ting attendance at several others, but Albert Shanker, the head of the teachers union, urged its members to report for work today.

title: U.S. AIDES REPORT YIELDING BY HANOI ON TRUCE ISSUES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  Wellplaced Administration of ficials reported today that a number of concessions were made by North Vietnam in the most recent phase of peace talks in Paris. But the officials, in various departments of Gov ernment, said at least two or three major differences re mained to be resolved before a ceasefire agreement was ready for signing.

title: Dutch Rule Unclear After Vote
description: AMSTERDAM, the Nether lands, Nov. 29The Catholic People's party, the largest in the minority coalition Gov ernment, suffered a major de feat in today's general elec tion by losing 7 of its present 35 seats in the lower house of Parliament.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Nov. 29  Year round school programs may begin in as many as eight school districts in New Jersey, perhaps as early as next year, the State Department of Educa tion disclosed today.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Sew a tent? Or a sleeping bag? Or a down jacket? Until Dale Johnson of Boul der, Colo., founded Frostline, Inc., suppliers of doityour self outdoor equipment kits, six and a half years ago the difficulties of undertaking such a project on a home sewing machine were almost insurmountable.

title: Male Centerfold Slated For Women's Yearbook
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 29The yearbook of Douglass College, the resi dent women's division of Rutgers University, may join the list of publications displaying male centerfolds, and the student government is not happy about the prospects.

title: Speer:  A Tough Act to Follow in Steel
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 29 Edgar B. Speer, who will be come the chairman and chief executive officer of the United States Steel Corporation, was described by an associate here today as a steel man's steel man. His entire work ing career has been with the company.

title: Two ExSenators Honored
description: Former United States Sena tor Wayne Morse of Oregon and Ernest Gruelling of Alaska, both Democrats, were named yesterday as the 1972 winners of SANE's Eleanor Roosevelt Peace Medal, The Associated Press reported. Previous win ners of the award, presented by the Citizens' Organization for a Sane World, include Dr. Ben jamin Spock, the Rev. Dr. Mar tin Luther King Jr., Senator George McGovern and former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy.

title: Advertising:
description: DORADO BEACH, Puerto Rico, Nov. 29  Generally speaking advertisers and agencies don't think govern ment and consumerist pres sures have hurt the creative product. In fact some think that they have helped.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: By all means let us pursue the imaginative though dangerous sugges tions of Prof. Freeman J. Dyson in The Times of Nov. 27 and comb the universe for evidence of a living and reproducing species in which tech nology has gone out of control and created a technological cancer spread ing through the galaxy.

title: Keene State Soccer Victor
description: DUNN, N. C., Nov. 29 (AP) Keene Stale of New Hamp shire defeated Harris Teachers, of St, Louis, 10 and Davis and Elkins of West Virginia downed Earlham of Indiana, 80, in firstround games today of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics soccer championship.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Nov. 29A Cahill administration bill that would provide $40million in increased state aid to public schools was temporarily blocked tonight by Assembly Democrats, who said they wanted the measure amended to provide still more aid.

title: Citibank Opens in Chicago
description: The First National City Bank yesterday opened an office in Chicago  its fifth in major exportimport centers across the country  to do an inter national banking business.

title: British Act on Thalidomide Trust Fund
description: LONDON, Nov. 29The long deadlock over compensation to 370 British children crippled by thalidomide eased somewhat today, apparently under pres sure of a press campaign, aroused public opinion and a mounting political controversy.

title: TOWMEN SUPPORT SHIFT IN CONTROL
description: A Lindsay administration bill to transfer the regulation of the towtruck industry from the Police Department to the Con sumer Affairs Department and give the latter additional rate fixing responsibilities was sup ported yesterday before a City Council committee by industry spokesmen and the Police De partment.

title: U.S. Steel Names a New Chief
description: The directors of the United States Steel Corporation an nounced yesterday the election of Edgar B. Speer as chairman and chief executive officer, ef fective March 1. He succeeds Edwin H. Gott, who will retire at the age of 65 on Feb. 28.

title: CITY IS INSPECTING CRIME BUILDINGS
description: Deputy Mayor Edward K. Hamilton said yesterday that a team of city inspectors would carry out checks today at six single  room  occupancy build ings, of which five are hotels. All have been described by the police as centers of crime and addiction.

title: Details on 2 U.S. Victims
description: Mr. Brettler, one of the three Americans who died in the crash, was the founder in 1960 of the Brettler International Sales Corporation of 135 West 50th Street, an importer of textiles and men's wear.
